PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 47 citizens) and Senator Short (from 53 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. the petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 302 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 67 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: New Zealand Work Permits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, express our concerns at current Australian Government Policy towards New Zealand (The Trans Tasman Travel Agreements) which allows New Zealand visitors to gain employment at the expense of Australian workers.
Accordingly, in view of the growing differences between Australia and New Zealand with regard to:
Currency exchange rates;
Taxation systems;
Industrial Relations law;
Industry/Award wages and conditions;

PETITION.PARA: we call on the Federal government to implement a work permit system on New Zealand visitors intending to work in Australia, similar to the work permit system that applies to any other foreign national in Australia intending to work. We also call for a non discriminatory standard policy on immigration towards all foreign sovereign nations including New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Faulkner (from 578 citizens) and Senator Reynolds (from 752 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and honourable members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
(1)They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
(2)They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:

PARA.TAB: (a)The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b)The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this plant Earth;
(c)The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.

PETITION.PARA: (3)They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
(4)They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5)They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw the notices of motion standing in my name for the next day of sitting and nine sitting days after today for the disallowance of the ministerial guidelines made on 5 February 1992 under section 44 of the Student Assistance Act 1973 and determinations Nos 1991-92/12 and 24 made under sections 10GI and 10F respectively of the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954. I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April and 26 May I reported to the Senate on the Committee's concerns with these instruments, which related to appropriate review of discretions and possible hardship to individuals. The Committee has now received satisfactory explanations about these provisions, although we will suggest to the Minister that the ARC be consulted about review rights under the ministerial guidelines. As usual, I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: 30 April 1992
The Hon P J Baldwin MP
Minister for Higher Education

PARA.TAB: and Employment Services

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to Ministerial Guidelines 1991 made on 5 February 1992 under section 44 of the Student Assistance Act 1973, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 30 April 1992.

Many of the Guidelines confer important discretions upon public officials. One such discretion is to decide a withholding from an entitlement; another is to decide whether failure to pay a debt was the fault of the debtor. Other discretions are to waive or write off a debt entirely or to approve repayment by instalments.

Most of these discretions have criteria to limit and guide their exercise. However, some criteria include other discretions. Some discretions appear to be subject to internal review, but there is no indication that they are subject to independent merit review by an external tribunal such as the AAT.

Some of the discretions have important implications for personal rights. For example, one provision is that a section of the Act may be used to garnishee deductions from wages and salary or from an account at a bank or other financial institution.

The Committee would appreciate your advice on the availability of review of all of the discretions in the Guidelines. Thus, in the case where wages or a bank account may be garnisheed, external merits review would appear to be essential. The parent Act provides extensive review provisions and it may be that the discretions in the Guidelines are caught by these. However, we would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
2 June 1992
Senator P J Giles
Chair
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles

I refer to your letter of 30 April 1992 detailing concerns of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances regarding the Ministerial Guidelines 1991 under section 44 of the Student Assistance Act 1973 covering debt recovery action.

I note your concern that the Guidelines confer important discretionary powers on public officials without clearly stating what review mechanisms, if any, are available to individuals affected by their decisions. The Committee is keen to ensure that debtors have appeal rights in relation to the garnishee of wages or a bank account, but it is also of the view that decisions to waive or write off debts, withhold from an entitlement or to approve repayment by instalments should be appellable.

As you are aware, the parent Act prescribes the appeal process available to AUSTUDY students. A decision of an authorised person may be reviewed by a senior authorised person. The outcome of a review by the senior authorised person may subsequently be reviewed by the Student Assistance Review Tribunal (SART). If the client is still dissatisfied, he or she may apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) for a further review.

In all cases the review process applies only to decisions made by authorised persons, or to such decisions as subsequently varied by a lower appeal body. Only matters of eligibility or entitlement are reviewable. (The exceptions to this ruling concern "procedural decisions" as defined under section 13(1) and relate to the discretion of authorised persons to extend the length of time clients have to lodge an appeal to SART.)

All decisions to waive or write-off debts, to approve withholdings from entitlement and garnishee arrangements are made by prescribed officers rather than authorised persons, and, as such, are not appellable under the Act. It is not possible to establish a review process for decisions of prescribed persons in the Ministerial Guidelines without amending the parent Act. Such action is not envisaged.

You expressed particular concern for clients subject to garnishee action. It should be noted that under the Social Security Act 1991, DSS clients have no rights of appeal against a decision to garnishee.

Clients who are dissatisfied with a decision concerning the debt recovery process may write to me seeking redress. Alternatively, as you are aware, they may appeal under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Yours sincerely
Peter Baldwin
The Hon Peter Staples MP
Minister for Aged, Family
and Health Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to Determination No. 1991-92/12, Community Aged Care Services General Conditions and Determination No. 1991-92/24, made under sections 10GI and 10F respectively of the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954.
Community Aged Care Services General Conditions

Clause 3 includes a number of detailed criteria which are to be used by a Community Aged Care Assessment Authority for the assessment of the needs of individuals. These involve the exercise of discretions. Then, apparently despite the assessment by the Authority, clause 3(5) provides that the Secretary may accept or reject a recommendation of a Hostel Care Assessment Authority or a Community Aged Care Assessment Authority.

The Committee asks whether there is provision for review of Authority decisions. Also, is there provision for review of the open-ended discretion of the Secretary to reject a recommendation of a presumably expert Authority applying clearly defined criteria? On the face of it, this would appear to be a clear case where AAT review should be provided. Perhaps this is included in the parent Act. If so, it should have been notified in the Explanatory Statement. In addition, it would appear that there should be provisions requiring the Authority and the Secretary to give reasons for the adverse exercise of a discretion.

Again, clause 9(3) provides for the Secretary to give notice to the organisation to take mandatory steps. Clause 9(4) provides for the Secretary, in his or her discretion, to impose sanctions on an organisation. In both these cases review may be appropriate.

In the context of the desirability of external merits review in the above cases the Committee noted that the Secretary, as defined in clause 1, includes either the Secretary or an officer of the Department authorised in writing.

Under clauses 6(2)(d) and (e) a recipient has to "show" that he or she has less than certain levels of income after costs. To whom does the recipient have to show this? This would also appear to be a suitable case for AAT review.

On a different matter, clause 10(8) provides in wide terms for an indemnity and release to the Commonwealth and its officers. The Committee was concerned at the extent of this indemnity, which includes the cost to the Commonwealth of defending or settling any claim, including those relating to any vehicle or equipment, in respect of any liability as a result of the provision of community aged care. Admittedly, an organisation is required by clause 10(9) to carry public liability insurance, but this would presumably only cover situations where the organisation was the defendant. Certainly it would not cover all of the situations included in clause 10(8) where the Commonwealth or its officers were the defendants.
Amendment of the General Conditions of Recurrent Subsidies
The provisions of this instrument largely parallel those of the previous instrument and our concerns are similar.

New clauses 2(b)(i), 3(2)(b), 3(3)(f) and (g) and 3(6) provide for the acceptance, rejection, variation or review by the Secretary of recommendations by the Hostel Care Assessment Authority and Personal Care Assessment Authority. Here, as with the previous instrument, the Committee is concerned about review of discretions. In particular, is there AAT review of the discretion of the Secretary, where presumably expert Authorities, applying clearly defined criteria, have their assessments rejected? Is there a requirement that reasons must be given for a rejection? The Committee noted that under clause 3(7) there is a right of review to the Minister from adverse decisions of the Secretary under clause 3(6). However, in this context Minister means the Minister or any officer authorised in writing. There is a similar provision for the Secretary. The argument in favour of independent review is stronger where there is a wide delegation power.
As with the previous instrument, it would seem that this is a case where AAT review should be available.

There are other discretions where review may be appropriate. Clause 3(5)(c) provides that the Secretary may extend the period during which assessments are to be made. Clause 3(8) provides a discretion about repayment of monies. With reference to this latter situation, the Administrative Review Council has recently recommended in respect of the Child Care Act 1972 that recovery powers not substantially different from those in other Acts should be subject to merits review.

On another point, clause 3(6)(e) provides that where there is a variation of an assessment or classification, it is taken to have effect from the original date of assessment and any payments will be adjusted accordingly. Clause 3(8) reinforces this by providing that, where there has been a variation under clause 3(6) or (7), the Secretary may require repayment and the moneys become a recoverable debt or can be deducted from future payments. On its face, this retrospectivity could operate to the prejudice of a person other than the Commonwealth with the provision consequently being of no effect.
The Committee would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
Senator P. Giles
Chair
Standing Committee on Regulations and
Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Giles
I refer to your letter of 7 May 1992 regarding Determinations number 1991-92/12 and 1991-92/24 made under section 10GI and 10F of the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954 ("the Act").

In you letter, the Committee raise a general concern about the adequacy of review mechanisms provided in these two instruments, suggesting several areas where merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal ("the AAT") should occur. The letter also raises concerns about a range of other powers within those Determinations.

I acknowledge the Committee's concerns and agree that it may be more appropriate to have an independent body, such as the AAT, review the exercise of certain discretionary powers. However, the points you query relate both to decisions which could appropriately be subject to merits review and other decisions where such a review would not, in my opinion, be appropriate. Later in this letter I have outlined some areas where I agree that merits review by the AAT could apply and other areas where I would submit that other existing avenues of review (such as review by the Federal Court) would appear to be sufficient and more appropriate.

However, in the meantime, it is imperative that the process of implementing the revised hostel General Conditions and the Community Aged Care Services General Conditions contained in the Determinations should continue unimpeded. This is crucial, as the amendments in the Determinations to the section 10F and 10GI Conditions allow for implementation of the new initiatives in aged care which will see substantial increases in funding to hostels and expansion of the services provided in the community. As you are aware, the new arrangements for hostels were introduced on 29 April 1992, while a number of Community Aged Care Packages projects have been funded since mid February 1992. To this end I am prepared to give the Committee certain undertakings as to making amendments to the General Conditions and seeking amendments to the Act in an effort to address the Committee's concerns. As the Committee appreciates, any changes proposed to the Act will be subject to the priorities of the legislative program of the Government which is a matter on which I am unable to give binding assurances.

In general, sections 10F and 10GI of the Act require me to formulate General Conditions for the payment of financial assistance to organisations which run hostels and which provide Community Aged Care Services Packages respectively, and list a range of specific issues the conditions could cover. The General Conditions form part of the Agreement which each organisation has with me and are the prime means by which I can ensure that organisations use the funds they receive appropriately.

The main issue raised in your letter focuses on the assessment role of Community Aged Care Assessment Authorities ("CACAA"), Hostel Care Assessment Authorities ("HCAA"), Personal Care Assessment Authorities ("PCAA"), and the Secretary's power to accept/reject their recommendations.

It is very important to note that despite the similarities in their names (which are due to historical reasons) those bodies have very differing roles within the aged care program. The primary role of HCAAs, and of newly created CACAAs, is to assess frail aged as to their eligibility for entry to a kind of care, against the specified criteria set out in the Determinations. Conversely, assessments undertaken by PCAAs are a basis upon which people already admitted to hostels are ranked in order of their requirement for care, which in turn leads to decisions about allocation of finite resources to hostel providers.

Therefore, while I agree that AAT merits review may be appropriate for HCAA and CACAA assessments, I would not see this as appropriate for the reviews of PCAA decisions. The AAT has previously expressed the opinion that decisions involving the distribution of limited resources (where to grant a benefit to one applicant would involve a denial of a similar benefit in respect of another applicant) would not be appropriate for merits review. This would appear to apply to PCAA assessments as the relevant Government decision which established the basis for this scheme did so by predetermining the proportions of residents which, when ranked, will be allocated to each personal care level. Estimates for the program are based on these proportions, as are the cut-off scores for the assessment instrument, and only a specific level of growth is included for increases in average dependency each year.

In relation to PCAA assessments, there is room for clarification of the decision and review points which may go some way to addressing the Committee's concerns relating to the Secretary's discretion. This would involve some clarification of wording in the relevant clauses of the General Conditions to clarify the role of the PCAA in making an assessment and the role of the Secretary in deciding an initial classification and at any time reviewing assessments.

Outlined below are details of the respective roles of the three assessment authorities and some changes to the current provisions which I am willing to pursue in an attempt to address the Committee's concerns:
HOSTEL CARE AND COMMUNITY AGED CARE ASSESSMENTS

The HCAA assesses for an entry to the level of care provided by hostels. In the majority of cases this is now done by Geriatric Assessment Teams ("GAT"), composed of a range of health professionals. However, there are still many HCAAs composed of people associated with the hostel who may not have specific assessment skills. It is intended that all non-GAT HCAAs will cease to exist by 30 June 1993, as all assessments for entry to hostels will by then be made by GATs.

The provision of clause 3(2)(b)(i) of 10F Conditions, by which the Secretary may accept or reject a recommendation by a HCAA, originated at the time when all assessments for hostel entry were undertaken by people associated with hostels, who often did not possess specific assessment skills. It was intended to allow the Secretary to intervene where the criteria contained in the Conditions were not applied correctly in the hostel's assessment of a resident. Under the current arrangements this power is used where review of a recommendation by either a GAT or other HCAA is requested by an aged person. There have not been many cases of such action to date.

I acknowledge the Committee's concern in this area and propose that a more formal process for review by the Secretary of HCAA assessments and subsequent appeal to me should be provided. Such changes would also ensure that hostel admission arrangements are brought in to line with those for nursing home admission.

The revised provisions would include reference to the criteria to be applied in reviewing the assessment and considering an appeal, a requirement for an authorised form to be used, and a requirement to give the reasons for a decision in writing.
I will arrange for the above provisions to be introduced in the forthcoming consolidation of hostel General Conditions formulated under section 10F of the Act.

In addition, I agree that there is value in ensuring that AAT review is also available for people wishing to challenge decisions resulting from assessments by HCAAs. AAT reviews are provided for the nursing home admissions, although to date there have not been any applications for such reviews. However, the introduction of AAT review may well require an amendment to the Act rather than merely to the Conditions. If this is necessary, I will pursue the making of suitable amendments to the Act.

The CACAA is composed of an organisation's own staff who assess a person for the higher level of services which a care package is to provide. This is analogous to the eligibility assessment of an HCAA (although at a different level) and, therefore, the same considerations apply.
Similar arrangements to those outlined above for review and appeal for hostel entry will be also be pursued in regard to assessments for Community Aged Care Packages.
PERSONAL CARE ASSESSMENTS

Personal care assessments are undertaken to enable determination of funding levels for hostels. The role of PCAAs is analogous to that of Directors of Nursing rating nursing home residents on the Resident Classification Instrument ("RCI").

As indicated, PCAAs, who are hostel supervisors or other staff responsible for provision of personal care, assess the degree of care need of their residents. The result of such assessment is used by the Secretary, on the basis of the organisation's application, to classify residents. This process amounts to a ranking of residents of all hostels in order of their requirement for care, relative to other residents. Classification to a level of personal care determines the amount of subsidy payable in respect of each resident to a hostel.

PCAAs have to undertake their assessments in accordance with provisions in clause 3(3), which include using the authorised form (Personal Care Assessment Instrument—PCAI), and carrying out the assessments over a specified period, in most cases 21 days.

The intent of clause 3(3)(f) of the 10F Conditions is not so much to enable a rejection of an application per se, but to ensure that only correctly completed applications (i.e. those completed according to clause 3(3) and following specific instructions, as indicated in clause 3(3)(b)) for classification to be accepted. Once a correct application is received, clause 3(4) will apply, and a resident will be classified to one of three levels of personal care. No discretionary power applies to this process.

I agree that to more accurately reflect this situation, the relevant clauses (ie. clauses 3(3)(f) to 3(3)(h)) should be amended. This will also be done in the consolidation of the hostel General Conditions.

The arrangements for reviewing personal care assessments and for appeals to me where such a review is disputed are consistent with provisions for RCI classifications in nursing homes. Under those arrangements assessments made by PCAAs are verified by delegates of the Secretary (who are appropriately qualified) who periodically visit hostels to establish whether the existing assessments, upon which subsidy is being paid, were made in accordance with clause 3(3).

Where an organisation disputes the review results, it can appeal to me pursuant to clause 3(7). My powers under that clause are not delegated to officers of the Department as I consider it important that organisations have this recourse to me available. An appeal would be investigated on my behalf by appropriately qualified staff, who would use the same guidelines and apply the same criteria as were used when the assessment in question was made, and report to me.

A final point of clarification which relates to PCAA reviews and appeals is that personal care funding is not specifically attached to each individual resident. It is pooled by hostels and, together with other income contributes to the general provision for the care needs of hostel residents. The review and appeal in question therefore is not in relation to funding specifically attached to an individual resident but to an effect on the hostel's overall income at the margin, which may be affected both positively and negatively by review of different clients.

Given concerns expressed earlier as to the appropriateness of merits review on decisions which affect allocation of finite resources and the indirect connection to the funding of care for individual residents, I do not think that AAT reviews in respect of PCAAs assessments would be appropriate. However, as indicated above, I am prepared to pursue amendments to clarify the decision making processes in the General Conditions on these issues.
Your letter also raised two more specific concerns of the Committee related to personal care reviews and their results.

One relates to the date of effect of those reviews. I would like to clarify that the review process under clause 3(6) establishes whether the claim on Commonwealth subsidy made by organisation through their assessments of the care needs of residents have been made correctly in accordance with sub-clauses 3(3)(a), 3(3)(b) an 3(3)(c). The Review Officers have regard to the condition of a resident at the time when the assessment was made (ie. during the 21 days, or other period as appropriate under 3(3)(b)). Therefore the adjustment of the payment, which will be either a recovery of money or additional payment, will reflect the actual entitlement of the hostel to that level of subsidy. Accordingly, I would submit that this could not be properly regarded as offending the prohibition on retrospectivity.

The other aspect of this concern was that this clause might seek to affect decisions made before the making of the conditions which brought in this review powers. If such an interpretation were given to the administration of this clause, subsection 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 would apply so that the clause would have no effect. I can assure the Committee that this clause does not have any element of retrospectivity as this review process will only be in respect of decisions made under the amended section 10F Conditions, which can not be made any earlier than 29 April 1992, which was the date of implementation of those new arrangements.
The second point relates to provisions for repayment of monies

following review or appeal in clause 3(8). The wording used indicates a discretionary power, however overpaid subsidy will be recovered in all cases, which reflects the Commonwealth obligation to recover debts. This clause will be amended to reflect this and make it clear that no discretionary decision making process on the Secretary's part is involved.
There are a number of other areas where you suggest the need for AAT appeal.

Clause 9 of the 10GI Conditions sets out the means by which continued breaches of the Conditions will be handled. This involves a process of discussions, actions identified and, if required, financial sanctions of varying severity upon future payments to the organisation.
By using this process the Commonwealth can seek to ensure that funds are appropriately used without resorting to my power under the Act to revoke an organisation's approval.

Where an organisation considers that no breach has occurred which permits a sanction to be imposed, it has recourse to the Federal Court under such provisions as the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Since the issue of whether a breach has occurred or not, given the nature of the Conditions, is clear cut, I do not see that it is appropriate or necessary for merits review of a decision to impose a sanction.

I need to make clear the provisions in clause 6 of the 10GI Conditions. While through this clause the Commonwealth regulates the fee charging policies of provider organisations, it does not set the fees, nor does it in any other way get directly involved in the fee charging process. Clause 6 requires the provider to reduce the fee where a recipient of a care package demonstrates to the organisation that they are being charged too high a fee (as defined in the clause). The only role the Department may play is where an organisation did not reduce a fee as required and the recipient complains. The Department would then investigate the complaint and make use of the powers under Clause 9 discussed above where a breach of the Conditions is identified.

Clause 3(5)(c) of the 10F Conditions hostels relates to the transition to the new personal care arrangements which were introduced from 29 April 1992. According to those new provisions hostels have 56 days to assess existing residents to receive a personal care subsidy for them from 29 April. This clause allows for extension of the transition period only in cases of substantial difficulties, where a hostel is prevented from assessing its residents in the required time frame due to circumstances clearly beyond a hostel's control, such as illness of staff responsible for undertaking assessments. The test to be applied to the granting of an extension of time is deliberately spelt out in detail in the text of this clause and is, therefore, clear in referring to an
exceptional situation. It may be that no hostels apply for this extension, but I felt it was important to provide for some exceptional circumstances.
You also raised another point not related to AAT review provisions.

The indemnity provision in clause 10(8) of the 10GI Conditions is a standard clause used by the Department with funded organisations to make clear that while the Commonwealth provides subsidies, the provision of care and the way in which it is provided is the organisation's responsibility. Given this, it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth or its representatives to be held accountable for the organisation's actions in delivering care services for which funding is provided.

I believe that the changes I have committed myself to pursue respond to the most significant concerns of your Committee and that clarification of provisions contained in the amendments to the General Conditions should allay the Committee's remaining concerns. I thank your Committee for its comments. If you wish to pursue any further matters of detail on the General Conditions or the programs which they regulate I would offer Mr Robert Griew (ph. 289 5475) as a contact officer in the Department.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Safeguarding Super—The Regulation of Superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to speak to the motion?

—On a point of order, Mr President: the arrangement at the Whips meeting was that Senator Sherry would present his report and incorporate his statement. That is agreed to. If he wishes to speak, then I indicate that Senator Alston would also wish to speak to the report. I am quite happy for Senator Sherry to speak, but I give notice that Senator Alston will speak to the report also.
—I seek leave to incorporate it.
—Is leave granted?

—No, Mr President. I wish to speak to that proposition. It has not been discussed with us. Indeed, as I understood the position, we were simply going to have the report tabled and adjourn discussion for a later hour this day. That is one approach that could have been taken, but until one moment ago I had understood that Senator Sherry was also proposing to speak to the motion to take note of the report. I would have no problem with that. If his tabling speech is not going to preclude me from now speaking, then I do not have a problem. But if what is being put is that somehow Senator Sherry ought to be able to table a speech and that no-one else ought to be able to contribute at this point, then we would certainly object.
—Senator Sherry could incorporate his speech and then seek leave to continue his remarks, which would leave it open for other members to speak at a later date.

—That is precisely what I do not want, Mr President. Let us be clear on this. I think what we are all wanting to do is either all have a discussion on the matter later or all have a brief discussion on the matter now. I do not have it in mind to speak for more than five minutes and I will give an undertaking not to go beyond that point. If Senator Sherry simply tables his speech, that saves us five minutes; and no doubt Senator Kernot would have the same view. So we can knock it off in 10 minutes, if the honourable senator wants to.
—This can be handled in a number of ways. Senator Sherry can move that he takes note of the report and seek leave to continue his remarks.
—Yes, but, as Senator Jones just indicated, that would mean that others would not now be able to speak. I am objecting to that approach.
—And neither would he.
—No, but he has tabled his speech.
—No, that is not what I said. I said that he could move to take note of the report and seek leave to continue, and that would mean that his speech would not be tabled and included.

—I wish to make a few comments on this. It was my understanding that we were all going to be given an opportunity to make a short speech now. I do not want this to be adjourned to a later hour. I go back to the example of the deaths in custody Government response, which we were promised would come back on and which a month later has not. I do not want to lose this opportunity. We should all speak briefly now.

—I propose essentially what Senator Alston put forward: that Senator Sherry incorporate his remarks so that they are on the record. I do not know the length of them; I have not had time to consult with him. If he read them, it might take up time unnecessarily. I propose also that Senator Alston—
—Five minutes each.
—I propose that there be three speeches of five minutes each on this report as tabled.

—Honourable senators would recall that the Committee was established on 5 June last year with terms of reference so comprehensive that virtually all aspects of superannuation, and retirement incomes policy generally, came within their orbit. The subject matter was, and still is, both topical and controversial. Indeed, the Government announced major policy changes in the area even before the Committee had held its first meeting. Some of these changes are the subject of legislation now before the Senate. The subject area is replete with great complex legal and taxation matters—so much so that even the experts on occasions are confused.

PARA.TAB: It soon became apparent that the Committee would be unable to do justice to the subject if it were to attempt to cover all the ground with the necessary thoroughness and complete its task by the original deadline of 28 May 1992. This became more obvious with the reference to the Committee of the superannuation guarantee legislation.

Accordingly, and with the indulgence of the Senate, we decided to report in three stages. We further decided that, in view of the rapid build-up of the sums available for investment by superannuation funds and the elevation of superannuation to a major component of personal savings, the highest priority should be given to those parts of the terms of reference that deal with the regulation of superannuation, in the interests of minimising exposure to risks of mismanagement or fraud and of maximising members' rights.

This report contains 48 recommendations which, if implemented, will go a long way towards the achievement of these objectives. They point to a way of widening the constitutional base of the Commonwealth's power over superannuation, giving more teeth and more resources to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission as the primary regulator. One of the recommendations we make is that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission should have active interventionist power in some circumstances to take control of superannuation funds, given prima facie evidence of theft or fraud.

They advocate the spelling out of trustees' duties and responsibilities in much greater detail than at present and the introduction of a wider range of prudential controls. They call for the specification of who may and who may not become trustees; for improved education and training; and for measures designed to improve trustees' ability to act independently in the interests of all fund members.

The report also covers the vexed question of the accumulation and ownership of fund surpluses, which has recently been the subject of legal disputation and remains one of controversy. We take a strong line against in-house investment and support measures to ensure that fund managers are properly qualified and accredited.

We do not, however, support the compulsory direction of investment toward so-called national interest projects, nor do we advocate restrictions on investment overseas. One member has, however, submitted a minority report on these matters. In terms of this issue we recognise that there are a number of problems, particularly regarding the ability of trustees to make objective and long term decisions, especially decisions in relation to spreading investment into some of the more innovative capital development areas. However, we believe that those objectives can be fulfilled and met by broader education requirements for trustees and by broader goals and objectives being set down, rather than compulsion at this stage. We recommend that in three years a review of this issue be undertaken.

The report contains recommendations for the stimulation of competition in the provision of superannuation in order to guarantee `value for money' and for the establishment of an ombudsman to resolve certain classes of disputes in a way which will minimise the need for action through the courts, thus saving extensive time and legal costs. These matters are highlighted by two case studies that are illustrated in the report. All of the recommendations are quite specific in setting out what we believe ought to be done, who should do it and, where appropriate, when.

The Committee has dealt with a huge workload and its task is far from complete. I pay tribute to my Senate colleagues, who have worked tirelessly towards its completion. I also pay tribute to the staff of the secretariat, who have worked in a similar manner. The Committee has worked very largely in a non-partisan way, as testified by the unanimous endorsement of all but two of our 48 recommendations.

The report covers some areas that have recently been the subject of recommendation by the Law Reform Commission in terms of prudential control. I believe the report will play an important role in leading to some finalisation of the various `big picture' issues which have been the subject of much discussion over the last decade and which, in many respects, have been unresolved for the last 80 years. I am pleased to say in a partisan way—this is the only partisan comment I will make—that the Government of which I am part is working very actively towards resolving all of the big picture issues.

It is very difficult to ensure overnight the resolution of the big picture issues. Some of the almost frightening aspects of superannuation are its enormous complexity, its breadth and the difficulty of ensuring the resolution of all outstanding issues on superannuation in one big hit with one piece of legislation. Personally, I hope that the big picture issues which are the subject of much discussion and controversy are resolved in the not too distant future, say in the next six to 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is a very important report. I commend the efforts of the Committee's staff. I have been particularly impressed by the quality of their work. Having been involved in a number of Senate committees over the last six years, I would say that the output of this Committee is better than that of any other with which I have been associated. I also pay tribute to my colleagues on the Committee. In particular, I think Senator Sherry has chaired the Committee very effectively and this has enabled us to operate in a very cooperative spirit. The Senate ought to be very proud that we have a report that goes to the heart of some very important issues. It is one that will make a major contribution to ensuring that we have more effective regulation of superannuation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is clearly an urgent need for one port of call when it comes to regulation. Therefore, we recommend that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission be a sole regulator of the industry. The Commission needs to be properly resourced. It currently has a budget of $17.3m. We recommend that that be reviewed and that there be a greater degree of formal and informal liaison with the other regulatory bodies which have an interest, at the margin at least, in the superannuation area.

In particular, it is essential, on the one hand, that we avoid perceptions that the ISC is the poodle of the industry and, on the other hand, that we avoid falling into the trap of its becoming captured by the populists. Therefore, one of the most important recommendations we make is that there be a panel of commissioners who are independent as far as possible, who have proven expertise in superannuation, and who are not simply the mouthpiece of vested interests. I think that will go a long way towards assisting the ISC in ensuring that it does play that pro-active role as regulator, that it does carry out effective random audits, that it is in a position to replace trustees where there is a need to do so, and that it operates very effective early warning systems. Otherwise there is a very great risk that there will be a massive loss of confidence from ordinary Australians.

Indeed, with the ever increasing growth of assets of superannuation funds, currently $130 billion plus, whichever government is in power is going to have to confront the ever increasing risk that the fast buck merchants will be drawn like moths to a flame. Australia cannot afford to do a Maxwell, and I hope that we will be anxious to act as urgently as possible to ensure that proper regulatory systems are in place and that investors or contributors are guaranteed that they will get their money back in the event of fraud. We simply cannot afford to have the punters left lamenting.

If we do go down this path, one of the most important watchdogs will be the media. Therefore we recommend that the ISC establish a national database, which hopefully will allow virtually instant access for quality journalists who will then be in a position to report to the masses. In many respects that is a much more desirable approach then spending ever increasing numbers of dollars and expecting all manner of regulators to publish all sorts of pieces of information which can often simply be a vehicle for patting the Government on the back. I would much prefer to put my trust in those in the media who do take a specialist interest in the subject and to ensure that they are fully informed of the facts.

One other area to which particular attention ought to be drawn, in view of the comment of some out there who talk longingly about the need for bipartisanship, is that whilst the industrial relations element bedevils superannuation it will be very difficult to achieve the sorts of reforms that are necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we were talking about multipartisanship.

—I am sorry, I will use that term. I was, in fact, invoking what had been said by others about the need for bipartisanship, but I take Senator Kernot's point. Multipartisanship is what we ought to be aspiring to. Let me give you one critical example of an area in which I think we will run into very big problems unless we can separate out the industrial relations debate, and that is in the area of preservation. A very important recommendation is contained in 10.4, where it says that there will be a significant cost to revenue unless we move to take action on that front.

PARA.TAB: As recently as last night, the ACTU again made it clear that it will continue to veto any increase in the preservation age. The Government again seems locked into doing whatever the ACTU asks of it in this area. The immortal words of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that raising the preservation age is too difficult politically and industrially is a classic example of an abdication of responsibility. Clearly, he recognises the need to move but is constrained by those who pull the strings.

If ever there was a graphic illustration of a need to get rational debate into the system on a multipartisan basis, then raising the preservation age ought to be it. I call on the Government to address that issue urgently to avoid the substantial cost to revenue. I urge the Government to avoid falling for the sophistry peddled by the ACTU that somehow we need more information and more research and more anything else but action on this front, and to bite the bullet as the Opposition has already done.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have done with the SGL.

—We can have that debate on 17 June. The approach on investment controls or directions and particular limitations on overseas investment is a very welcome bipartisan commitment. I should say that I am very pleased to see that the Government has not lost its nerve on this front. The populists will always pick up a degree of support out there—
—What is popular about it?

—What is popular about saying that we ought to limit the opportunity for those foreign rapists to come in and pillage all of our resources and to deprive us of the opportunity of investing locally and maintaining jobs?
—Don't take up your five minutes or seven minutes on that.

—No, I will not. I am almost finished. The requirement for trustees to establish investment targets is important. Spelling out the duties of trustees is again an important way of ensuring that people are very much aware of their responsibilities. If we can ensure that trustees are qualified people and that they are fit and proper persons and satisfy the normal test, then we will be in a much better position to ensure that the hard-earned savings of ordinary workers and others will not be at risk and that the Government will have exercised its proper role: not simply to accept total responsibility and have people walk away from their own responsibilities but to ensure that all those people charged with different levels of responsibility take advantage of what needs to be done.
—I just take this opportunity, while credit is being taken here, to remind all honourable senators that the Select Committee on Superannuation was set up on a Democrat reference.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true. I support the Chairman's remarks and the work of the Committee in handing down this report in such a short time. I would draw attention to what we understand about the complexity of the whole superannuation debate, and how the report—especially in its opening chapters—will assist in educating a wide cross-section of the population on superannuation. This is something which is long overdue. We have seen so much evidence of the naivety of consumers who trustingly hand over to some agent the whole future of their retirement income, no questions asked.

PARA.TAB: This report goes a long way towards addressing the need for public education. It addresses two of the so-called black holes in the superannuation debate. The first is that of trustees, including the very complex law which governs their operations. The second black hole concerns funds managers who handle billions of dollars, but who are not known either personally or in a corporate sense by the millions of contributors who have joined one of the 100,000 superannuation funds responsible for investing over $140 billion. If the SGL is to go through, that will rise to an amount of something like $600 billion. This is why we should be very serious about what we do with the supervision and regulation of superannuation funds in this country.

In respect of trustees, the law needs codifying to ensure that superannuation trustees are operating on the basis of a common national standard vis-a-vis their obligations to members. We believe it is essential that all arm's length funds have equal employer-employee representation. This principle is an essential ingredient of any good watchdog system. We have seen evidence of the need for this in the Byrnwood case. Trustee education is a prerequisite to funds being operated in a way which maximises a fund's assets, and pays due regard to the returns which long term investments can bring.

In the case of the second black hole, the funds managers, the top five fund managers control 44 per cent of superannuation funds. That is why we believe the ISC and the TPC—the Trade Practices Commission—will need to monitor this characteristic of superannuation to ensure that it does not stifle true competition. That is why Parliament needs to maintain a watching brief on this. Funds managers and their performance do need to be the subject of close community scrutiny in future years. Such scrutiny requires an informed community, and this report, as I said, goes a long way towards assisting an informed community.

I have made some minority recommendations, but before I touch briefly on those, I want to say, from the point of view of the Democrats, that it is essential that the Government gives a very clear and specific commitment to act on the recommendations of this report. We have talked about the big picture. Here is one part of it that is able to be filled in. I agree with Senator Alston that not only is this important but matters such as preservation are, indeed, essential parts of the big picture.

I have touched on two areas. One is investment direction, and the other is a limit on offshore investment. I will not go into those in detail except to say that I really challenge the underlying assumption that it is not in the national interest to stimulate overall economic performance by direction of a small amount of investment, because it conflicts with a trustee's duties to provide maximum return for members. I contend strongly that if we can maximise overall economic performance, in the long term returns can be maximised as well.

I want to spend the last minute commending the special secretariat. I think they are a special secretariat, and I want to mention them by name: Richard Gilbert, Lyn Curran, Michael Game, Rod Power and Heather Hibbitt. I thank them for their harmonious and professional approach. They are a wonderful team. They have provided members of the Committee with consistently first-class research material and assistance—not just research but assistance to us. They deserve special commendation. I commend my colleagues on the Committee. We have, I think, behaved very professionally, but I wonder how we will go on the next Committee report, where we already know of obvious areas of disagreement. I commend the report and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: SUGAR CANE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Sugar Cane Levy Amendment Bill is to amend the maximum rate of levy on sugar cane, to 15 cents per tonne, as provided for in section 7 of the Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987. The Bill has been prepared following a request from the Australian raw sugar industry. The request was made by the Australian Cane Growers' Council, represented by Canegrowers, and the Australian Cane Farmers Association on behalf of sugar cane growers and the Australian Sugar Milling Council on behalf of the millers of sugar cane.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sugar Cane Levy Act 1987 provides for an industry levy on sugar cane, produced in Australia and accepted for processing at a sugar mill, to provide funds for the activities of the Sugar Research and Development Corporation. The Act provides for a maximum rate of levy which is currently set at 10 cents per tonne of sugar cane.

The Government provides funding to match industry levies up to 0.5 per cent of the annual gross value of production (GVP), in line with established policy of encouraging increased rural productivity and profitability through research and the commercialisation of research findings .

It is generally recognised that research and development in the sugar industry is underfunded at present when compared with Commonwealth funding of research and development efforts in other rural industries. Currently about 0.17 per cent of GVP is being matched in the sugar industry when compared with an estimated 0.5 per cent in the wool, meat, wheat and oilseed industries.

The sugar industry is committed to industry funded research and wishes to increase this commitment to the Commonwealth scheme through an increased levy in order to maintain its competitive export and domestic marketing position. The current rate of levy is 6 cents per tonne. However the sugar industry has indicated its wish to increase that levy to 14 cents per tonne for the 1992 season. The current maximum levy rate of 10 cents per tonne is thus hindering this increase and so preventing the sugar industry from utilising the full potential of the Commonwealth R&D scheme.

The Government's rural research and development policy, which encourages increased contributions by primary industry, was established by the Government in February 1985 and reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, "Research, Innovation and Competitiveness" .

The sugar industry is one of Australia's most important agricultural industries. Sugar is Australia's third most valuable export crop, after wheat and cotton, and 75 to 80 per cent of raw sugar production is exported. Production in 1991-92, was 3.2 million tonnes of raw sugar from a drought affected crop of 21.3m tonnes of sugar cane, with a gross value of production estimated at $585m. This is well below the record level of 3.8 million tonnes of sugar produced in 1989-90, but production is expected to rise again, with increases in the area of land under cane.
About 95 per cent of total Australian sugar production is based in Queensland with the remainder drawn from Northern New South Wales .
The Bill will come into force on Royal Assent.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to debate the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill will seek to amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to provide royal commissions with the same authority to seek information that is available to specified law enforcement agencies under section 3E of the Act. The Bill will now allow the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters and future royal commissions access to relevant taxation information under the Act.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's position is not to oppose the Bill. But our concern is about the amount of access which has been given, with which we disagree. The Government is proposing that access will be available only where it is necessary to prove a serious offence. The definition of a serious offence is normally taken to mean one that attracts a prison term of more than 12 months. The coalition regards this as too high a barrier, particularly in the case of royal commissions. Therefore, I should be stating clearly a case for the different treatment of this access being provided to royal commissions by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to certain tax files.

This Bill has arisen from a specific request from the Royal Commission in Western Australia to the Federal Government that the law be amended as necessary to ensure that the Western Australian Commission has full access to the information it needs to pursue the terms of reference of its inquiry in relation to Western Australia Inc.

Mr Templeman, counsel assisting the inquiry, was quoted in the Sun-Herald newspaper on 13 May 1992 as stating that he wrote to the Commission requesting the same access as was given to the Queensland royal commissioner, Tony Fitzgerald, in 1987. In particular, in the opinion of the Commission, the Government's original refusal for investigatory access to tax files has helped to make impossible any conclusive findings on corruption in the so-called Western Australia Inc. scandals. Further, consequent requests from all associated with the Western Australian Royal Commission have been for the same powers as the Federal Government extended to the Fitzgerald Royal Commission in 1987.

The Western Australian Premier, Dr Carmen Lawrence, demanded in her press releases that the Royal Commission be granted these same powers. The Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Ron Edwards, from Western Australia, also reiterated that call. We all know the original government position was that the current level of secrecy should not be disturbed. The Bill before us today is evidence that the Government has reversed its stance on the matter. It does not mean that the Western Australian Royal Commission will get exactly the same level of access to the information that this Labor Government gave to the Fitzgerald Royal Commission. I cannot understand this Government's refusal in the first place not to give the Western Australian Commission its request.

In 1982 the Government empowered the Commissioner of Taxation, under the Income Tax Assessment Act (No. 2), to pass tax information to the Costigan and Stewart royal commissions and to any other Federal royal commission that the Governor-General declared should have access in its terms of reference. In 1982 the law was changed to provide full access to a royal commission for the purpose of conducting its inquiry. That was the clear, legislatively stated policy position of the Commonwealth for royal commissions. This policy was continued with the Fitzgerald inquiry. Yet the moves contained in this Bill fall significantly short of the provisions on tax file access given to the Fitzgerald inquiry into corruption in Queensland. Today the Opposition will aim to rectify this, and I foreshadow an amendment, which will be moved in the committee stage of this debate, to effect this change.

In 1987 the Commonwealth Attorney-General appointed a senior officer to assist the Fitzgerald inquiry's dealings with the Commonwealth after the Hawke Government speedily acted to ensure special legislation to give the inquiry access to Australian Taxation Office information. Note that I said, `speedily acted'. Note the fuss that has surrounded this particular Bill compared with the Fitzgerald inquiry. This has created enormous concern. Mr Tony Fitzgerald, QC, documented the arrangements in his 1989 report. The Fitzgerald legislation was specifically written for the broader requirements of a commission of inquiry rather than those of a law enforcement agency, to which section 3E of the Tax Administration Act relates and to which this Bill relates. Yet section 3E is the avenue this Government has suggested the Western Australian Royal Commission use to gain access to Tax Office information.

In order to respond to the needs of the Queensland Fitzgerald inquiry, this Parliament enacted the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act 1987. This not only inserted the Fitzgerald legislation, section 16A, into the Income Tax Assessment Act but also amended a number of Commonwealth Acts to give statutory assistance to the Queensland inquiry across a range of Commonwealth agencies and departments. The legislation written for the Fitzgerald inquiry allowed the Queensland inquiry to communicate or pass on Tax Office information to a range of authorities for follow-up investigations or prosecutions. In several cases, a test required was whether it indicated a serious offence or related to a possible tax offence.

However, under section 3E, which is the vehicle being used for the Western Australian inquiry—I remind the Senate that section 3E was inserted in 1989—the Commissioner of Taxation may communicate confidential information only if he is satisfied that it is relevant to establishing a serious offence or a proceeds of crime order that may arise from any serious offence. Section 3E, unlike the Fitzgerald legislation, requires that a stringent test be applied by the Tax Office to requests for information, and the use of tax information, once obtained, is precisely limited.

Further, unlike the Fitzgerald legislation, section 3E of the Taxation Administration Act, as opposed to the Income Tax Assessment Act section 16(k), does not specify the right to divulge Tax Office information before public or private hearings of an inquiry. Section 3E does not specify that the Tax Office information can be communicated to the Governor, which is the equivalent of a written report to Government.

When the powers to both inquiries are analysed, it is very apparent that there is a great disparity between the two. One would have expected to find certain even-handedness, but this is not the case. The Bill we have before us this morning does not give the Western Australian Royal Commission the same freedom to pursue the complex money trails under which corruption is hidden as was available in Queensland to Fitzgerald. The Government has inferred that if the same power is given to the Western Australian commissioner, and other royal commissions, a broad fishing licence approach would be undertaken. The `fishing approach' metaphor refers to the Government's own words. I do not think the coalition would use such an insult to this Royal Commission.

I remind the Senate that royal commissions are limited by their terms of reference. The essence of a royal commission is that it should inquire more widely than the police. Where financial scandal is involved charges are unlikely unless the investigators can follow the money trail. The need to re-establish trust in the institutions of government is paramount when questions of public propriety, such as the Western Australian situation, are involved. The public needs to be reassured that investigators of such scandals are willing and able to pursue the trail wherever that trail might lead. Denying such full access would not give the public the assurance that I believe they require.

However, what I regard as the `fishing' expedition insult is not only directed to this Royal Commission but to the previous Stewart Royal Commission, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Fitzgerald inquiry, all of which have been provided with far greater powers. To claim that the provision of information and the extension of power of access to the Western Australian commission would somehow be a breach of privacy and that the commission was not following its terms of reference is an insult to the commissioners of the Western Australian Royal Commission, including Sir Roland Wilson, a former High Court judge and a person whose integrity and authority should really not be questioned.

This is the first occasion on which the access powers of a royal commission have been limited. The wording of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was inserted in 1982 and, by its reference to other royal commissions, clearly indicates that it is an intention that such bodies should have access for the purpose of their inquiries. The subsequent insertion of a limited access arrangement, that is, section 3 of the Taxation Administration Act, simply reinforces our argument.

I point out that my argument today for the extension of access powers is not at odds with our previous calls in chamber for the maintenance of confidentiality of an individual's tax information. I firmly hold to the view that the confidentiality of tax files should not lightly be breached. However, the cause of justice occasionally demands a qualification of such liberties, and the Western Australian commission certainly seems to constitute such an extension. Further, granting access to royal commissioners is not to be compared with releasing tax files publicly.

Why has the Western Australian Royal Commission not received the same status as the Fitzgerald inquiry? The only reason and sense that the coalition can make out of the situation is that this Bill before us is merely a tactical backdown on the most inadequate position of refusing access to tax files, which had been taken by this Government previously. This has been stated in the lower House during the debate on this Bill.

The only conclusion one can really draw from this fairly analytical review of the facts is that the whole exercise has been tainted by a certain degree of political bias. For example, when it came to the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland, the Government was prepared to open its doors to information with respect to tax files so that the Royal Commission could comprehensively follow its terms of reference and, in particular, follow the money trails which are so often characteristic of inquiries into corruption.

With respect to the situation in Western Australia, the reality is that the request was the same, yet it was denied. Having looked at all the arguments for refusing access, one can only conclude a degree of political bias, which is regrettable. Since Mr Templeman, counsel assisting the Royal Commission in Western Australia, made public his comments concerning the Government's refusal to provide access, discussions have occurred between this Government and officers of the Royal Commission.

Consequently, the commission, through its solicitor, has provided a letter to the Government, which has accepted the amendments that are now before us. The coalition, however, has no information upon which to judge the manner in which the Royal Commission has formed this view. The only information on the public record is that the Royal Commission specifically asked for access on the same basis as was provided to the Fitzgerald inquiry; but this has been denied it. So we have a limited form of access through this legislation here today.

The only explanation the coalition has arrived at in respect of the Western Australian commission's attitude, following a comprehensive review of the evidence, is that it has a fair amount of material on which a case could be based that a serious offence has been committed. In that event, the Commission has probably acquired as much as it currently needs to proceed further in its reference.

So we have before us a very complex Bill—far more complex than that which is really required. However, the Royal Commission in Western Australia does appear to be happy. The Bill picks up the prescribed royal commission standards for both the Commonwealth and the State. However, the Opposition is concerned that there is not the same degree of access.

The Opposition is also concerned that there is some confusion or some overlap between section 16(k) of the Income Tax Assessment Act which seeks to deal with these issues and the extension of section 3E. During the committee stage, we would like the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to give some explanation.

Finally, the Opposition, while not opposing the Bill, will be introducing in the committee stage a number of amendments so that access will be the same as provided to the Fitzgerald inquiry. This, we believe, will correct the definite Government political bias and present a much fairer and better Bill. With those qualifications, we support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Watson indicated, the history which leads us to this piece of legislation, the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill, is indeed a very sorry one. We had in the case of the Fitzgerald inquiry a government which was very keen to provide access to relevant tax information. I understand that in that situation the legislation passed through the Parliament in as little as three days and that access was provided, as Senator Watson indicated, under the Income Tax Assessment Act, section 16, and was made specific to the Fitzgerald Royal Commission.

PARA.TAB: When, however, the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters in Western Australia sought access to the relevant tax information, that access was denied on several occasions. That, in our view, clearly indicates that there was a political bias built into that decision. It was a decision made by the then Treasurer; it was not in any way made by the Taxation Commissioner.

When, later, the former Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), sought to hide behind the decision of the Taxation Commissioner we found that to be completely despicable. The Taxation Commissioner was clearly giving a decision that he had to give in the light of the legislation that must guide him. He was acting in full accord with that legislation. I believe it was with great impropriety that the Prime Minister sought to hide behind the Commissioner of Taxation in relation to the denial of access to the Western Australian Royal Commission.

Also, I think the Prime Minister was most blameworthy when in his celebrated press conference he described the access that the Western Australian Royal Commission would get as tearing the lid off the Taxation Office in the way one might tear open the lid of a can. That led me last week to ask a question of Senator Button, which honourable senators will remember, to which Senator Button replied that only 110 records were released to the Fitzgerald inquiry as a consequence of the section 16 amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act. That is hardly tearing the lid off the privacy provisions that are correctly built into the secrecy that surrounds tax information.

The section 16 amendment which was provided to Fitzgerald was itself guarded by the discretionary power of the Commissioner of Taxation. It was not open slather at all. The Fitzgerald commission had to apply for the records—I understand that a small group was set up within the Taxation Office to assess the request—and only when sufficient grounds were established were records released. We now have firmly on the record that only 110 records out of many millions in Australia were released to the Fitzgerald inquiry. However, when the Western Australian Royal Commission sought similar access in about May last year it was denied by the Prime Minister, who was then the Treasurer, and later in the year when access was sought again it was also denied.

We now have before us a belated amendment to the Taxation Administration Act which, as Senator Watson has pointed out, seeks to provide access that is different from the access given to Fitzgerald but similar to the access that is given to law enforcement agencies. TALK.START.PARA: —What else could he say?

PARA.TAB: We are concerned that a different form of access is being given, but in this case we have fairly firmly on the record that the Western Australian Royal Commission is satisfied. There is, however, another matter which arises out of this whole sorry history: the fact that the Western Australian Royal Commission had been denied access only came to light extremely late in the day. It came to light only in the closing stages of the Commission when Mr Templeman said that the Western Australian Commission had been inhibited in its ability to pursue certain matters because of lack of access to tax information.

So we are seeking to insert an amendment into this amending legislation which will ensure that when a royal commission applies for access to tax information, under this new amendment a decision must be given. One can only note in passing that it would seem far more appropriate for the Western Australian inquiry, which is pre-eminently about financial matters, to have been given access rather than the Fitzgerald inquiry, which was principally about police corruption—even though money trails are very important in these matters, as Senator Watson has pointed out. TALK.START.PARA: —It was about conduct of government too, Senator.
