TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I take this opportunity to now table in the Senate one substantial volume of Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade documents relating to Gregory Symons, and to table also a second volume of Austrade documents relating to Gregory Symons. In each case there will be immediately available, literally within the next few moments, a full set of those documents—separately available for the Opposition and for the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I make a few remarks in the context of this tabling. I have gone as far as I possibly can—consistent with the kind of confidentiality obligations that I outlined in the Senate yesterday—to release documents in full or with minimum deletions. The schedules in each of the two volumes that have now been tabled clearly explain the nature of each document and the reasons for any deletion or withholding.

The shorthand descriptions given of the reasons for deletion should be self-explanatory in each case, but perhaps I should add specifically that the description `legal confidentiality', which is used on a number of occasions, refers essentially to material which, in my judgment, would be likely to be embarrassing or prejudicial to a person in the defence of his position in court.

It may be helpful for me to respond at the outset to some questions or requests for clarification that may be made in respect of five particular documents in the two volumes. First of all, I refer to DFAT document No. 13. The language of paragraph 5 of this particular cable may on its face suggest that there was some reluctance on the part of the Australian Government to put in place an extradition agreement with the Republic of the Marshall Islands Government. I have been advised by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that this was in no sense the case. I seek leave at this point to incorporate in Hansard a full response from him to that effect. Might I add that I will give a copy of what I am now saying to those opposite immediately so that they do not have to wait for the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

The document referred to must be seen in its context as one step in a chain of events. The process of reaching agreement on a basis for extradition between Australia and the Marshall Islands had been continuing since the extradition without treaty to Australia of a person from the Marshall Islands in September 1989. In August 1991 the Australian post at Pohnpei had been asked to put formally to the Marshall Islands a proposal for Australian legislation to be applied to the Marshalls so that extradition could take place pursuant to the standard terms and conditions in the Australian Act. As at 10 April 1992 no reply had been received to that proposal. The purpose of the cable on 15 April 1992 was to ascertain whether the proposal had in fact been formally put to the Marshalls and what reply, if any, had been received.

I am informed by my Department that the reason for the cable was the raising by the Marshall Islands Attorney-General by telephone on 10 April 1992 of the possibility of an extradition request in the near future from the Marshall Islands for extradition from Australia. In that conversation, the status of the Australian proposal to establish a basis for extradition was not raised because, on the Australian side, it seemed necessary to find out what had happened through the formal channel.

I am informed by my Department that there were two reasons for asking our post at Pohnpei not to put the proposed extradition arrangement to the Marshalls if that had not been done already. The first reason was that it might have been desirable to explain the Australian legal requirements in more detail if the Marshalls authorities were under the wrong impression that Australia had already taken the necessary action to put itself in a position to extradite to the Marshalls. The second reason was so that consideration could be given to submitting the question of application of the Act to the Marshalls to the Australian Attorney-General for his decision on how the application of the Act should be handled if it was to take place with a particular extradition in prospect i.e. for the apparent purpose of facilitating a particular extradition.

In the result, the cautious approach adopted in the cable proved to have been unnecessary. The post at Pohnpei had already submitted the proposal to the Marshalls. Moreover, it was subsequently confirmed by the Marshall Islands Attorney-General that he was fully aware that the ball was in his court and that it was, and remains, a matter for the Marshall Islands Government to consider if and when the process of establishing extradition relations on the basis proposed by Australia should be carried forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate. Secondly, I refer to DFAT document No. 28. This is a file note prepared by Mr David O'Leary, Assistant Secretary of the South Pacific Branch of the Department, on a telephone call from my senior adviser, Mr Miles Kupa, on the evening of 13 May. Mr Kupa advises me that in one respect this file note does not accord with his own clear recollection of the conversation. PARA.TAB: Thirdly, DFAT document No. 43, which is a memorandum from Mr Lamb in Washington, should be read in conjunction with document No. 48, which is a later DFAT file note on the same subject. It might otherwise be overlooked that there is a connection between those two documents, and the latter explains the former.

Fourthly, as to DFAT document No. 71, this fax to my Department from Pohnpei covers a compendium of documents 24 pages long. Just in case there should be some question raised about the apparently missing pages, may I say that five of those 24 pages are included in document No. 71. The other 19 are included chronologically among the other documents.

Finally, as to Austrade document No. 31, this minute from Austrade, in so far as it relates to the confidentiality obligations of Ministers in relation to the disclosure of EMDG material, should be read subject to Austrade document No. 41. This later document includes detailed advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the confidentiality obligations of Ministers under section 94 of the Australian Trade Commission Act.

That is all I want to say at this point. I will make available copies of what I have just said not only to Hansard but to the Opposition and to the Democrats, and I would hope that any debate on these matters could be deferred until everyone has had an opportunity to look at the material.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill, which is a rather belated, after the hour move from the Government and which has only been brought about by pressure from the Western Australian Royal Commission and the public generally—and of course the Opposition. Unless this Bill is amended to give to the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government the same access to taxation information as was given to the Fitzgerald inquiry by legislation in 1987, it will serve as nothing more than an exercise in double standards and a clear rebuff to the resolution of the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia, as tabled in the Senate last week.

PARA.TAB: I made some comments at that stage about the resolution moved by the Western Australian Legislative Assembly, and the fact that it too wished the Government to give exactly the same rights, the same access, to the Western Australian Royal Commission as was given to the Fitzgerald inquiry. What this resolution calls for—no more and no less—is a repeat of the action taken in December 1987, when the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill amended both the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Taxation Administration Act, to enable access to taxation information on the same basis as applies to Commonwealth royal commissions, that precedent having been set in 1982.

The then Attorney-General stated on 8 December 1987 that there was genuine public interest in the provision of Commonwealth assistance to the Fitzgerald Commission. We can only ask why this same public interest does not apply in regard to Western Australia, when the Bill allows only the more limited access provided to law enforcement agencies under section 3E of this Act.

Therefore, what we really have to look at—I do not believe that this is being cynical in any way, shape or form—is that, when it came to the Government looking after its mate in the Western Australian inquiry, the door was firmly shut, slammed clean in the Commissioner's face. When it came to getting stuck into the National Party in Queensland, the present Prime Minister—who was the Treasurer at that stage—was quite happy, probably deliriously happy, to give the Fitzgerald inquiry all the access that it needed.

It is a great shame that the Democrats today, in the amendments that they plan to move, are now toeing the Government line. I have to say, as a Western Australian, that I was relieved to hear Senator Coulter, at the time when this was raised, say that he was wishing the same access to be given to the Western Australian Commission as was given to the Fitzgerald inquiry. I would hope that Senator Coulter today would see the difference between the Democrat amendments and those which we are moving. Those which we are moving are directly in line with the access which was given to Fitzgerald.

This Government well understands that a royal commission, by its very nature, has a far wider purpose than the investigation of a serious offence. The Prime Minister certainly knew this when, on 14 May, he poured scorn on the Commission for engaging in a fishing expedition. He made a personal attack on leading counsel assisting the Commission, describing his submission as offensive and self-serving. At the same time, he advanced the spurious excuse that the 1989 legislative changes would have allowed police attached to the Commission to seek information from the Tax Commissioner. Quite clearly, those police were not available for the same type of investigation. If the police attached to the Commission had sought and received that type of information, they would have been running the risk of being slammed in gaol.

This has not been any fishing expedition whatsoever. It is a bit like Senator Evans—and the Prime Minister—talking the other day about the Opposition going on a fishing expedition in relation to the Marshall Islands. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a Tasmanian, may have seen a cartoon which I think really summed that one up well. One section of it showed the Prime Minister saying how disgraceful it was that the Opposition was going on a fishing expedition about the Marshall Islands affair; the next section of the cartoon showed Dr Hewson with a great big fishbowl, with Senator Richardson swimming around in it. Quite clearly it was no fishing expedition: the results were there. There was the fish in the bowl. We now know that the fish has got a hook firmly caught in its mouth.

So this exercise is not a fishing expedition. It is a very serious matter. The people of Western Australia are deeply concerned about the ramifications of the Royal Commission into government activities, and with the passage of every day they are becoming more and more concerned as they see key players in it having more and more evidence stacked up against them. But, as Senator Coulter mentioned a little while ago, the Royal Commission has a great problem in tracking the money trail, because the money trail has mysteriously wandered overseas. Therefore it is imperative that we come back to the point of why the Government would do one thing for one royal commission which was attached to the National Party, and do completely the opposite for another royal commission which is just as significant but which is associated with the Labor Party. As I said before, the police attached to the Royal Commission did not include the Commissioner and therefore did not have the seniority to request or, indeed, pass on such information. Once they work with the Royal Commission, the four police officers become royal commission investigators and have absolutely no entitlement to seek taxation records under the Taxation Administration Act. Ignoring this fact, the Prime Minister sought to erode the public standing of the Commission by alleging that these officers were feuding with the Commission's staff and accused the Commission of provoking political controversy for having the temerity finally to make public a major impediment to its investigations nearly 12 months after he had, as Treasurer, denied their request.

The Prime Minister backtracked on 15 May by at least conceding that this legislation would be coming into the Parliament; but there has, of course, been no apology for the very deliberate political attack on the distinguished Australians who are conducting an inquiry that is causing well-deserved embarrassment to the Labor Government. I might add that I do not believe this lack of apology is any accident, because neither can this inadequate Bill gloss over the fact that on three occasions over the last year this Labor Government has refused the Commission the access that it sought. The Government has, indeed, been very consistent in its clear, underlying objective of protecting Labor mates by stonewalling, by misrepresenting the provisions of section 3E, by attacking the credibility of the Commission and, finally, by disregarding the express wish of the Parliament of Western Australia through a piece of inadequate legislation.

It is for those reasons that we will be moving in the Committee of the Whole a very different set of amendments to those which the Democrats are moving. I certainly hope that the strong line that Senator Coulter took at the time of the exposure of this is conveyed in the vote of the Democrats today, because I do not believe that we can now set a further precedent whereby we water down access to any royal commission when the precedent has already been set by Fitzgerald.

I think it would be dangerous to start going down that track, because we really need to make sure that the Western Australian Royal Commission has every access possible to be able to make sure that justice is not only done but is seen to be done. I repeat: it is certainly of great concern to Western Australians that the refusal took place in the first instance; but then, of course, it took place with subsequent requests. I believe that a request to Mr Kerin, in the brief time that he was Treasurer, was not even acknowledged. Therefore I think it is very important, and we will be moving these amendments in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, of course, debating the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill 1992. I will be brief, because I understand that there is a sense of urgency about this matter and the quicker the Bill can get through the better. That in itself has a nice touch of irony about it, because the Government has taken since May 1991 to do anything about this legislation, but I heard Senator Coulter say it took only three days in the case of the Fitzgerald inquiry for there to be a response from the Government.

PARA.TAB: One might speculate as to why we are debating this Bill and not a further amendment to section 16A of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which would simply mean adding the Western Australian Royal Commission into that section. That would have the effect of providing the Western Australian Royal Commission with the same powers that were made available to the Fitzgerald inquiry.

The distinction between this legislation and the Fitzgerald inquiry legislation is startlingly obvious. In respect of this matter, there is a stringent test at the discretion of the Commissioner placed on the availability of information, because section 3E says:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding any taxation secrecy provision, the Commissioner may disclose information acquired by the Commissioner under the provisions of a tax law to an authorised law enforcement agency officer if the Commissioner is satisfied that the information is relevant to:
(a)establishing whether a serious offence has been, or is being, committed; or
(b)the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order.
In the case of section 16A, Fitzgerald was virtually given carte blanche. He was given open access to information. As Senator Coulter said, he made 110 requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were 110 released.

—Yes, 110 were released. One can assume that under the criteria there would have been 110 applications, but one cannot be certain about that. I take it that these commissioners employ great diligence and take great responsibility in seeking information of this nature, sensitive as they are to the information to which they are gaining access. One can only assume that the Western Australian Royal Commission, given the difference of references, would be requiring considerably less information than the Fitzgerald inquiry.

PARA.TAB: What is the distinction between the Fitzgerald Royal Commission and the Western Australian Royal Commission? There are two distinctions, and not too subtle ones at that. One is an inquiry into corruption in a police force, and the other one is an inquiry into corruption in a government. The other distinction is that one was an inquiry into activities that may have been relevant to a conservative government, and the other one is an inquiry into the conduct of a Labor government. That is the distinction.

A further difference is that we got this piece of legislation with the amendments to section 3E for Western Australia and section 16A in the case of the Queensland Royal Commission. On that occasion, there was a great deal of cooperation. In fact, there was unbridled enthusiasm on the part of the Government in accommodating the requests of Fitzgerald. The truth of the matter is there was political mileage in it and political gain in it. If the same access were provided in Western Australia, one can assume there would be political damage, and therefore we have got political decisions. This inquiry in Western Australia is not about corruption of a law enforcement agency, it is about the potential corruption and impropriety of a government of the day. That information is not available, yet we are told by counsel from the Commission that they are now satisfied with these amendments.

I find that curious, although there is no doubt a very simple explanation. I find it curious because the initial request—and I am sure it was not an ambit bid, because I trust these commissions to make responsible requests—was for powers similar to those of the Fitzgerald inquiry. One can only take it that, after an enormous amount of work and endeavour, the Royal Commission has been able to define and refine its levels and directions of inquiries and that they can now satisfy the commissioner within the terms of section 3E.

I have grave reservations, and I always do, about widening the ambit of those that can have access to taxation information or any other information which goes to the heart of privacy or that impinges, or has the potential to impose, upon the right to secrecy and the right of access to people's personal and private information. One of the fundamental cornerstones of the taxation Act is that people believe that access is not available and, therefore, they are likely to be frank in their disclosures. In any democracy the giving of information, notwithstanding the penalties, will very much depend upon the levels of people's integrity and honesty. If people feel that there is unfettered access to that information, it will no doubt in some respects inhibit the level of compliance.

I do not stand here as somebody who calls for open access, but I am here debating that there ought in this case to be equal access. I might well have disagreed with Fitzgerald's request. In the political environment and the political climate prevailing at the time, if any Liberal or National Party senators had got up and opposed the legislation, they would have been painted as corrupt and as supporting corruption. They would have been painted as frustrating and inhibiting proper inquiry into the conduct of the law enforcement agencies of Queensland. Such was the political climate created by members of the Labor Party.

It is always difficult in these circumstances to have rational and reasonable debates. Yet we now have the circumstance where, without concern or regard, the Labor Party is prepared to be seen to be inhibiting the proper inquiries set up to investigate potential corruption in the Government of Western Australia. That inquiry was set up in the face of violent and

SPEECH.PARA: bitter opposition by the Labor Party and the Labor Government of Western Australia. I have myself heard in recent weeks the current Labor Minister for Police violently opposing the Western Australian Royal Commission. It was not set up by the Liberal Party as some political act or for some political advantage; it was ultimately set up by a Labor government because of the enormous pressure from society, the enormous pressure from the community, demanding a certain standard of accountability of the Government. Already it is apparent that members of a previous Labor government were tainted to some degree. If the public cannot have confidence in the functioning, the systems, the management and the manner of government, the very system of democracy is threatened. Of course, that is why in Australia we have open government to the extent that we do.

PARA.TAB: It is of no credit to this Government that it draws distinction, by way of this legislation, between the Commission of Inquiry in Queensland and the Royal Commission in Western Australia. I can only suspect that it is something to do with `mateship', that Australian colloquialism that Neville Wran said had been tainted and tarnished by the Liberal Government and by the Liberal Party when they pursued previous matters. This is not about Anzac mateship. This is about special favours and special protection, and special treatment of special people, known in the Labor Party as mates.

If this Government wanted to be seen to be fair, to be equal, to be balanced, to be doing the right thing, it would have been introducing legislation today identical with that for Fitzgerald. This sort of information is, as Senator Coulter said, more germane, more relevant to the Western Australian inquiry than it was to the Queensland inquiry. That was about corruption of police officers. This is about the potential of senior members of a government to accept bribes. Ultimately, as the National Crime Authority now accepts and understands, the very best way of establishing whether or not a crime has been committed is to follow the paper trail, to follow the money. Crimes of this nature are committed for reward, and the reward itself manifests itself in a financial benefit.

A corrupt politician is not going to go down the street and open a bank account under the name of Johnny Smith. The money invariably will go offshore. With electronic transfers and private jets these days, it is not difficult to get money offshore, but it is difficult to trace it and so access is necessary. That means, regrettably, access to taxation files. Prima facie evidence of corruption may well be sudden and unnatural wealth held by a decision maker, which seems to be contrary to his known forms of income. For that reason access is required. We find that the Treasurer of the day—the present Prime Minister—said yes to Fitzgerald but no to the Royal Commission in Western Australia.

The truth of the matter is that we know about that only because, not for political reasons but in summing up, counsel for the Royal Commission noted that it had been inhibited and, as I recall, that it would be unable to make certain findings in respect of certain matters without access to certain information. That was a submission put by counsel assisting the commissioners.

When that information was made public, but 12 months after the request was declined, the Government felt under some pressure. Notwithstanding that pressure, the Prime Minister of the day took the unusual step of calling a press conference, to pour a bucket over the Royal Commission.

We would all remember the incremental steps that Tony Fitzgerald took when he expanded his terms of reference, where for the very first time access to Cabinet documents was made available. Not once did Mr Keating call a press conference to criticise Tony Fitzgerald. He was applauded for expanding his terms of reference. In this case, the Prime Minister of the day called a press conference to sledge and pour a bucket over a royal commission that was investigating the affairs and the conduct of his mates. He was not even politically sensitive enough to close his mouth and hope the matter would go away.

In spite of his attacks on the Royal Commission and its competence, ultimately public opinion prevailed and we have the legislation that we have today. I take some comfort from the Commission saying it will provide adequate information. I hope that it is adequate information. For my part, I would want no more access than adequate information for the Commission. I take it that, when it made its first bid in May 1991, it knew the level of access it required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to make clear in summing up the debate on this Taxation Administration Amendment Bill is that this is not a Bill solely about providing information to the current Royal Commission in Western Australia. It is also a Bill which sets the framework for the provision of such information to all royal commissions in the future; and that is important.
—Did you wake up one morning and think, `This sounds like a good idea'?

—In case Senator Crichton-Browne thinks this is some stunning revelation he has come up with, I am not pretending that the catalyst was not the request from the Western Australian Royal Commission. What I am simply saying is that what we are doing is setting a framework into the future. Nobody knows into what those subsequent royal commissions may be inquiring: it may be the activities related to governments of any political persuasion. We cannot say in the future, `This is a Bill that is only going to be allowed to look at people of this persuasion or that'. Perhaps we could, but we do not. I am not quite sure how we would do it if we set out to; but, anyway, the Bill does not.

PARA.TAB: That is the first thing to say. If we are going to do that, we have to look at the question not of what happened in the past but of what should happen in the future. The past may be a guide but it cannot be a master. What we need to do is to say, `Are we setting up an adequate framework?'.

Notwithstanding that I disagreed with nearly all the later comments that Senator Crichton-Browne made, I thought he very validly highlighted his—and, I think, widely shared—reservations about any access to tax information. Once you raise that question, I think we all have to say, `My first reaction is no; persuade me why it should be otherwise'. I cannot speak for everybody but I think it is pretty well the shared view of everybody who has ever been associated with, or aspired to be part of government: firstly, because of the fundamental question about the right to privacy; secondly, and very closely related, because of the need to preserve the credibility of the tax system.

Once again, Senator Crichton-Browne said this in different terms, but made substantially the same point: the capacity of a tax system to operate in a free democratic society fundamentally depends upon voluntary compliance by individuals with the system. If there is massive failure to comply, either there are massive adverse social and economic consequences or there are significant civil liberties consequences in the steps that are needed to be taken to enforce the tax laws.
They are very powerful arguments. They are very strong reservations. But, also, we all know that that cannot be absolute. It has never been absolute and we need, therefore, to strike a balance.

I think the Parliament accepted in the past that the balance that is struck here was appropriate with regard to a wide range of law enforcement authorities. We are providing here the access powers that are available already to a wide range of bodies. The Royal Commission in Western Australia, to which particular attention has been given, and obviously it would be, is the one to which this measure will have immediate practical application, although until the legislation is amended it will have application to all royal commissions—and so it should. Obviously people will focus their attention on this one because that is where the legislation will have effect from the day the Parliament passes it, although it is a broader framework.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us hope we will need no more.

—I would be delighted to say something about royal commissions in general, and I will before I finish. Everybody accepts the bona fides of the individual royal commissioners. I know only one of them, although I know of all of them. I regard them as people of integrity. I do not think I know any of the counsel assisting the Royal Commission or the people involved, so I cannot comment on them. When those people said, `We need this information', the Opposition said, `Well, if they say they need it, they must be right'. But when those people said, `What is being provided in this Bill is sufficient', then that assessment of theirs was not as readily accepted.

PARA.TAB: I am prepared to accept that the people involved in the Royal Commission felt the need for this information to pursue the matters before them. I cannot judge whether they are right or wrong, but I am not surprised that they had that view. They have accepted this framework, which I think strikes the right balance for the long term. What we have to ask is, `In striking the right balance for the long term can we satisfy the reasonable requirements that are before us immediately?'. I think the Royal Commission itself has said yes. We should not be in any doubt about the capacity of the people involved to be forthright in saying that they disagree with us, if they do, because they have not been so reluctant at other stages in this debate to say that they disagreed with us.

I want to say only two other things, one very briefly about royal commissions in general. I have made some long speeches here about royal commissions in general. I do not think the Western Australian Royal Commission existed at the time I made the speeches but they certainly were not in relation to it. They were actually in relation to a proposal to have a royal commission into banks, which I disagreed with then and I disagree with now. But that is not the point.

I have very severe reservations about Australia's enthusiasm for royal commissions. It is a two-edged sword politically. Over the long term, it does not advantage anybody. We all take hits from time to time. This is not an attempt either to make this argument in terms of political partisanship immediately or in the long term or to refer to a particular case. Too often we resort to the royal commission process when the proper democratic processes are the most appropriate way to resolve matters before us. That is not to say there is never a case for royal commissions. Some of them have been outstandingly valuable and some have done work that could not have been done otherwise. But I think there are far too many, at far too great a cost to the taxpayers, with far too little benefit. It is one of those soft option responses to difficult issues to say, `Let us have a royal commission into this and then the rest of us do not have to apply our minds to it; we will let some independent umpire resolve it'. I have severe reservations about that.

Secondly, I do not believe it is fair for Senator Coulter to allege that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was despicable—I have not got his words absolutely right but I have got the key work right—in his attitude and the way in which he dealt with information provided to him by the Commissioner of Taxation. In my view, the Commissioner acted properly. I do not think there is any argument about that. Senator Coulter was not implying that he did not, nor was the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite the contrary; I think he behaved impeccably.
—I was not trying to imply that Senator Coulter thought otherwise. I am just trying to establish that.
—The Prime Minister was trying to hide behind the Tax Commissioner.

—No, he was not. He properly released the information. Notwithstanding Senator Knowles's contribution and her view, which I know some other people share, I think the better reading of the law currently is that access was substantially available, equal to the terms of this legislation, to the Royal Commission. Not so unequivocally clear—
—That was not the view of the Royal Commission.

—I understand that the Royal Commission disagreed, else it would have made a request under the existing law. I think that it is wrong. This will make the situation clear. That is why it is a good idea to do it. I am not arguing that point. I am simply saying that that point was made by the Tax Commissioner to the present Prime Minister when he was Treasurer. He shared that view—and not only about this Royal Commission, as the honourable senator knows. I do not think it is fair to say, whether or not we disagree with people about the views they express or the views they accept, that there was something new or something despicable. I think it is at most a disagreement about the way in which these matters might most appropriately be dealt with and about what the law, as it then stood, meant. The Prime Minister said in his May 15 press statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has always been prepared to make relevant taxation information available to the Royal Commission.

That remains the case. This Bill will facilitate that. I will not go through explaining the Bill. The second reading did that and the explanatory memorandum did that. I will essentially deal with the amendments in committee rather than duplicate the debate because the House is under some time pressures. While we will have a debate about amendments, I thank the Senate for its support of the Bill and commend it, with emphasis on a speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 5, page 5, add the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "6. After section 17B of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Requests to be prescribed as an eligible Royal Commission

PARA.TAB: `17C.(1) This section applies to:
(a) a Royal Commission of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or
(b) a commission of inquiry of a State or a Territory; or
(c) a board of inquiry of a State or a Territory.

`(2) The person, or any of the persons, constituting the commission or board may give the Minister a written request that the Governor-General make a regulation prescribing the commission or board for the purposes of paragraph (b), (c) or (d) of the definition of `eligible Royal Commission' in section 2.
`(3) Within 28 days after receiving the request, the Minister must give the person who made the request a written notice:
(a) stating whether or not the Governor-General will make the regulation; and
(b) setting out the reasons why the regulation will be made, or will not be made, as the case requires.

`(4) The Minister must cause a copy of a notice given under subsection (3) to be laid before each House of the Parliament on the next sitting day of that House after the day on which the notice was given.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up the point Senator McMullan has just made because I do not think it can be allowed to pass without some comment. In that absolutely incredible press conference that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) held, he was indeed attempting to hide behind the Commissioner of Taxation. He said that the Taxation Commissioner had advised him that information could not be released and that, therefore, he was not releasing it. The fact of the matter was that in the application made by Fitzgerald he, with great alacrity, inserted a further section by amendment into the legislation so that Fitzgerald could get access. It was a political decision and it was inappropriate for him to use the advice he got from the Taxation Commissioner, which was absolutely correct. The Commissioner behaved impeccably. The Taxation Commissioner, of course, could not release the information because the amendment was specific to Fitzgerald.

PARA.TAB: This Democrat amendment is quite a simple one, yet it is a very important one. The whole saga which led to this legislation arose because of the refusal by a succession of Labor Treasurers to change the law to allow access to taxation records for the Western Australian Royal Commission into the Activities of Government and Other Matters.

The Parliament and the public heard about this matter only because of a remark in a submission by one of the barristers to the Royal Commission. The public furore developed when the Government's decision to cooperate fully with the Fitzgerald inquiry was compared with this hindrance to the Western Australian inquiry. Mr Keating then attempted to bluster his way through, basically by denigrating anyone who dared to question his decision. Finally, as we can see in this legislation, he saw the good sense; and we now have the legislation which is before us.

The amendment seeks to ensure that this sorry episode will not happen again. Accordingly, we are seeking to insert a new provision which will force any future government to notify the Parliament of any request by a royal commission or other board of inquiry to be prescribed as an eligible royal commission so as to allow access to taxation records. The request must be considered by the Minister and a decision made within 28 days. The Parliament must then be informed of the request, the decision made by the Minister and the reasons for the decision, either in favour of or against the granting of access. I emphasise that this amendment does not relate to any decisions on the access to particular taxation information, merely as to whether the particular inquiry is to be treated as a prescribed royal commission under the legislation.

I wish to put on the record again that the Democrats do not think that Mr Boucher, the Taxation Commissioner, has acted other than properly in regard to this matter. The Prime Minister initially sought to blame the Commissioner for his refusal to grant access. The Commissioner acted properly in defending the secrecy of his files. It was the Treasurer who made the policy decision—this is the point—to not grant access. The policy decision in regard to the Fitzgerald inquiry was that of the Treasurer and would have been made irrespective of the advice of the Commissioner.

The Democrats believe that this amendment satisfies the principle that the Government should be accountable for its decisions. We are not seeking to make the decision formally reviewable by the Parliament. That would introduce a political element, yet again, into what should not be a political matter. The possibility of such a procedure was raised by Mr Willis on 5 May 1982 in relation to the Costigan Royal Commission. We do not think that would work well in practice. However, the public are entitled to know the reasons why access is or is not granted. I would like to foreshadow the Opposition's amendment very briefly. In the second reading stage the Opposition pointed out that I had made statements in relation to access by the Western Australian inquiry. I will quote a few words in connection with this from a press release which I issued on 15 May:

SPEECH.PARA: The WA Commission is at present satisfied with the Government decision to amend section 3E of the Taxation Administration Act. Our concern is simply to assist the Commission in carrying out its terms of reference.

I accept what Senator McMullan has just said: that this is a prospective piece of legislation, so it lays down appropriate conditions for future royal commissions and commissions of inquiry. To continue with the press release:
If the Commission is happy then we are satisfied.
If the Commission is not happy with the final amendments, then we will introduce a Fitzgerald style amendment in the Senate.

The Democrats have consistently stated that the WA commission should be treated in exactly the same way as the Fitzgerald royal commission, given the serious nature of the matters under investigation.

Honourable senators will remember that at this time I was even suggesting that if it was necessary to recall the Senate to get this access through we would be prepared to do that, if it had the agreement of the Opposition. It looked as though the Western Australian Commission, at that time, would not be able to get the access in time to take that information into account.

PARA.TAB: When the amendments were first foreshadowed by the Prime Minister, the section 3E amendments which are now before us, I recall—and I point this out to the Opposition—that Mr Fischer, the Leader of the National Party, said that he was completely satisfied with the 3E amendments. I think it was the same day that Mr Reith, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said that he was not satisfied. So there was some confusion in the Opposition ranks as to whether they were or were not satisfied. All along our position has been that if the Commission was satisfied, we would be satisfied; if it was not, we would seek to move the sorts of amendments that the Opposition is seeking to move. I commend the Democrats amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition proposes to move the amendments as circulated. I do not wish to delay the Senate any longer than simply stating that the reasons why we have moved those amendments—

PARA.TAB: The CHAIRMAN—I have to dispense with Senator Coulter's amendment before we get to yours.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government agrees with the amendment proposed by the Democrats. I think it is appropriate public policy that requests for access and the Government's decision whether to grant or deny access should be open to public scrutiny. That is what the amendment says, and we support it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

2. Clause 4, page 3, line 8, omit "3E(1)", substitute "3E(1A)".
3. Clause 4, page 3, line 12, omit "3E(1), substitute "3E(1A)".

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, I do not wish to canvass the subject any further than Senator Crichton-Browne and I have already done. We believe that these amendments give the Western Australian Royal Commission the exact access that this Government granted very expeditiously to the Fitzgerald inquiry a number of years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit in which Senator Knowles so succinctly put the case, the debate on the second reading has essentially been about the merits of the alternative approaches to this matter. The Government will be opposing the amendments on that basis.
—For the reasons I have already outlined, and because of the prospective nature of this legislation, we also will not support the Opposition's amendments.

That the amendments (Senator Knowles's) be agreed to.
