DEBATE.TITLE: REPATRIATION INSTITUTIONS (STAFF) BILL 1991VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (PROVISION OF TREATMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised draft of the repatriation private patient principles, which has been prepared under the proposed provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill 1991, together with the repatriation private patient principles, represent the legislative machinery associated with the transfer of repatriation general hospitals to the States.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), in his second reading speech in the other place on the Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill, said that the Bill would `set in train the most significant changes to the administration of veterans' benefits in the history of repatriation in Australia'. In that he is absolutely correct. The importance of what is proposed by this legislation cannot be overstated. Implementation of these Bills will set in motion fundamental and irreversible change to a central and long-standing element of the repatriation system.

The present veterans' health system has its origins in the aftermath of World War I. At that time the Repatriation Department assumed responsibility for providing medical treatment for discharged soldiers suffering service related disabilities. At the end of World War II the Department took over the much larger and more modern Army hospitals built during the war to meet immediate and postwar needs, and it was these institutions which became repatriation general hospitals. They have since been progressively modernised to the point where the mainland hospitals are all high quality teaching hospitals.

The legislation before us now proposes to facilitate the transfer of these hospitals from the Commonwealth to the States. Given that these Bills effectively provide for the single biggest change in the history of the repatriation system, there is a crucial need to ensure that the interests of veterans are properly protected. Also of paramount importance is the need to evaluate and assess this change on the basis of full and complete information.

In considering the effect of this legislation on veterans, it is useful to take stock of the repatriation health system as it exists. Entitled veterans and war widows have unrestricted access to repatriation general hospitals. The number of entitled veterans and war widows in 1991 was 347,745.

Veterans in the metropolitan region of each State capital are required to attend the repatriation general hospital, unless approval is obtained from the Department to attend another public hospital or a private hospital. Non-metropolitan veterans can enter a public hospital without requiring prior approval. They may also enter a private hospital with which the Department has an arrangement without prior approval, as long as elective surgery is not the treatment required. Prior approval is not required for emergency admissions.

One of the central issues in assessing how integration will impact on veterans is priority of access. The Government no longer refers to priority of access when talking about the repatriation general hospital system as it stands. The constant refrain we receive from the Government is that access to repatriation general hospitals is and always has been on the basis of medical need and that integration will not change this.

I do not dispute that it will be the treating specialist, as it always should be, who will decide the clinical necessity and urgency of proposed treatment. What I do object to, however, is the Government's attempt to diminish and play down the priority of access currently accorded to veterans and war widows by virtue of a dedicated hospital system.

Community patients do have access to repatriation general hospitals; but their access is restricted, not on the basis of medical need, but on how it effects treatment for veterans. Thus the Repatriation Commission's own treatment principles state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission may provide treatment in a Repatriation Hospital for community patients if its capacity to provide treatment to entitled persons is not effected adversely.
The Commission may set limits on the levels of community patients admitted to its hospitals. And this is confirmed in the Department's 1990-91 annual report, which states:
The number of beds available in Repatriation General Hospitals for treating community patients is restricted to ensure the ready availability of services to entitled veterans and war widows.
So, in a very clear sense, veterans and war widows can be said to have priority of access as the system currently stands.

PARA.TAB: In the absence of that dedicated hospital system, this will no longer be the case in the future. Following integration, veterans and war widows will, if this legislation is passed, be covered by the private patient principles.

I must put on record the deep misgivings which the coalition has with the Government continually referring to these principles as a private patient scheme. The Minister has often trumpeted the so-called private patient status which will be available to veterans and war widows, without emphasising enough the strict associated conditions. For example, veterans will not have the hospital of their choice as does a real private patient. In the first instance they will be required to attend a public hospital. The veteran or war widow will not get to a private hospital if he or she can get into a public hospital within `reasonable time'. Explicit and prior departmental approval will be required for entry into a private hospital.

Veterans and war widows will not necessarily have the doctor of their choice. The veteran's doctor would need to have visiting rights to the hospital attended by the veteran, whether public or private. Of course this is true of any private patient. However, in this instance it is the Repatriation Commission which decides whether a veteran can attend a private hospital, not the so-called private patient. This is not real freedom of choice, where the choice of hospital, and therefore the choice of doctor, is restricted by the Repatriation Commission.

Another concern is with the timing of integration. The Minister would be well aware of a study commissioned by the Department of Veterans' Affairs on projected demand for in-patient care for entitled veterans and war widows. This study was completed by the Australian Institute of Health in August 1990.

The study suggests that from 1988-89 to the year 2005-06 there will be a decline with respect to in-patient separations of 30.27 per cent. It also projects that occupied bed days will decline by 13.09 per cent over the same period. But that is not the whole story. Crucially, the study found that the declines will not be constant over the projection period. Total in-patient separations will not peak until 1992-93 and even more dramatic is that occupied bed days are projected to continue to increase until 1995-96. That is, it can be said that veteran demand for hospital beds by veterans and war widows will not peak—just peak—until 1995-96.

The reason for the increased bed demand is that despite an overall decline in the entitled treatment population, average length of stay will increase from just over 8 1/2 days in 1988-89 to nearly 11 days in 2005-06. We are not talking about long term aged care here. These figures reflect the fact that, as veterans age, they will require longer periods of in-patient recuperation from any serious illness or operation.

Interestingly, the same study considered the impact of policy changes on its projections, since any changes will modify demand trends. One of these policy changes was to alter the proportion of veterans and war widows treated in the repatriation general hospitals. The study suggests that even if the Government were to transfer as many as 15 per cent of the repatriation general hospital population to non-departmental hospitals, this would result in only a marginal improvement of resource utilisation. It is in this context that the Minister and the Government have been relentlessly pursuing integration.
Given this, it would be useful for the Senate to be reminded of a promise made by the Minister, in the other place, on 10 November 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: The integration of the repatriation hospital systems will not take place until all of the concerns of the veterans' community are dealt with. That is an unequivocal guarantee that is given by this side of the House.
That was stated by the Minister, Mr Humphreys.

PARA.TAB: Until the decision of the RSL, taken only in April, that it would support integration in principle, the Minister must have regretted terribly his `unequivocal guarantee' because on all of the occasions when I have highlighted this notorious promise he has never once defended it. He has continually run away from it, and therefore he has run away from the veterans' community. This is because he and his Government were in reality seeking to impose integration with or without veteran support.

I believe that the recent change in attitude by the RSL was a case of recognising the Government's steamrollering campaign for what it is, coming to realise that come hell or high water the Government was going to transfer the hospitals. It realised that rather than making a futile fight against this, it should accept integration in principle and try to obtain the best deal it could on each of the transfers.

I remind the Senate of another infamous promise made to veterans about the repatriation general hospitals. This time the promise was made by the previous Prime Minister to an audience of veterans at Repatriation General Hospital, Concord. Perhaps he just thought they were more `silly old buggers' and that he could tell them anything and get away with it.
On 7 March 1990 he promised them:

. . . no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters such as priority of access and quality of health care for veterans and war widows, and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safe-guarded; and
. . . no final decision will be taken if the RSL has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The former Prime Minister committed himself further when he said also:

PARA.TAB: . . . there is nothing unequivocal about these guarantees and no secret agenda underlies the initiatives. I stand firmly behind these guarantees.

SPEECH.PARA: It can be imagined just how hollow those words now ring in the ears of veterans.

PARA.TAB: The crucial element of this promise was that no final decision would be taken as long as the RSL had reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements. That promise was never kept.

Negotiations between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian State governments were signed well before the decision of the National Congress of the RSL in April. Negotiations on the transfer of Concord were also virtually completed before April. The long, brawling and costly campaign that the Government is engaged in with the veteran community on the issue of integration, and the many Government promises that have been broken along the way, will not be readily forgotten by the veteran community.

When these Bills were introduced into the Parliament last November, the coalition indicated that it would be opposing the legislation. Our decision was based on two factors. First, the Government had failed to keep its promise that integration would not occur unless the ex-service community was satisfied. The second factor was the total unwillingness of the Government to provide to the Opposition, or to the ex-service community, details associated with the transfer of the hospitals. The coalition has consistently argued that integration should not occur without the support of the veteran community.

Earlier in my speech I alluded to the need also for a sound information base on which to make decisions on the issue of integration. Facing the prospect of defeat of its legislation in the Senate, the Government has, since November, been more forthcoming in providing information to the Opposition and the ex-service community on the details of the transfer in the States where it is imminent—namely, New South Wales and Tasmania. For too long the Government was not even prepared to provide the Opposition with details of what the relationship of the repatriation general hospitals would be with the ex-service community in each of these States following integration. This included information such as whether Concord, for instance, would remain a teaching hospital or, at Hobart, what palliative care arrangements had been agreed to.

It was not until April that the Government publicly released summaries of the agreements for New South Wales and Tasmania. Accompanying the release of this sort of crucial information has been a change of attitude by the National Congress of the RSL. In April it decided not to oppose integration per se. Instead, it suggested that it should be up to the ex-service community in each State to undertake negotiations on the transfers. In the light of a changed government and ex-service community attitude, the coalition announced publicly last week that it would not oppose the legislation if, and only if, the legislation were strengthened to properly protect the interest of veterans.

We believe that the legislation fails to do two important things. First, it does not provide accurate monitoring of the impact of integration on veterans' health care. Yet it is adequate monitoring that will be crucial as integration proceeds. It will also be crucial that the Government be held accountable to the Parliament for any reports or recommendations that might arise from the monitoring process. The Minister in his second reading speech in the other place said that inclusion of the private patient principles in the legislation reflects `the Government's determination to ensure the Parliament as a whole remains committed to the health care of entitled veterans and war widows'. Unless adequate monitoring provisions are in place, this will not be enough.

The Government has indicated that a peak national monitoring committee, known as the Repatriation Commission's National Treatment Monitoring Committee, will monitor veteran access to health services, and the range of these services, after integration. On this committee will be a member of the Repatriation Commission, the Department's national health program director and six veteran community representatives. State monitoring committees are also to be established along broadly similar lines.

It seems that the national committee will be able to consider reports from State treatment monitoring committees, as well as reports from DVA and State health departments on aspects of the private patient scheme. This all sounds very promising, but the crucial question is: what standing will the national committee have? What authority will be accorded to it? Will it be anything more than a token gesture on the part of the Government in a cynical attempt to placate the veteran community?

As the proposal stood, the monitoring committee would report only to the Repatriation Commission. The Opposition regards it as being very important for these reports to be presented to the Parliament. In this way the reports of the Committee and the effects of integration on the veteran community would be subject to ongoing parliamentary scrutiny and could never be buried in the Repatriation Commission. It would go some way towards making the Minister, his Department and the Commission more accountable to the Parliament on this issue.

In my press release of 27 May this year I called on the Government to address this concern by amending its legislation to ensure that the reports of the National Monitoring Committee were tabled in the Parliament. I wrote a letter to the Minister the same day, setting out the Opposition position. I seek leave to incorporate my letter in Hansard. I am sorry; I did not show it to the Minister at the table. I have shown it to the Democrats.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 27th May 1992
Hon Ben Humphreys MP
Minister for Veterans' Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I write in relation to legislation currently before the Parliament concerning the transfer of Repatriation General Hospitals to the States.

As you know the Coalition in November of last year announced that it would be opposing the Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991 and the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill 1991.

We were concerned that the Government was proceeding with integration in breach of promises made by you, and the former Prime Minister, The Honourable R J L Hawke, not to do so until the reasonable concerns of the RSL had been met. We were also concerned at your unwillingness to provide information to the Opposition and the ex-service community on the details of the agreements being struck between the Commonwealth and the States. A final concern was the adequacy of the legislation in ensuring accountability of Government to the ex-service community and the Parliament once the legislation had passed the Parliament.
Since last November there have of course been important developments.

More detailed information has been provided on the nature of the agreements with New South Wales and Tasmania, and the National Congress of the Returned & Services League of Australia has resolved to accept integration in principle.
In light of these developments the Coalition has decided that it will not oppose the legislation provided two outstanding concerns can be addressed by amendments to the legislation.

The first concern is the blanket nature of the legislation. In recognition of the different issues to be resolved in different States, and in order to ensure greater Government accountability in negotiations with the ex-service community in each State, the Coalition believes the intention to transfer a hospital should be the subject of a disallowable instrument. This would ensure that the transfer of a particular hospital could only occur with Parliament's approval.

The second concern is the proposed monitoring arrangements of veterans' health care following integration. Informed debate on the impact of integration on veterans' health care will be critical. The Coalition believes that the legislation should be amended so that reports of the National Treatment Monitoring Committee are required to be tabled in Parliament.

While an officer of your Department has claimed that reports of the Committee will be freely available, the Coalition believes that the Parliament must be given the opportunity to regularly monitor the new health care arrangements as they are implemented in each State. In this regard the tabling requirements are crucial.

I look forward to your response to the above concerns, and in particular to an indication as to whether or not your Government would be prepared to take action to address these concerns in the terms outlined.
I also take this opportunity to congratulate you on your promotion to the Federal Cabinet.
Yours sincerely,
Jocelyn Newman

TALK.START.PARA: —I had Opposition amendments drafted which could meet this end if the Government refused to accept this responsibility and I sent those to the Government for its consideration. I am glad to say that the Government has now amended its repatriation private patient principles to ensure that the Committee must report to the Repatriation Commission at least annually and that, its having passed this report to the Minister, the Minister must table the report in Parliament within 15 sitting days. I welcome this change of heart and the recognition of the rightness of the coalition's position on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The other failure of the legislation relates to the lack of recognition that different issues and problems will need to be resolved in different States before the transfer of any particular hospital. In my press release and letter of 27 May I also called on the Government to amend its legislation so that the intention to transfer a particular hospital would be the subject of disallowance in the Federal Parliament. This would mean that the Parliament could prevent the transfer of a particular hospital if it considered that the concerns of veterans in a given State had not been properly addressed by the Government.

The Government has, strangely, not been prepared to meet these quite reasonable expectations of the veterans' community, and so I have circulated amendments which the Opposition will be moving to ensure that no hospital can be transferred without the Minister first notifying the Parliament of his intention to do so, with the Parliament having the power to prevent the transfer, if it becomes necessary.

These amendments recognise the different circumstances and concerns in different States. Importantly, they would make the Government accountable for negotiations which must take place on a State by State basis with the veteran community before the transfer of any hospital. I have discussed these amendments with members of the ex-service community and they have expressed their support for them.

A draft copy of the amendments was also sent to the Australian Democrats for their consideration. They have now circulated their own set of amendments. They are different from those of the Opposition in two important respects. Firstly, they effectively exclude the transfer of Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, and Repatriation General Hospital, Hobart, from parliamentary scrutiny. They cover only the other four general hospitals and the auxiliary hospitals. The transfers of Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, and of Hobart will not be subject to disallowance. They still have details outstanding in their negotiations.

Secondly, the amendments effectively contain a sunset clause in that they have effect only until 1 January 1995. This means that if any repatriation general hospital were still not transferred at 1 January 1995, the Minister would not have to inform the Parliament of his intention to do so after that date. He could transfer Daw Park, for example, or Hollywood, despite the objections of the South Australian and Western Australian veterans, or the Parliament. This effectively removes parliamentary scrutiny of the decision to integrate any repatriation hospitals which are not transferred by January 1995.

The Government will tell us that all hospitals will be transferred by then, so the clause does not really matter. However, how can we say in 1992 that there will not be hospitals yet to be transferred by 1995? The Government's timetable on this has been sadly out all along. I can well imagine situations where negotiations could break down and the Government could simply wait until January 1995 and do what it liked. I find it strange that the Democrats are proposing such a clause, especially when their spokesman, throughout the months this legislation has been before the Parliament, claimed that their one and only concern was the protection of veterans and their health care. I know that the veteran community would certainly be disturbed by the effects of that clause. Perhaps we could be kind and suggest that the Democrats got their amendments from the Government's draftsman and did not fully realise the implications of that 1 January 1995 date.

The inclusion of a sunset clause can suit only the Government's purpose, not the veterans'. I urge the Democrats to look very carefully at the lack of protection for veterans that they could directly cause if they proceed with that amendment. I urge them to remove the date from their amendment. If they are not prepared to do so, I shall be obliged to move an amendment to their amendment.

In conclusion, I repeat that throughout this whole sorry saga of the Government's imposing its will on the veteran community, the coalition has consistently sought to ensure that the legitimate concerns of veterans were addressed. The veterans have now grudgingly accepted integration in principle and have indicated that they are prepared to accept the passage of this legislation. We have forced the Government to agree to modify its own legislation so that, as integration occurs, there is a close assessment of its effect on veterans' health care and that the Parliament is informed of this assessment. But due to intransigence on the Government's part, the Opposition will be seeking to move amendments ensuring that no repatriation hospital, not only the RGHs, can be transferred without parliamentary approval in the form of a disallowable instrument.

This whole exercise has once again highlighted why the veteran community has become so disillusioned with the Labor Government over the last nine years. Its promises have only been made to be broken. There is no getting away from the fact that the veterans do not trust this Government. The long, high-pressure, costly and dishonest campaign by the Government to hand over the repatriation hospitals to the States is but the latest in a long and sorry saga of Labor's treatment of our veterans.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic problem behind the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991 has been one of timing. No party in this place is opposed to the eventual transfer of these hospitals. Indeed, very few veterans out there in the community have been arguing that the transfer should never happen. The introduction of this legislation into the House of Representatives virtually coincided with my taking over the responsibility for this portfolio following the resignation of Senator Paul McLean. I wish to praise him here for the excellent work he did in this area.

PARA.TAB: My first reaction, and indeed the first reaction of the Democrats, was simply to oppose it, as the Opposition was doing. However, in line with our usual practice, we continued negotiation and discussion with those people who were most affected, that is, the veterans across the country.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A year ago I attended a dinner of the Australian Society for Medical Research, which was addressed by Professor John Coghlan, the Director of the Florey Institute in Melbourne, one of Australia's leading groups in medical research. It was interesting that the highlight of the speech that he gave was that there would be more scientific developments in the next 20 years than had occurred in history. I was a bit taken aback by this and I went over to him afterwards and said, `That was an extraordinary statement. How do you come to that conclusion?'. He took one look at me and at my grey hair, and said, `There have been more scientific advances in your lifetime than have occurred in history. All I am saying is that developments are occurring so quickly that it is halving in time'. He was talking about genetic engineering.

PARA.TAB: Last night I attended the dinner of the Australian Society for Medical Research and the same theme came through: genetic engineering is going to be of greater importance to this country than practically anything else that has occurred in history. It is a subject that I think we are not completely aware of, yet I was pleased to see that Parliament itself had a committee inquiring into it. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology produced a report in February this year entitled Genetic Manipulation: The Threat or the Glory?.

Genetic engineering does not just affect medical research; it affects a whole spectrum of development both in industry and in fibres and food and animal production of food. Gene manipulation is the subject of an ongoing and often acrimonious debate. There is certainly a need for wider discussion of the implications of this science. However, it is hard for me to understand the justification for the grant to the Australian Conservation Foundation to establish the `Australian genethics network'. It is difficult to see this generous donation of public funds meeting its stated objective, to efficiently promote and encourage and inform public discussion on genetic engineering. My judgment is that this grant-in-aid does not serve the very worthy aim of furthering informed public debate but is merely a further extension of this Government's practice of using public funds to promote the activities of politically sympathetic special interest groups.

Clearly, the ACF and its members have made some valuable contributions to environmental management. If they approached the issues of gene manipulation responsibly, they could play a valuable role in allowing some of the concerns and disquiet that are felt about some of the issues to be addressed by those who are proposing the work. But those in the ACF are hardly likely to provide the Australian public with impartial and accurate advice on gene manipulation ethics, because they are aggressive campaigners against all aspects of modern gene technology and they have no special knowledge or training about genetics, or about the ethics for that matter. Their genetic engineering campaign officer, Mr Phelps, in his zeal to pursue his role as a professional anti-genetics activist, has a record of making inaccurate and misleading statements on the topic. For example, he has repeatedly made the incorrect claim that genetic engineering has not contributed any benefits to society. Unbelievable!

As the Minister has so cleverly observed, the ACF will twist arms, bend knees, even kick ankles to get results. It has not, however, seemed to have considered whether or not it is ethical for the Government to pay a special interest group to inflict this damage on other sectors of society or whether twisting arms or kicking ankles is conducive to helping the general public come to informed and wise decisions on such complex issues.

I contend that the Minister has made the very basic mistake of supporting a group that has a flawed policy on genetic engineering. The flaw is a simple one, obvious to any student of history: while they enthusiastically correct the injustices they readily perceive being perpetrated by the rest of society, they seem blind to the injustices of their own policies. In short, they are keen to see their own approach to social engineering being forced on all members of the community but seemingly place little value on the personal rights of the targets of their criticism.

Their policy is to delay or stop genetic engineering and it disregards the needs of those who require genetically engineered medicines. They are disregarding the welfare of all those who may benefit from disease resistant crops and other improvements in agriculture. They are disregarding the intellectual and creative rights of scientists who want to contribute to society by their inventions and who, in the case of genetic engineering, have to spend many years of effort and millions, if not hundreds of millions, of dollars in going about these goals. They are denying the right of a reward for honest effort due to all those commercial concerns and public agencies, such as the research and development corporations, which are willing to put up huge amounts of risk capital for expensive biotechnology research.

The ACF anti-genetic activists group, by actively campaigning to abolish all biotechnology patents, are disregarding the rights of the general public to purchase the results of this effort, since their misguided patent policy undermines the basis for obtaining risk capital for new products. This policy would cripple most biotechnology research, and indeed the pharmaceutical industry, if enacted. It displays a complete absence of realistic understanding of the industry.

I will just mention one specific example of the valued new products which consumers get because of patent protection and which were not produced in countries such as the former Soviet Union, where patent protection was weak. The example that I give is the genetically engineered anti-cancer treatment Neupogen, which the National Health and Medical Research Council has just approved for use in this country. According to ACF doublethink, this drug does not exist; even if it does exist, it represents a socially unjust abuse of human rights by a greedy transnational corporation.

Senator Bolkus, who is the responsible Minister, might care to reflect where, for example, CSIRO's gene shears invention would be without patent protection or corporate participation. My guess is that it would be probably largely unused and be bringing no return for all the Australian taxpayers' dollars that have been invested. Senator Bolkus saw no need to discuss his funding decision publicly, or to call for applications from alternative educational groups.

He has got a rich range of options. CSIRO is already mounting a colourful travelling road show on the topic and he could have avoided conflict with funding guidelines and simply let it get on with the job; or he could have chosen from well-informed, impartial or highly ethical and scholastically scrupulous groups—Ms Loane Skene of the Victorian Law Reform Commission, Professor Peter Singer of Monash University, or other ethics specialists, a religious group, perhaps. It seems to me that the Minister must have had other things on his mind than the interests of the general Australian taxpayer when coming to his extraordinary decision.

As I looked through the April Gene Report newsletter produced by the ACF with Senator Bolkus's gift of public funds, I realised that my concerns about his decision were fully justified. I could find no mention at all of any positive aspects of the science: no mention of new vaccines for diseases in the Third World—anti-hepatitis vaccines, anti-cholera, anti-diarrhoeal, anti-malarial vaccines; no mention of benefits for agriculture, such as the bollworm resistant cotton and the virus resistant wheat that our own CSIRO has recently developed, or disease resistant potatoes and tomatoes, or of any new efforts to develop disease resistant yams, cassava and sweet potatoes, for farmers in non-industrialised countries; no mention of the crucial importance and wide-ranging application of genetic engineering in almost all branches of biological science; in fact, absolutely no evidence of a balanced viewpoint from which the average man and woman in the street might gain helpful insights. Instead, what did I find?

The title of the column establishes the tone and intent of the newsletter: The Troubled Helix. It is a tabloid style newsletter that talks only about problems and fears. It paints bio-industry as a supposedly unethical group which acts against the public interest. It talks about a hypothetical group of scientists, not identified by name or affiliation, who supposedly want to work outside the regulatory guidelines. We get simplistic anti-business untruths, such as a view that genetic engineering is simply `a conflict between the public interest on the one hand and bio-industry on the other'.

Perhaps the Minister would like to try repeating that statement to the great bulk of CSIRO, university or medical researchers who do not work for industry, especially those who are being pushed to get money from industry even for their own salaries.

In the newsletter we also get unhelpful and ill-informed scare stories about trivial issues such as the recent inadvertent release of harmless soil bacteria at Murdoch University in Western Australia, voluntarily reported to GMAC regulators. We get misinformation about the laudable use of yeasts to obtain rennin for cheese making. The fact that this new product replaces the killing of calves to obtain enzyme is not deemed worthy of being mentioned. These red herrings divert effort from resolution of some of the more serious and thorny ethical issues that could have been canvassed.

I would like to end by drawing the chamber's attention to recent events in Europe, particularly in Germany, Denmark and Switzerland. Minority Green activists in Germany have succeeded in introducing draconian laws that are crushing scientific productivity under a mass of paperwork and petty officialdom. Green activists are, by their own admission, being deliberately obstructionist in using the legal system to hold up patents and prevent building of factories.

For just one example of obstruction I refer honourable senators to the 1 May issue of the Science journal, where a Swiss Green activist is quoted as admitting that legal challenge to a building permit was used as a legal tool to oppose several companies working in genetic engineering. That is not an isolated example of legal obstructionism by activists. We should all think long and hard about legal tools we provide for our own activists, and make sure that laws have provisions that minimise irresponsible obstructionism.

In one instance in Germany, the anti-genetics hysteria has resulted in the fire bombing of a laboratory. Strangely, this hysteria has even spilled over to Australia in the form of activist inspired demonstrations outside the Howard Florey Institute in Melbourne, the institute that I mentioned previously, where a major genetically engineered childbirth drug, relaxin, was developed—a drug which allows painless childbirth.

The net result of these excesses in Europe is that many biology based industries are moving out of these countries and setting up elsewhere, in France, in the US and Japan, where there is a more enlightened and wiser approach to managing any concerns about this new technology. Let us try to avoid making the European mistakes here. We do not have the luxury of being able to lose a billion dollar technology industry and we have nothing to gain from whipping up emotional hysteria on the issue.

It is noteworthy that, on 26 May of this year, it was announced in the US that biotechnology firms there will not need special approval to market food products that they develop, as long as they do not drastically alter the genetic make-up of the food. It was stated that this long awaited policy proclamation decreed that genetically engineered foods, an emerging line that may range from tomatoes to cucumber and rockmelons, are not inherently more dangerous than other products and do not need extensive pre-marketing tests. The Food and Drug Administration, which regulates most US foods, would also not require identifying labels on genetically altered products under this new policy.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a paper prepared by Dr David Tribe, coordinator of biotechnology in the Department of Microbiology, University of Melbourne.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Position Paper: ACF and the Genetic Engineering Debate. 4/3/92

PARA.EMPHASIS: Only Seeing Issues in Black or Green Terms

SPEECH.PARA: "What if pigs can fly?" is a very clever choice of a theme by the CSIRO's travelling exhibit on genetic engineering. Some groups in our clever country are expending a lot of energy and money getting concerned about the damage that will be caused by flying pigs. My viewpoint is that far more common-sense, and certainly some old-fashioned wisdom is needed. We should concentrate on bringing home the bacon.

The main group involved in keeping a focus on hypothetical hazards of genetic engineering alive as a public debate is the Australian Conservation Foundation led by ACF Genetic Engineering Campaign officer Bob Phelps (now associated with the ACF offshoot Australian Genethics Network). He has been involved in a highly emotive campaign including demands for a genetic engineering moratorium which would affect most biological research in Australia. His largely environmentally oriented campaign stands in contrast to the carefully researched and responsible report of the Victorian Law Reform Society on this topic, and the quietly reasoned comments by human ethics experts such as Nicholas Tonti-Filippini, research officer for the Catholic Bishop's Conference.

These stone-walling tactics of the ACF and other Green groups, and especially their legal challenges to key medical patents, will have tragic consequences world-wide. The credibility gap between their claim to be acting in the public interest and the actual consequences of their anti-genetic engineering propaganda is wide. As a consequence, the Federal Government's recent financial sponsorship of the ACF on this specific issue raises serious ethical concerns.

In coming to a realisation that one can disagree with Greenies and still be a decent citizen, I keep on remembering a conversation with a Green friend. The topic of discussion was pens. I have taken to using, whenever possible, a good old fashioned fountain pen rather than a disposable plastic biro. It makes me feel good when I write because of the smooth flow of ink and its subtle smell. Also, I can avoid the guilt associated with adding to the mountain of plastic on our rubbish dumps. The remark, however, that has echoed in my brain since this conversation, in which I revealed my inner feelings about fountain pens, is that she was glad I was ideologically correct.

Ideological correctness (American version: political correctness) is a term which applies to all sorts of actions and attitudes which fit in with a particular philosophy of life. From the Green perspective, for example, it implies rejection of plastic in such forms as kitchen wrap and hamburger cartons, a strong dislike of disposable consumer goods, belief in biodiversity as a guiding principle of life, and acceptance of conspiracy theories involving the CIA and Wall Street. From other perspectives ideological correctness could require agreement with feminist view points and acceptance of the level playing field concept and the power of free-market forces. In even more extreme forms it can involve rejection of anything proposed by Uncle Sam or multi-national corporations, or, on the other side of the political fence, a deep suspicion of Russian political motives. Unfortunately, ideologically correct viewpoints avoid the need for critical thinking about the merits of particular issues, and can be dangerously mis-applied if they rest on flawed assumptions.

ACF's treatment of genetic technology issues in the past has been dominated by the use of ideologically correct catch-phrases. It displays a totally superficial understanding of the scientific, social welfare and ethical issues involved, and generally lacks careful discussion of specifics, or careful weighing of the pros and cons of particular courses of action. Most disturbingly, it contains a plethora of misleading written statements combined with exotic cartoons designed to create an awful image of danger, but at the same time calls for something more than simple rhetoric to inform the general public, so that an atmosphere of trust can be developed(1).
The ACF's stance on genetic engineering emphasises risks and costs. They argue:

`The assessment of risks and costs should include ecological, social justice, ethical, consumer, animal welfare and other legitimate concerns. They should be fully investigated, assessed, understood and widely discussed by the whole community before we decide on a case by case basis whether to accept Genetic Engineering and its products.' Bob Phelps, for ACF in Farrago, (Melbourne University student paper), 1990.

At first glance this may seem a reasonable approach to contentious technology, given that all participating groups are acting in good faith, and may be willing to accept trade-offs in the interests of community welfare. However ACF's actions make it clear that many hypothetical hazards of low probability, akin to the dangers of being hit by flying pigs, are included in their concept of a legitimate concern. Their concept of social justice ignores many of the legitimate interests of society, and their proposal is a recipe for indefinite delay for any development that the ACF deems ideologically unsound.

The first deliberate release of genetically engineered organisms in Australia was for control of bacterial disease in fruit trees. It involved a product developed by Australian researchers at the Waite Institute in South Australia, and now marketed as No Gall'~. This first experimental release of No Gall was used by the ACF as a political issue to dramatise a supposed need for special legislation in this area. ACF seems proud to have delayed the introduction of this product in Victoria as compared to more rapid licensing in New South Wales, but the facts remain that genetic engineering made this particular product environmentally safer than the one it replaced. The development of this product involved the use of simple genetic surgery which was well understood by the scientists who carried out the experiments. There are no legitimate concerns about its effect on the environment, and the ACF opposed its introduction for nonscientific reasons. Any student of the No Gall debate should ask themselves the question "Which, if any, specific environmental concerns about this product were articulated by the ACF?"

The level of private financial investment in new technology is very sensitive to perceptions of delays and regulatory problems. The high financial costs of excessive regulatory zeal also result in postponed or delayed projects and lack of new investment. A good illustration of this relationship has been the recent relaxation and simplification of US FDA procedures to allow new AIDS therapies to receive a fast track approval. Nothing will completely destroy Australian private investment in biotechnology more effectively than acceptance of the ideological stance of the ACF. It is because the economic damage caused by ACF's ill-considered rhetoric may be so far reaching that their genetic engineering statements and their ideological basis must be exposed to rigorous criticism.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Scope and impact of the Genetic Engineering Issue

SPEECH.PARA: Genetic engineering is used in a huge range of biological research and biotechnology applications ranging from AIDS and cancer treatment to agriculture. It is a technique even more important in fundamental research than in applied research. Although medicine is only one area of biology in which it is used, ample illustration its importance in this discipline alone can be got by quoting Sir Gustav Nossal:
1 Today's Life Science, February 1992, plO.
Position Paper: ACF and the Genetic Engineering Debate. 5/3/92 Page 3

"The most important role for genetic engineering technology in medicine is in basic research, teaching us more about bodily processes in health and disease. One important practical fallout is the production of precious proteins that are useful in therapeutics.

Inevitably, people who don't know anything about the subject assume that it involves scientists tampering with their genes. At least 99.9% of medical research on genetic engineering has nothing whatsoever to do with fiddling around with human genes. The media don't seem to understand that. It is the kind of ignorance that creates newspaper headlines and is the stuff of tabloid high drama. But nothing could be further from the truth.

What we are concentrating on is the production of the interferons, the biological response modifiers, the clotting agents, the anti-clotting agents, the new vaccines, the colony stimulating factors, this veritable bevy of new therapeutic agents that are revolutionising medicine."
(The Bulletin, December 3,1991)

Research in genetic engineering has moved at breathtaking pace, but it is only recently that genetically engineered products have started to be used on a large scale in medicine, due to the need for lengthy process development, extensive testing, and highly demanding regulatory requirements. In the US, for every one major genetically engineered medicine on the market there are about ten that have recently completed clinical trials, and so there will certainly continue to be a massive increase in sales in this sector of the US economy. This process of therapeutic product development is enormously expensive (at approximately $200,000,000 per product) and the last year or so has witnessed as massive a raising of US venture capital in biotechnology as in any period of the biotechnology industry. To me it is an impressive demonstration of the power of the free-market system to enrich our lives.

Any general review of genetic engineering would be incomplete without mention of how the technique has allowed the invention of several safer ways of making natural drugs and vaccines. Regrettably, naturally occurring starting materials for drugs or vaccines are sometimes at risk of contamination with dangerous infectious organisms, obviously introducing complications to the process of making safe medicines from these natural products. Nowadays genetic engineering technology allows the starting materials to be changed to a fresh source that is free of this risk, which is a tremendous boon to human welfare. Quite typical examples of this idea are the newly available genetically engineered vaccine for hepatitis, and another vaccine, for cholera, following it in the research pipeline. These two examples alone (and others readily come to mind) represent very tangible benefits of biotechnology for all of us, but particularly for third-world peoples.

The idea allowing an increased assurance of safety is simple—it hinges on the concept of simply deleting dangerous genes by genetic surgery, or transplanting selected genes to a safer host cell—but it is of extreme value in medicine since it allows chances of infection with dangerous organisms to be minimised, and is now being widely applied. Hopefully in the future, because of genetic engineering, we will hear fewer and fewer stories of tragic cases of accidental infection by viruses during medical treatment. Recent news stories on CreuztfeldJakob Disease are just one example.
The ACF View of Biotechnology.
The ACF assessment of the status of this whole field of genetic engineering is worth quoting for contrast:

"There is still scant evidence that this untried technology can deliver the miracles claimed for it. . . Whether many of its proposed applications will ultimately be practical and commercial successes, and acceptable to the community remains to be seen. . . Corporate control and community welfare are rarely synonymous and the hidden costs of every technology must also be countered .
Bob Phelps, for ACF in Farrago, (Melbourne University student paper), 1990 .

Genetic technology is the latest technology on the scene and is a watershed, because its raw material is the substance of life—the DNA within all living cells. Damage will be done to our environment, reducing biodiversity and our chances for ecologically sustainable systems, but its extent remains unclear. . . If it is to be used the technology must serve socially and environmentally beneficial ends, not corporate greed and environmental destruction. As yet, no-one has properly addressed the social justice issues associated with patented genes and the possibilities they hold for monopoly control of the food supply. Until all the problems of genetic engineering are clearly defined and resolved, and an open national system of laws is in place, we must learn from past experience and delay its deployment.
Bob Phelps in Conservation News, 1991.

The ACF treatment of genetic technology continues to lack an objective review of the progress that has been made in biotechnology and continues to put forward hypothetical hazards as more worthy of debate. Suffice it to say that the Australian Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee s approach to ensuring adequate safety provisions for this work is carefully considered, well respected, represents input from different sectors of society, and is efficiently administered .

The extent to which genetic engineering may affect the environment remains to be seen, but I challenge the view that it will necessarily damage the environment to any significant extent. Unthinking acceptance of ACF-type rhetoric may add needless delays and extra costs to the introduction of new treatments for diseases such as haemophilia and cancer, and may cause losses to Australian farmers in the future if we fail to follow through with our excellent research efforts in plant and animal biotechnology. It is not an exaggeration to say that all biological research in this country could be affected adversely by their proposals. It is thus crucial to challenge ACF for specific explanations of their concerns, and particularly their concerns about corporate involvement in biotechnology, which display a naive view of the profit motive as a force in society. Certainly in Australia, we do not suffer in any sector of the economy from a problem with overly massive investment in new technology development driven by greedy corporations lusting after monopoly positions. Quite the reverse, the Government has to offer a 150% tax break to encourage any activity of this sort!

Patenting of biological material is a complex issue meriting an article on its own. It does however provide a mechanism for allowing those who wish to risk money in developing new technology some assurance that they will reap a reward for their labours. The Greens who protest against the patent system for human genes because it supposedly is an exploitation of human rights need to have well explained and compelling reasons for interfering with a very effective, equitable and efficient financing mechanism for life-saving new drugs.

A short comment titled Greens versus genes by Laurence Chipman in a recent Melbourne Herald-Sun (February 24, 1992) however goes quickly to the heart of the matter. It describes recent legal action by European Greens attempting to block a patent for a genetically engineered drug relaxin, used to assist childbirth.
The Greens are ideologically opposed to the idea that anybody might enjoy a commercially profitable monopoly based on reproduction of a constituent part of the human body.

One suspects that their real reason is their deep-seated opposition to commercial development and profit in general. In any case to claim that an abuse of human rights is involved [in patenting a method of reproducing the human hormone relaxin] is laughable. It is actually the very reverse of the truth.
Unless patents such as those relating to relaxin were available, its life enhancing and indeed life-saving benefits would simply not be available."

One can further add that the international biological patent system is of special value to Australia. Large amounts of public money have been invested over the years in biological research, yielding discoveries such as relaxin (in Melbourne) and the well known Gene-Shears idea by CSIRO in Canberra. Unfortunately the proper further development of these discoveries requires huge amounts of further investment (hundreds of millions of dollars) which is beyond the resources of a small industrially under-developed country like Australia. Fortunately, because of the protection to intellectual property afforded by patents, it is possible for Australian organisations to enter into business arrangements where we get a real dollar return for our investment. The international Gene-Shears consortium negotiated by CSIRO is a fine example of what can be achieved.

By raising the idea that patenting of plants may result in a monopoly of the food supply, Bob Phelps is creating a wonderful hyperbole, but not a very likely scenario. For one thing, patents have a limited life-time. With biological inventions long delays in testing and meeting regulatory hurdles reduce the effective patent-life further. At least the statement implies acceptance, in principle, that this kind of research has the potential to give plants that are so greatly superior that everyone will want to grow them, which is one of the reasons for investing in genetic engineering research! The ability to patent plants, however, in no way guarantees a monopoly of the total food supply, but it certainly promotes research investment and we can all gain from this in a competitive market.

Genetic engineering technology is one technological revolution that Australia has a real chance of participating in, after missing out on the computer micro-chip revolution. We cannot remain unaffected by it. If we disadvantage any further our industries (including agriculture) involved in this technology—they already have enough problems—they will simply wither away or move overseas. As other countries, certainly the US and Japan, continue their efforts in this area, we will end up being economically clobbered on the trade balance front by both imports and exports. That is the economic reality that the ACF do not seem to be concerned about, but which all Australians should be aware.

A common claim of the ACF is that we have incomplete knowledge of the consequences of genetic technology and therefore it should not be used until community understanding of all the complex issues is essentially complete. This is abject nonsense. Intellectual understanding of almost every field of human endeavour, including ecology and management of the environment, is incomplete and yet ecologists and environmentalists make recommendations regarding the management of ecosystems. In Physics we have even a celebrated uncertainty principle which puts a limit on what we can know about the behaviour fundamental particles, and still experimentation continues. With a little common-sense we can even get involved in all sorts of theoretically hazardous occupations, such as driving cars, eating and having children. The point is, that we should use good judgement in how we carry out these activities.
Political Activities of the ACF:

Political support given by the ACF to the Labor party in the last election is being repaid by financial support by the current government through the ACF-offshoot, the Australian Genethics Network. This has severely compromised the independence of the ACF organisation. Most analysis of the effects of this relationship has centred on the effects of the Hawke Government's decisions on the mining industry—notably the Coronation Hill debate. Recently the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has responded to ACF political activities by refusing to meet with Phillip Toyne, and has shown a welcome perceptiveness in referring to "A different agenda" of that organisation to that of the Liberals. Although Dr Hewson's decision is probably based on issues other than those discussed here, consideration of the ACF's compromised stance on genetic engineering adds further weight to his argument.

I believe Frank Devine (The Australian, February 10, 1992) made an important distinction in discussing this rebuff of the ACF. Certainly a Prime Minister has an obligation to discuss environmental issues. It does not however inevitably follow that a Prime Minister has an obligation to discuss Green issues. Or for that matter, I should add Red-Green alliance issues.

The development of Australian industries, and particularly emerging "Sunrise" industries is being damaged, probably intentionally, by the ACF's ill considered and extreme policy viewpoints on genetic engineering. Most surprisingly these ACF activities are now sponsored by the Commonwealth Department of Administrative Services, which certainly gives a confusing signal about Federal Government's support for the Biotechnology Industry.

Ethical considerations demand that DAS give full public justification of its selection of ACF officers to establish the Australian Genethics Network and particularly, full disclosure of the extent of such financial support, in light of the political activities of the ACF in the last election. For example, I would like to ask what was the peer review process used in funding the ACF on this issue? Was there a requirement for the recipients of this grant to have advanced training in ethics and genetics? What other recipients were considered and why wasn't a less doctrinaire group selected for government funding as an agency to supply ethics advice to schools and the general community? Was any consideration given to the grave ethical implications of the antigenetic engineering campaign pursued by the ACF? Maybe I'm being old fashioned but I expect those who nominate ethics and social justice as the issues for debate to set high standards of conduct, and to demonstrate a balanced understanding of their actions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The road to hell is paved with good intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: Two incidents will prove to be a watershed in the fight for the protection of the Australian environment and its protection—the Nufarm issue and the Monkeywrench affair. The attacks by Greenpeace on the Nufarm factory in Altona led to much needless expense for the Victorian public—each assay for dioxins cost many thousands of dollars—and the end result of an expensive public inquiry was the finding that levels of dioxin release were of no significance for health.

The Monkeywrench affair involved implied support for Earth First! ecoterrorist extremists by selling of the book Ecodefense: a Field Guide to Monkeywrenching authored by Dave Foreman, in various Green bookshops, accompanied by uncritical reviews of this publication in a Green newsletter. Monkeywrenching refers to sabotage of supposedly environmentally unsound industry operations—by spiking of trees for example, to damage logging operations. We have yet to see an Australian report of sawmill accident caused by spiking, but a report alleging spiking appeared in Tasmania—after the state elections.

The point of these incidents is that they are changing public perceptions of the ethics and intelligence of the environmental lobby groups involved. The way in which the ACF has conducted its genetic engineering campaign so far bodes for a similar course of events occurring with genetic engineering issues. Possibly the relaxin patent issue will be the breaking point. Unfortunately, because of the technical nature of genetic engineering, it may take some time before the general public catches up with the situation, and in the meantime a lot of damage may be done.

My suggestion is that the ACF should change direction on genetic engineering. They currently adopt extreme viewpoints on issues on which they display a simplistic understanding. This is possibly a negotiating tactic, but more likely the true agenda is to bring as much of this work to a halt as long as possible by whatever tactic seems available. This is not consistent with its demands for a balanced discussion of the merits of genetic engineering.

The organisation should be more constructive in its approach to the issues, inform its members more accurately about the status of biotechnology, and focus criticism on the areas where there are real ethical or biohazard concerns. Another way in which the ACF could take a positive lead is to support the use of genetic engineering methods to improve management of the environment. This is currently an active research field, and several Australian groups, including the CSIRO and the Waite Institute are at its forefront.

The ACF could well take a leaf out of the book of Monash University's Prof. Peter Singer, whose concerns about animal experimentation carry a lot of force, or from Nicholas Tontini-Filippini. It should seek input from a wider range of professional scientists, economists, and different sectors of the general public. It should re-develop a balanced vision for the future which is economically rational, for without more realism than offered by ACF's current prescriptions our environment will be pretty bleak.
