TALK.START.PARA: —For some time now the Australian Labor Party has been running a fairly ineffective campaign to denigrate the Fightback package proposed by Dr Hewson on behalf of the Liberal and National parties. The campaign has mainly been one of lies and misinformation, but I am pleased to say that it has not been working. I point out, for those people that do not know, that in a couple of South Australian State by-elections a couple of weeks ago the Labor Party actually ran on a campaign of, `Use this by-election to express your opinion on the GST'. It even issued its how-to-vote cards with that on them. The results of those by-elections are well known. In both instances the Labor Party lost votes and came in after the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: With all respect to Senator Lees, she knows what my opinion of the Democrats is, and to come in after them just shows how pitiful the Labor Party has become. Labor members campaigned wholly and solely upon this point of using the by-election to lodge a protest vote against the GST. So when I say that the campaign by the Labor Party has been ineffective, that demonstrates that point very clearly.

The campaign by the Labor Party has gone through several stages. Two or three weeks ago, it seemed to be local government's turn to bear the brunt of the misinformation by the Labor Party on the GST. I will take a few minutes today just to point out how much better councils around Australia will be under the coalition's Fightback package.

The Minister for Local Government, Mr Simmons, has been given the unenviable task of roaming around Australia trying to say to local authorities, `Look, you are going to be worse off'. It is unenviable, because I think even Mr Simmons now understands that it is simply wrong to suggest that councils around Australia will be worse off. In fact, I challenge Mr Simmons to find one council in Australia that will not be cheaper to run under the coalition's Fightback package. He has been sent out, no doubt on the direction of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to raise the problems. I challenge him to find one council that will not be cheaper to run under the coalition's Fightback package.

The reason why he will not find any council that is not cheaper to run is that, under the Fightback package, councils will no longer have to pay the fuel tax which this Government currently imposes upon them; they will no longer have to pay the payroll tax that some councils around Australia do pay; they will no longer have to pay the training guarantee levy; and, in spite of what Mr Simmons said on the Gold Coast last week, they will continue to be in the position of not having to pay the wholesale sales tax. Councils do not currently pay it directly, but they do, of course, pay it indirectly. Our policy is not to bring back the wholesale sales tax—it still will not be payable—and, what is more, no GST will be paid by councils, either. So with all of these savings that councils will make, they will be able to produce their services at a cheaper base cost.

Another way in which councils will save is that, because a lot of their existing services are done by private contractors, those private contractors at the moment pay sales tax, fuel tax, payroll tax, the training guarantee levy, and all the other taxes that this Government has imposed upon them. Under our policy, these private contractors will no longer pay sales tax; they will no longer pay fuel tax; they will no longer pay the training guarantee levy; and so it goes on.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you have had a long and distinguished career in local government, you will understand. I will pick an example, say, of a water truck that might be contracted to a local authority. Currently, the man who owns his own water truck has bought that truck for $60,000, $70,000, $80,000, or $120,000, and he has paid 20 per cent sales tax on it. Every time he blows a tyre, every time he smashes a windscreen, he pays an extra 20 per cent sales tax on top of the cost, and that is what he pays now. Every time he fills up his truck with fuel, he pays 26c a litre more than he should; it is a fuel tax that this Government imposed upon him. Under our policy, all of those taxes will go, so a man who owns his water truck and contracts to councils will be able to provide his services to councils at a much lower tendered cost. That is just one very small example of how this will benefit councils around our nation.

Councils will not pay the GST, for two reasons: either the activities will be regulatory and non-commercial, which we have said in our Fightback package will be zero rated so there will be no incidence of GST on the way through, or for the commercial activities they will attract a GST but, as it is a business, the GST on those inputs will be refunded in full, as it would be for any other business. So councils themselves will not be paying GST for either of those reasons.

As opposed to councils, ratepayers may have some incidence of GST on part of their rate bill, but it will not be on the part of their rate bill that relates to the council's regulatory or non-commercial services, and that is a substantial amount of what councils do. They will pay a GST on that part of the rate bill which is related to the council's commercial activities. What is going to be regulatory and non-commercial and what is commercial will be defined by us in legislation. As our package says, those matters are being looked at and worked over at the moment, and we will be making further announcements on those.

Certainly there are many activities of council that will be regulatory and non-commercial. In our package we use the example of maintenance of parks and gardens. That is just one example of the sorts of things that are classed as regulatory or non-commercial. For that aspect of a ratepayer's rate bill which relates to regulatory or non-commercial activities there will be no GST on the rate notice. For those activities that are commercial in nature there will be a component of the rate bill that relates to that and there will be a GST on that.

I emphasise again that the addition of the GST will be on a much lower base cost, and it will be a much lower base cost because of the complete abolition of the fuel tax, the complete abolition of the training guarantee levy, the complete abolition of the GST on inputs to businesses and the other savings that I have mentioned. There may be a small effect of the GST on the final rate bill but it will certainly not be 15 per cent, as the Labor Party is trying to say. In fact the Municipal Association of Victoria, the independent body that represents most municipal associations in Victoria, has done some calculations and has come up with some figures that show that in Victoria, on average, the increase in the rate bill would be less than 2 per cent. I am not quite sure what an average rate bill is in Victoria because I do not come from there but, if the average rate bill around Australia is $1,000, a 2 per cent increase would be about $20.

We have always said in our Fightback documents that the cost of living will increase, but not by 15 per cent. We have said it could be about 4.4 per cent. The Federal Treasury has said we are wrong and that it is only 3.6 per cent, which is much less. Let us take the Treasury figure of a 3.6 per cent increase across the board. The municipal organisation in Victoria says that for rate notices it will be less than 2 per cent.

In the Fightback package we have indicated that any increase in the cost of living will be more than compensated for by a range of specific benefits. That is the most important aspect of our proposals. Those specific benefits are led by massive cuts in personal income tax, by the abolition of the fuel tax for private motorists, and by increases of 8 per cent in the case of people who are pensioners or 6 per cent in the case of people receiving other government assistance.

A ratepayer earning $20,000 will be making a saving of about $15.60 per week and a ratepayer earning $30,000 will be making a saving of $30.40 per week. It does not need me to point out to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that $30 a week saving made as a reduction in income tax will more than cover the increase in rates that the Municipal Association of Victoria has estimated might apply. Every time a ratepayer fills his motor vehicle with fuel he will be saving something like $11. So he needs to fill the tank only twice or thrice to cover any impact there might be, on the estimate given by the Municipal Association of Victoria.

This is why I say that for all Australians the Fightback package will be a great boost for the country. It will achieve the two million jobs that we set out to create by the end of the century, and it will do very positive things for all aspects of Australian industry and endeavour. But as far as local authorities are concerned, as far as councils are concerned, their current costs of operation will be cut. They will be less because of the fact that we are making all of these savings—the taxes they currently pay, which will no longer be payable. I repeat my challenge to Mr Simmons: go out and try to find me one council in Australia which would not be cheaper to run under the coalition's Fightback package. The campaign by Mr Simmons and his colleagues is typical of the campaign that the Labor Party has run everywhere, full of lies and misinformation. If Mr Simmons thinks that he can meet my challenge, I would be pleased to hear from him. Find me one council that would not be cheaper to run: that is his challenge—I await his response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rising today to ask my colleagues in the Senate to ask those people who work around Parliament House and support us in the way that they do through the long hours that we work, to make an early Christmas purchase. In particular, I draw my request to the attention of Senator O'Chee, as a young person, and to Senator Meg Lees, as the mother of an adolescent family. Only last week the Australian Paralympic Federation launched a CD featuring the 19 top Australian rock groups. The proceeds of this venture will assist in a fundraising appeal to send members of the Paralympic team to the winter Paralympics and the other Paralympic events. I commend them for initiating the project of putting this CD together, and also for setting up an appeal, which was also launched last week, to raise money. The Federation asked every athlete, every sportsperson—man and woman—to donate $1.

PARA.TAB: Why has it had to do this? It has had to do it because there is an inequality between the funding for our Paralympic team and our Olympic team. We should all be aware of that and we ought to think about whether that is proper and equitable. Why should our top disabled athletes, who are competing in the Paralympics, receive less funding than able-bodied athletes going off to the Olympics? It might be because they do not get as much press coverage. It might be because the Government cannot get the same kudos out of supporting those who are disabled as they can out of supporting our able-bodied athletes.

But that is no excuse for the inequality in the distribution of taxpayers' funds. The disparity is not only in dollar terms, it is in percentage terms as well. If the percentage disparity were right as the difference between what an able-bodied athlete gets and what an athlete with a disability gets, it would still cost the Government less than a third as much to fund the disabled athletes as the non-disabled athletes.

It is an issue that I believe the Government ought to be addressing. Senator Reid was talking to me today. She is on a Paralympics fundraising committee in Canberra. She told me that she wanted me to speak on her behalf on the importance of the Senate's taking note of this discrepancy and of doing everything in its power to address it. This morning I gave a notice of motion calling on the Senate to address the concerns that I am raising here today at lunchtime.

Senator Reid was telling me that the able-bodied Olympic team is totally fitted out with their uniforms, their blazers and so on. The Paralympic team is fitted out with less equipment than that, and if team members want an Olympic blazer they have to buy it themselves. There is no proper place for that sort of discrimination in this day and age. One wonders what other sorts of discrepancies there are in training grants, scholarships and other sorts of facilities to promote sportsmanship amongst people in our community with disabilities. Is it that the Government thinks that they are one-third less deserving? That is how much less they get in terms of support to represent Australia. Our Paralympic team was very successful at the last winter Paralympics. They are athletes of distinction and they should not be discriminated against.

It is ironical that I should be speaking on this today, when only a couple of days ago the Disability Discrimination Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives. You can bet your bottom dollar the Government will lord it around the place saying, `Look what we have brought in: the Disability Discrimination Bill 1992'. I will read from the second page of that Bill, clause 3:

SPEECH.PARA: The objects of this Act are:
(a)to eliminate, as far as possible, discrimination against persons on the ground of disability in the areas of:
(i)work, accommodation, education, access to premises, clubs and sport.

It seems crazy to me that we have a Bill brought into the House of Representatives specifically to legislate against discrimination, while what we have in the funding arrangements is discrimination. That is two-faced hypocrisy. Those on the other side talk about duplicity all the time, but that is the ultimate in duplicity. The Bill will get publicity and the Government will say, `Look what we have done for people with disabilities', but it is what people do that counts. Actions count louder than words. It is no good having this legislation unless it is followed in practice.

PARA.TAB: It is exactly the same thing as when the Government says, `All people with disabilities should be out in open employment'. We went through in the Chamber in this session looking at how well various Government departments have done in employing people with disabilities. Appallingly! I cannot remember the figures exactly, but something in the order of 40-odd departments and authorities had decreased the number of people in their employment with disabilities, some had stayed the same, and a few had gone up—a precious few. Another example of not practising what they preach.

Some might say, `Senator Patterson, you are asking for more money'. I am glad Senator Calvert is in the chair. I do not want to implicate him, because he should be impartial in that role, but one only has to go through the rorts and the waste of money that he has identified in the Waste Watch Committee. In 1990-91 Foreign Affairs spent $100,000 designing a new passport form that was never used. What is the order of the money that we are looking for? We are looking for about an additional $700,000 to have our Paralympic team funded at the same level as our able-bodied Olympic team. There is $100,000 of it—a seventh of it—wasted on designing a new passport form that was never used. The Australian Industry Development Assistance Bureau wasted $11m on a botched aid program to the Solomon Islands. Dr Edwards, a consultant to Mr Keating when he was Treasurer, received an $80,000 pay-out after four months work.

Pensioners last year received a 10c increase in their pensions. I note that in Hansard: it was 10c, not 10 per cent. The Government wrote to them all, and it cost $100,000 to tell them that they got 10c extra. I am sure every one of those pensioners would have said, `Give that money to the Paralympic team. I do not need to be told I have got another 10c'. I am sure I would have every pensioner in Australia behind me in saying, `That money—that postage and all the effort from Social Security—could have gone into supporting our Paralympic team.' I bet there is not one pensioner who would disagree with me on that, and say they needed to be told they would get another 10c.

What did the Government spend on pot plant hire in 1989-90? Senator Calvert has shown us that it spent $1.07m on pot plant hire, but we cannot outfit our team for the Paralympics; we cannot support it. We have stories of families struggling to support their disabled sports people to ensure that they can execute and put into place at the Paralympics all the training that they have gone through to represent Australia.

I have said before that how we treat the aged in our community is a reflection of our society. How our society treats people with disabilities in our community is also a reflection of our society. It could be any one of us tomorrow or tonight. All it takes is a stroke or an accident, and fate does not discriminate; all it takes is that split second and any one of us could be in that situation. It is not a very good record and I hope the Government can justify this Bill when its practice does not reflect what is in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is the third anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre in which the Chinese authorities butchered thousands of defenceless men, women and children, whose only crime was to protest for the democratic freedom which we in this country take for granted. Unfortunately, the sense of outrage expressed by all the civilised world at that time is too quickly forgotten as similar outrages are perpetrated by other governments and in other places. Despite their apparent differences, however, these dark regimes have one thing in common—they use the dark hand of tyranny to crush the aspirations of their people for peace and democracy. The power of a barrel of a gun overcomes the longing for a more just world.

PARA.TAB: How should we lucky few in Australia and elsewhere deal with China as the years pass by and the sense of public outrage declines? How should we treat the People's Republic of China as a sovereign state in the international community? To forget what happened on that morning in Beijing and on subsequent days throughout China would be to dishonour the memory of those who laid down their lives for principle. To isolate China from the world at this stage would arguably do little to further the cause of reform in that country. In this context, I believe it is incumbent upon us to end the economic isolation of the People's Republic of China and actively to encourage better trade links between the mainland and the nations of the free world.

It is also appropriate for us to call upon the Government in Beijing to implement with all haste the necessary economic reforms which will improve the living standards of ordinary people and bring them as far as possible in line with those in the Western world. The inexorable march for better prosperity, which is at the heart of every nation and which indelibly stamps the actions of every legitimate government, cannot and should not be impeded on the Chinese mainland. Further economic sanctions against the Government of the People's Republic of China will not serve those goals and will in fact only delay the introduction of much needed reforms to eradicate poverty and hardship. This does not mean, however, that we should in any way legitimise the many repressive actions of the current Government, whether they were perpetrated then or in the intervening period. The world must make it perfectly clear that it will not tolerate the use of force for political repression, the banning of free speech or the imprisonment of people for their ideals.

Just the other day the Government in Beijing banned laughter in Tiananmen Square for fear that it might be used as a form of protest. It banned laughter! That the Chinese Government should go to such lengths is a measure of just how isolated it is in a political sense, both from the international community and from its own people. This is a government which is afraid of the strength of the human spirit which survives repression, torture, and tyranny and which is sustained by a belief in the fundamental rights of man. I believe, therefore, that our duty must be to offer light in the darkness, succour to the suffering, and hope to the hopeless that one day the freedoms which we in this country enjoy as rights will be available to the people of the Chinese mainland, as it will be available to people everywhere, and may God speed that day.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill will amend the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act, following the recent case of Australian cyclist Martin Vinnicombe, who tested positive for anabolic steroids in the United States through tests carried out at the request of the Australian Sports Drug Agency by Canadian authorities. However, Mr Vinnicombe subsequently avoided sanctions on a legal technicality, despite admitting to using the drugs. I announced on 27 April, on behalf of the coalition, that we would move to close the Vinnicombe loophole should the Government fail to do so, and I commend the Government for seeking to close that loophole.

PARA.TAB: However, I do have some problems with this legislation. This is the third time in something like 15 months of operation that the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act has had to be amended in one way or another. It does not really give us a great deal of confidence in the people drafting this legislation in the first place. It does not seem that they are enormously aware of the problems that this sort of legislation faces or that they are aware of the sort of legislation that is required to make the whole program of opposing the use of drugs in sport work properly.

The Bill contains a large number of amendments and makes provision for a coordinated national approach through the States and Territories to eliminate drugs in sport following an agreement between State and Territory sports Ministers last year. It will enable the Agency to test a wider range of athletes, both in Australia and overseas, for the presence of prohibited drugs. The Agency will also be allowed to enter into contractual arrangements with overseas governments and other anti-doping authorities to arrange for the collection and testing of samples.

The central thrust of the Bill will enable the Agency to recognise procedures adopted by foreign anti-doping authorities which conduct tests on its behalf, even if those procedures do not precisely mirror those set out in the Australian Sports Drug Agency regulations. The minimum standard will be that provided for in the International Olympic Charter against doping in sport. The Agency will now be able to act on those results.

Australian standards are currently stricter than, and slightly different from, those in the Olympic charter but, in our view, basically no threat to the rights of Australians will emerge from allowing Australian athletes to be tested overseas under the Olympic charter requirements.

The Bill also gives athletes the opportunity to make a challenge to the validity of a positive test result if procedures relating to, first, the sealing of the container holding the sample and, secondly, testing of the sample by an accredited laboratory are not complied with; or if, thirdly, there is evidence of tampering with the sample.

Should the Agency decide that the test is valid, the competitor will now be entitled to apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to have the decision reviewed. The Agency must verify that all the three above procedures were followed before validating a positive test result, even if there is no appeal by the competitor. Written notification to approved sporting and anti-doping organisations of a positive test result or of a refusal to provide a sample is now required.

The name of the register will be altered to `register of notifiable events', to remove any implications that the entry of a person's name on the register necessarily implies guilt. The question of guilt and the application of sanctions is the responsibility of the sporting organisations, not the Australian Sports Drug Agency.

In order to protect minors, the Bill also makes allowance for the removal of a minor's name from the register once the period of any sanction imposed by sporting organisations has elapsed, provided that at the time of the request to provide a sample the person was under the age of 18. The Agency will also now have the power to approve foreign anti-doping bodies which adopt at least standards provided for in the Olympic charter and to request such bodies to take a sample from a competitor who is an Australian citizen or permanent resident when the competitor is overseas. The Agency will also be required to keep the list of such bodies.

There will be no additional financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by this legislation because any additional costs arising from contracts with overseas organisations will be fully recovered and any additional costs arising from the complementary legislation passed by the States and Territories will be borne, of course, by those States and Territories.

I do have a couple of problems about the way the Government has gone about this. As I said, we fully support the Bill—in fact, we announced that we would initiate such legislation—but it is extraordinary to me that this legislation was not referred by the Government to such organisations as the Australian Olympic Committee who have a clear and significant interest in this matter. The only way the Australian Olympic Committee found out what this legislation was all about was when I sent it a copy last week. Frankly, that is not the way to run a government. I am quite astounded that there was clearly a lack of consultation with the people most involved—at least consultation at the point when the legislation was presented. One would have thought, if one were running a department or an organisation which is seeking the cooperation of bodies like the Australian Olympic Committee, that that kind of action—

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is the ACTU lot, they will confer with them.

—Exactly. As Senator Panizza says, if it was the ACTU, the Government would confer with it to find out what it was allowed to do. In this case, it does seem to me unfortunate. I do not know to what extent there was any other consultation—I was not advised of any; there may have been some—but it would seem to me just basic courtesy to say to the Australian Olympic Committee, `Have you got any feelings about this legislation? Are we covering it properly? Have we covered all angles?'. In fact, I think there are still some problems with the legislation. I expect more amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act, because there are problems.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that one of the problems we cannot really deal with in the Act itself relates to the problems that emerge when an admission from someone such as Vinnicombe—who cheated and admitted that he cheated because he thought he had been caught out by the test—is not regarded as a positive test for the purposes of action being taken against him. We discussed this in the appropriation debate the other day. It was put to me that penalties are up to the sporting bodies themselves and therefore it is up to them to determine whether an admission of having taken drugs should carry the same weight as a test by the Australian Sports Drug Agency. What I would like to see is appropriate legislation introduced in this place by the Government to make it a requirement, if sporting organisations are to receive government funding grants through the Australian Sports Commission, that they accept admissions of guilt along with these other test matters. I hope the Government will take some kind of action on this.

There is as well, however, a basic problem that has been put to me relating to this Act: it requires too many procedures. The amendments here today do not address those problems. There are 58 procedures to be followed when doing a test. Therefore, it is possible to omit a procedure and void a test, as in the Vinnicombe case, even though it is clear and evident that the person has tested positive. With 58 potential slip-up points, surely there are ways of condensing the escape hatches for people who have cheated by taking drugs.

There are four basic elements to be dealt with when testing. The first is selection of the athlete, either in or out of competition. The second is control of the sample when it has been given, to ensure there is no substitution. Thirdly, one must be able to show that it is the proper sample. Fourthly, the sample must be properly tested. They seem to be four relatively simple and basic propositions and I would hope that the escape hatches would be significantly reduced to fit in with those four basic objectives.

We have a problem that, after these amendments, foreign athletes are still unable to be tested in Australia if they are here for training only and do not use government facilities. I mention this as a matter of some significance, because Vinnicombe claimed he was in the United States for training only and so, without our approval, the Canadian drug testing people could not have tested him. The reverse is equally true: that foreign athletes are still unable to be tested in Australia if they are here for training only and do not use government facilities, or are not in international competition, and they do not agree to be tested. In those circumstances they can be tested only if their controlling body agrees to the testing.

What this means is that, if it is clear and evident to ASDA as a result of information that there is clearly some international athlete taking drugs—and, one may fear, encouraging other athletes, Australian athletes with whom he is training, to take such drugs—no action is to be taken without the controlling body of that organisation agreeing. I believe that it is worth examining that situation.

There is also a view around that we should not be saying that this Act is being changed to follow IOC procedures, but that it will substantially follow them. I understand that that is a significant difference and that the Act means that we will be substantially following but not actually following them. There is no requirement, by the way, for the Australian Olympic Committee to be notified if an athlete tests positive—only that athlete's sports body.

The reason I raise that as a problem is this. Suppose the Australian Olympic Committee is to have its funding dependent on its following the rules and requirements for the penalties that would emerge from positive drug testing but a constituent body—say, the Cycling Federation, because that has been in the news—does not tell the Australian Olympic Committee that one of its members has been found positive. The AOC may then suffer. The sins of one of its associate members could well be visited upon the Australian Olympic Committee without its knowing what the problem really is. So there are further changes that need to be made, particularly in view of the Government's failure, it seems to me, adequately to consult with the bodies involved.

Nonetheless, I conclude by saying that the coalition strongly supports the Government's actions in trying to close the Vinnicombe loophole. We condemn those people who have sought to excuse or justify Vinnicombe's cheating on his colleagues. As I mentioned the other day, I have had some people writing to me saying how disgraceful our actions are. A couple of people from Tasmania, actually, Mr Acting Deputy President—I know that that will shock you—have written saying, `Why are you hounding this poor innocent man who has served his penalty for drug taking?'. The fact is that he has not and did not, and that was the disgrace.

An innocent person who was suspended for drinking too much coffee—and, thank heavens, at last has been exonerated—had to serve a penalty of two years, but Vinnicombe, who admitted to taking a performance enhancing drug and who, by the way, had been accused of being involved in these drugs for quite some time before this, was allowed because of a technicality to escape half his penalty. It seems to me to be extraordinary. Vinnicombe himself has accused me of hounding him.

All I want to do is to make certain that drug cheats have to pay the penalty for their misbehaviour. I am glad to see that the Government strongly takes that view, with the result that it has introduced these amendments, which are the third amendments in 15 months of operation of this Act. I end by commending people in the Sports Drug Agency for their commitment to their objective. I suppose a slight family bias could be alleged in that my cousin, Professor Peter Baume, is Chairman of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I commend the Sports Drug Agency for its efforts. I just regret that in this situation the Act has clearly been found wanting.

I hope that there is no prospect whatsoever of any loophole like the Vinnicombe loophole being repeated. I regret to say that I do not believe these amendments ensure that there can be no such escape, particularly because of the Government's failure at the moment to address in a legislative way the matter of admissions of guilt to drug taking even if a drug test is found not to have met exactly all the 58 required steps that have to be taken without slip-up for it to be able to be used as evidence of drug taking. The coalition supports this Bill and will support subsequent Bills that may have to come in to block the holes that we think still exist in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been noted, many of the amendments within the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill have been made necessary by recent events both in Australia and overseas. In particular, a series of amendments have been made necessary by the events surrounding the Australian cyclist, Martin Vinnicombe, who tested positive and who admitted to being positive after using performance enhancing anabolic steroid drugs but who was able to avoid appropriate sanctions on a legal technicality. I believe the Government is to be congratulated on the speed with which it has acted to remove this technical loophole through which Mr Vinnicombe was able to escape. It is just 35 days since this chamber was given a guaran-

SPEECH.PARA: tee by Senator Collins that the Government would act and just some 51 days since the Minister for Sport, Mrs Kelly, issued drafting instructions to close the Vinnicombe loophole.

PARA.TAB: That short timeframe indicates the seriousness with which the Government approaches the matter of drugs in sport, a seriousness which, I know, is shared by the Opposition, certainly by the Democrats and, I believe, by all within the community. It is particularly appropriate, with just 52 days to go to the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games in Barcelona, that we should be sending to the world as strong a message as possible that Australians do not condone cheating in sport. Who knows how many Australian athletes, particularly swimmers—more particularly, women swimmers—have missed out on medals at previous Olympics and also at world competitions because they have had to compete against drug cheats.

It is somewhat ironic that the loophole through which Mr Vinnicombe was able to escape and avoid full sanctions existed because the procedures adopted by the Australian Sports Drug Agency regarding testing are somewhat more stringent than those adopted by other nations and even those in the international Olympic charter against doping in sport.

The Act has been amended to ensure that the Australian Sports Drug Agency can recognise procedures adopted by foreign anti-doping authorities testing on the Agency's behalf, as long as those procedures meet a minimum standard of those provided for in the international Olympic charter. That will consequently allow the Agency to make entries recording positive tests on the register of notifiable events, even if the procedures followed by a foreign agency did not mirror exactly those set out in the Australian Sports Drug Agency regulations. That was the main loophole in the Vinnicombe case. Some other features in these amendments provide for Australia to take a coordinated national approach to the elimination of drugs in sport, and provide for the Australian Sports Drug Agency to take a wider international role.

On the national level, the Bill enables the States and Territories to confer testing powers on the ASDA through complementary State and Territory legislation. I understand that there has been a commitment from all States and Territories that such legislation will be introduced—and that is to be encouraged and commended.

In the international arena, the Australian Sports Drug Agency is increasingly being recognised as having professional expertise in testing for prohibited drugs. The Bill includes amendments which will give the ASDA the power to enter into contracts or arrangements with overseas governments and other sporting authorities for the collection and testing of samples.

On the flip side of the international equation, the Bill protects the interests of Australian athletes by making sure that the Agency actually monitors and approves the procedures of foreign anti-doping authorities with whom we have reciprocal arrangements to ensure that they are conforming to at least the minimum international Olympic charter standards.

There are a number of other amendments—and I will be brief, considering the time. These cover such matters as the appeal process for athletes challenging a positive test result; the notification of athletes and sporting bodies of test results; the change of name of the registrar from the `register of defaulting competitors' to the `register of notifiable events', to remove the immediate association with guilt of entry of a person's name upon that register; and the provision that minors have their names taken off the register once the period of any sanction imposed by the sporting organisation has elapsed, provided they were under 18 at the time of the request.
In conclusion, I state very strongly that the Australian Democrats fully support the measures taken in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill amends the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act, and it follows, as has already been pointed out, the Vinnicombe case, whereby Vinnicombe slipped through a loophole. I do not know what Senator Lees was doing congratulating the Government on the speed of the amendment. The Government had done nothing until Senator Baume pointed out on 27 April, actually in this Senate chamber, what the position was. Then the Government obviously decided to move after that.

PARA.TAB: I will not go in depth into the amendments, but there are a large number of amendments in this Bill to coordinate the approach to cutting out drugs in sport. One of the main ones, as far as I am concerned, is the contractual arrangements that the ASDA will have with the governments of other countries.

The other forward movement is an appeal to the AAT, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, if the person is found to have a positive case. I believe that, in anything where a person has been found guilty, this could be an avenue of appeal when before there was none.

I will now mention, briefly, the Alex Watson case. I was on the original inquiry into drugs and sport. We had a lot of witnesses before us, some of whom were less than convincing. In this case of Alex Watson, however, when I listened to his story and his case—not what I read in the newspapers about when he was banned and thrown out of the Seoul Olympics, and put on the next plane home without much explanation; I did not take any notice of that but I am talking about when he came in front of the inquiry—he was one that I wanted to believe, because he seemed genuine in what he was saying in comparison with a lot of less than truthful witnesses at the time.

Among the questions to Alex Watson, I asked him about Dr Fitch, from Western Australia, who is eminent in sports medicine. I asked, `Did you ever talk to him about it, or did he ever question you about it?' and he replied yes. When I asked what he had said on the matter, the reply was, `Listen, young fellow, you are over and you cop it!'. When he said that such an eminent, experienced person as Dr Fitch had told him that, I said that it must have been right.

History has proved that the caffeine that he took came from the sources that Alex Watson said it did, and he has now been exonerated. That shows that even experts—I am not being unkind to Dr Fitch, whom I have had the pleasure of knowing for 40-odd years—can make rather off the cuff, rash judgments that are not necessarily right. I was very happy to see Alex Watson exonerated. The AOF has now got to think whether other such happenings may occur.

I believe that this Bill will make a better sports drug agency but we have already heard the criticism that, when this amendment Bill was prepared, it was not referred to the Australian Olympic Federation whatsoever for its input. That is akin to preparing a tax amendment Bill and not referring it to the Commissioner of Taxation, or indeed an industrial relations Bill without conferring with the ACTU—even, as Senator Baume said, contacting the ACTU to see what the Government is allowed to do. In this case the Government has failed badly in not referring the Bill to the highest organisation in sport in Australia, the Australian Olympic Federation.

In conclusion, I would like to commend the efforts of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, headed by Professor Peter Baume, for the efforts it is making to stamp out drug use from Australian sport. I commend also the efforts that Dr Fitch and others throughout Australia put into getting the Sports Drug Agency going in the first place. I believe that it is starting to make progress and that, with these amendments—although there will be a lot more around the corner; we will probably be back next session amending it again—it will get to the position with drugs and sport that we are looking for in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1992 introduces a number of amendments. It is prompted by the appeal which was upheld by arbitration by Bob Ellicott, QC, an appeal by Martin Vinnicombe, a well-known, notorious and self-confessed cheat, who has been riding against athletes who have been competing on their merits while he has been competing on anabolic steroids. He has shown absolutely no remorse, no apology and no regret for his conduct, save for his bitterness that he was detected.

PARA.TAB: The technicality was essentially that the authorities which tested him did not comply strictly with the provisions of the Australian Sports Drug Agency; therefore, the test was found to be invalid. By any measure it is a technicality in the sense that in no way is there any suggestion that he was not cheating. He was detected in Canada or America, as I recall, by another body. Mr Vinnicombe had learnt not to take anabolic steroids in Australia because of the efficiency of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. He refined his skills in taking drugs when he was overseas.

I can imagine the bitterness of all those athletes and competitors who have ridden against him in the past at the various venues and the various Olympic Games and Commonwealth Games, and who have been cheated out of a place by this man. They have probably given a lifetime of endeavour in their sport, not to succeed only because they chose to succeed on their merits. While this man is on a dais, taking gold and glory, they are forgotten names in the world of amateur cycling. Now, because of this technicality, Mr Martin Vinnicombe is going to be riding as a professional athlete in Australian colours—something about which neither we, nor he, ought to be proud.

I want to commend the Australian Sports Drug Agency for its diligence, and for the part it played in cleaning up sport in Australia. Steve Haynes, the executive officer, has done a magnificent job and so has the commission generally, headed by the eminent Professor Peter Baume. Without taking a partisan shot at the Government, can I say that I very much regret that it was not long ago that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was saying that we have gone over the top in this business of worrying about drugs in sport, and that there was too much emphasis on that matter. That has been found to be a misguided nonsense, at the very least, and a gross irresponsibility, at the very worst.

The facts of the matter are that the Committee inquiring into drugs in sport in Australia revealed an enormous amount of indiscriminate use—if there can be such a thing as discrimination in this respect—of anabolic steroids. One of the recommendations of that Committee was that there be an upgraded surveillance at the barriers by the Customs authorities, a recommendation which was adopted. As a result of the implementation of that recommendation, it has been subsequently disclosed that there is enormous trade in the sale of anabolic steroids for human use, including veterinary steroids. There have been recent revelations that they are used not only by elite athletes in elite sports but also by body builders, by weight-lifters and by young people. The tragedy of young people using anabolic steroids is the severe psychological and physical affect it has upon them. To date, there has been no prospect of that being stamped out, and we can only hope that in the future, with greater surveillance and greater activity, we will see some reduction in the use of anabolic steroids.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Given that yesterday the Prime Minister confirmed the Government's support for the full ACTU national wages claim—meaning that the Government will not be supporting a discount to the claim on account of the superannuation guarantee levy—and further that Treasury Secretary Cole has said, `There is an implicit full offset to the SGL from reductions in other wages costs' in the One Nation wages growth projections, why is it not the case that these projections are now wrong and that there will indeed be a substantial rise in Australians out of work due to the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy?

—In terms of the detail required in that question, I will obtain it from the Treasurer and advise Senator Alston as soon as I can. Let me say, though, that the Government has never accepted that there will be a substantial reduction in employment arising from the implementation of the superannuation guarantee levy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This matter has been on the agenda for the last week. Is the Minister saying that he has had no briefing on the

QUESTION.PARA: subject and, indeed, is not aware of the employment implications as spelt out by Treasury to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation? In other words, if the full unit labour cost is borne by employers, there will be up to 100,000 jobs lost over the next five years and the only way to avoid that is to discount wages. Is the Minister telling us all of that? Further, I refer the Minister to evidence presented last night to the Select Committee by Mr Ian Ross on behalf of the ACTU that the additional cost of the SGL from 1 July will be of the order of 1 1/2 per cent aggregate wage costs on a national accounts basis. Is this simply not further evidence that, unless the wage claim is discounted by around the 1 1/2 per cent figure, there will inevitably be a very significant level of job losses? If the Minister is not able to answer that, I ask him why he bothers coming to Question Time at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entitled to ask questions here. If I were, I would ask one of the same sort of Senator Alston. The supplementary question makes the point about the answer which I originally gave; that is, I am not briefed on or aware of what Mr Ian Ross said last night at a meeting. I have not had any briefing on that because I have not been here this morning. I assume Senator Alston wants an intelligent, thoughtful and comprehensive answer. I am saying that I am not in a position to give one. There is nothing unusual about that in any Question Time.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of media reports as to the effects that funding cuts to the ABC's budget would have on its operations? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the effect such cuts would have on the ABC's programming and operations?

—My public support for the institution of the ABC has been mentioned just recently. I am a lover of the ABC; I make no bones about it. I must say that I do feel that retaining a truly national broadcaster free of advertising and sponsorship and providing particularly the independent news service that it does—apart from the fantastic contribution it makes to Australian content and drama—have provided this country with a great national service over a long time. I hope it continues to do so.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that the Fightback scorched earth approach to what this country would look like should the Opposition ever get into control proposes funding cuts to the ABC in the order of $50m a year. The effect of that on the ABC would be, in a word, catastrophic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—We will have that tested. It is interesting, I must say, to hear interjections such as `Rubbish!' from members of the Opposition. In other Question Times they—particularly from the National Party corner, and fair enough too—are continually asking in here for more and more ABC services to be provided, not fewer. In fact, they propose to substantially cut the funding of that organisation. I do not know what they expect it to run on—fresh air, presumably, or advertising probably.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that, to live within a reduced budget such as this, there are no soft options for the ABC. Major cuts in functions would be needed and some or all of the following areas would have to be looked at: the Australian content level; and State based TV production and local and regional radio production—and I stress, regional radio production. There is the constant cry from the Opposition, `Why aren't you providing more and more?'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave the bush alone.

—Absolutely! Senator Boswell should tell his mates. The National Party, I know, gave up looking after the bush years ago but we are still trying to. The other areas that would have to be looked at are: transmission hours; specialist programming, for example, arts—and, wait for it, Senator Walters—religion; science and rural programs; and overseas news bureaux. As well, it may be necessary to close an entire radio network—ABC FM Radio National or JJJ.
—How about Andrew Denton?

—Leave Andrew Denton alone; I like Andrew Denton. Ransacking the ABC and SBS would reduce media diversity at a time when the Government is pulling out all stops to bolster the choice that is available to Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Government is proud of the following achievements of the ABC in enhancing its services dramatically over recent years at no extra cost to the taxpayers: expansion of radio networks to more rural communities; 24-hour radio schedules; more TV drama productions; more Australian content and first run TV programs; and, I am pleased to say, more and more Australians listening to ABC radio and watching ABC TV. This is possible only because of the stable financial position the ABC is now in thanks to this Government's determination to support this great Australian institution.

Yesterday the Government made another commitment in support of the ABC, and I am pleased to see the ABC's welcome of it this morning; that is, to assist the ABC to participate in pay TV, free of risk to its normal services—and I stress that: free of risk to its normal services—and without needing to form special commercial partnerships. The ABC will be allowed to bid for the fifth or sixth pay TV channel. I understand the ABC is also investigating a role as a program supplier to the first multi-channel service.

In conclusion, overall, this Government has tangibly backed the development of the Australian Broadcasting Service as a world class broadcaster owned by and available to all Australians. This contrasts starkly with the Opposition's Fightback approach of cutting away all that is worthwhile in our community.

—I have concluded, Mr President.
