—I do not know what that has to do with anything. I have seen the statement from Mr Hollis. I am obtaining a briefing from the Department on the matter and I will make a statement about it soon.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. If the Government does proceed with an inquiry—and, quite frankly, I do not see how it cannot—will he give the Senate two assurances: firstly, that none of the consultants who were used for auditing the contract along the way will be used in any subsequent inquiry; and, secondly, given the fact that the selection process, unorthodox though it was, was designed to result in equalisation of the bids so that now there is essentially no major difference between Australian industry participation, no essential difference in time to fulfil the contract and no significant difference on price, any inquiry will not be limited to the final phases of the contract determination, but will start at the beginning and go through every element of the contract selection?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said that I have seen Mr Hollis's statement and that I am calling for a briefing. I do not have the matter before me at the moment in order to make a decision. Until I make a decision I cannot give any assurances at all. I understand and note the two assurances that are being sought, but at this stage I am not in a position to deal with what might be a hypothetical question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Associated Pulp and Paper Mills: Dispute

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and it relates to the industrial dispute at APPM in Burnie. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of statements by Mr Henderson, the manager of APPM at Burnie, on Tuesday of this week to the effect that the legal action taken by the company against union officials is a sticking point to a solution of the APPM dispute? Does the Minister agree with Mr Henderson's assessment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend APPM issued 19 new writs against union people, including the President of the ACTU, Mr Ferguson. That was, I think, on the last day of May. On 2 June Mr Ken Henderson, who is the mill manager at Associated Pulp and Paper Mills at Burnie, was quoted in the Hobart Mercury as saying that the writs were the problem and were now the major sticking point in the settlement of the dispute. His actual words were:

ANSWER.PARA: These writs are the only outstanding issue of the dispute so far.

Mr Howard has accused the governments of Tasmania and of Australia of meddling in this dispute but here is a company spokesperson saying that the problem that is preventing a settlement of this dispute is these particular writs. Today I can inform the Senate that Mr Groom, the Premier of Tasmania, and I, acting on behalf of this Government, have jointly—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Premier of Tasmania.

—Senator Sherry is quite right. The Liberal Premier of Tasmania, and I, as a Minister in a Labor government, acting on behalf of the Commonwealth, have jointly, in a rare display of unity in an industrial relations matter—a display of unity between Liberal and Labor governments is something quite extraordinary in industrial relations—following on from our talks on Sunday, approached and written to the Industrial Relations Commission calling for the Commission to convene a hearing in Burnie between the parties as soon as possible. If the Commission accedes to that request, I, on behalf of the Commonwealth Government, will seek leave of the Commission to be joined to the proceedings and put a view to the Commission in that conference.

PARA.TAB: It has been said in this dispute that the only thing that the company wants is to deal with its employees. I am amazed by that bland and, might I say, disingenuous statement because this is the company which has served writs on its own employees and their representatives. As many as 85 per cent of its own employees have signed a petition saying that unions of which they are members should be recognised by the company as their bargaining agent. This is the company which has sent notices of dismissal to all of its employees. This is the company which applied yesterday to the Tasmanian Training Authority to suspend the indentures of 80 apprentices in Tasmania. That leads me to the now bizarre advent of the `ninja turtles'. I am advised that ABC Radio and the Hobart Mercury are chasing a group of imported APPM security men, allegedly skilled in martial arts, who have been dubbed the `ninja turtles'.

The other jibe in this dispute is that it is a product of this Government's industrial relations system. Mr Henderson of APPM says that what is preventing settlement of this dispute is the writs that have been issued. Those writs have been issued under section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. John Howard, the shadow spokesman for industrial relations, claims to be the father of that section of the Act. Ergo, what Mr Henderson is saying is that this provision of the Trade Practices Act, for which John Howard is responsible, is what is preventing the settling of this dispute.

Mr Howard said that politicians should butt out of this dispute. He is a politician; he should butt out. He should not have the private meetings that he and Dr Hewson have had in secret with APPM. In this context, I am not a politician; I am the representative of a government. What politicians should do is one thing, but governments do have a responsibility to the public interest and this Government will be steadfast in exercising proper and due responsibility in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question by reminding the Minister that enabling legislation for the establishment of public or community television was passed 15 years ago. Is the Minister aware that the community broadcasting sector had to wait until 1987 before a single test permit was issued, despite the development of draft guidelines for the introduction of community television by DOTAC in 1981? In light of the current inquiry into the possible use of the sixth high-power television channel—not to be confused with the sixth Aussat transponder—is the Government finally able to conceive of a television channel that is not a network and not a third government channel and gives Australians the community television access they have been promised since the Whitlam era?
—The short answer to Senator Powell's question is yes—
—Who is going to get it—Packer?

—I wish Senator Walters would pack up. The Government would certainly be able to conceive of that. Mr Beazley, as Senator Powell would be aware, gave the HORSCOTCI committee—the House of Representatives committee—a reference on this. We can certainly see that as being a conceivable use of the sixth channel. Of course, we cannot make a decision until we receive the report from that committee. I would be extremely hopeful that the committee could report later this year.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister may be aware of comments suggesting that the first four transponder licences for pay TV are not commercially viable. Would the Minister inform the chamber as to whether this criticism is well founded?

—No. The statements that have been made in this regard are profoundly ill-informed. I am pleased to be able to assure the Senate that, according to some feedback I received this morning, the interest in proceeding with applications for the four transponder licences is very active indeed. In the policy that has just been announced, there is a balance in competition which, at the end of the day, will greatly benefit consumers. This policy is fundamentally designed to do that. Like our aviation policy, which is not to look after aviation interests, this policy is not designed to look after broadcasting interests but is designed to further enhance the opportunities that exist for Australians to have access to this technology. Australia is probably the last English speaking country on earth that does not have access to pay TV. That is not in fact strictly true: we do have pay TV here already for those that can afford it. If anybody wants to visit a few of the cattle stations in the Northern Territory, they will see how, if one has $5,000 to purchase the necessary equipment, it is possible to access pay TV.

PARA.TAB: This policy will enable pay TV to be made available to ordinary consumers at much lower cost. It is a good balance of interests between the four transponder licences and those that will be able to come on stream later on. Part of the Government's policy—the further details of which will be announced later—relates to the industry conditions which are attached to the licence, which, I am pleased to say, include a threshold condition. For example, decoder equipment will have to able to be accessed by subsequent pay TV services, which will avoid a proliferation of this equipment.
Senator Powell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fundamentally, I think Senator Powell and I have a philosophical agreement on pay TV. It may not be my cup of tea; it may not be Senator Powell's cup of tea. I have expressed my personal preference. My favourite TV channel is SBS, and I make no bones about it. However, Mr President, there are a great many people who do find these services attractive and they are entitled to have them. There has been a rash of media comment, as one would expect. No other policy area gets as much attention from the media. It is not a particularly surprising coincidence that we hear about the cultural devastation that will be brought on Australia by pay TV.

PARA.TAB: If these services are not made available by Australian companies, they will be made available in the very near future by American companies. Australians—certainly all of those living on the east coast—will simply be able to access American pay TV if the Australian pay TV is not available. It is a competitive policy framework and I have no doubt that the actual tangible results of that will be revealed in the very near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice. On what basis can the Minister possibly justify his letter as Minister for Justice to legal practitioners and members of the financial community in Adelaide indicating that he will be canvassing his Government's views on certain legislative proposals and seeking feedback on those proposals at a lunch in June, when entry to that lunch is conditional on a $45 payment to the western suburbs ALP? Did the Attorney-General's Department provide the list of legal practitioners? Did any arm of government provide the list of prominent members of Adelaide's financial community? Is the Minister, as a Tasmanian senator, a subscriber to the Ausdoc or DX distribution system and, if the Minister is not, whose membership was misused to distribute these invitations? Lastly, how much profit per head will his ministerial consultations earn for the Labor Party in the western suburbs on this occasion?

—I will be attending a luncheon in Adelaide, I think next week, in order to fulfil a commitment to a candidate in the election who, as I recall, was to organise this luncheon mainly in conjunction with the Australian society of credit unions—I do not know the exact terminology. That society is concerned to get a first hand account from me—I was then Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs—in relation to progress on the uniform credit legislation. It is basically in order to inform people about that very important topic, which has been the subject of much discussion by the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers. This topic will be the subject of further comment by this Federal Government as it responds to the Martin committee report, which also made some important observations concerning the necessity in the Australian marketplace, from the point of view of both credit providers and consumers, for Australia-wide uniform law and regulations relating to the provision of credit in our society.

PARA.TAB: Further, when I had discussions with Mr Rau, I said that perhaps it might be a good idea if I also broadened the subject matter of the luncheon address to thank the members of the credit providing community for their cooperation as far as the Cash Transaction Reports Agency legislation was concerned. This is an important piece of legislation which has enabled Australian law enforcement agencies to track and target those who are distributing and trafficking in drugs in our community, those who are evading taxation and those who engage in major fraudulent activity in our society. The idea was that I wanted to thank members of the credit providing community and lawyers for that contribution to Australia's well-being.

It is a very simple matter. The luncheon is being organised by Mr John Rau. There is no secret about the fact that it will be used in order to get a very important message across to lawyers and credit providers within the Adelaide community. It was initiated and, at least certainly in a cooperative way, discussed between Mr Rau and the credit unions of Australia representative. That is the main purpose of it. If there is any profit on the luncheon, then, as is quite common—as Senator Vanstone would know from luncheons that she and everyone else attend on behalf of candidates—it will go into the candidates' pool of moneys for their election support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, albeit that it was a hopeless attempt at blaming the poor old candidate for Hindmarsh, Mr John Rau, who is a former staffer of Mr Mick Young, by saying that it was all his fault. The Minister needs to answer this—
—You're giving him more publicity, you boofhead.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw that offensive remark.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw it.

—Thank you, Mr President—not that anyone cares what Lurch says. Senator Tate, as Minister for Justice, has written on ministerial letterhead to legal practitioners about matters associated with his portfolio. He has said, as he said in his answer, that he wants to canvass these areas and get feedback on them. But he has not told us why he does not see a problem in mixing his ministerial duties to consult widely on government legislation—he undoubtedly has that responsibility—
—Order! Senator Vanstone, ask the supplementary question.

—Mr President, I am asking the supplementary question. I am seeking of you only the same leniency in asking questions as you give with the answering of them. If I was not being interrupted so much from the other side, I could get to the point.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.

—The supplementary question is: does the Minister not see some distinction between his ministerial responsibility to consult widely with the legal profession in whatever State and members of the financial community and his desire, rather than responsibility, to raise money for the ALP? Does he not see that distinction? Can he comment on what the Fitzgerald royal commission had to say about people who do not see that distinction, who blur it and bring it together, and the sort of trouble they then get into? Will he also answer the question originally put to him, which is: is he, as a Tasmanian senator, a subscriber to the Ausdoc or DX distribution system? If he is not, whose membership was misused to send this stuff around? In particular, will the Minister also answer whether the Attorney-General's Department or any arm of government provided the list of legal practitioners and the list of members of the financial community? Where did he get this list from, because he did not get it from the Law Society?

—I have no idea about the compilation of the list. I am certainly not a subscriber, from my Tasmanian office, to the network to which Senator Vanstone refers. I imagine that the list was put together by those who are organising this event, including the credit union personnel and Mr Rau, I would imagine—certainly not me. In any case, I do not see anything which would—
—Do you deny it is the Attorney-General's list?

—I have indicated that I have no knowledge as to where that list came from. I hope that senators will accept that in making this important contribution to understanding in Adelaide, I will be raising the awareness of very important and influential people within the legal and credit providing community of these very important issues.

—I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce of his announcement in March of new initiatives to speed up the development and expansion of the pharmaceutical industry. In a statement to the Senate the Minister announced the extension of the so-called factor F scheme to 1999. Can the Minister inform the Senate of industry reaction to this announcement? Has the extension of factor F resulted in any new investments by pharmaceutical manufacturers? Could the Minister also explain to the Senate exactly what factor F is?

—The Government has a program which takes account of the fact that the pharmaceutical industry is research based, with high value added products and high export potential. When I announced that program, the Opposition spokesman made some mealy-mouthed comments about the statement. I cannot divine what the Opposition thinks about these sorts of issues in industry policy.

—It was a response. As usual, the response was waffly—the sort of response Senator Lewis is familiar with when he tells some of these high value added industries that if the waterfront were fixed up all their problems would go away. Senator Lewis knows the answer he got. They said, `We have never used the waterfront in our lives. What has that got to do with us?'. This is a high value added industry which is very much concerned with a research base in the medical and pharmaceutical industries in this country.

PARA.TAB: There is currently an environment in the pharmaceutical industry of Australia which will help it develop and grow. In the program that I announced a month or so ago the industry estimates of its exports by the year 2000 were $2 billion. That started from nothing a few years ago and it is now about $500m. It will be $2 billion by the end of the century. Because of particular skills and a particular research base in Australia, the industry can be highly competitive.

This morning I took part in an announcement with the Managing Director of Merck Sharp and Dohme—the biggest pharmaceutical company in the world and perhaps one of the most respected companies in the United States—of a $75m investment at the company's plant at Granville in Sydney. That will be spent on a new facility to produce new and significant products, particularly a drug which represents a very significant breakthrough in the treatment of prostate disease among men—something the male senators on the other side may be interested in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume my own interest and the interest of my colleagues; I just wanted to arouse a bit of interest in those opposite. Significantly, the Sydney plant will produce the new drug for the Japanese market, the second most important pharmaceutical market in the world.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, Merck Sharp and Dohme's export sales from this country were just under $62m. I gather that this year the figure will be about $80m. As a result of this investment made in Sydney, the company expects to increase exports to a total of $1 billion between now and 1999—in the next seven years. I make the point that that approximate figure of $250m a year is in addition to the estimates made by the industry of its export potential up to 1999 of $2 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they export through the waterfront?

—By aeroplane. I do not want to digress at all, but the new aviation policy announced by the Government earlier this week will be of considerable help in assisting this industry to transport its exports, particularly to Japan. I said that the exports will be additional. By the year 2000 the pharmaceutical industry in Australia will be at the point where pharmaceutical exports balance pharmaceutical imports.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the footloose nature of industries such as the pharmaceutical industry and their capital investments around the world, Australia was competing with other countries for this substantial investment. Merck Sharp and Dohme is to be congratulated on making the decision to build this plant here. It has been done for a number of reasons: the strong research base in Australia but, particularly, the Government program which has been supportive in terms of regulatory issues and price related factors for this industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Of the many documents tabled this morning relating to the Marshall Islands affair, I refer specifically to one—a cable dated 22 November 1991 from Ms Graham, the First Assistant Secretary (Political) in Washington, to the Department in Canberra.
—What number document is it?
—I do not know; I am taking it off another copy. I am referring specifically to a handwritten note on the cable which reads:

QUESTION.PARA: Have you heard of this proposal? Plse copy to Pohnpei & seek their views & further background. Sounds fraught with negative potential to me!

Why is it that only the Embassy in Washington saw the negative potential? Why could not the Minister's office see something so patently obvious to a First Assistant Secretary (Political) in Washington? Why was this note whited out of the same document when it was made public by the Prime Minister, as attached to Senator Sibraa's statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted for the question because I was beginning to get withdrawal symptoms as I sat here. That problem has now been overcome. I have absolutely no idea why that note was whited out. I do not know whether the particular copy that was previously publicised was whited out or whether it was simply a separate copy of the same document that was on the file in question and made available as a result. I will have to seek information about that.

PARA.TAB: The reason I did not white it out in the copy that I gave to Senator Hill was that I saw no particular substantive significance in it. It just shows a department sensibly at work. That was exactly the reaction this proposal had—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, get those opposite to calm down.
—Order!

—The poor, overwrought persons opposite! Obviously, the kind of scheme, when it was brought to the attention of the people in Washington, to which this particular document is a response, was fraught with difficulties so far as any involvement in it by the Australian Government was concerned and any lobbying on its behalf to the United States authorities or anyone else was concerned. That was exactly the advice that was given by Mr Lamb to Mr Symons and his friend when they visited Washington in pursuit of this particular matter. That is amply on the public record. There is absolutely nothing to be concerned about in that respect.

PARA.TAB: The reference to letting the post know in Pohnpei—to follow it up and seek some further information—was followed up, as I recall, in a couple of visits over the subsequent weeks. But in the course of those subsequent visits the Ambassador to the Federated States of Micronesia was unable to obtain any further information from his contacts or the people to whom he had access in the Marshall Islands Government. There is no particular reason to get excited about that or, for that matter, anything else in this large pile of documents. I await with interest the next question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to a discussion earlier this week on the issue of violence and the elderly, particularly in the context of the outrageous scare campaign being mounted by the Liberal Party through its disgraceful and misleading pamphlet on the subject. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether any research has been conducted in this area by the Australian Institute of Criminology which establishes an accurate picture of the vulnerability of the elderly to criminals in our society? I further ask the Minister whether he can indicate to the Senate anything about the whereabouts of Senator `Own Goal' Baume, missing in action since yesterday's Question Time.
—Order!

—A major research project has been undertaken by the Australian Institute of Criminology. It has identified fear of crime rather than the actual experience as victims of crime of the elderly in Australia. I believe the report, which I have publicly released today, seriously undermines the Opposition's current scare campaign, which is directed at those persons perhaps 60 years or over who have their fears aroused and are concerned about what they are led by headlines to believe is a real danger to them of being possible common victims of violent crime. In fact, those who seek to heighten the anxiety of the elderly in our community bear a very real responsibility. I am disgusted that the coalition media unit today has circulated in the Press Gallery a story in the Telegraph Mirror headed `Mugger preyed on elderly—Court told'. In other words, the coalition wants to spread the word, spread anxiety and spread all this fear among the elderly in our community.

PARA.TAB: The facts are to be found in today's Institute of Criminology trends and issues series entitled `The Elderly as Victims of Crime, Abuse and Neglect' by Mary-Ann Pinkerton-James. I ought to emphasise the timing of the release because of the very proper integrity of the Institute. This paper has been in preparation for four months. It was by coincidence available for publication today.

The trends and issues paper covers a range of areas of crime, abuse and neglect and analyses the vulnerability of the elderly. It finds that, in the area of theft and violence in particular, the exceptionally high level of concern amongst elderly Australians is not supported by the figures. In fact, in both these areas the risk is relatively low. Honourable senators will know that I have pointed out on many occasions in this chamber that in relation to homicide the age group most vulnerable, most likely to be killed, in our society is infants between zero and one year of age. It is certainly not the elderly.

A recurring theme of the report is the one word `fear'. It emerges over and over again. If we look at the actual statistics, in 1991, for example, 2,012 respondents in all were surveyed, of which 439 were aged 60 years or older. Only nine, 2.7 per cent, of the elderly respondents had received threats of non-sexual violence during the previous five years. None said they were actually hurt. Based on this sample, the elderly are therefore four times less likely than average to suffer threats and the risk of actual assault was too small to be measured. Only four, 0.4 per cent, of the elderly female respondents had experienced a sexual incident during the previous five years. Three described the incident as merely offensive behaviour, the other as an indecent assault. None described the incident as rape or attempted rape.

In the overall sample, 12.8 per cent had experienced such crimes. Based on this sample, the elderly are therefore 32 times less likely than average to suffer sexual incidents and the risk of actual or attempted rape was too small to be measured. I put those figures down because I think it is important for the elderly in our community to understand that whilst their fears might be aroused—and quite clearly where one has a serial killer on the rampage through Mosman it is true, as I know from an elderly aunt of mine who lived in Manly, that they are very frightened indeed; those fears are real—the likelihood of their being subjected to violent crime is very remote indeed.

However, the community does have to take steps to try to prevent any such incident of crime. The Australian Police Ministers Council meeting in July will be establishing an Australian program to deal with the prevention of crime and the social causes of crime and to try, even by way of urban structures and planning—for example, by the provision of well-lit thoroughfares and so on—to ensure that the elderly are not subjected to any violent attacks.

This is a very important matter which ought not to be subject to propaganda but to trying to do the best we can to ensure that the elderly people in our community live in a way which is not fearful and which is certainly not subject to the real incidence of criminal activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I remind him that on 26 May he tabled documents in the Senate, including a copy of a letter of advice of Mr Lamb dated 14 May. I ask the Minister: why did he not also make public the advice of 15 May of Mr Lamb which contradicted his earlier advice?

—It only contradicted his earlier advice to the extent that, on second thoughts, Mr Lamb said he must have received the letter from Senator Sibraa at some earlier date when he was out of Washington. But, as I said this morning, there were still further thoughts that came from Mr Lamb 10 days later. They appear in document 48 of the ones before Senator Hill—and I specifically mentioned that this morning so he would not have to ask me this question as it would be self-evident from the material in front of him—when Mr Lamb, in further discussion of this matter with an officer of my Department, agreed that his revised recollection was manifestly wrong to the extent that he said he thought he might have received the Sibraa letter as early as 5 or 10 November, and that it must have been a later date when he was out of Washington between 20 and 22 November.

PARA.TAB: That recollection was based on the fact that from the date that is evident—not on the letter itself because it is not dated, but on the fax line that appears at the top of the Sibraa letter—it is clear that it was sent to Washington on 20 November. It does not fit with any known version of the facts that it could have gone there earlier.

So what we had was a second thought which was overtaken by a third thought which cancelled out the second thought. Therefore, rather than troubling Senator Hill's capacity to cope with all that detail, since it did not bear on any substantive matters before the Senate, I simply gave him the important part of the document and left it to this later process for him to see the whole story. We have not in any way sought to conceal the second thought or the third thought. It simply adds nothing to the first thought.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did Mr Farmer not then contact either Ms Richards or Ms Graham, who apparently were aware of the relevant date according to the advice of Mr Lamb dated 15 May? Is not the real reason the Minister failed to table the document of 15 May that it included the following:

QUESTION.PARA: Ms Graham immediately noted that the letter raised the possibility of the Government of the Marshall Islands having sought Australian Government assistance with the project being promoted by Mr Symons?
In other words, the interpretation that everyone has made of the letter of the President of the Senate, except the President of the Senate and Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but there is no follow up documentation to that. Presumably the outcome of those particular peregrinations that are reported there was the realisation by the officers in question that the kind of interpretation I had been giving to that particular clause in Senator Sibraa's letter was that ultimately accepted by the officers concerned.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that it rapidly became apparent that there had been no such communication by the Marshall Islands Government; that it was simply a slip or a misstatement by the person in Senator Sibraa's office drafting the letter; and that when there was a reference to President Kabua asking the Australian Government, it was manifestly—in the context of that particular letter—in the context of the situation of a reference to the Marshall Islands asking the Australian Government for assistance through the person of Mr Symons standing there asking Senator Sibraa. That is the context obviously in which the thing was written, and Senator Hill is not persuading anybody by chasing these hares down really empty burrows.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Does the Government intend to alter the role of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service to enable it to refuse service to people with disabilities in need of rehabilitation? The reason I ask this today is that I am in receipt of two Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service interoffice memos: the first dated 28 November 1991 and the second dated 12 May 1992. The second of these seeks a way to circumvent `wilful decisions' by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which, to date, has found in favour of anyone who has appealed against a decision not to give them any rehabilitation support. The first talks of a single-minded and active focus on employment as the only acceptable and legitimate outcome of the rehabilitation process. It goes on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . cases must not be managed. . . passively, but must be pushed, bullied and organised with a single minded focus on an employment outcome. . . casemanagers must not be pre-occupied with or distracted by any client or client family issue or problem which does not directly impact on the return to work focus of the program.

Does the Minister agree with the sentiments expressed here by departmental officers, and does the Government intend to make return to employment the only acceptable outcome of the rehabilitation process through the CRS?

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service operates through about 150 community-based centres throughout Australia and does offer rehabilitation programs for Australians. As I understand it, Senator Lees is posing a question as to whether that service is, through its guidelines or through internal memoranda, trying to subvert a decision by the AAT. I think that is a most serious charge. I do not know the exact sequence in dates of any relevant decision by the AAT, though it is true that the AAT has overturned certain decisions by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service not to provide particular rehabilitation programs.

PARA.TAB: In general, though, the answer is that the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service has as a priority the return to work. As I understand it, most clients of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service express that desire. They want to make employment and re-entry into the work force their goal. So there is a mutual coincidence there of the desire of the client and the programs provided by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service.

Non-vocational programs will continue to be provided. In 1991-92 up to today, about 40 per cent of clients have completed non-vocational programs. I do not know exactly what that is in aggregate terms, but it indicates that non-vocational programs are being offered, or have been completed. I think Senator Lees would understand that the existing legislation regulating the activities of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service indicates that the CRS may refuse rehabilitation services if there is no prospect of substantial gain—I take that to be gain measured in some physiological, therapeutic or other way.

Legislation currently before the Parliament to amend the Disability Services Act removes the notion of entitlement and introduces the recognition of resource limitation. I suppose that the sort of memorandum to which the honourable senator is referring, which appears to be rather blunt in terms of management direction, is caught up in the need to prioritise the expenditure of money and the allocation of resources within the Rehabilitation Service.

Quite clearly there is a right of appeal to the AAT. This must be the case—and will continue to be the case—in relation to those instances where a program of rehabilitation is not offered to a person. In light of what I have said, if it is refused on the ground that the only programs to be offered are those which are directed to re-entry to employment, the appeal ought to succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I would just like an assurance that there is no plan to remove the right of appeal to the AAT. I ask the Minister again: what is going to happen to the severely disabled people who seek support through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service?

—As I understand it, the rights of appeal will be retained, both within the CRS structure and then on to the AAT if a person is still dissatisfied. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator O'Chee asked me a question about whether the Government or, in this case, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service was currently reviewing or monitoring the import restrictions on pig semen. An answer has been supplied to me by the Minister for Resources. It is a long answer. I seek leave of the Senate to have this answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: QUESTIONS FROM SENATOR O'CHEE TO SENATOR COOK REGARDING MYSTERY SWINE DISEASE: SENATE—3 JUNE 1992

Is the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service currently reviewing or monitoring import restrictions on pig semen and other breeding material banned because of the possible introduction of mystery swine disease [porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS)] which spread from North America to European countries that also want to export pig semen and other breeding material to Australia? Does the virus causing mystery swine disease survive freezing? Was the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service directed to undertake this review by the Minister for Resources, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy or the Prime Minister?

Yes. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is currently monitoring and reviewing import restrictions on pig semen and other breeding material that have been imposed because of PRRS (mystery swine disease). This task is part of AQIS' ongoing responsibilities to monitor the international occurrence of, spread of and scientific knowledge relating to unwanted diseases, and to review Australia's import requirements in the light of significant developments.

Since PRRS is a relatively newly emerged disease of economic significance overseas, AQIS' monitoring and review processes have been intense. AQIS has, for more than a year now, been actively seeking up to date information from researchers and authorities in countries affected by the disease on a regular basis.

An expert working party has been established at AQIS' request to periodically review developments and provide advice concerning the necessity or otherwise for further action. AQIS has been periodically providing updated advice to industry organisations and other interested parties concerning significant developments and new scientific information of which it has become aware.

The findings and recommendations of the expert working party have been provided to industry and interested parties for consultation and comment. AQIS has instigated several meetings with industry specifically to discuss international developments and its actions concerning PRRS.

Yes. The limited scientific research that has been completed overseas to date has confirmed that the virus of PRRS (mystery swine disease) can survive temperatures between 4 degrees celsius and minus 70 degrees celsius for several months albeit with some apparent reduction in the level of infection. Recent evidence suggests that virus may be excreted in semen of boars for about a week after infection. This supports AQIS action in suspending imports of semen and breeding material from affected countries. The Minister for Resources and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy have been kept fully informed of developments and have supported and encouraged this review work.

The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Departmental files do not indicate whether the then Australian Consul-General in Hong Kong, Mr Geoff Bentley, provided Senator Richardson with an economic briefing on Australian investment in Hong Kong during Senator Richardson's transit of Hong Kong on 25-26 September 1990.

It would be normal practice, however, for the Consul-General or in his absence for a senior officer of the Consulate-General, to have briefed a visiting Minister about Australia's relations with Hong Kong, including trade and investment issues, if the Minister so desired.
Mr Bentley is today en route from Europe to Australia, but my Department has been able to contact him by telephone.

Mr Bentley recalls that, as part of the normal courtesies he extended to visiting Australian Ministers, he gave Senator Richardson an oral briefing, the substantive nature of which would have covered the political and economic situation in Hong Kong, and Australian interests in Hong Kong.

Mr Bentley cannot recall, without recourse to his diary, whether he gave this briefing on 25-26 September 1990 or whether it was given on 7-8 October 1990 when Senator Richardson also transited Hong Kong. A document in my Department, which I can table, indicates that Mr Bentley offered a general briefing to Senator Richardson and it was agreed that the briefing should take place on 8 October.
Such briefings were normally oral, although Mr Bentley sometimes provided his visitors with a simple facts and figures sheet about Hong Kong and Australian interests in that territory.

Mr Bentley does not recall whether he gave Senator Richardson this standard facts and figures sheet. He may have done so. He hopes to be able to provide me with a copy of that sheet on his return to Australia.
Mr Bentley said the facts and figures sheet contained no reference whatsoever either to Mr Symons or to Multiplex.
Mr Bentley has further advised that, to the best of his recollection, he has never discussed either Mr Symons or Multiplex with Senator Richardson, at any time in late 1990, or on any other occasion.

Mr Bentley has advised that there was no operational requirement for him to have kept briefing notes or written minutes of conversations he had with Senator Richardson—nor would I have expected him so to do unless the conversation required follow-up.

A search of documents in my Department has produced communications between the Consulate-General and the Department of Social Security, and between my Department and the Consulate-General in August and September 1990, which relate to Senator Richardson's transiting Hong Kong in September and October of that year. These communications relate primarily to logistics arrangements, hotel bookings, transport and the like. I do not propose to table them.

I am pleased to table copies of two communications which indicate that the Department of Social Services asked the Consul-General to arrange a meeting on 25 August 1990 with the Principal Migration Officer in the Consulate-General to discuss migration issues and the possible impact on the Australian social security system. In the event, Senator Richardson did not transit Hong Kong in August 1990.

A meeting was subsequently arranged for the Principal Migration Officer in the Consulate-General to meet officials travelling with Senator Richardson when he and his party transited Hong Kong on 7-8 October 1990. The Consulate-General has advised that Senator Richardson did not personally attend that meeting between officials.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Durack asked me about a particular conversation that had been referred to by Mr Duffy involving a member of the Attorney-General's Department and a member of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I responded in general terms about that—

I am happy to seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard if that is what Senator Durack wants.
—You are not being dismissive about it?

—No, I am not being dismissive. I am giving Senator Durack a detailed account of the conversation they had at the Deakin High School gymnasium on the morning, chewing over old times together in the Pacific law enforcement business. That is all there is to it. But if Senator Durack wants the detail, there it is.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: SYMONS MATTER: COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN A-G'S DEPT AND DFAT

On 2 June at the request of the Attorney-General's office I prepared a short PPQ brief setting out the full extent of communications between this Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with regard to the Symons matter in the Marshall Islands. For completeness, I noted in the `background' a short conversation I had had on 16 May at a chance meeting on a Saturday morning with a DFAT officer. In Parliament on 2 June 1992 Mr Duffy made a reference to that conversation, and on the following day Senator Durack pressed for further information about it in the Senate. Accordingly, I provide the following further information.

2.The background to the conversation on 16 May was as follows. In September 1991 there was a meeting of South Pacific Forum country officials, including Australia, Fiji and the Marshall Islands, on extradition and other aspects of criminal law enforcement cooperation. That was at Sigatoka, Fiji. I was a member of the Australian delegation, which included David Tough, First Secretary at the Australian Suva Embassy. In that capacity Mr Tough and I discussed various aspects of law enforcement cooperation with which the conference was concerned, including how to deal with a growing number of requests from Pacific Island countries for information about Australian companies and individuals seeking to do business with island governments.

3.On 10 April 1992 when the Symons case in the Marshall Islands first came to the Department's attention, I had made an oral inquiry of the AFP whether there were on foot any proceedings or investigations involving Symons from an Australian police viewpoint. The reply was negative, although I was told that there was some intelligence on file involving Fiji. I did not ask for any details of this.

4.On 16 May, after the Symons matter had received publicity, I met David Tough at Deakin High School in connection with a Saturday morning children's activity. I had not seen Tough since the Fiji conference although I had dealt with him since then on unrelated Pacific law enforcement matters. I learned that Tough was now back in Canberra with DFAT working in the South East Asia area.

5.The conversation on 16 May, so far as relevant, consisted of my asking Tough whether Symons had come to the attention of the Embassy in Suva, during the time Tough had been there, for any activities involving Fiji. Tough said no, although he had known of activities by Symons in the Marshalls—but only because of the involvement of a colleague, the immigration officer in Suva (Holthouse), in a visa matter relating to the Marshalls.

6.There was some further discussion about respective responsibilities of overseas posts for matters involving the Marshalls (where there is no resident representation) and about lines of communication, but I do not have a clear recollection of the details. My purpose in raising the matter had simply been to clear up the loose end concerning Fiji.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone on 4 June 1992 relating to a luncheon.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion refers to my question today concerning a letter that the Minister chose to send to members of the legal profession and prominent members of the financial community, as described by himself, inviting them to a luncheon in Adelaide next week and making entry to the luncheon conditional upon a $45 payment to the ALP.

PARA.TAB: In the Minister's answers to my question and my supplementary question, and in the information he provided following Question Time today, he has in fact ducked the central issue at question. Senator Tate has some ministerial responsibilities, including the canvassing of government legislative proposals and seeking public opinion on them. There is no question about that. But the central issue is: does he understand the difference between his responsibility in that respect and his desire to raise money for the ALP? This responsibility is not to be flirted with and misused simply to raise money for a candidate that Senator Tate made a promise to some time ago, which is in fact what the Minister says is the reason for this lunch.
Mr Acting Deputy President, it might throw some light on the matter if I give you an indication of what the Minister said in his letter. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will be visiting Adelaide on Thursday 11 June and I would like to invite you to be my guest—
I'd love to be someone's guest at $45 a head—
at a luncheon to be held at the Terrace Hotel.

Being a guest and paying $45 is a bit of a misnomer. The Minister goes on to say that a number of policy issues are of interest and that he will be making a certain presentation. In particular, he says that he will be canvassing a number of legislative issues, including the Privacy Act, the Cash Transaction Reports Act and the proposed uniform credit laws. He goes on straight after that and says:
I am particularly interested in hearing a wide cross-section of views on the proposed credit legislation.

On his ministerial letterhead he writes to people saying, `Come to this lunch; I am the Minister responsible. I want to canvass some government legislative issues and the Government wants to hear what you have to say about them'. But he does not have the stomach to say anywhere in the letter, `By the way, it is a fund-raiser for the political party that I belong to'. He let someone attach a little pink slip that says, `Senator Tate's luncheon, PO Box 508, Plympton', with the almost unmentioned words, `Please make cheques payable to the Western Suburbs ALP'.

PARA.TAB: The crucial question that has been put to the Minister, on which he has made no comment at all, is: does he understand the difference between his ministerial responsibilities and his desire to make money for the ALP? Does he understand the risk when those two merge? Has he read anything from the Fitzgerald royal commission about the sorts of problems people get into when the difference between those two responsibilities is misunderstood or when they overtly seek to merge them for their own benefit or for the benefit of their Party? Does the Minister understand those things? He seems to have made no comment about that.

The second point I want to make is that the Minister, in seeking to derive some humour from events that came to the attention of the Fitzgerald royal commission, came in here with a brown paper bag from which he produced the Yellow Pages. He would have us believe—he would succeed only if people had half a brain or a quarter of a brain—that that is where the address list for the legal profession in South Australia came from. The Minister must know that that is not true; if he does believe it is true, he must not have practised law for too long.

The letters are headed `Managing Director'—in this case of Clelands, a firm of which my husband is a partner—`DX163'. I do not know whether Senator Tate has ever practised law. If he has, he would know that DX is a document distribution system run by a crowd called Ausdoc. One has to become a member of Ausdoc to use this system. Instead of posting this legal firm a will and that legal firm a title to property or whatever, one just addresses it to its DX box; it is like a pigeon hole system. But one has to be a member to use it.

The letters that the Minister has sent are addressed to DX163. I do not think the legal profession puts the DX numbers in the Yellow Pages—they are not useful to anyone other than members of the DX system. So the addresses for the legal profession clearly did not come out of the Yellow Pages.

Ausdoc is a national system. The question is: whose membership of Ausdoc did the Minister use to send around this invitation to a party fund-raiser that he, on the face of it, would have everyone believe is an invitation to participate in ministerial consultations? Where did the list of legal practitioners come from? We know that it did not come, as the Minister just said, out of the Yellow Pages. We know that that is not right.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely none of your business.

—Old Lurch interjects and says that it is none of my business. He might like to find something to do with a glad bag, because he obviously does not understand just exactly how much of this chamber's business this is.

PARA.TAB: If a Minister has misused his ministerial entitlements, if he has misused the access the Attorney-General's Department has to the Law Society list, which is not freely given out—I would almost bet London to a brick on that the Minister did not get this from the Law Society; where did he get it?—it raises a serious question about the misuse of funds in the Attorney-General's Department. Has the Attorney-General's Department used its time, its labels and address lists to organise fund-raisers for Mr John Rowe, a former staffer of a former member for Port Adelaide? That is the public policy issue here.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making a goose of yourself. Why don't you sit down?

—If Senator Faulkner does not understand, I hope my simple run-through gives him a glimpse of what we are talking about. I would be grateful if he would button up. I will then finish this more quickly than I will if he keeps interrupting.

PARA.TAB: We know that what the Minister has told us is not true. We know that the address list did not come from the Yellow Pages. If the Minister did not know it before, he certainly knows it now. It is not true. I want to know: where did this list come from and whose membership of Ausdoc has the Minister misused in order to send around this thing that he purports to be ministerial consultations, which is nothing more than a cheap fund-raiser?

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the general question put forward by Senator Vanstone, the fact is that I do not admit to any wrongdoing in addressing this luncheon. As I have said, it arose out of a genuine interest amongst members of the credit providing community in particular in the question of uniform credit legislation throughout Australia. Indeed, it coincided with the interests of the candidate. That has been admitted and it is in the accompanying document. Senator Vanstone has said that herself.

PARA.TAB: The real question is in relation to the list of lawyers. If Senator Vanstone had been listening when I gave my answer she would have heard me say this: some of the lawyers came from a legal directory—a public document. I said that. Senator Vanstone will find it in the Hansard. I believe that that public document is called the Law Calendar and I think it is published by the Law Society of South Australia. I think there may have been interjections when I was speaking so I do not say that Senator Vanstone has deliberately misinterpreted what I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you absolutely denying any involvement of the Attorney-General's Department in your office?

—As far as I know, there was absolutely none. As I understand it, it was compiled in South Australia, not by the Attorney-General's office and not by my personal office. My advice is to that effect—that it was compiled from the Law Calendar, which I understand to be a public document. As I said in my answer, it is the source of the addresses of the various firms of lawyers.
—Whose Ausdoc membership did you misuse?
—I do not admit that there was any misusing of an Ausdoc method of transmitting this material. I am advised that the Law Calendar was the source of the list of lawyers.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
