PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop on 4 June relating to the Marshall Islands documents.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—The President has received a letter from Senator Chamarette proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

In the light of the overwhelming support by other world leaders for the Earth Summit, which commences in Rio de Janeiro today, the necessity for the Senate to express its deep concern at the lack of support shown by the Prime Minister for this important international forum, as illustrated by his decision not to attend, and for his failure to acknowledge the importance of the issues discussed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The many reasons for this matter of the Earth Summit being extremely important are apparent to hundreds of thousands of Australians who reflect and share worldwide concerns being raised in relation to the global environment. Tomorrow is World Environment Day, which is being observed by many environmental and green community groups throughout Australia. On 22 December 1989 the United Nations decided to convene a two-week long United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, referred to as UNCED, in Brazil to coincide with World Environment Day, 5 June 1992, by resolution 44/228.

PARA.TAB: I must correct the wording of my letter to the President. Yesterday, not today, marked the opening of the Earth Summit, which will go for two weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Its agenda will include the following items: an earth charter, which will include the principles for sustainable development, now being referred to as the Rio declaration; agenda 21, which will be an action plan to implement the principles of the earth charter; the signing of an international convention on biodiversity; the signing of an international convention on climate change; and possible agreement on a statement of principles on management of the world's forests.

This is possibly the largest single gathering in world history. The two years of preparation have revealed the priority given to this summit by all major nations in the world. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has let this opportunity for Australia to take its place, and maintain its place, as a world leader on environmental concerns pass us by, due to pragmatic and political involvement at home. One hundred world leaders are attending this conference in Rio, but our Australian Prime Minister is not. Australia is one of 12 countries classified as megadiverse—the only one of these on the north side of the north-south debate. I will dwell on that point later when I refer to the biodiversity convention. Australia has a unique potential for influence and we are not using it.

In October 1991 the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, announced that he was attending UNCED in Rio, but the present Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has decided against attending. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, announced that she would be leading the Australian Government delegation to the Rio summit, accompanied by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, and the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths. Sir Ninian Stephen, leader of the Australian delegation to the preparatory committee meetings, will be a senior participant. A large group of 50 delegates, including State government representatives and non-government members from industry, unions, ACFOA and non-government conservation bodies, as well as the Opposition spokesman on the environment, Mr Chaney, will also be attending the conference. It falls to this delegation to reflect the kind of leadership that I would have hoped our Prime Minister would have given to our particular delegation.
Mr Phillip Toyne from the ACF has pleaded that this delegation take note of certain things. He said in passing:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst unfortunately Prime Minister Keating is not attending the Earth Summit, Australia's delegation should drop the "we will only if everybody else does" rhetoric, and take the lead to ensure full advantage is taken of the unique opportunity to protect our world into the future.

There is abundant recognition of this unique opportunity. In relation to the participation within the delegation, I am sad to report that we have not, even symbolically, given the importance to it that the delegation deserves. I have already mentioned my deep concern that the Prime Minister is not leading this delegation himself.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the membership—and I have already discussed it—we see that there are 27 males, 15 females and seven of unknown ascription of gender attending in this delegation on behalf of Australia. At the most optimistic estimate that the seven unknown delegates are women, we find an imbalance even in our gender basis for representation at that conference. It would make it 27 males to 22 females. When Australia has acknowledged throughout the world that women's impact on development issues is crucial, I think this may well be a reflection on the lack of commitment we are showing to very serious environmental issues.

I am pleased that the opportunity has arisen to discuss the Earth Summit which is currently being held. As I have said before, this summit is by far the most important gathering of the peoples of this planet for many years. If successful, it will provide a framework which can be used to guide us to a more sustainable future. Unfortunately, self-interest and indifference may thwart the opportunities presented by this gathering. Phillip Toyne yesterday issued a media release entitled `Threat to Earth Summit Potential' which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations itself has declared the world now stands at the crossroads with regard to addressing the crucial environmental and development issues. The very survival of the earth as we know it is at stake. Preparatory sessions over the past two years have established solid progress on a framework for international co-operation and action on major issues.

But when it came to the crunch, richer developed nations have failed to make the essential commitment to change their ways, and to encourage and enable poorer developing countries to participate in efforts to protect our world environment and pursue sustainable development.

Even President Bush from the United States is making a token visit to the conference. This visit was referred to by Mr Toyne rather aptly as a photo opportunity. Mr Toyne also took the opportunity to make particular criticism of the United States, which is one of the richest nations on earth and also one of the greatest polluters. He stated:

This lack of commitment is demonstrated, for example, by the refusal of the United States to be bound into reducing greenhouse gas emissions, even though that country alone contributes 25 per cent of carbon dioxide emissions.

PARA.TAB: In the Australian context, the apparent indifference of the Prime Minister to this crucial summit is disappointing. Whilst the leaders of all the major industrialised nations are meeting to discuss ways of saving the planet, our Prime Minister remains in Australia to sort out factional disputes within his own Party and push through some predetermined deals on the airline industry and pay television. When viewed in the context of the planet, and more particularly from the viewpoint of many people living in poverty, this can only be likened to Nero fiddling while Rome burns.

The Labor Government in the past would have been far more ready to respond to and initiate positive actions in relation to environmental issues as reflected in the international treaty for the protection of Antarctica. Both President Bush and the Prime Minister have failed to appreciate the interconnectedness of ecological and economic issues. What is required is a fundamental reappraisal of our lifestyles and consequently a greater appreciation by policy makers of the link between ecological and economic imperatives.

The other important issue that arises out of the Earth Summit is the relationship between developing and industrialised nations in the context of repairing environmental damage. It is ironic that at this time in the history of human development, when technology has effectively diminished the size of the planet, we are at the same time beginning to appreciate that our lifestyle and technology is causing global and environmental problems of great significance. Whether we are talking about greenhouse gases, ozone depletion or acid rain, the fact remains that no-one can escape from the consequences of our collective actions. The planet really is very small and fragile.

I am in no doubt that the various conventions that are being discussed will be raised by Senator Coulter from the Democrats as he also pursues this topic. But I would stress that our involvement in a positive way in response to the climate convention is commendable. We still need to maintain our leadership status in that regard. The bio-diversity strategy, as I mentioned before, is one where we are holding back by not being properly represented. Mega-diverse status means that, with 11 other countries, we hold 60 to 70 per cent of the world's species; all other 11 countries are developing nations.

Australia has a very important contribution to make to the north-south debate on environmental concerns. As I stated at the commencement of this speech, I find it disappointing that, when the opportunity for progress towards the sort of international agreements referred to is being negotiated, our Prime Minister remains in Australia to work on what are, in context, relatively inconsequential and passing issues. I therefore urge the Prime Minister to reconsider his position to attend the Earth Summit and, if he does so, to take a lead in promoting the development of international agreements that will work towards a truly sustainable future for the planet.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for the debate today and that the speaking times during the debate will be as follows: as Senator Chamarette had 10 minutes, Senator Loosely as the Government speaker will get 10 minutes; Senator Brownhill as the Opposition speaker, 10 minutes; and then Senator Coulter as the Democrat speaker, 10 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, retrospectively of course, I have asked the clerks to set the clock at 10 minutes per speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take issue with the propositions advanced by Senator Chamarette in this debate on a matter of public importance, although there is much by way of the remarks she made earlier with which I am in very considerable agreement. If we look at the terms of the MPI as advanced by Senator Chamarette, much of what has been introduced in the proposition is fair comment. There is no doubt, for example, that the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro does enjoy overwhelming, very broad support internationally, and there is no doubt also that the conventions that are being discussed, the detail of the work, is of great significance for humanity. I have no disagreement with that at all.

PARA.TAB: However, I make the point that the Earth Summit ought not to be seen as the end product of international effort and endeavour in regard to the global environment. It ought to be seen as a way station in that process. The fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is not able to attend in no way reflects a lack of acknowledgment, interest or commitment in the matters that are before the gathering. I therefore argue that Senator Chamarette's criticism of the Prime Minister in this regard is unfair, particularly when we judge the Australian Government's record in environmental protection, safeguards and, I think it is fair to say, achievement. I think it is also unfair, given the Government's considerable policy initiatives over the past few weeks.

If we look very briefly at the record of the Labor Government over recent years in protecting not only the Australian environment but also the international environment, I think we will see that it stands the most rigorous analysis, and by that I mean the most rigorous comparative analysis by international standards. Let us look at the record in terms of moving towards ecologically sustainable development; what the Government has been able to achieve on the priceless question of World Heritage listings, such as not allowing mining at Coronation Hill, for example, and protection of the Kakadu National Park environments; what we have been able to accomplish as a government virtually down the east coast of Australia and in Tasmania; our achievements in protecting endangered species through the endangered species program; our establishment of the wildlife protection unit; our response on issues of land degradation; our move specifically to broaden and consolidate the protection of the Great Barrier Reef; the landmark achievement in cooperation with the French, in particular, on Antarctica; and a whole range of issues locally and internationally. From that record we can see that the Government has been very forthright in its commitment and has moved in the face of considerable opposition from our political opponents in the Liberal and National parties and from some sections of the community.

This has not been an easy war that has been waged to protect the Australian environment and to move internationally. That is also true of moves to try to improve the urban environment through initiatives on greenhouse gases and the ozone layer, on waste minimisation, on recycling and on industrial chemicals and hazardous waste. The list, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you are aware, is very long and, indeed, impressive.

There has been no failure on the part of the Prime Minister to acknowledge the significance of the issues that are being debated in Rio. As a matter of fact, I think it is fair to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in the background to UNCED Australia has been very active in various international forums on climate change, both scientific forums and political forums. We are heavily involved in the climate change worker bodies such as the Inter-governmental Panel on Climate Change, the IPCC; the international geosphere and biosphere program; and the World Meteorological Organisation. The record there speaks for itself. There is no question about the commitment of the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Prime Minister get involved in this?

—I will take the interjection from Senator Chamarette because there really is a threshold question there. The threshold question is simply this: would Senator Chamarette prefer Prime Minister Keating to be in Rio with the environmental record of George Bush, Helmut Kohl and John Major; or the potential environmental record of John Hewson, Peter Reith and Tim Fischer?
—Or being pushed around in Australia by Chris Schacht!
—Being pushed around at home—

—I think the response will be that Australians prefer the environmental achievement of the Hawke and Keating periods over what is likely to loom. I note the vexed reaction from Senators Brownhill and Macdonald on environmental questions, because after industrial relations and tax policies the coalition is most vulnerable on the environment.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the Prime Minister's statement in the House just recently in response to a question from the Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, the Prime Minister put matters in context—the context of the last few weeks of extraordinary political initiative. It is a political climate in which the Government has been working on some very significant issues. I am not referring now only to the changes in aviation policy; I am also referring, of course, to the changes in communications policy that were announced in the last 24 hours or so—which will be landmark changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which version? First, second, third, fourth or fifth?
—The Government's policy initiatives. They will be absolutely landmark policy changes for people living in remote areas of Australia.

PARA.TAB: But there are also very important initiatives being discussed with the States in terms of technical and further education. In the case of some States there has been considerable cooperation; in the case of other States they really need to come to the party. These are very important matters that are on the public agenda in Australia at the moment.

I think it is useful to put that in the context of the alternative, which was for the Prime Minister to go to Rio de Janeiro to, as he told the House of Representatives, deliver a prepared six-minute address in support of a protocol which was going to be signed, regardless of his presence—a protocol which did not go as far as the Australian Government wanted to see it go. Senator Chamarette has the courtesy to nod agreement on that. Neither is it a protocol that would receive universal acclaim opposite. Quite the contrary would be the case.

I am always interested to hear the coalition talking about the environment. It reminds me of Leonid Brezhnev's speeches where he used to endorse peace. The coalition comes very late to the equation. As a matter of fact, at the moment it is difficult to read any Opposition position at all on environmental questions. We are taking all these matters into context, including the capacity, already announced by Australia, to sign the UNCED biological diversity convention. That has already been made absolutely clear.

The delegation that we have sent to Rio de Janeiro is a very capable delegation consisting of Ministers Kelly, Griffiths and Kerin. Of course, the Australian delegation overall includes a significant ambassadorial and State presence. There is no doubt at all that the Australian presence will be registered.

It is true—and I think it is useful to reinforce this in the Senate this afternoon—that Australia would have liked to have seen more achieved prior to Rio and at Rio in terms of the protocols being signed. We have made that absolutely clear. It is to be hoped, seeing Rio de Janeiro as a way station, that more can be achieved in this regard. The Prime Minister had to make a reasoned decision. He took a balanced decision—balancing out domestic concerns as against what would be achieved in Rio de Janeiro. I hope the conference is highly successful in that respect.

Perhaps if the protocols had been stronger and more effective, and if greater determination had been shown by a number of other countries, particularly by the United Kingdom and the United States, the prime ministerial decision would have been different. I think we have to measure substance against shadow sometimes—and I am talking about some of those who will be attending there rather than about the Australian domestic context. We have to measure the record against the rhetoric. I am happy to measure the record of this Labor Government against the rhetoric of those opposite and against the rhetoric of some attending.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not in dispute with this matter of public importance raised by Senator Chamarette. The UN Earth Summit has been hailed as the world's biggest and most important meeting on global environmental problems and ecologically sustainable development. One hundred and fifty other nations thought it of sufficient import to support it at the highest levels. Leaders such as US President George Bush, British Prime Minister John Major and the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, all feel that this conference is of such vital concern to the future of the earth that they have found the time to attend.

PARA.TAB: Australia's former Prime Minister—maybe the one that Senator Loosley, who is now leaving, did not vote for—agreed with his world colleagues, because Mr Hawke endorsed the conference warmly, claiming it was a crucial forum for the development of greater international cooperative efforts in solving the world's environmental problems. He planned to lead Australia's delegation.

However, Australia's current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is different. He believes he knows better and that his time is far too important to waste talking with these particular world leaders. So Australia is sending a delegation of 49 rather than 50. Obviously, what we lack in quality we will make up for in quantity.

When we look down the list of just who is going, our sentiments range from fear to anger. In the same week that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has been forced to publicly admit that she actually had not got around to reading an environment kit she so warmly endorsed twice, she is leading this delegation to Rio where it is likely she will have the opportunity to not read the great stack of material that will be put in front of her. I suggest that, if she had difficulty finding sufficient concentration powers to read the schools kit, the agenda papers for this conference will leave her right out of the discussions. In fact, she will be way out.

Moving down the list, we see that the next delegate is John Kerin, the man who, when he was Treasurer, could not explain his own press releases. Then we have Alan Griffiths, the real friend of the foresters and forests who could not even get his views past his own colleagues in his Cabinet. So he would be as real a winner for us in Rio as we could ever get.

Next we have Mrs Susan Lenehan, the South Australian Environment Minister, known locally in South Australia as the mouth from the south. Her ability to apply herself to portfolio detail is on a par with that of Mrs Kelly. She too has a great ambition for self-stardom. They should be a pretty good combination, I would suggest.

This caravan of revellers is off to Rio on the public purse, at a cost of $1m, to make decisions that could seriously affect Australia's standing in the world and its ability to be competitive in that world. If it were not so serious it would be funny. The reality is that this conference could result in conventions which affect Australia's competitiveness. It could result in a large transfer of funds from the North to the South without any real benefit. It could be an acrimonious contest between the developed and the developing world. Clearly, while Australia's position in Rio ought not to be industry driven, it must be industry sensitive.

The coalition's representation in this delegation—thankfully he is there to bring some sanity to the debate—is Mr Fred Chaney. He put the coalition's view very succinctly last week when he quoted four principles. I seek leave to have those principles incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Chaney MP

.the caveats relating to international competitiveness and national interest espoused with respect to greenhouse emissions should be applied to any commitments Australia considers entering into at Rio
.devising and administering environment protection laws are matters within the jurisdiction of our own Government
.Australia's parlous economic situation renders it essential to pursue development while maintaining high environmental standards
.the extent of foreign aid devoted to environmental programmes abroad is a matter for decision by the Australian Government

TALK.START.PARA: —He said that Australia's approach must be consistent with our own high environmental standards and the ongoing need to achieve sustainable development. Of particular concern are the two conventions on climate change and biodiversity. These are legal treaties carrying legal obligations.

PARA.TAB: The convention on climate change is significant for Australia. As a major coal producer we are vulnerable to any change in international climate change policies. We are also sensitive to the need to address global warming issues. Cabinet has already agreed to the signing of this convention, which commits industrialised and emerging former communist nations to limit greenhouse gas emissions. The Opposition has expressed concern that we ought not to be committed to any convention in which we would disproportionately bear the brunt. We are concerned that the Government may well be locking us into an agreement that will impact on Australia's efficiency and competitiveness. In many ways we more closely resemble a developing nation than a developed nation but in international agreements we are regarded, of course, as a developed nation.

Australian business has expressed similar concern, and it needs to be listened to. ACIL Australia quite recently announced the results of two studies which suggest that the cost of Australia's commitment under this convention would be two or three times higher than previously estimated and more costly to Australia than to any other country. The report found that Australia would lose 10 times more in GDP than the United States, eight times more than the European Community, and 40 times more than Canada, which has a similar economy.

Too often people and groups fail to recognise the simple principle that it costs money to save the earth. If the economy is not sound, if business is not viable and strong, then environmental obligations cannot be paid for. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who is at the table, said that himself. We have to be able to afford to pay to look after our environment.

The Australian Government of which Senator Button is a part has claimed that its endorsement of all proposals before the summit would be contingent upon domestic economic circumstances. That is all well and good, but does the delegation we have sent to Rio have the capacity or the clout to push that or any agenda for Australia? I suggest it does not have the clout; nor does it have the capacity to push those issues in that forum. How will our three go against the Bushes and the Majors of the world? If our people do not have the clout or the ability, why are we even bothering to send them?

I do not often endorse sentiments expressed by the Australian Conservation Foundation, but its Executive Director, Phillip Toyne, summed up the coalition's attitude very well when he said this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: A hundred other heads of government are going, including some of the biggest nations on earth.

PARA.TAB: I think that it sends the wrong signals to the international community about the way in which we are treating the event.

SPEECH.PARA: He was talking about the Prime Minister not going. I suppose that is not much different from the fact that the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, did not even bother to attend the children's summit at the United Nations the year before last. Mr Hawke was really missed and the Government sent along Senator Evans in his stead.

PARA.TAB: The status of Australia's delegation signals to the world either that we are prepared to accept whatever the rest of the world feels we ought to pay or, perhaps worse, that we really do not give a hang for what the world thinks. That is another indictment of the fact that the Prime Minister is not there.

A country the size of Australia, with such a dependence on trade, simply cannot afford to give those sorts of impressions to anyone. If this delegation is an example of the Prime Minister having a two-way bet, he has picked the wrong horse. If he thought he would make less of a fool of himself by not going than by going, he has made a mistake, and Australia and the rest of the world will judge him poorly for it. I finish by quoting what my Leader in the other place said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's that?
—Mr Tim Fischer. He said about Mr Keating's non-appearance at the conference:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Keating . . . had `cheapened' the conference and `sold short all the conference stood for'.

PARA.TAB: `The real action is not only the formal sessions,'. . . `It's the interactions between conference delegates who are heads of States and bilateral meetings on the edge of the conference.'

SPEECH.PARA: What a great opportunity we would have had if the Prime Minister had had the guts to go instead of staying back here trying to look after all his factions, as Senator Chamarette said. We condemn the Prime Minister for his shameful disrespect for the world's leaders and his shameful waste of Australian taxpayers' money in sending what could best be described as the Second XI.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Chamarette and to point out that the non-attendance by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the Rio conference is simply indicative, if another indication were necessary, of the very low priority this Government and, indeed, the Opposition have given to the environment. I think we have heard enough in the debate this afternoon to underline very heavily that lack of concern.

PARA.TAB: We have heard from both sides of this chamber—we heard it just now from Senator Brownhill—that it costs money to save the earth, that we must look after the economy so that we have money to look after the environment. There is this peculiar idea that the environment is dependent upon the economy. They are such ignoramuses that they do not even understand that it is the other way round: that the economy is fundamentally dependent upon a vital, continuing and viable environment. If we do not look after the environment we will have no economy whatsoever.

One could go back in time and say that both the Labor Party and the Opposition in this place are really in a pre-Darwinian time warp. I am reminded of the debates that occurred between Bishop Wilberforce and Thomas Huxley at the time of the publication of On the Origin of Species. The argument then was that mankind—and I apologise to Senator Chamarette for using the term—was somehow above the environment and somehow separate from the rest of the `creation'.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are part of it.

—Precisely; we are part of it, we are dependent upon it, and if we do not look after it we will simply be the next species to become extinct. Repeatedly in this place we hear debates that are based on the absolute falsehood that we can take the subset of the human economy and apply the principles that have been derived from the sub-sub-subset of the totality of living experience on the face of this planet broadly to the environment. It is a logical stupidity.

PARA.TAB: In moving a notice of motion today, I drew attention to the fact that last year the mala, the rufous hare wallaby, became extinct on the mainland of Australia. Australia has a shocking record of extinction of species, and for Senator Loosley to say that we have a good record in this sphere is not true. For seven years, successive Labor governments have promised to introduce national, comprehensive, Federal legislation to protect endangered species. It was promised again for this session of Parliament. We are yet to see that legislation. The amount of money being spent in that area is absolutely paltry. It will go nowhere to reverse the incredibly bad record that Australia has—in terms of the extinction of species it has one of the worst records in the world.

In relation to greenhouse gas reduction, Senator Loosley again mentioned Australia's membership of the IPPC. On two separate occasions the scientific committee of the IPPC has said that we need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent as rapidly as possible; that is its recommendation. What have we heard from the Government? We have been told that it might reduce the greenhouse gas emissions from Australia by 20 per cent if it does not cost very much.

Yesterday, Senator Button sought to rubbish the suggestion that we might move more firmly in this direction by pointing to the coal industry and the aluminium industry. While the rest of the world will progressively demand less and less coal because of its concern about the greenhouse effect, this Government, aided and abetted by the Opposition, would lock us into a situation where we spend most of our energy research funds on coal. It would invest large amounts in mines for the exploitation of coal—a commodity which is attracting a lower and lower price per tonne on world markets—and lock us into further environmental damage and into a situation where most of our investment funds will go into industries that are not sustainable in the long run, even on economic grounds. The Government has failed to recognise that the economy is underscored by these environmental matters and that we must pay attention to environmental matters first and not afterwards.

It is important for Australia to take a leadership role. We find a good example of that when we look at the actions of Senator Chamarette's predecessor in relation to the Antarctic. It will be recalled that when Jo Vallentine first moved in this place that Australia should not sign the CRAMRA agreement and should seek a World Park status for the Antarctic, the motion, which was supported by the Democrats, was opposed by both the Government and the Opposition. A few weeks later Mr Howard was up in Queensland and must have had some strange feeling that there were votes in being seen to be green, as he suggested that the Opposition might change its view. The Opposition came back about a fortnight later and suggested that the Antarctic might be saved. We had a further debate after which the Opposition, the Democrats and Senator Vallentine voted together. Again, the Government voted against the motion on the grounds that Australia alone could not do very much. Several weeks later the Government did a backflip and said, `Yes, we will try'. What has happened since? We now have a 50-year agreement in relation to the protection of the Antarctic.

Australia can play a very important role. I believe that Australia should play an even more important role, namely, a leadership role. It is simply untrue that we cannot meet the very, very modest greenhouse targets that have been suggested—the 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gases—without damage to the economy. We can meet those targets and do better, and at the same time develop in Australia technologies and industries which the rest of the world will need.

Yesterday we debated a Bill which seeks to amend the Ozone Protection Bill. In that debate I pointed out that we should be developing an alternative refrigeration industry and moving the technology quite aggressively into Asia and many other under-developed countries. It is a technology which does not cause ozone depletion or lead us up blind alleys by using HCFCs or HFCs. It is one which is based on a quite old technology but one which is well developed here. It is a technology in which again we can lead the world.

It is simply untrue, as the Government and the Opposition try to maintain, that we must balance protection of the environment against protection of the economy. We can do both. Until the Government and the Opposition recognise that both those objectives can be achieved, and until they turn the rhetoric around and look after the environment first in a way that supports alternative industries, we will continue to see a rundown in our environment, as is well-shown in the recent publication by the Bureau of Statistics, which was the basis of my question yesterday to Senator Button. He castigated the Department for their statistics—

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I castigated you for your use of them. I have nothing against the statistics.
—Senator Button certainly did. I quoted the statistics exactly from that book.
—They are right—but you were wrong.

—The statistics indicate that Australia is moving further and further away from sustainability, guided by a government of which Senator Button is part. He does not understand the first thing about sustainability or about environmental protection. Moreover, he wilfully does not care—he does not give a damn about the environment. Senator Button has a peculiar, anachronistic view of the economy which is leading the Government down a destructive road, both in terms of the environment—(Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—That concludes the debate on the matter of public importance.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EIGHTY-SEVENTH INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION CONFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the eighty-seventh Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union held in Yaounde, Republic of Cameroon, during April 1992, together with two documents relating to women in politics which were distributed at the conference.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO POLAND, CZECHOSLOVAKIA, BULGARIA AND HUNGARY

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Hungary during July and August 1991.

PARA.TAB: I have been fortunate to have had the privilege to lead two delegations to east and central Europe in recent years. The first was in July 1989, immediately prior to the collapse of communism in most countries of the region. This delegation visited the four countries last July, following the downfall of their communist regimes. This provided an excellent reference point for monitoring the changes which are occurring so rapidly in the region.

The delegation met the leaders of each country—in most cases the President, Prime Minister and Foreign Minister. In Poland we met President Lech Walesa, leader of Solidarity, and a leading figure in history as the man who began the fight against communism which led to its downfall. The success of Solidarity encouraged public expressions of opposition by dissident movements in the other countries of the region.

The political and economic problems facing each of the countries cannot be over-estimated. Lech Walesa put it succinctly when he told us that he much regretted that there was no historic blueprint for the conversion from a communist command system to a market economy. Each country now faces a catch 22. Without a stable political environment, foreign investors will be discouraged: without foreign investment to assist in the funding of economic recovery, political instability is bound to continue.

The evidence of a depressed economy is nowhere more evident than in Lodz, a large industrial centre in central Poland. Incidentally, Lodz is the birthplace of Senator Spindler, who I am sure will want to contribute regarding the delegation's visit there. In Lodz we saw block after block of factories which had closed down. Unemployment exceeds 30 per cent. The social and political consequences of such high levels of unemployment weigh heavily on the country's leaders.

Lodz used to be the main centre in Poland for the processing of Australian wool. Our market in Poland for wool has collapsed. The city is perhaps typical of the plight of industry throughout eastern Europe. Its manufacturing plant and processes are outmoded and inefficient. Without substantial investment in new plant and technology, there is little prospect that Polish industries can successfully compete in world markets. Without investment, there are no funds to purchase raw materials or to provide jobs. It is a downward spiral.

One of the disastrous legacies of the communist regimes has been the destruction of the environment. The promotion of heavy industry—fuelled mainly by the inefficient burning of brown coal—has caused high levels of polluted air and has poisoned rivers. Forests have been destroyed by acid rain. However, there does seem to be a commitment by the current governments to try to solve these problems. For example, in Hungary the delegation visited the regional environment centre for central and eastern Europe, which is dedicated to this purpose.

The safety of the Soviet-built reactors in the nuclear power stations dotted throughout eastern Europe is cause for great concern. For example, still operating in Bulgaria is one of the world's—if not the world's—most dangerous nuclear power plant. The authorities are aware of the danger, but, such is their desperate need for electricity, the reactors simply cannot be closed down unless there is massive Western assistance in the provision of alternative sources of energy.

In all the countries there is a general commitment to the development of a market economy. However, there are significant difference between political parties and the countries themselves regarding the nature and pace of such change. There is no doubt that economic reforms are, and will continue to be, painful. There is concern that loss of faith in the benefits to be won from reform may result in the return to power of the communists. This is not an unjustified fear. After recent elections in Poland, the renamed communists are the second largest party in the Parliament, and in the second free election held in Bulgaria the communists were only narrowly defeated.

The disintegration of the Soviet Union has had a marked impact on east and central Europe. Most of the former Soviet satellites were dependent on the Soviet Union for more than 50 per cent of their trade. That trade has now evaporated. Not only have the countries to change their political focus, but also they have to change their trade relationships. Those we met in each country were strong in their conviction that they must gain full membership of the European Community as soon as possible. While Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary have been granted a phased associate membership of the EC, it is likely that full membership will not be granted quickly or easily. There is certainly no shortage of countries wishing to be members of the EC.

The long years of communist domination served to contain simmering nationalist rivalries among the various ethnic groups in each country. With the downfall of the communist governments and the lifting of social repression, ethnic tensions have come to the surface. In some cases those tensions have boiled over—as has occurred in Yugoslavia and several former Soviet republics.

Hungary's interest in the Hungarian minority in Romania continue to strain relations between those two countries. Czechoslovakia is threatened with partition by calls for Slovak independence. Elections to be held throughout Czechoslovakia this Saturday will indicate the future direction of the country in this respect. Ethnic tensions throughout the region make the implementation of political and economic reforms all the more difficult.

On a brighter note, I was amazed by the obvious benefits of the changes since my previous visit. Three years ago in Prague, for example, there was a general air of repression, despondency and resentment. The change in the meantime has been remarkable. Shops are open and well-stocked, tourists are everywhere and the pervading atmosphere is of a city coming back to life.

With so much to offer, tourism will certainly play a major role in the recovery of the countries we visited. It will bring benefits both as a direct source of foreign exchange and by encouraging foreign investment in tourist facilities. It will also provide employment in the construction and operation of hotels and other tourist services. Strangely, however, many of those to whom we spoke seemed not so impressed by the potential of tourism.

In all places we visited, Australia was well regarded. Our reputation as a destination for migrants and as a haven for displaced persons following the Second World War and subsequent political crises is well known. Australia's assistance thus far has been small, but I believe well-targeted. Australia is a member of the OECD Group of 24 which co-ordinates economic assistance to eastern Europe to sustain the momentum of the reforms. We have taken a one per cent shareholding in the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, representing a grant of $45m over 5 years.

In 1990 we also established a $5m training program for east and central Europe under which participants from several countries undertake training in Australia in management and related areas. The success of this program has led to its expansion this year with a revised budget of $9.5m.

It will be important for exchange visits by parliamentarians, Ministers, officials and business groups to continue to ensure that the good relations are maintained. To ignore the plight of east and central Europe during its current difficulties will be to our long term cost. I believe we are on the right track in this regard. As honourable senators would remember, only last week we received visits from delegations from Poland and Romania. Amongst others, we have also received visits from Chairman Dubcek, the President of the Polish Senate, the Polish Foreign Minister and the Hungarian Minister for Education.

I wish to acknowledge the valuable contributions made during the visit by all members of the delegation: Senator Panizza and Senator Spindler, and our colleagues from the House of Representatives, the Deputy Leader of the delegation, the Hon. Michael MacKellar, the Hon. Laurie Brereton, Dr Richard Charlesworth, Mr Noel Hicks and the Hon. Stewart West. During a very full and tiring program—so ably arranged for us by the parliaments of each country, assisted by their diplomatic representatives in Australia—we were fortunate to be accompanied throughout the visit by Mrs Brereton, Mrs Hicks, Mrs Panizza, Mrs Spindler and Mrs West.

On behalf of the delegation, I express our appreciation of the assistance in planning the visit by the Parliamentary Relations Office, particularly Keiran Schneemann and Dalma Dixon, and during the visit by the Australian Ambassador in each country and his staff—despite the difficulties of small posts and limited resources. My thanks also go to the delegation secretary, Rob Alison, and to my own staff members, Fred Peppinck and Julie Hatcher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment briefly on the report of the parliamentary delegation to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Hungary. I felt privileged for two reasons to be a member of that delegation. Firstly, we are certainly aware of the momentous changes that are taking place in eastern Europe at the moment as the countries in that region are struggling to emerge from the long years under a socialist regime and to move towards an individualistic and free market economy.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, as the President has mentioned, it gave me an opportunity to see Lodz again, the town of my birth. More than that, due to the courtesy of the leader of the delegation and Polish officials, it was possible for me to actually find the house in which I was born and visit the factory that my grandfather occupied decades ago as part of the textile industry in Lodz, which was established 200 years ago by German migrants contracted by the King of Poland to do just that.

That leads me straight away to the issues we were considering. When we visited a textile factory, after looking at the cloth they produced, which was superb in quality, we engaged some of the staff in questions on marketing. We found that they were almost totally ignorant of markets in the West, how to handle exports and what prices they could obtain. I certainly came away with the view that they had a long way to go.

One of the thoughts that was in my mind throughout the visit by the delegation, and which took hold even on that first day, is that I wish them well in those endeavours, in particular in finding the right balance between a market economy and the human values of social support, without which a civilised society cannot exist. As I watched them, they were talking about and sometimes acting as though they were going helter-skelter into a totally deregulated community, and I thought of the debates in this Parliament to find just such a balance. I hope that they will not throw out the baby with the bath water.

I also recall our meeting with the Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee of Foreign Affairs in Poland, Mr Geremek, who forecast that there would be a multi-party model in existence in Poland before long. I note in the report some concerns expressed by the members of the delegation about the electoral system to be used—the proportional system. I do not share their concerns. I commend this system to the Senate and, indeed, to Australia.

There are two national treasures in Hungary that I would like to name. One of them is the refurbished Parliament House, which is a superb example of architecture and decoration. The other is a person, Mr John Charody, who is an Australian of Hungarian extraction and our Austrade representative in Hungary. Watching Mr Charody operate in Hungary and listening to the comments offered about him, I could not think of a better person to represent Australia's trading and economic interests in Hungary.

One other person I wish to mention is Mr Imre Pozsgay. Mr Pozsgay was a politician during the socialist regime, but was instrumental in opening the borders to people who wanted to cross them within Europe. I think it was this action of opening the Hungarian borders which precipitated the falling of the wall in Berlin. Mr Pozsgay is a survivor. I was glad to see him there. It is individuals such as Mr Pozsgay who are prepared to take risks who will lead Europe into a better future.

In Bulgaria it struck me that, while it was certainly the most backward country economically, it had an interesting political process. Bulgaria had three different governments in almost as many years. It did not happen as a result of a revolution or elections. What happened was that people took to the streets, those in government got the message and resigned, and other people took their places. Bulgaria will be one of the most vibrant countries in Europe soon. One of the highlights of the trip to Bulgaria was our trip to Plovdiv, an ancient town where we saw recently excavated Roman ruins and, on the way back, we visited the Bachkovo Monastery, which gave us the message that one does not need a lot of money to be happy and lead a worthwhile life.

Czechoslovakia gives the indication even now, after a long period of stagnation, of being a nation that can uphold with a degree of vigour its cultural and intellectual tradition—a position it has occupied in Europe for many years. The fact that the Czechs can elect a philosopher and writer, Mr Havel, as their President, gives some idea of the orientation of the population as a whole. Our visit to the university in Prague bore witness to that. Also, I had great pleasure in greeting again here in Australia the present Ambassador, Her Excellency Yara Mozorova, whom we met during our trip to Czechoslovakia. It should be noted that she, too, is an academic and, apart from being a surgeon, a translator of some note.

It is also worthwhile noting that in Slovakia, the other part of the Czech Republic, we saw and heard that the large armament factories geared up to produce thousands of tanks were trying somewhat desperately to turn weapons into ploughshares, but not finding it particularly easy. In fact, on one occasion they had been urged by a delegation of Americans—and I am not sure whether they were businessmen or representatives of the Government—to continue with their production of tanks. Personally, I have great confidence that the Czechs will have more sense than that.

Mr President, at this stage I wish to pay tribute to the sensitive leadership and the insistence on organisation that you brought to this delegation. Without that leadership and sensitivity, and without your contacts in Europe, we would not have had the access to the top levels of government that we had which made this trip worth while at that, and also the social, levels. Even my old sparring partner, Senator Panizza, and I got on famously after the first day or two, and the feeling of cooperation and good sense prevailed throughout that delegation's visit.

I would be remiss if I did not mention Rob Alison, Fred Peppinck and Julie Hatcher who supported us well at all times, as did the ambassadors and the staff of our embassies. As you said, Mr President, the embassies are somewhat under-resourced, but they never failed to provide us with the services that we need.

I close by adding two comments. I have already made one comment—that a balance needs to be found between social concerns and a market economy. The second concerns the depth of environmental degradation, and solutions must be found for that. I look with some hope to the future of Europe, particularly as I read last week that France and Germany had created a joint army corps. That augurs well for the future of Europe and we can look forward to a future that is not as blood drenched as was the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will speak briefly to your report of the parliamentary delegation to Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Hungary. I will deal with the points of interest that I found in Eastern Europe. All the other points relating to the new-found democracy have been covered by you and Senator Spindler, so I will briefly state my interest in the fields of agriculture, transport and housing.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you know, but others may not, that I was surprised at the differences between the state of agriculture of the four countries we visited. Having spent 45 years under communism, one would think that the advancement of agriculture, secondary industry and any other industry in those countries would be roughly the same. However, they were as diverse as the numbers of places we visited.

I was surprised to see how advanced the agriculture of Poland is and what a fertile country it is. Perhaps I was neglectful in not reading up on a lot of that stuff before I went. I was very surprised that, having had 45 years of communism, the Polish have developed agriculture to where it now is—and that is allowing for the fact that they have run mostly communes, state owned farms or whatever term one chooses. Wheat growing is fairly well advanced, with modern varieties and, surprisingly, modern machinery and methods.

We visited a state farm not far from Warsaw which employs 115 people in all. While talking to the experts that day we could see what they were producing. They were productive—they had modern varieties of cereals and other horticultural products—but they would not have been making a great profit from the place because of its overemphasis on labour.

I was also surprised at the level of education of farm workers and farm operators at that place. Even under communism, the Polish have made a certain advancement. One thing I did find throughout eastern Europe is how educated the people are compared to what I thought they might have been under 45 years of communism. Communism probably supplied employment to those countries—everyone seemed to have a job. That is part of the dogma of communism. Communism also provided a fair share of the advancement of education.

Poland was well up with current trends in agriculture. There is also a big swing back to privatising the land. Families that used to own land are encouraged to reclaim their old holdings, if they are interested in them, and restart private enterprise farming. They are very interested in doing so and are, in fact, doing it. In Czechoslovakia the advancement of agriculture is not quite as great as in Poland. There is not the great interest in returning to private farming that there is in Poland. The Czechs' attitude is, `We have the big government farms, what's the use of breaking them down?'. Nevertheless, their production seemed to be quite okay.

The delegation then moved to Bulgaria, which was like moving back 60 years in terms of agriculture and almost everything else. Strip farming was still the norm and donkeys were pulling carts. There were 30 or 40 people working together on strip farming the fields. To me it was very depressing. Probably 50 or 60 years ago the Bulgarians were reasonably advanced in their agriculture, but they have obviously let it go backwards. For example, just driving along the highways one could see that those farms must have lacked fertiliser for the last 45 or 50 years under communism. Fences were disappearing or non-existent. The farms were totally backward and it must be very depressing to work in such an environment. The last country we visited was Hungary. I believe that agriculture there is pretty well advanced in terms of modern methods and modern machinery. As you pointed out, Mr President, Hungary is almost a westernised country and there are plenty of well-stocked shops in the cities.

The other area which I am very interested in is housing, whether it be single housing or condominium housing. In Poland, Bulgaria and, to a certain extent, Czechoslovakia I found big concrete housing blocks which were nothing but pigeon holes. From memory, each was 10 to 15 stories high and 100 to 200 metres long. Such structures, three or four deep, continued for many kilometres. That would be a very depressing environment to live in.

We were told a story about children starting school. The teacher told them to draw a car, but they drew it as a plan—in other words, looking down at it from above. Unfortunately, without open spaces for these children to play in before school days, they are only able to view such things from above, in their homes. That is the sort of concept that came through. It was very depressing. I certainly hope that it will not be too many years before they have different housing from what they now have.

As Senator Spindler pointed out, while we were in Poland we visited a wool mill. Even though the most modern piece of machinery was at least 30 years old, it was putting out a good product. The Polish do not have the money to set up new factories. However, I can see an opportunity for joint ventures between, for example, Australia, which has the wool and a big stockpile; Poland, which has the willing labour to work those factories; and Japan or Italy, which have the technology to build a modern wool factory. We could get together in a tripartite joint venture and set up something like that. That certainly could develop as a result of the trip.

We spoke to members of the governments of these countries and they all told us that they would get their economies going again when Russia can buy again. A lot has happened to Russia in the last 12 months, so it is not really in a position to help out these other countries. After 45 years of communism I just could not believe that they still want anything to do with the USSR. One after another, they said, `If only Russia can start buying again, our economy will pick up'. I am afraid that with events in Russia over the last 12 months, they will have to look in other directions to get their economies going.

In conclusion, I appreciated the cooperation amongst the eight delegates and their wives and the back-up advisers from the President's staff. Relationships could have become very strained, but in a delegation like that it is marvellous how much common ground people can find. Senator Spindler and I could not be further apart in ideology, but we found some common ground. I appreciated it as I appreciated the company of all other delegates.

I would especially like to thank you, Mr President, for the way that you headed the delegation. As Senator Spindler said, if it was not for your presence as President of the Senate leading such a delegation, we would not have been able to get doors opened to the places that we visited. I thank you and your staff, including the Black Rod, Fred Peppinck, who has had a few mentions in despatches lately, and Julie Hatcher.

I also thank all those posts in the countries we visited that helped us to the utmost, especially the post in Poland that is badly in need of new housing. Perhaps the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) could take that on board and provide something. There are many emigration applications in Poland and I understand that, even in winter, people are queuing up in the streets for their appointments. I urge the Minister for Foreign Affairs to look at the idea of upgrading that post. I also thank the post in London that welcomed us at the airport and despatched us back on the plane home.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone, on behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the Committee's report entitled Legal casinos and organised criminal activity. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a tabling statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

Under paragraph 55(1)(d) of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 it is the duty of the Committee 'to examine trends and changes in criminal activities, practices and methods and report to both Houses of the Parliament any change which the Committee thinks desirable to the functions, structure, powers and procedures of the Authority'.

SPEECH.PARA: Pursuant to this duty the Committee decided in December 1990 to conduct an inquiry into aspects of the establishment and operation of legal casinos in Australia.

The report I have just tabled announces that the Committee has decided not to pursue this inquiry at this stage. The Committee emphasises in the report that it is not terminating its inquiry—merely suspending it. Early in the next Parliament the Committee will review the decision to suspend its inquiry.
The report sets out the background to the Committee's decision. I will briefly summarise this.

Since the Committee decided in December 1990 to undertake the casino inquiry, three other inquiries commenced which have looked at aspects of possible criminal involvement in legal casinos. The Committee wishes to avoid duplicating the work of these inquiries.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Street Inquiry in New South Wales

SPEECH.PARA: On 6 August 1991, the New South Wales Government announced an Inquiry into the Establishment and Operation of Legal Casinos in New South Wales. The Inquiry was headed by the Hon. Sir Laurence Street and reported in November 1991.

Of direct relevance to the Parliamentary Joint Committee's inquiry, the Street report stated that the regulatory scheme proposed for New South Wales casinos was one 'in which the casinos can be protected from criminal influence and exploitation, kept free from money laundering and maintained as places for honest gaming'.
The Street report also identified:
.the exchange of operating information and criminal intelligence; and
.the establishment of a database to assist in the licensing processes for casino operators and staff
as areas in which a nationally co-ordinated approach would be beneficial.
The Street report considered that a more formal, structured approach was highly desirable in these areas.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The National Crime Authority's Inquiry into Money Laundering

SPEECH.PARA: In December 1990, the Attorney-General gave a reference to the NCA to investigate money laundering. As the NCA's work on the reference progressed, it became apparent that one aspect of its investigations would be into the extent to which legal casinos were or could be used to launder money.
In February 1992, the National Crime Authority reported to the Attorney-General on its inquiry. The non-confidential parts of the report were released to the public last month.

The NCA inquiry brought to light no known cases whereby casinos were used to conceal the origin of criminal funds. Casinos were not found to be used for 'laundering money' in Australia in the commonly accepted view of the phrase.

However, the NCA inquiry did identify some matters of concern in relation to casinos. The NCA recommended 'that the Attorney-General refer the NCA's findings in relation to the casino industry to the appropriate State Governments, with the recommendations that:
(i) consideration be given to the establishment of a National Casino Standards Organisation; and
(ii) junket operators should be licensed and all participants on junket tours should be fully identified.'
The Attorney-General has yet to respond to the NCA report.

In January 1991, a Royal Commission was appointed in Western Australia to inquire and report whether, amongst other matters, there had been corrupt, illegal or improper conduct by anyone in the affairs of the Western Australian Government or its agencies in respect of the Burswood Island Casino.
The Parliamentary Joint Committee has also received evidence on this matter.
The Royal Commission sat in June and July 1991 for some 25 days hearing evidence and argument on the Burswood matter. It has not yet reported.

Mr President, in view of the findings and recommendations of the Street and NCA Inquiries, and the fact that the Western Australian Royal Commission has heard casino-related evidence but not yet reported, the Committee considers it would be unproductive to pursue its inquiry at this stage.

When, early in the next Parliament, the Committee reviews its decision to suspend the inquiry, it will take into account any action by governments in response to the Street and NCA inquiries, and whether the WA Royal Commission has reported and sufficient time has elapsed for its findings to be acted upon.
Finally, Mr President, the Committee expresses its appreciation to all those who made submissions and in other ways assisted its inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Giles, on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 316th report of the Committee on the administrative and financial relationships between Medicare and Medibank Private. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my tabling statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The report I have just tabled presents the results of an examination of the financial and administrative relationships between Medicare and Medibank Private.

The Committee undertook the inquiry in response to ongoing criticism, particularly by representatives of voluntary health organisations, of the joint administration of these functions by the Health Insurance Commission.

Concerns have often been raised about the extent to which the current system fairly and accurately apportions costs between the two functions. Questions about the division of assets and possible cross subsidisation of Medibank Private by Medicare have also arisen.

The inquiry was brief. Only two submissions were received by the closing date—one from the Health Insurance Commission and one from the Australian Health Insurance Association. Each was subsequently invited to comment on the other's submission and the input of the Australian National Audit Office was also sought.

Having considered the evidence presented, the Committee was persuaded that the current cost apportionment system meets the requirements of predictability, administrative simplicity and equity in the distribution of total costs between Medicare and Medibank Private. While some preciseness at the lowest level of cost may be sacrificed, the Committee is satisfied that the present system accurately and fairly distributes total costs between the two functions.

The Committee was not persuaded by the evidence presented to the inquiry that cross-subsidisation occurs. It noted, in this regard, that the Health Insurance Commission, Medibank Private and Medicare are subject to regular audit by the ANAO. The auditing process includes scrutiny of the cost apportionment and asset rental systems. If instances of cross subsidisation were noted by the audit process they would be reported by the ANAO to the Parliament. In the absence of such reports the Committee was unable to substantiate allegations of cross subsidisation.

The Committee notes, however, that this inquiry did not consider the broader questions raised by the AHIA. These include the viability of Medibank Private and the extent to which it complies with the requirements of the National health act. Similarly questions of policy, such as whether Medicare should reimburse the Commissioner for Taxation for collection costs fell outside of the scope of the present inquiry. A separate inquiry could address these issues.

Despite the brevity of the inquiry and the report, the Committee considers that the process has been a valuable one, as it has provided a forum in which these long standing concerns could be aired and counter arguments presented.
On behalf of the Committee I thank the secretariat staff for their assistance with the inquiry—in particular Richard Cavanagh, Geraldine Skinner and Yolanda Campagna.
I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Cook)—by leave—agreed to:
That General Business and consideration of committee reports and Government responses be not proceeded with this day.
