DEBATE.TITLE: REPATRIATION INSTITUTIONS (STAFF) BILL 1991VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (PROVISION OF TREATMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the debate on the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill 1991 and Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991 was adjourned earlier this afternoon, the problem relating to this issue has been one of timing. My first reaction was that the Australian Democrats should oppose this Bill. However, I discussed the issue further with a large number of people who got in touch with my office. I then sought, as is usual, views from the community and particularly from those organisations throughout Australia which are most interested in this—the veterans' organisations. It quickly became obvious that this was not a black and white issue; it was not a yes or no issue.

PARA.TAB: There was no uniformity in the opinions expressed to me by these people; there was a wide range of views and concerns, even within individual veterans' organisations. Some members were in favour of integration, others were vehemently opposed. However, when all of this was put together, one common thread emerged. The deciding factor had nothing to do with the organisation or the interests of the veterans but, rather, with the State they came from. Where they lived made the difference as far as their opinions were concerned. In my State of South Australia the veterans groups strongly opposed the integration of Daw Park, while the greatest majority of submissions I received from New South Wales urged the Democrats to urgently support the legislation so that the integration of Concord hospital could go ahead.

I therefore proposed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) late last year that the transfers take place on a State by State basis; that hospitals other than Concord and Hobart be specifically written out of the legislation. I understand that that is where we would have ended up in that the negotiations have to proceed with the State governments. My State did not want anything to happen until 1995, which is the generally agreed date when negotiations can proceed.

With this in mind, I began to look at some of the problems. Obviously, one of the biggest problems was that the RSL was still not prepared for any integration anywhere. I set about a further lengthy round of consultations with veterans' organisations and a number of individual veterans. Consultation continued through late 1991 and into the early months of 1992. Since November 1991 I have been in constant discussion with the TPI Association of South Australia and have spoken on quite a number of occasions now to the members of the Consultative Council of Ex-Service Organisations in South Australia, which represents 21 ex-service organisations in that State.

In February and again in April this year I visited New South Wales to talk to the veterans groups there, including the Vietnam Veterans Association. Throughout the year I have had discussions in my Parliament House office with representatives from ADVASC, the War Widows Guild, the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association and the RSL. I also spoke to officers from Concord hospital.

I am very surprised at some of the comments Senator Newman made earlier suggesting that somehow the veterans are being pushed or railroaded or moved against their will into these arrangements. As early as February this year, I think it was, the New South Wales RSL told me that it had already negotiated 20 of the 21 points that were of concern to it before it moved towards agreeing to the transfer of Concord repatriation hospital. I did not detect at any stage, particularly in New South Wales, even the slightest hint that this was going ahead against its will.

The RSL went through many of the problems in New South Wales specific to Concord, including issues such as the length of time veterans had to spend travelling if they needed to go to the hospital and particularly the inconvenience for family and friends of veterans who had to go to Concord, in some cases from as far away as Gosford and the Blue Mountains. From a hospital executive I heard how essential it was that Concord be integrated into the State system if it was to remain comparable with other teaching hospitals in New South Wales and if the standard of veterans' care was to be maintained.

Professor J.A. Young, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Sydney, wrote to me of the major role Concord plays in undergraduate teaching at the university because of a particular case mix which offers a different and particularly valuable educational environment for undergraduate students. He assured me that the university considered that the transfer of Concord into the State system was the only way to guarantee the long term sustained existence of the clinical school within the hospital, the maintenance of its present high standards, and the delivery of health to the inner west of Sydney.

I have also received a copy of the signed staffing agreement between the hospital-based staff, the unions and the staff association at Concord and the Commonwealth of Australia in relation to the transfer. I have had the opportunity to discuss this issue at length with a union representative.

All of this is quite contrary to what I found in South Australia. It is directly opposite to the situation in South Australia, in that we have a small State—one where veterans already have ready access in country areas and outer metropolitan areas because there are so many veterans who still live within easy reach of the Daw Park Repatriation Hospital. They are more than happy to continue going there for their treatment.

As for the other States, there seems to be absolutely no interest on anybody's part in Western Australia and that includes the Government. In Queensland, I detected some interest in transfer but certainly not enough to move in that direction at this time. In Victoria, I have had only opposition from those people who have contacted me. All of these discussions further highlighted the different needs in different States. So it was obvious that we could not go ahead in any way other than a way that made it very clear that the only hospitals to move at this point were the two that were ready—Hobart and Concord in Sydney.

If the legislation is blocked in the Senate, New South Wales and Tasmania will be severely disadvantaged. If we were to accept Senator Newman's proposed amendments—with which I am quite familiar because they are the same as the amendments that I had drawn up and circulated on 6 May and which proved to be unsatisfactory—this would delay the transfer of Concord and Hobart until further negotiations could get under way with the State governments in terms of anything being signed before October this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the hurry?

—I welcome that interjection. The hurry is that the veterans in New South Wales, and certainly in Tasmania, wish to proceed to the next stage now. This involves the actual formal arrangements, as we are so close, particularly in Tasmania, to getting staff agreement and staff involvement. I do not think the veterans there would be very happy at all with a further delay. In fact, my advice is that the New South Wales RSL contacted Senator Newman as late as yesterday assuring her that they wanted the process to go ahead without further delay.

PARA.TAB: Just to go back a couple of months, even though it had become very obvious to us that we had to go on a State by State basis, our problem was that the RSL did not agree with that. Even though individuals and branches were saying one thing, the national body still had a motion on its books. Every time the proposal went to the national body it had been turned down. We recognise the RSL as a peak negotiating body for veterans. We believed that our hands were tied. We certainly could not vote, as we will today, unless the RSL was happy. Therefore, I took it upon myself on 27 February to write to the National Secretary, Captain Robert Ray, setting out our proposal to transfer the hospitals on a State by State basis. I asked him for the views of members on this at its national congress, which was to be held the following week. I seek leave to table a copy of my letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, at this particular meeting the issue was not able to be discussed. However, within a week or two of my letter being received, the South Australian branch of the RSL proposed that an extraordinary national congress be held on 21 April 1992 to specifically discuss this matter. The outcome of this extraordinary national congress meeting was that the RSL accepted the principle of integration of RGH hospitals into the State health system on a State by State basis, with State branches being authorised to negotiate satisfactory settlements with their own State governments and Federal Government representatives in the States, providing that there was a guarantee by the Federal Government and each State government about priority of access given to the State and private health systems for veterans and war widows. That all relates to whether that priority is medically justified. I would also like to table a copy of that letter from the RSL informing me of results of that special national congress.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to move amendments when we reach the committee stage of this Bill proposing that the transfer of the repatriation hospitals in Concord, New South Wales, and the RGH effectively go ahead because they have been taken off the list of repatriation hospitals. I have also listed repatriation auxiliary hospitals as they will also need some time to discuss and debate their future and to have involvement of the veterans' communities in their States.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that some people still have concerns—that is quite understandable—in particular about the private patient principles, but I believe that we have reached the point where we really are as close as we can possibly be at this time to fully satisfying the requirements of the veterans in the various States. The monitoring committees will be set up to effectively oversee the transfer of these two hospitals and will quickly identify any problems which may be developing. In addition, the veterans' organisations in all the other States will be watching very closely what happens in New South Wales and Tasmania and will put further pressure on their governments, on the Federal Government and on the hospitals themselves to make sure that everything goes 100 per cent according to plan.

In conclusion, I stress that the private patient principles are a disallowable instrument. I believe that the Parliament will be able to exercise sufficient control to ensure that veterans receive the best possible deal they can on the issue of integration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are finally debating the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlements (Provision of Treatment) Amendment Bill 1991. As you, Mr Deputy President, and those of us who have been waiting for this debate to come forward are aware, these Bills come to the Senate after a very considerable delay—a delay which has been caused by the failure of this Government to adequately take into account the needs of the veterans in our community. I was very interested to hear about not only the amount of travelling and talks that my colleague from Tasmania has had—I was well aware of that—but also the amount of work that Senator Lees has done. Whilst I have not consulted as widely and at as much length as Senator Lees, I have certainly had discussions with RSL members in Tasmania and members of the TPI organisation over a great period and I can assure Senator Lees that their concerns were just as great as the ones that she has been made aware of.

PARA.TAB: These Bills were originally listed for introduction into the Parliament in June of last year. In fact, I had a speech ready which I have had to change because there have been a lot of changes since June last year. The Bills did not reach the House of Representatives until November. They were pushed through the House of Representatives in a great hurry on 12 November and were listed for debate in the Senate before the end of last year. However, as a result of the predictable cry of the outraged veteran community, the Government was obliged to reconsider its original legislation. The actions of the Government up until then were a distinct contradiction of the promise it had given the House of Representatives on 10 November 1988 by the Minister, who indicated that the integration would not occur until all the concerns of the ex-service community had been resolved. My colleagues Senator Newman and Senator Lees would also have to agree that up until that date there was plenty of concern by the ex-service community.

The Minister further claimed in 1988 this was an unequivocal guarantee from the Labor Government. These sentiments were subsequently endorsed by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, who made a similar promise to the veterans during the last election campaign. Unfortunately, as is the case with a lot of these promises made by the Government, these words proved to be empty rhetoric and the veterans' community had to spend many months experiencing considerable concern about their future.

As Senator Newman pointed out, the coalition has put forward two amendments to the present legislation which we believe will go further towards meeting the needs of the veterans' community. I remind the Government and members of the Senate of the coalition's position on repatriation general hospital integration as expressed in the Fightback package:

SPEECH.PARA: We are . . . committed over time to the transfer of all Commonwealth repatriation general hospitals to the States. We will ensure that this process now under way does not diminish the quality of health care, nor the priority of access granted to veterans. This policy will be implemented in full consultation with the R.S.L. and other veterans' organisations.

This is, and always has been, the coalition's position. As I said earlier, we have now reached the point where the Government has decided that some means of discussion and consultation with the veterans' community is appropriate.

PARA.TAB: The coalition indicated in November last year that we would oppose the Bills as they stood, as I think Senator Newman said earlier today. That opposition was based then on the unwillingness of the Government to provide either the Opposition or the ex-service community with details associated with the transfer of the hospitals. I remember that I had great difficulty trying to get some answers out of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in Hobart.

We also believe that the Government failed to keep its promise that integration would not occur unless the ex-service community was satisfied. I can speak from personal experience after discussions with Mr Ken Alexander representing the RSL organisation in Hobart.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good man.

—Definitely. I also had discussions with a former local government colleague of mine, former Alderman A.V. A'Church, who was a member of the Monday morning TPI pensioners group on the eastern shore. He was expressing similar concerns to those expressed by Mr Alexander.

PARA.TAB: Thanks to the cooperation and discussions I had on Anzac Day with Mr Alexander and John O'Connor, who is well known for travelling around different services on Anzac Day, I received some information by fax today which will support the comments made during Senator Lees's speech when my colleague Senator Newman said, `What's the big hurry?'. I think Senator Lees is under the impression that things are moving very quickly in Hobart. Having read a copy of the letter from the Minister, Roger Groom, to Mr Humphreys, I can tell the Senate that they are not moving quickly at all. In his letter, Mr Groom said:

SPEECH.PARA: You would be aware, however, that the transfer is subject to agreements on staffing, property transfers and leasing arrangements being in place.
He continued:

The Crown Solicitor is currently examining draft agreements on staff and property matters negotiated by DOH and DVA representatives. When this progress has been completed and those agreements have been signed by the State and the Commonwealth I agree that a joint press statement be released.

We know how things work between governments. This letter was dated 28 May. Quite frankly, I will be very surprised if all these matters are concluded before the October date that my colleague Senator Newman was talking about.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the present Government has frequently underestimated the value of the contribution the ex-service community has made to our way of life. The provision of first-class health care services to the veteran community remains a national acknowledgment of the sacrifices made by our military personnel.

I think that from time to time we should remind the Government, particularly one or two of its members, including the Prime Minister, of the promises that were made by former Prime Ministers Menzies and Chifley about veterans never being disadvantaged. We are also aware that since the First and Second World Wars, Australian service men and service women have also seen action in Korea, Malaysia, Vietnam and only last year in the Gulf. Even today our Government has committed Australian military personnel to a highly sensitive military environment in Cambodia. I heard on the radio yesterday that a United Nations peacekeeping force under the command of an Australian officer, which was endeavouring to deliver humanitarian supplies in Bosnia, came under attack from Serbian militia. As a result, one member of that force was killed. These are the sorts of risks that Australian armed service men and service women are experiencing, and no doubt will continue to experience.

I am sure that we in the Senate would agree that throughout these engagements our three Services have continued to display a standard of dedication to their duty which has become symbolic of our nation. All this means that unfortunately, as we live in a world which seems unable to exist without military turmoil, it is likely that there will be a need for repatriation services for some time to come. From information I have received—I took note that my colleague Senator Newman also used the same figures—the number of veterans and others entitled to medical treatment at repatriation general hospitals will not peak until 1995. It is likely that this predicted peak will not begin to fall until the year 2000. There is no doubt that there will be no great diminution of services until that time.

The proposal for the integration of repatriation health institutions with State health systems had its origins in a report entitled The Review of the Repatriation Hospital System which was conducted between March 1984 and June 1985. That review recommended major changes to the repatriation hospital system, including immediate increases in staff and equipment spending, extensive rationalisation and incorporation into the State hospital system. The Government forced the recommendations of the review in 1986 and further clarified its position in 1988.

In a press release dated 14 August 1988, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) gave an assurance that no final decisions would be taken if the RSL had reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the arrangements proposed. It is a pity the Government did not see fit to honour those previous commitments. As a result of the RSL's concerns throughout the nation at the Government's legislation, which passed the House of Representatives in November last year, as I have already said, Brigadier Alf Garland, the President of the Returned Services League of Australia, was obliged to write to Minister Humphreys on behalf of the Australian veterans' community outlining 21 concerns in the existing legislation. That was in November last year. I note that Senator Lees said in relation to the Concord case that 20 of those matters had been cleaned up by February this year. Those 21 concerns were a clear indication that the veterans' community had not been consulted as was promised and had not been kept informed of the Government's actions. I think it is a disgrace that the veterans' community was obliged to contact the Minister with 21 concerns after the legislation had passed the House.

It appeared that the Government had realised that unless it were more forthcoming in providing details to the ex-service community, the legislation would have been lost. It was well known then that the Opposition intended to oppose the Bill. I believe Senator Lees also had made it pretty well known that unless things changed, the Democrats would be combining with the coalition to stop this legislation. As a result of the feeling that was around the community, we had a belated effort of cooperation from the Government which saw that more information should be provided to the Opposition and the ex-service community about the details of the transfer. Quite frankly, finding out what was going on was like getting blood out of a stone. As Senator Lees has said, it was important to the veterans in New South Wales, and particularly to those in my own State of Tasmania because we were being set up once again. As an island State, Tasmania is somewhat isolated and tends to be used for the testing of pilot schemes or as the guinea pig.

The integration of the repatriation general hospitals in Hobart and Concord, as has been said, is expected to occur this year. It is therefore imperative that this Parliament provides veterans and war widows in both Tasmania and New South Wales with legislative provisions to support the repatriation private patients scheme. Many people in Tasmania have come to me in a private capacity because they are very concerned about the integration of the repatriation hospital in Hobart. No doubt Senator Tate also has had thousands of people knocking on his door. Ignorance was bliss and a lot of the veterans were fed some sort of information along the way that was not correct. People of that age tend to be more fearful than younger people. Therefore, parliamentarians were at the receiving end of many of these concerns.

But I notice that the national executive of the RSL at last has recently decided not to oppose integration. I believe that it has even convinced Bruce Ruxton that things are okay; I suppose if he feels happy with it, obviously the Minister must have solved most of the problems that we have been concerned about. The RSL has instead suggested that individual ex-service communities in each State should be responsible for undertaking negotiations on the particular transfers, as they are in the best position to reflect the needs of their State members.

It should be understood quite clearly, though, that although there is now greater acceptance of integration in the veterans' community, many veterans are still concerned as to what effect the loss of repatriation general hospitals will have on their future health care. The coalition believes that it is the responsibility of the Parliament to ensure that veterans' interests are fully protected by this legislation. As a result, the coalition is proposing two sets of amendments, which my colleague has already spoken about. These amendments will make it possible for the intention to transfer a particular hospital to be the subject of a disallowance in the Federal Parliament.

The amendments will also make sure that the national treatment monitoring committee, which is the body set up by the Government to monitor the impact of integration on the health care of veterans, is open to public scrutiny. We believe there are different circumstances in different States and that the Government should be accountable to the Parliament for any negotiations which take place on a State by State basis with the veteran community before the transfer of any hospital occurs. This will provide the State veterans with the opportunity of having their concerns discussed in the Parliament should they wish to do so.

The second amendment concerning the national treatment monitoring committee is very important, given the Government's previous record in keeping veterans aware of proposed integration changes. If there is to be an informed debate on the impact of integration on veterans' health care, it is essential that the reports of that committee should be made available to both the public and the Parliament. This will provide a forum for monitoring the progress of integration.

One of the main concerns expressed by Brigadier Garland to the integration package was the secrecy with which the Government handled this matter. In correspondence dated 6 March, Brigadier Garland expresses that concern to the Minister. An extract reads:

Item four is the linchpin of all negotiations as secrecy has been our main objection to the whole package. By secrecy I mean we have no indication as to the attitudes of State health authorities in relation to the acceptance of the many facets of integration contained in the package you have presented to the ex-service community. Nor are we privy to the contents of the Federal State agreements or proposed agreements.

What we require is a copy of any final draft agreement to be made available for perusal and comment prior to the signing of the same by State and Federal authorities. As in other matters we will respect the commercial in-confidence content cannot be disclosed.

It is unreasonable to expect the R.S.L. or other ex-service communities to accept many points on integration which you have put forward without us knowing they have been accepted unreservedly by State health authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: This quotation from Brigadier Garland details the overwhelming concern of the RSL and the veterans' communities towards ensuring that secrecy is removed and the veterans have full understanding and input on integration.

PARA.TAB: The concern is also reflected by both amendments put forward by the coalition. It is therefore dependent upon the Government to support those amendments. Not to do so would be further evidence of the real lack of commitment to the veteran community by the Government. It will then be dependent upon this Parliament to attend to the concerns of veterans as they arise through the integration process. As a coalition, we have always been concerned to ensure that it is the needs of the veterans' community which are considered the most important aspect of this protracted debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think my friend and colleague Senator Calvert has just finished his speech on the correct note, which is to emphasise the focus on the needs of the veteran community for health care, in particular, and medical treatment. I believe that if we, as politicians in the Federal Parliament, keep that focus clearly in mind, then we will understand that the needs of an ageing veteran community are changing and that there is a desire amongst many of them to be treated in a hospital which is closer to their homes and, therefore, closer to their families and friends and the normal support of the communities in which they live.

PARA.TAB: I know that Senator Newman would agree that when the State conference of the RSL was held in Burnie only a few weeks ago, it was a very wet and windy day—it was absolutely appalling. To think of aged relatives setting out for the trip to Hobart to see a spouse in the repat hospital there would be—

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have to.
—No, but I am just saying that, quite frankly-
—People from a distance don't have to come now.

—Yes, but that proves my point that people would prefer, obviously, to be able to visit somebody in hospital in the local area—and I am sure the patient concerned would prefer that to be the case too.
—They do not have to.

—It is an example of the phenomenon that we are trying to deal with by this legislation. I believe it is very good that the Senate, after many months—maybe it is years—of dealing with and grappling with this particular matter, is coming very largely to a tripartisan support for the Bill before us.

PARA.TAB: I think that is important for another reason raised by Senator Calvert, that is, that the ageing veteran community is naturally fearful and easily led into concerns and anxieties. Perhaps it is a bit unfair to say that it is easily led; but by misinformation, partial information or lack of adequate information, its concerns and anxieties are raised. The concerns of the veteran community would be emphasised or exacerbated if it thought that in the future this arrangement could be undone.

Therefore, it is very important and very gratifying that in the chamber this afternoon we have had expressions of acceptance anyway of this proposal which should therefore give a firm foundation for the matter to go ahead. It is, in any case, in accordance with the policy over time, I agree, of the Opposition parties and of the present Government. I think `acceptance' would be the word to use also in relation to the Democrats in this matter. But that acceptance is important and will give a confidence to the ageing veteran community in this matter.

Mr Acting Deputy President, as you will know, these Bills and the proposed repatriation private patient principles provide continuing Commonwealth responsibility for the arrangement of veterans' health care, an unequivocal requirement on the Repatriation Commission to provide for timely hospitalisation based solely on medical need, effective monitoring arrangements, and a range of staff guarantees agreed with the ACTU and DVA unions. Of course, that is spoken in very general terms. But, as has been pointed out by all the contributors to the debate this afternoon, each State will have its own emphasis and differences, and integration should only occur when local arrangements and sufficient understanding is reached between the governments, Federal and State, and the veterans' community concerned.

That is why the noting in the repatriation private patient principles of the composition and role of these monitoring committees—the national treatment monitoring committee, for example—is very important. I believe it is very important that the committee have on it persons of high status, two representing the Commonwealth—being a member of the Commission, who is the Chair, and the National Program Director Health of the Department—and, representing veterans, a representative of each of the Returned Services League of Australia, the War Widows Guild of Australia, the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, the Australian Federation of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Ex-servicemen and Women, the Legacy Coordinating Council and the Regular Defence Force Welfare Association. I believe that the State committees will of course mirror that particular arrangement. I think, once again at the State convention or congress of the Returned Services League of Australia in Tasmania, Mr Ken Alexander, the esteemed President already mentioned by Senator Calvert, indicated that the committee was already at work.
I have no doubt that that is why the Returned Services League of Australia, by virtue of the resolution held at the extraordinary national congress on Tuesday 21 April, has been able to agree:

SPEECH.PARA: That notwithstanding any other Resolution which may have been passed at a National Congress on the question of RGH Integration, that the RSL accept the principle of integration of RGH Hospitals into the State Health systems, providing there is guarantee by the Federal Government and each State Government, priority of access to the State and Private Hospitals for veterans and war widows, where that priority is medically justified.
It has also agreed:

. . . That State Branches be authorised to negotiate satisfactory settlements of as many as possible of the RSL's minimum requirements on RGH Integration, with their own State Governments and Federal Government representatives in their states.

I believe that the sentiment expressed by the national secretary that we now need to work closely together to make sure the integration process proceeds without detriment to the welfare of the veteran will be the guiding principle for the work of the national committee and certainly of the State committees.

PARA.TAB: I understand from what Senator Newman said that it is agreed that the principles are an adequate vehicle for incorporating the composition and task and functions of the national treatment monitoring committee. The Australian Democrats have circulated proposed amendments which require the Minister to give notice to the Parliament prior to signing any agreements for transfer before 1995 of the repatriation general hospitals, other than Concord or Hobart, or the repatriation auxiliary hospitals. The coalition would go further and make Hobart and Concord subject to that disallowance process.

The Government does not accept the coalition's position. The arrangements for Hobart are well in hand. Over 300 job offers have been issued to RGH Hobart staff to work in the hospital as State staff after integration, and it should proceed on 1 July 1992. The integration of Concord has strong and widespread support amongst ex-service organisations in New South Wales. I think Senator Lees indicated that that was certainly her impression from conversations she has held as recently as yesterday. The New South Wales Government, I understand, is very keen for transfer to occur, as are staff at the hospital.

Insertion of a requirement to bring forward a disallowable instrument would set back a process which is already endorsed by both the New South Wales and Tasmanian governments. As I understand it, the ex-service organisations are involved in the process too. So the Government will support the Democrats' amendments, including the change in the long title. I understand that there is also a sunset clause to come into operation on 1 January 1995. I think that is part of the Democrats' amendments.

The ongoing viability of the RGHs is critical and is contingent on their integration into the State system as this provides them with a continuing role. Since 1988, with the first announcement of the proposed transfer of the RGHs, the year 1995 has been embedded in RGH and State health planning as the latest date on which sensible planning can be based. It does not mean that the Government or future governments would bulldoze the transfers. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) believes that integration of the RGHs in Queensland, South Australia and Victoria will be successfully settled with the support of veterans, staff and State governments well before 1995. It would have to be said that the outlook for RGH Hollywood in Perth is less clear at this stage.

The Commonwealth, through the Repatriation Commission—this cannot be emphasised too much—will continue to be responsible for the health care of veterans and war widows. This legislation enshrines that responsibility. The repatriation private patients scheme will mean greater health care options for all veterans and war widows, and this Government will continue to work towards the implementation of these benefits in all States as soon as possible. With the support of all major ex-service organisations, medical staff and the unions, the stage has been reached, I believe, where Parliament as a whole should support these Bills. As I have indicated, the Government will support the amendments.

After at times acrimonious and understandable controversy concerning this proposal, we have reached a stage where the Senate can in good conscience support this legislation underpinning and giving guarantees concerning the integration process. That would be of great comfort to veterans and to the general community, which wants to ensure that those who have served in the armed forces receive the best treatment possible within our society in relation to their medical and health requirements.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: CHAIRMAN—Is it the wish of the Committee to take the Bill as a whole?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to move all my amendments in a block, in view of the time and the fact that we have already discussed these in the second reading debate.
—Is leave granted to move the three amendments together?
—I have no objection, Mr Chairman.
—No, Mr Chairman. I was going to ask whether it was possible to deal with the amendments to be moved by the Opposition prior to those to be moved by the Democrats.
—Leave is not granted.
—I was on my feet before, Mr Chairman.
—I could give you a lecture about how the Chair makes the call, Senator Newman. We will take the Bill clause by clause.

—Mr Chairman, this matter is one that all members of this chamber, and probably all members of the House of Representatives, have been very interested in. I do not intend, nor would you permit me, to make a second reading speech in a committee debate. However, I wish to make my position clear on this matter, as it affects the amendment moved by Senator Lees. I indicate that this will be my attitude also in respect of the amendments to be moved by Senator Newman.

PARA.TAB: Because it appears to me, in the final analysis, that something of a fait accompli has been imposed—I suppose that is the only word I can use—on the veterans community and, indeed, on the unions involved in staffing repatriation hospitals, we are faced with a difficult circumstance. I know and everybody around the chamber knows that these negotiations have been taking place, certain undertakings have been given, and at last we are virtually requested by this legislation to rubber stamp what has been taking place.

My view is that there is still a very strong argument that special arrangements need to be made for the health care, et cetera, of veterans. In so far as these veterans live within relatively close proximity to the repatriation hospitals, then those are the places, and I believe should still be the places, where they continue to be catered for, and solely catered for. Obviously, for those who live a greater distance away from repatriation hospitals, other circumstances may well be desired by individual veterans, and those desires should be accommodated.

I realise that negotiations have been going on with the organisations, the unions involved, and also with the veterans' communities, including the RSL. But, as I think was indicated by Senator Calvert, there are still a lot of people in the veterans' community who are not very happy about the situation. I propose to support those amendments that will be before us which will recognise that fact and, so far as is possible, will have a public type of audit over the Government execution of the enabling measures contained in this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has no objection to the first amendment which will change the first clause of the Repatriation Institutions (Staff) Bill, as that is identical to an amendment that has been circulated by the Opposition.
—The Government agrees to that amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 2 to 6—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 2.After clause 6, page 4, insert the following new Part:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "PART 1A—RESTRICTION ON RIGHT TO TRANSFER CERTAIN REPATRIATION INSTITUTIONS
Minister to notify intention to transfer

PARA.TAB: "6A.(1) This section applies in relation to the following repatriation institutions:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)Repatriation General Hospital Daw Park;
(b)Repatriation General Hospital Greenslopes;
(c)Repatriation General Hospital Heidelberg;
(d)Repatriation General Hospital Hollywood;
(e)the repatriation auxiliary hospitals, being:

PARA.TAB: (i)Lady Davidson Hospital; and
(ii)MacLeod Repatriation Hospital; and
(iii)Repatriation Hospital Kenmore.

"(2) The Commonwealth must not enter into an agreement under which a repatriation institution to which this section applies is to become, before 1 January 1995, an institution operated by a State or an authority of a State unless:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the Minister has determined in writing that the institution should be transferred to the State or authority; and
(b)the determination has not been disallowed and is no longer liable to be disallowed, or to be taken to have been disallowed, under section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.TAB: "(3) A determination under subsection (2) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.".

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment puts in very clear place, evident to all, that the transfers are not to go ahead in the following repatriation institutions at this point in time: Daw Park, Greenslopes, Heidelberg and Hollywood; and the repatriation auxiliary hospitals, Lady Davidson Hospital, MacLeod Repatriation Hospital and Repatriation Hospital, Kenmore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not entirely happy with this amendment. It is for that reason that I was hoping that we might have been able to take the Opposition's amendment prior to that of the Democrats because our amendment, although wider, covers the same area. Perhaps I can explain why I believe that our amendment is preferable to the one which the Democrats have moved. Senator Lees, in speaking on the second reading debate, outlined, as she saw it, the position in each State. I do not suppose I have a great deal of disagreement with her. She said there was opposition in South Australia; there was opposition in Victoria; no interest in Western Australia; and not much interest in Queensland. She gave a different impression about Tasmania. As Senator Harradine said, Tasmania was steamrollered. It is a little State with few people and it was just run over the top. Even there, the details are not complete. So it is incorrect to give the impression that Tasmania is ready to go and that the veterans are satisfied with it. It is quite a false impression.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees said that around Australia some people are vehemently opposed to it. That is also the situation in New South Wales. It is a pity that Senator Lees seems to have not heard that. Her former colleague Senator McLean was on the same platform as me in New South Wales about 18 months ago when something like 1,000 veterans crowded into the Sydney Town Hall to protest strongly about just this proposal. Last year at the RSL Congress in New South Wales, by a very small margin, the RSL there agreed to the hand over of its hospital. But it does not mean to say there is not a sizeable body of veterans in New South Wales who are unhappy. In addition, not all the details are ironed out there.

I did ask by way of interjection on Senator Lees, `What is the hurry?'. Why is it that her amendment to this legislation means that it has to go through now? We are perfectly prepared to let the legislation go through now provided the proper protection is in place for the veterans. Why is it that her list of hospitals which can only be transferred by way of a disallowable instrument does not include Concord and Tasmania? What is the hurry for those two hospitals? What is the difference of another couple of months or three months? If they are to be transferred, let it be done fairly and squarely, taking into account the details that have to be ironed out and the remaining concerns of those veterans.

Perhaps the answer is that the Government is scared that there might be a last minute hiccup. I am sure that is the reason and the Democrats are prepared to go along with that. I cannot understand them not giving the same protection to the veterans in Tasmania and in New South Wales as they are prepared to give to the veterans in South Australia, Victoria, Western Australia and Queensland.

Senator Lees lives in South Australia, so she obviously speaks with considerable authority of the veterans there. She knows their concerns. Those concerns are also very evident in my home State, as they are amongst many veterans still in New South Wales. Why is she not prepared to extend that same protection to the veterans in the other two States?

I am not trying to suggest that those things will not go through. I am just saying they should be given the opportunity to see that the deals that are done and the provisions that are put in place do protect the veterans in those States. I find it hard to understand how she can justify not including those two States in her list. Senator Lees has obviously been trying to go in the same direction as we have with our amendment; that is, to give the Parliament the power to protect the veterans in any State where the arrangements are not satisfactory to them.

Senator Tate mentioned the acceptance by the Opposition and the Democrats of this legislation. I say to him: yes, we do accept it, but I have to qualify that and say that it is pretty grudging acceptance and it is very wary acceptance. That reflects the views of our constituents, the veterans communities, in each of the States, whose acceptance is also extremely grudging and very wary.

The amendment of the Democrats is nearly there. I implore the Democrats to expand this measure—to amend their own amendment, if they care to do it that way—or to support the amendment which has been tabled by the Opposition. Perhaps the Government can explain to us why it is prepared to accept that amendment as drafted for the Democrats but is not prepared to accept the amendment as sent on 27 May by the Opposition to the Minister. The protection of all veterans is guaranteed by our amendment. The protection of veterans in New South Wales and Tasmania is not. Why not? Is it only a question of timing? As I asked before, what is the difference of a couple of months? I imagine it would be a couple of months at the most. I can only see that the exclusion of those two hospitals is provided by the Democrats for the Government's convenience. It certainly has nothing to do with the veterans.

The second part of the Democrats' amendment relates to the date. The disallowable instrument provision is to end in January 1995. Once again, this seems to give protection to the Government rather than the veterans. If there are any States which are holding out—and the Minister has just acknowledged that Western Australia is very likely to be in that position—it is quite possible that Daw Park will be in the same position, if not Victoria or Queensland. So there are four States still quite a long way from being ready to hand over their hospitals.

Senator Lees pointed out that there will be further pressure on the Government as the veterans watch how the New South Wales and Tasmanian handovers proceed. If those veterans do not like what they see in New South Wales and Tasmania, if they find the negotiations they are undertaking unsatisfactory, and if they hold out until January 1995, the Government will win under the Democrats' amendment because it gives the Government a gun to the heads of the veterans. The Government only has to sit around and wait until January 1995 and the hospital transfers will fall into its lap.

I do not understand why the Democrats' are not prepared to leave it open-ended—not that the hospitals will go on forever; we all agree that they will not. But why put something in the legislation that limits the protection when there is no need? That is why, as I said a little prematurely a minute ago, we have an amendment which would remove the date from the Democrats' amendment so that the protection of having a disallowable instrument on the handover of each hospital would go on, even if there were some unfinished business by January 1995. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That amendment No. 2 moved by the Australian Democrats to the proposed subclause 6A(2) be amended by the omission of `, before 1 January 1995,'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support Senator Newman's amendment. I will deal firstly with the other two hospitals, and I refer Senator Newman to what I outlined in my speech. It was the Democrats who initiated the idea—in a way, putting it into the Government's head—that this legislation should let only two hospitals go. That was not because we thought that somehow it might be a good idea; it was because of the overwhelming pressure we were put under by the veterans, particularly in New South Wales. I did not simply take the views of one or two; I visited organisations and spoke to several of them. Eventually, it became very clear that there was a little opposition, and I believe that that will be so even after the transfer goes ahead. But, overwhelmingly, the feeling and belief in New South Wales is that 20 of the 21 points were met back in February—not just recently; they were happy back in February to go ahead. Without this legislation they cannot finalise any of the arrangements and understandings that they were coming to with the State Government. Therefore, we will proceed as we planned to do.

PARA.TAB: I note from comments made by Senator Tate that planning has been going ahead in Tasmania. I have been through my files and cannot find one letter from Tasmania objecting to this proposal—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't like Democrats much in Tasmania.

—That is fine but the message certainly has gone out. I spoke to the RSL informally there and said that we have been dealing with this issue. Since November last year I have made it very clear that I welcome contact with all the veterans organisations.

PARA.TAB: The date of 1995 has been long accepted as the time by which arrangements with the States would begin. I think it was mentioned in Senator Calvert's speech as the date that the Prime Minister gave some years ago. It is not the automatic transfer date; it is the time when those organisations in the other States can begin negotiations.
As I have said before, without this piece of legislation no negotiations can be finalised with the States at all. Therefore we will be sticking with the amendments as I have moved them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that I can match the eloquence of Senator Lees in indicating that the Democrats' amendments are to be preferred in this matter.
—You wrote them, didn't you?
—No, that is not true.
—Who did?

—I believe, as Senator Lees said, that they emerged from her consultations and cogitations on this matter. I do not know whether the Parliamentary Counsel helped in the actual drafting in order to encapsulate them in a way which was consistent with the rest of the Bill. That is normal practice, as Senator Newman would know, even if she were to offer an amendment from time to time.

PARA.TAB: In relation to Tasmania, I have a letter dated 28 May from Mr Roger Groom, the Minister for Health in Tasmania—and I can incorporate the letter, if need be, so people can see that I am not being selective—which states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised by the Department of Health that there is agreement with the unions concerning employment arrangements to apply beyond the 1 July transfer date. The ex-service community in Tasmania has advised me that they are not opposed to the concept of integrating the RGHH with the State's public health system. Now that the matters referred to above are settled the Tasmanian Government is prepared to commit itself to the transfer of the RGHH as provided for in the arrangement negotiated by the former Labor Government and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. You would be aware, however, that the transfer is subject to agreements on staffing, property transfers and leasing arrangements being in place.

It continues with matters relating to the Crown Solicitor. Adding the position stated in that letter to the functioning of the State Monitoring Committee, which has already been mentioned, we have, I believe, a proper basis for the implementation as soon as possible of the arrangements with Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: As for New South Wales, I understand that the New South Wales Minister for Health Services Management, Mr Ron Phillips—who I think has the task of the day to day management of the New South Wales health system, as opposed to Mr Hannaford who has more of a general policy role—said that the transfer envisaged is `the most important health project confronting New South Wales'. He told reporters, I am advised, that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the State Government is totally behind the concept of bringing Concord into the State system provided the questions of funding and the restructuring of health facilities in Sydney's inner west could be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty big questions.
—It is up to him to be satisfied on that point. I agree that they are important questions and it requires the satisfaction of the State Government.
—It can't go ahead in a hurry.
—It should go ahead in a hurry. Mr Phillips said further:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government will continue to work with the Federal Government and other interest groups towards integration.
The reason it should go ahead in a hurry is, as Mr Phillips indicated, that:
Integration would provide substantial benefits to both New South Wales veterans and the general community.

He indicated that the medical staff at Concord were keen to come into the State system. I understand that nine days before the media conference Mr Phillips told State Parliament various things, in the course of which he quoted a letter from the deans of Sydney's two major teaching hospital universities saying that agreement between the two governments was `imperative'. I think that gives some indication why it is important for it to go ahead. Of course, the Government is prepared to accept the Democrats' amendment in relation to the other hospitals—Daw Park, Greenslopes, Heidelberg, Hollywood and auxiliaries; that is accepted—but not in relation to those which are on the verge of being completed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Newman's) to Senator Lees's amendment be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment (Senator Lees's) agreed to.

(a)notes that Amnesty International reports that thousands of pro-democracy protesters are continuing to be held under arrest or detention in China for their role in peacefully demonstrating for democracy in 1989 and that many have been subjected to ill-treatment, torture and trials not in accordance with internationally accepted norms;

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding my remarks I wish to touch on one further amendment to the Bill, and that relates to the list maintained by the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Because of a decision in respect of privacy matters, ASDA is not entitled to publish the list of athletes who test positive. It has been held that the national sporting bodies themselves ought not disclose athletes who test positive.

PARA.TAB: With respect, that is something of a nonsense, as I was moved to observe on another occasion. If six of the Broncos tested positive, were found guilty, were banned from playing, and suddenly vanished from the field, it would forever remain a mystery as to what happened to them. It seems to me that if athletes test positive and the positive test is found to have been caused by the use of an illegal drug or a banned drug, that ought to be published.

One of the problems we seem to have in Australia when dealing with banned substances, such as anabolic steroids, is that there has been a notion amongst law enforcement agencies—and perhaps not an unreasonable one—that if athletes are silly enough to take these drugs exclusively for the purpose of enhancing their performance and do themselves a damage, well, that is their business and nobody else's.

When I contacted the Western Australian police force on one occasion and drew their attention to a clear outlet of anabolic steroids in that State, I was told by senior officers of the Western Australian police force that the last thing they would be concerning themselves with would be the illegal use of anabolic steroids, because at that time they did not have sufficient police to monitor commercial crops of marijuana. Perhaps it is only in more recent times that the state law enforcement agencies understand the implications of this matter.

I conclude by saying that I hope in due course the Government will reconsider its position in respect of an appeals mechanism of some sort. Perhaps if there were a proper appeals mechanism of the type recommended by the drugs in sport committee, cheats like Martin Vinnicombe would not be able to ride for Australia in spite of his positive test. It also means that people like Alec Watson, who was found guilty on a basis which was without foundation, may not have gone through the pain and suffering that he experienced. To the extent that the Bill goes as far as it does, I support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Like you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have taken such an interest in this Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill that I do not need to have a written speech, because I can take up the sentiments already expressed in the chamber about the great importance of this measure. It is an indication by the Government, but even more by the whole Parliament, that we are determined to ensure that athletes do not cheat on their fellow competitors, their sport and its international reputation in Australia, or cheat on themselves. Senator Crichton-Browne made an important observation about the damage they could be doing to themselves. They should not be able to escape the sanctions that the community thinks they deserve, and these amendments are designed to ensure they do not escape them. They follow the recent publicity concerning an Australian cyclist who tested positive for anabolic steroids and who subsequently, on a legal technicality, was able to avoid sanctions.

PARA.TAB: All senators would agree that there needs to be a coordinated and national approach to the elimination of drug abuse in sport. Considerable discussions have taken place between State and Territory Ministers and officials. Obviously it is important that we have an Australia-wide approach to this matter and that the state boundaries do not impede or frustrate what should be a national viewpoint expressed in legislation by the whole Australian community concerning these matters. The relevant sections in this Bill enable the Commonwealth to play its part in ensuring that that is the case.

It has already been acknowledged by various speakers that Australia is taking the lead in international developments in the fight against drugs in sport. As Minister for Justice, I find that very encouraging. I believe that a change is occurring in society as far as the view taken of the use of drugs is concerned, be they drugs which have for generations been legally available in society or those, due to more recent legislation or development, which are proscribed. I believe that the need for that sentiment—which is so important particularly amongst young Australians—to be fostered is extremely important. To let those who are in positions of great influence as role models and heroes and heroines in a sporting field to be associated in any way with drugs as a method of enhancing their competitive edge in a particular sport or to permit, countenance or allow that to go unchecked in our society would be to send a very wrong message to young Australians. As you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be aware—though I might need some assistance with the name—a member of the Australian test team a couple of years ago from Tasmania—

TALK.START.PARA: —A cricketer?
—A cricketer.
—Have Tasmanians actually had a cricketer in the Australian team?
—Yes. It is not David Boon but another.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Campbell.

TALK.START.PARA: —Campbell. I could tell a good joke against Tasmanians, but I do not know whether I should. The Australian cricket board of control is refusing to hold any more test matches in Tasmania at that beautiful Bellerive oval.
—Why?
—Because everyone got in on one family ticket. But, of course, only a Tasmanian could tell that.
—Lucky the preselection is over.

—The preselection is over, so I think I got away with it. I have been diverted from what is actually a very important Bill which sets up further features of Australia's fight against the abuse of drugs in sporting activity. I am very glad that it has received such support around the chamber.

PARA.TAB: In my diversionary interlude in the very serious matter of addressing this Bill, I may have omitted to mention why I mentioned Mr Campbell's name. I would hate to leave the impression that he was one of those involved in drug taking in sport. In fact, I was going to make the point that the Department of Health in Tasmania actually employed him to go around the schools, in conjunction with others, to promote its program under the Drug Offensive, which tries to alert youngsters to the dangers of taking drugs. He performed a very good role in that regard, being a very good role model and a person whom the youngsters in Tasmania, particularly those interested in cricket, looked up to for advice in this respect. He gave his services in that respect unstintingly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating here tonight the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, which is primarily a housekeeping Bill. Section 66 of the Constitution provides for a maximum annual sum for the payment of Ministers, unless the Parliament provides otherwise. I suppose that, with the thought of mischief that runs through one's mind, one would have to wonder whether these Ministers were worth an increase in pay. But we will not pursue that at this stage.

PARA.TAB: The Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990 links the base salaries of parliamentarians at the top of the Senior Executive Service band 1 in the Australian Public Service. Similarly, there is a proportional increase in the salaries of Ministers of State. Therefore, Ministers' salaries are increased at the same rate and at the same time as are salaries of members and senators.

The amount of increase appropriated equates to the 2.5 per cent national wage increase, effective from 15 August 1991. Ministerial salaries are to be adjusted in accordance with that increase. As I said earlier, I am not sure that Ministers are worth it, but that is the way it has to be under the Constitution.
It is worth noting the following remarks of the Remuneration Tribunal in its 1992 review of salaries of members and senators, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The total remuneration package of Members of the Parliament is no longer assessed objectively on a "work value" basis or according to its essential worth from time to time. The base salary of Members is now by statute equated to that of a Member of the Australian Public Service at the lower end of the Senior Executive Service scale. In addition, the remuneration package is, as to its main part, no longer reviewed or fixed by an independent and impartial body. As long as the Parliament maintains the present statutory provisions: see Act No 71 of 1990 section 6 and clause 1 of Schedule 3; the basic salary component of that package rises or falls with the award or wage agreement made from time to time with relevant members of the Senior Executive Service through their union.

We have made it quite clear in the past that we supported the independent tribunal making its determination, because we thought it was quite improper that Parliament itself should decide the salaries and conditions relating to the members and senators in the Parliament. We are equally opposed and offended by the fact that the only way that the remuneration or salaries of members and senators of the Parliament of Australia is determined is by the union of the Senior Executive Service. Frankly, we find that offensive. We will not oppose the Bill, but we will be looking at this carefully when we get into government next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government thanks those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Ministers of State Amendment Bill and seeks its speedy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ACT Supreme Court (Transfer) Bill 1992 transfers the Supreme Court of the ACT from the Commonwealth to the ACT Government. In theory, the Supreme Court was transferred at the time that ACT self-government was established but the actual transfer was deferred for two years. That is the period that we are now dealing with. The Supreme Court is set to become part of the ACT Government on 1 July this year. The Supreme Court of the ACT was established in 1933 and has been administered by and paid for by the Commonwealth since then.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition supports the Bill which we have before us, but there are several matters that I wish to refer to which have come up in discussions since the Bill emerged. The Law Society was concerned about certain aspects of the Bill. These matters have been looked at by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the Australian Democrats and me. The Attorney-General has written a letter to me, dated 4 June 1992, in which he deals with the matters which I took up with his office. I will seek leave to incorporate a copy of the letter in Hansard. I think that is the most appropriate way of doing it.

There was concern over the wording of clause 48A(1) of the ACT Self-Government Act. The Attorney-General has dealt with that in detail. Concern was also raised about the amendment to subsection 7(6) of the Supreme Court Act. Hopefully, what is now said in the letter will clarify any misunderstandings which may have existed. The incorporation of the letter in Hansard will enable it to become a useful part of the record should there be any queries about this in the future.

The other matter which was of particular interest to those of us in the ACT was the funding of the Supreme Court. Given that one judge is owed 37 weeks leave and another is owed 18 weeks—which, at the present rate will continue to escalate—it was a matter of concern that those who were responsible for the judges' salaries during the time that the leave accrued should pay for it. The Attorney-General's letter indicates that that will be the case. The judges have accumulated so much leave—if one of them took it he would be away for a very long time—because there have not been sufficient judges in the court to cope with the work there has been. The ACT is being left with the matter of establishing another judge in the court and dealing with the Commonwealth's failure to maintain the court properly and see that it was adequately staffed.

The Supreme Court of the ACT hears about the same number of criminal cases as the Northern Territory, with half the number of judges. The distances that people may have to travel in the Northern Territory may create some differences, but not that many. We have to take into account the fact that the ACT Supreme Court, being in the national capital, gets caught up with national and political matters which would not normally occur in a court of this kind. For example, cases arise from things such as the AIDEX exhibition which occurred last year and the incident which occurred at the Iranian Embassy just a short time ago. This puts extra pressure on our court which means that it needs more space and more facilities than it has been given by the Commonwealth Government.

The buildings are inadequate. I lay this at the door of the Commonwealth because in the early 1980s there were proposals for a new Commonwealth courts building, so no-one can say that it is not that bad. The Commonwealth has known for a long time that the building needed to be replaced. A master and a registrar have been added to the court but the same amount of space is available now as was available when I came to Canberra in the 1960s. For that reason, I say that the Commonwealth has treated the ACT fairly shabbily.

I refer to other questions of funding. The Commonwealth has spent a lot of money on technology—as senators would know from being on Estimates committees—in establishing computers and things of that nature everywhere else in the Public Service. The Supreme Court of the ACT is still well in the nineteenth century as far as records are concerned. The records are not computerised—they are still kept on cards—and statistics have to be produced manually. Again, this is something that the Commonwealth has quite cheerfully allowed to continue to happen. The citizens of the ACT, the taxpayers of the ACT, will have to pick up the costs which were clearly the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government. The Commonwealth Government has not taken the trouble to see that modern technology was put into this court. There are other matters I could refer to.

I feel concerned about the way the Supreme Court has been left to the ACT—I am on strong ground in suggesting that the Commonwealth has been fairly negligent—because of what happened when the hospital system was left to the ACT. Millions of dollars are required just to maintain the hospital system in reasonable order as we discovered when we got it and found what had been done over the last few years.

I received a report only the other day, entitled Environmental and Process Audit May 1992 of the Lower Molonglo Quality Control Centre. The report tells us neatly on the last page that $91m is needed for the lower Molonglo waters sewerage works. That is a lot of money in a community the size of the ACT. I agree that some of that relates to the future, but some of it relates to the past—things that clearly should have been done before the sewerage works were handed over to the citizens of the ACT. When I know that about the sewerage works, and when I know what I know about the hospital system and I see the court being handed over as it is, I am inclined to wonder.

The other aspect which attracted my attention was the explanatory memorandum which says, `no financial impact to the Commonwealth'. Is it any wonder I raise the question of who will pay for the accumulated leave of the judges and some of these other things? The document, which the Attorney-General presented to the Parliament, says, `no financial impact to the Commonwealth'. We have seen what other Ministers have done to the ACT and, with good reason, we are concerned about what is happening with the Supreme Court.

I welcome the legislation. The Opposition supports it. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter from the Attorney-General, dated 4 June 1992, addressed to me, and the letter from the Attorney-General, dated 4 June 1992, addressed to Senator Spindler.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ATTORNEY-GENERAL
The Hon. Michael Duffy M.P.
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Senator M Reid
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Reid

I refer to correspondence from the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the ACT, the ACT Bar Association and the ACT Law Society about the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory.

At the outset, I should indicate my view that there appears to be some misunderstanding about the purpose of the Bill. As you will be aware, it is not necessary for the Commonwealth to enact any legislation to facilitate the transfer of the ACT Supreme Court to the ACT Government because the Self-Government Act already provides that the ACT Government is to have power to legislate in relation to the establishment of courts from 1 July 1992 when the ACT Supreme Court Act becomes an enactment of the ACT.

You will recall that when self-government was under consideration, in 1988, the Government proposed that the ACT Government should not acquire power to legislate in relation to the establishment of courts. However, the Government agreed, after a discussion in the Senate of a proposal by Senator Hill, to include a provision for the transfer of legislative power in relation to the courts by 1 July 1992. The current Bill will modify the intention previously expressed by Parliament, in order to provide the judiciary with protections that were not provided when the Self-Government Act was enacted.
What the legislation does is to provide the ACT judiciary with entrenched tenure and remuneration protection by providing—
. for the retirement ages of judges,
. for the establishment of a judicial commission to deal with the removal of judges,
. that remuneration and allowances will not be diminished while the judges hold office, and
. that a judge holds office on terms no less favourable than those applicable to a Federal Court Judge.

The legislation does not seek to direct the future structure of the ACT judicial system because the Federal Parliament has previously, in the Self-Government Act, indicated that the ACT should be treated as if it were a State to the greatest extent possible. The purpose of the legislation is to ensure that the current jurisdiction of the Court remains with it and to permit the ACT Government to add to that jurisdiction.

In respect of jurisdiction, a question has been raised as to the meaning of the phrase "that is necessary" in clause 48A(1) of the ACT (Self-Government) Act. The purpose of these words is to enable the ACT Government to expand the jurisdiction of the Court. The Court's present jurisdiction is guaranteed by both clause 48A(1) and proposed subsection 11(1) of the Supreme Court Act.

The effect of the proposed amendments of the ACT (Self-Government) Act is that the ACT will have, in its constituent document, a provision dealing with the jurisdiction of the ACT Supreme Court, which the Assembly will not, itself, be able to amend. I consider that the provision provides the ACT Supreme Court with a level of protection from Executive interference that is not available in other States and Territories. You have expressed your concern that the Bill does not expressly prohibit the repeal by the ACT Assembly of the Supreme Court Act. Although I accept the theoretical possibility that the Supreme Court Act could be repealed there are many practical reasons that I consider reduce the significance of that particular concern. Not the least of those considerations is the power of the Governor-General to disallow any ACT legislation, which is contained in subsection 35(2) of the Self-Government Act.

I note, also, the concern that amendments of subsection 7(6) of the Supreme Court Act relating to the removal of Judges are ineffective because no reference is made to the Judicial Commission. The amendment provides that a judge may be removed on an address by the ACT Assembly to the ACT Executive, rather than an address by both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament to the Governor-General. This remains the case when the Court is transferred. However, the amendment must be read subject to the other provisions of the Act. In particular, it must be read subject to new section 48D of the Self-Government Act, which provides that an ACT enactment providing for the removal of a judge must make provision for a judicial commission. Subsection 7(6) is inoperative until the judicial commission legislation is in place.

It was considered unnecessary to amend the Supreme Court Act to include the procedural provisions as these will be included in the ACT's judicial commissions legislation. It is inappropriate for the Commonwealth to provide the detail of that legislation. I have been advised that the Judicial Commissions Bill will be tabled in the next session of the ACT Assembly and that no amendment of section 7(6) of the Supreme Court Act will be required once the ACT Assembly has passed its judicial commission legislation.
In recent days a number of matters in relation to the finances of the Supreme Court have been raised. The following comments address the concerns that I have been made aware of.

Judges of the Federal Court who act as additional Judges of the Supreme Court will be paid by the Commonwealth. Remuneration for Judges who are Judges of the Federal Court on long leave will also come from the Commonwealth. The financial arrangements made with the ACT Government ensure that there will be no added costs for the ACT Government.

On the question of funding for the Court, my Department is responsible for maintenance, cleaning and security costs until 30 June 1992, and about $315,000 will be spent this year on air conditioning and Stage 3 of the refurbishment of the Court. Since the commencement of self-government the Commonwealth has upheld its commitment to maintain the courts buildings, and has expended more than a million dollars on the maintenance of the Court. In addition further amounts of $165,000 for court reporting and transcription costs and $75,000 to cover increases in jury fees were provided in the additional estimates for the 91/92 financial year.

The Commonwealth has not provided new court premises in Canberra. The construction of court premises depends on national priorities and it has been determined that greater priority exists in Melbourne and Adelaide for future court construction.

Upon transfer of the Court on 1 July 1992, the entire operational costs of the Court will be transferred to the ACT Government in accordance with the agreement reached with the ACT. After that date, funding levels for the ACT Supreme Court will be a matter for the ACT Government to determine.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL DUFFY
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
The Hon. Michael Duffy M.P.

CANBERRA ACT 2600
Senator S Spindler
