Dear Senator Spindler
I refer to your discussion this morning about the arrangements made for the payment of salary and accrued benefits of the Judges of the ACT Supreme Court.

The current Judges are also Judges of the Federal Court of Australia and the Commonwealth retains a constitutional obligation to pay their salaries. For that reason an annotated appropriation will be made to the Federal Court for the salaries of those judges. This arrangement has been negotiated by my Department, the Commonwealth Department of Finance and the ACT Treasury. If, at some future time, there are Judges of the ACT Supreme Court who do not hold federal commissions the funds for their salaries will be included in the ACT's general revenue grant and the Federal Court's annotated appropriation will be reduced accordingly.

In principle agreement has been reached by my Department and the ACT Attorney-General's Department that the Commonwealth will accept full responsibility for the accrued judicial pension entitlements of Justices Miles and Gallop. In relation to Justice Higgins, the Commonwealth will retain primary responsibility for his pension entitlements, but arrangements for the ACT to contribute to those entitlement will be made. The precise detail of those arrangements has not been finalised.

In relation to long leave, the ACT has, in principle, accepted responsibility for all long leave entitlements after 1 July 1992. Of course, in relation to the current judges the Commonwealth will be paying the Judges salaries while they are on long leave. An amount to be transferred to the ACT Government has been agreed with the ACT Treasury in relation to long leave payment obligations.

Future judges of the ACT Supreme Court will be paid by the ACT Government, and the funding arrangements for the ACT Government include amounts for the payment of salary and all other entitlements for three Judges of the ACT Supreme Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reid for her support for the ACT Supreme Court (Transfer) Bill 1992. This is a most important matter and I believe it should now be put to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 7 May 1992, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 should more properly be entitled the small business union conscription Bill. It is a Bill which gives the Industrial Relations Commission absolute jurisdiction over the use of contracts, contractors and the terms of contracts, and would give unions monopoly powers to represent contractors in the Industrial Relations Commission. What it all means in practical terms can be broken down into two categories: first, the unions now, more than ever, will be able to force small business people who do not want a bar of union membership to pay union dues and to be subject to control by power-mad union bosses; secondly, the union monopoly powers to represent contractors in the Commission will mean that individual employees and their employers will be forced to join a union.

PARA.TAB: The Bill provides, for instance, that contractors may be members of a union. Although innocent enough looking, the clause will give open slather to unions such as the TWU and the Building Workers Industrial Union, represented very ably here by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). Using the example of the TWU, in the past owner-drivers who did not wish to join a union were able to argue that they could not do so because of their status. There were numerous cases of this occurring in my home State of Queensland. They used that argument because they did not want anything to do with the union. That escape hatch has now been removed in this Bill.

What bugged the closed shop union militants was that owner-drivers could turn up at wharves, building sites, printing houses and so on where the no-ticket, no-job rule applied. They were appalled that non-union owner-drivers were not bound or owned by the union, that they worked harder and made a lot more money. No union delegate could instruct them to slow down in order to maintain featherbedding or reduce productivity. It is for this reason that contractors have always been a source of great annoyance to the trade union movement. A series of subcontractors are doing additions to my home at the moment. I was speaking to my wife on the phone this evening and she told me that the subcontractors turned up at 6 o'clock this morning in the dark and were still there in the dark tonight at 5.30.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good thing, too.

—That is a good interjection. It is an excellent thing. One of the most productive elements we have in Australia today is the cottage industry—the people who build the little homes for everyone in Australia. It has been estimated that if those people are now coerced by the BLF in Brisbane, or the BWIU in any other State where the BLF is deregistered, into becoming part of the union, first of all the earnings of those subcontractors will drop off substantially but, more importantly, the cost of building an average home will go up by about 20 to 25 per cent. That will add anything up to $20,000 to $30,000 to the price of a new home. It is hard enough for the ordinary person or young married couple to buy a house today without having that added impost. Anyone who believes that that threat has gone away with the proposed amendments to this Bill is having himself on.

PARA.TAB: At this stage there is no recognition in the Bill for employees to reach agreement with their employer without union involvement. This is particularly relevant to Metway Bank in my own State. The legislation will force union coverage on Metway, against the wishes of the employees and the employer. I understand that the Australian Democrats intend to move an amendment to the Bill which will enable organisations such as Metway to get through the gate, but for anyone coming after Metway it will no longer be available. I think that is illogical; it does not make any sense at all.

I think it is important to run over the history of Metway because it is indicative of so many other organisations in this country who, if allowed to go down this route, will end up with agreements that are beneficial not only to themselves, to the employers and the employees, but also to the community as a whole. Metway was formed in 1959, more than 30 years ago, and became a bank in 1988. It is currently the largest bank headquartered in Queensland, with assets of nearly $3 billion and offices throughout Queensland, northern New South Wales, Newcastle, Sydney and Melbourne. It has a staff of more than 1,300, many of whom are shareholders in the company. Its core business these days is banking, whether it be retail, business or funds management.

There are no restrictions in Metway on whether a person should or should not join a union. My understanding is that there are some 50 or so members of a registered union and the rest are members of the staff organisation of the Metway Group. Prior to converting from a building society to a bank, the staff were covered by the Federated Clerks Union from 1976. The staff petitioned management against union coverage, but threats by the union to stop supplies to their computer centre resulted in the staff joining under protest. That is the sort of coercion we have had in this country for so long. If this Bill is allowed to pass, it is the sort of coercion that will be exacerbated to such an extent that individuals will lose their freedom altogether.

When the bank conversion was announced, the ABEU—the union normally covering banks, now the FSU—said it would seek coverage and the FCU said it would seek to maintain coverage. We had the old demarcation dispute, the headhunters, with one union trying to get enough heads simply to get the money. They said, `To hell with the employees, to hell with the people who work there, let's build it up in a head-hunting exercise'. As it was felt that the Australian Bank Employees Union would be the most appropriate, an agreement was reached on mutually acceptable terms.

Here we had an organisation that became a bank, reached an agreement with the Bank Employees Union, and two days before conversion to a bank the union advised that the agreement was no longer satisfactory and the negotiations totally disintegrated. After conversion, the Bank Employees Union and the Federated Clerks Union continued to argue over representation. They were arguing over the body. It was unsettling for the staff, who finally acted on their own initiative to form a staff association. This is a very interesting case history.

This process led to an agreement with staff on wages and conditions which was registered under Queensland law as a voluntary employment agreement. The new State Government, the Goss Government, abolished VEAs, and Metway's VEA was replaced by an interim State award, which has been extended on a number of occasions and continues to apply. This award is union free. The union has proceeded to pursue claims in the State and Federal commissions and a number of matters are currently part heard or pending.

This is the old tack: coerce and force people into becoming members of an organisation against their will. We on this side of politics have made it very clear over and over again that we are not opposed to trade unionism but are opposed to compulsory trade unionism. We think that everyone should have the right to decide whether they wish to be a member of a union and of which union they wish to be a member. We would fight equally as hard for people to join a union as for them not to join a union.

It is often thrown up, even by some philosophers on the other side such as Senator Cooney, who quotes papal encyclicals on the matter, that people should join a union. Nothing could be further from the truth. Back at the turn of the century when these philosophical arguments were used, it was almost impossible for people to freely get together and form a union. Of course, that was the basis of the strikes that occurred back in those years. We have a different climate today, but to force people to join an organisation against their will is absolutely no different from not allowing them to join together of their own accord.

So what happened under this staff agreement with which, from my own discussions with the staff of this bank, as far as I can see, everyone is extraordinarily happy? The staff ended up with more flexible working hours. The ordinary hours were 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. for a 40-hour week. They now work 38 hours a week and those 38 hours can be worked at any time from 7.30 in the morning. That can be of benefit to mothers with young families, for instance, who want to be home either early in the morning or towards the afternoon. They can adjust their working hours. No more than 9 1/2 hours in one day or 38 hours in one week is worked.

The salary structure moved away from age and years of service to grades and pay on performance. In other words, people were paid on merit, on their ability to do the job better. Is that not what this country needs today? It is crying out for this sort of thing. We do not want mediocrity. We want people to be rewarded for the type of work they do. The bank introduced part time employees as well as casuals. There was time off in lieu of overtime. It is very sensible sort of stuff but impossible to get through under the structured union system and the centralised wage fixing system we have in this country. There was cash in lieu of one week per year annual leave; casual loading was increased to 20 per cent; a higher duties allowance was paid after five days; there was a branch restructure; and there were skills based training programs—all things that are required in this country.

I think it is interesting to ask what the effect was on the bank and its staff. The bank moved totally to an in-house enterprise agreement with the parties. They had a personal stake in the agreement and did the negotiating. There was not some remote person 1,000 or even 100 kilometres away. They had an interest in the agreement. There was an ownership of the employee relations program. The bank and the people who work there took total responsibility for their own future.

This is the sort of philosophy we have seen in successful countries in Asia such as Japan. I spent many years going to Japan and I never got used to the idea of the incredible attitude: `If the organisation with whom I work is successful, I will succeed and I will do better; if it fails, I will fail, I will lose my job, my family will not have a breadwinner'. I often recount the story of being in Japan over a decade ago when one of the major companies in fact had a strike. It would not be the case today. When I asked what the strike was about I was told that it was very embarrassing. I said, `Well, it might be embarrassing, but why are you having a strike?'. I was told, `We have cut the working week back from six to 5 1/2 days. The workers believe we will lose our competitiveness on world markets, we will become less competitive; therefore, they are objecting to our doing something which might affect their long term livelihood'. What a different attitude.

The enterprise agreement at Metway—which is an example and why I am quoting it in detail—is the sort of agreement we could copy throughout Australia. Sure, it would destroy the power of these union moguls at the top of the union movement, but if they only thought it through they would find that they would still have a degree of influence within the enterprise itself. That is where it counts; that is what matters. I have heard union people say over the years that they will not give up certain restrictive work practices. The phrase one hears all the time when they say they will not give up work practices is `giving up hard-won gains'. They do not want to give up hard-won gains because they think it will have some sort of domino effect across the board as a result of the centralised wage fixing system. It is the flow-on domino effect. That is exactly what is wrong with it. The enterprise agreement removed all barriers between `them and us'. That is very important.

In my own working life before coming into this place we never had a `them and us' syndrome, but I recall a valiant attempt by militant union leaders to build it up, to create this artificial `them and us'. This is not a Kipling society of `East is East, and West is West. . . '. We are all Australians and we should all be moving in the same direction and working as a group to enhance our own productivity, profitability and, of course, standard of living.

The line managers in Metway are managing; they are leaders and accepting much more responsibility. Communications have improved; people discuss how to make ideas work to increase quality and productivity. They have eliminated most of the small complaints. This is very important because it is often small complaints that are built up out of all proportion that cause industrial problems. If those things are done in an atmosphere of an enterprise agreement, they are more likely to be sorted out than by one party rushing off to a third party and the other one rushing off to another one. It becomes almost like a divorce situation in which there are a couple of lawyers who have a vested interest in keeping the fight going. That sort of thing disappears in an enterprise agreement.

In Metway, complacency has gone; the staff association understands the business decisions and understands the rationale of thinking. I have tried to indicate all through this that enterprise bargaining is all about making a genuine attempt to improve competitiveness and, in so doing, to work with staff on enhancing their wages and conditions on the basis of real and demonstrable gains in productivity, efficiency and flexibility.

The bank, which was only launched four years ago, has been extremely successful. It is not one of those that got into difficulties. It did not take big risks, so it did not have a lot of non-performing loans. In other words, it played within its own class and I think this has been shown by the benefits that have flowed through. I can say from my own personal experience that dealing with that bank is a joy. It is like going back in time—not that everything back in time is good—because one gets that personal treatment that there used to be. One is no longer like talking to a computer, which I know is the feeling we get today when dealing with the larger organisations. One is dealing with people. That is what has come out of this special arrangement at Metway.

I have not gone into the Metway example to single it out and say, `Here is one sitting up there'. There will be Metways all around Australia if they are permitted to do what they want to do. When I say `they' I do not just mean the employer organisation, the shareholder owned part of an organisation; I mean the people who work there. A lot of points have been made about what people call sham agreements. I am aware of sham agreements in quite a number of industries. I am aware of $2 companies set up as employment groups that hire off their labour back to themselves.

They do it because the employees also want to do it. They do not want to walk out the gate. They want to get in there and be productive and they want to be paid for their output and their increased productivity. They do not want everyone to be dressed up in Chairman Mao tunics where all the work is the same, where there is no such thing as good or bad and where there is no such thing as a good worker or a bad worker. People who apply themselves to a particular job know that the results of their hard work will show and that they themselves will end up being more productive. We have to get away from featherbedding and so on.

Towards the end of last week I had the opportunity to speak to a builder—a good builder. This person had been apprenticed many years ago. One of the things that this builder taught his son, who had also decided to become a builder, was to be efficient. As an apprentice, he taught him that he must be able to do things in the shortest possible time without affecting the quality of the job. This is a very important requirement, particularly in the home building side of the industry. If a builder does not do a good job, his mistakes will come back to haunt him. The builder told me that he can recall telling his son that if the son could not do a certain job in half an hour he should stop being a builder. The son then challenged the old man and said, `Well, you show me'. The father said that he did it in 15 minutes.

The father then told me that in the last six month his son has been working in a closed shop organisation. The son rang up his father and said, `Listen, these fellows have told me to slow down. When they told me the first time, I slowed down a little bit. They said, "You don't understand mate. You've got to cut it right in half because unless you do so they might find out that there is more work we can do within the given hour. Some of us could lose our jobs"'. That is old fashioned, archaic, Luddite mentality which is exacerbated by a centralised system and by a Bill which, if allowed to go through this place, will make this country less productive at a time when we are crying out for increased productivity to ensure that not only are we equally competitive with the rest of the world but that we are more competitive.

It should be the aim of all people from the day they go to school to be the best at what they attempt to do. They do not have to be the best and I do not think anyone should expect people, even their children, to be so. But all that can be asked is for someone to work at being the best. There is no greater shame than for a person with ability to work below his capacity and not do very well. Such a person deserves to be the subject of extreme criticism. People without ability who work hard to achieve what they can are to be praised.

The Minister for Industrial Relations is responsible for this Bill. Senator Cook is often referred to by people on this side of the chamber as the Minister for the BWIU and the Minister assisting the President of the ACTU. Before he came to this place, Senator Cook was the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia and also, I think, an official in the BWIU. Even though his membership is common knowledge and was disclosed by him, for some strange reason last week in debate it took him two hours to admit that he was a member of the BWIU. Senator Ray, in an attempt to defend Senator Cook, kept interjecting on me with such profound words as, `so what?'.

I would have to say to you, Mr Deputy President, that if ever there were a conflict of interest, it is in this instance. Here we have a person committed to the trade union movement, committed to the BWIU, bringing in a piece of legislation that will make it easy for the BWIU itself to recruit people within its ranks who do not want to be members of that union. In other words, as I said at the beginning of my speech, this Bill should more correctly be called the small business union conscription Bill.

Why is this matter so important? Everyone is aware that the Labor Party is made up of two arms—the industrial arm, which is the unions, and the political arm which is represented by people who come into parliament. I do not know about the preselection process of the Australian Democrats but I know that our preselection process covers a very broad range of people. Labor Party candidates who do not have the unions on side will not gain preselection. I understand that 60 per cent of people on Labor Party preselection panels come from the trade unions. The branches do not matter. So, individual Labor members and senators are in fact owned by particular unions. And Senator Cook is the BWIU man in this Parliament.

We have made it quite clear right from the word go that we are opposed to this Bill. Obviously, the Minister has brought in this Bill in an attempt further to entrench his trade union mates in one of the few areas in Australia—and I think this is the sad part—which is really productive. Everybody knows that once these people are unionised, they will become less productive. Not only will they become less productive, which is bad for the country, but they will earn less money.

A lot of Opposition senators want to speak in this debate because they feel very strongly about the Bill. I am aware of some of the amendments that will be put forward by the Government and the Democrats. Although some of the Democrat amendments would certainly improve the Bill, I should point out that the Bill is not accepted by the business community. I know that some members of the business community have come out and said that the Bill is better than what is in place at the moment. But when one talks to them one finds that they oppose the Bill altogether. They think that maybe the Labor Government and the Minister for Industrial Relations have achieved the best they can. In other words, they have compromised on the basis that nothing better can be achieved. But if given the opportunity to do so, those people will make it quite clear that they are opposed to the whole Bill.

I point out that the Australian Democrats' amendment will let through only the Metway Bank and maybe one or two others who are already there. But it shuts the gate for anyone else who would like to repeat the Metway experience. So I would ask the Democrats to reconsider their amendment.

Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to move a motion to vary the order of the Senate today referring the IR Bill 1992 to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. In other words, we are going to suggest that it be referred to another committee.
Motion (by Senator Parer)—by leave—agreed to:
That the order of the Senate be varied to refer the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I received a letter, probably letter No. 3,600 and something or other. But this particular letter was different from those that preceded it on this subject because it was not immediately apparent that it was addressing the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, that is before us at the moment. The letter I received was from the Transport Workers Union of Australia, Tasmanian branch, and signed by Mr Ken Bacon, the branch secretary. He begins:

PARA.TAB: I write on behalf of log truck operators currently stood down as a direct result of the APPM/North Broken Hill-Peko "restructuring" exercise.

It is not widely known that these contractors, many with long periods of service, have been effectively sacked by APPM/North Broken Hill as of June 1st. From that time, they are expected to work directly from the harvesting contractors, with all that that means in terms of loss of security and regular income.

SPEECH.PARA: He continues:

The log hauliers situation is made increasingly difficult when the harvesting contracts are scrutinised. These contracts, under any light, are neither fair nor equitable but the harvest contractors are not in any position to refuse to sign as required.

PARA.TAB: The most reasonable proposal for contractual arrangements, and one in line with the State Forest Industry Strategy and subsequent legislation, is the idea of a three way contract that puts specific rights and obligations on all the parties—APP/North Broken Hill as the principal; the harvesting contractor, and the log haulier.

SPEECH.PARA: He refers then to an enclosed sample contract for my information. The next paragraph of this letter reads:

PARA.TAB: What is desperately needed in this area is the creation of a contracts tribunal—an independent arbitrator either as a separate entity or attached to the State or Federal Industrial Commissions. In this regard, your support would be most welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter continues with a couple of other niceties, but the central point was the last paragraph. As far as I am concerned, such matter as was raised in that last paragraph is certainly the subject of this legislation. As I interpret it, this legislation provides an essential part of the answer to the problems being faced by independent contractors working as log hauliers in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Other examples of the need for legislation in this area abound in our community. Several of them have been brought to my attention in recent weeks, not that I did not previously know of some examples. I brought to this chamber an example of one which I had been the subject of some 20-odd years ago. Good examples of this very same need can also be found in New Zealand, the place which is often quoted as being `the' place to go to observe industrial relations, individual contracts, et cetera, in application in real life.

I have an example of the real life situation that applies today in New Zealand, as it was obtained just a few days ago by Senator Powell on her visit to New Zealand. She has provided me with a copy of an actual contract which was `negotiated'—and I use that term in a very serious manner; I may come back to that in a minute. This contract was negotiated between truck drivers and the company that they were working with.
I think one of the most important things to see in this contract is the lack of opportunity for negotiation; rates are spelt out. Section 3 of this contract reads:

SPEECH.PARA: During the first 12 months of employment with the company, including the three month probationary period, the employee—
note the word `employee'—
shall be paid an hourly rate of $12.50 an hour.

That is $NZ12.50. At the current exchange rate, $NZ140.76 equals $A100, so that particular person would net somewhere between $A8 and $A9 an hour. At the expiration of the first 12 months, the ordinary rate would be increased to $NZ13.50 an hour.

PARA.TAB: At that point I would just like to take up one of the things that Senator Parer was mentioning. In some way, the term `contract' was associated somehow, perhaps by osmosis, as guaranteeing sort of payment for productivity. Here we have an example of a so-called contract in which, after 12 months, the pay rate would be increased by a dollar, with no mention of a test for productivity, skill or any other qualifications that would bring that result.

As I worked my way through this contract, it became immediately apparent to me that it is an employment agreement to disguise the operator of the company vehicle as a contractor. In no way does this person have the capacity to negotiate terms, to talk about productivity, to vary the nature of the employment, to pass any of the tests which would normally be applied to determine whether somebody was a contractor or not. We find in part 11(c) of this so-called contract, there is the requirement that the person work exclusively for the company, except with the prior written consent of the company. To me, that shuts the gate as far as the definition of the person being an employee.

I agree with Senator Parer and many of the other commentators who have talked about the advantages of being an independent contractor. One of those advantages is, in fact, the capacity to exercise that independence and to engage in contracts with a variety of principles. There is no doubt that that is an advantage, one which is exercised by many people and which contributes to the effectiveness and efficiency of, for example, our housing industry.

The document brought to me from New Zealand by Senator Powell is one which should terrify us. It is a document which exemplifies the sort of attitude that prevails in that country now. In essence, it is saying to an employee, `We are going to rearrange your employment status; here is your contract—like it or lump it'. In fact, that is what the negotiations consist of. Senator Powell told

SPEECH.PARA: me of the style of negotiation used. It involved the principal of the company lobbing up to the truck, sitting in the cab next to the driver and suggesting, in a one-on-one conversation, that this was the only option that the person had because the remainder of the work force had signed the contract and some people would have to leave the employment of the company. It was a case of saying, `So there it is; do you want to sign it now?'.

PARA.TAB: That sort of negotiation seems to be recommended by those who espouse freedom and the opportunity for individuals to make choices on their own behalf. But I have said in public, and I repeat for this particular debate, that no matter how big, strong, noisy, fat and ugly somebody might be, that person is not necessarily qualified as a negotiator. Some of the wisest of these people have been able to recognise negotiation skills and elect others to do that on their behalf. This is a process which has taken 100 years to evolve. We now have recognised within our society the right to delegate, the right to elect, the right to appoint others to negotiate on our behalf. The old concept of the law of the jungle and the survival of the biggest and the strongest is not the concept which belongs in twentieth century Australia, much less in twenty-first century Australia, which is approaching.

Leaving that and returning to the idea of deciding whether a particular person is an employee or a contractor—because I think it is germane to this debate—I point out that the Australian Taxation Office uses similar terms to those I have used already in discussing the New Zealand contract. The Taxation Office uses those terms to identify whether a person is a contractor or an employee. Although the Taxation Office's tests are to determine the liability for PAYE payments, I believe those tests are relevant to this debate.

I quote from part of the CCH Digest, the digest of Australian income tax rulings which is commonly used in taxation law. This ruling is dated 19 March 1985, and the ruling number given is IT 2129. I quote from it because it is instructive:

SPEECH.PARA: The presence of a right to control how, where, when and who is to carry out particular work points very strongly and usually conclusively to employee status.

If the result of the "control" test is inconclusive, the "integration" test may be used. A person may be an employee if he is part and parcel of the principal's business organisation. A person satisfies the integration test if the relationship with his principal is a continuing one, or if his activities are restricted to providing service to one principal, or if the benefit arising from his work flows to the principal rather than to himself.
A contract that disguises what is really a master and servant relationship will not avoid the requirement for instalments to be deducted.

I know that we are not talking about whether PAYE instalments should be deducted, but I am still making the point that it is a relevant part of the test which should be applied to determine whether somebody is an employee or an independent contractor. I continue quoting from the Taxation Office's decision:

Timber workers, fruit and vegetable pickers, mining and exploration field workers and shearers are regarded as employees where their work is performed under the direction and control of the owner or principal contractor. Fishermen who work under the direction and control of the owner/operator of the fishing vessel are also regarded as employees even if they are paid on a "share of the catch" basis. Where in such cases a master and servant relationship does not exist tax instalments are still considered necessary in most instances because the payments are considered to be wholly or principally for the labour of the person.
The next passage is under the heading `Payments for labour'. It reads:

A payment made wholly or principally for the labour of the payee is subject to tax instalment deductions by virtue of the extended definition in para. (a) of the definition of "salary or wages" in sec. 221A(1). The purpose of the extended definition is to encompass payments to any individual who, although a contractor, is virtually in the position of an employee. In deciding whether an individual stands in this position, the following questions should be considered—
and this is where I think it is particularly relevant to this debate—

1. Does the individual perform tasks under general conditions similar to those applicable to employees? Whether he is paid in a similar way to an employee, whether he is provided with an office or workshop or other facilities, and whether he is expected to work towards an end preconceived and defined not by him but by someone else, are relevant considerations.
2. Is the individual integrated in the business organisation of the principal, rather than being an accessory?

There is a little more on that, but I think the most relevant parts have been quoted. In those definitions there were examples, which may have sounded familiar to some honourable senators, of industries in which the question of designating somebody, a contractor, when they are really an employee has often arisen.

PARA.TAB: The trouble is that in following that debate it is usually assumed that we are pointing the finger at the area of private enterprise. Lest it be assumed that these tests need to be applied only within the private enterprise sector, I think we should consider a letter from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I think it is a damning piece of evidence of the inability of some sectors of the Government to understand exactly what the heck they are doing. This particular letter is signed `D.L. Westcott, Director, Language Services', and is dated 23 January this year. Part of it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Interpreters and translators engaged by TIS are required to sign and abide by the terms as laid out in these documents as a condition of their employment with TIS.
The document referred to ignores all and every one of the tests that I have already quoted. In fact, section 5.1 on page 6 of the document reads:
If the Language Service Provider is working as an Interpreter under this Agreement, he/she will not solicit work in a private capacity . . .

To me, that damns this document as a contractual agreement. The person signing it cannot possibly be considered an independent contractor because he does not have the capacity to make an agreement with a variety of principals; he is bound to this Department. As such, he really should be considered an employee. Essentially, being bound as an employee then brings with it the rights and obligations of being an employee and does not allow the freedoms and opportunities of being an independent contractor, able to solicit work from whomever that contractor might desire. A second test is failed by this document. Section 5.2 reads:
. . . a Language Service Provider working as an Interpreter—
(a) must present himself/herself to clients in person; and
(b) must not substitute another person to undertake the Language Services.

Again, the person who is supposed to become a contractor is suddenly denied the opportunity to subcontract that work out. Senator Panizza would know that one of the opportunities provided to all contractors is to pass down the work, if it is seen fit, to have the work done in any way that the contractor would choose to have done.

PARA.TAB: The people who are the subject of this document in fact organised themselves a little and wrote a letter to Dr Andrew Theophanous MP. In part, the letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the most fundamental issues of concern include:

1. Any "agreement" as the contract is termed, must have at least two parties; this "agreement" was totally unilateral without involvement of AUSIT representing the professional interests of interpreters and translators.
2. An amended form of the AUSIT Code of Ethics was attached to the contracts; such amendments were made without consultation or agreement of AUSIT.

In other words, the professional organisation had been ignored, and even its code of ethics had been altered without its consultation. Eight other concerns are spelt out. Even No. 6 of these concerns is most alarming. It reads:
6. While the contract enumerates at length the rights of DILGEA, the interpreters/translators are stripped of fundamental rights including:
* intellectual property rights
* indemnity
* workers' compensation
* right to terminate the contract
* right to sub-contract
* right to refuse DILGEA's entry into their homes
* right to question DILGEA's "conflict of interest".

I do not enjoy presenting this to the Parliament. I would have thought that the Government would have been responsible enough to realise that such moves compromise the independence of people working for it and certainly do not set a good example. This is the very reason why such legislation is necessary, legislation which gives people who are subjected to unfair negotiation processes and unfair administration of their working conditions the opportunity to have their concerns addressed by the Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: This legislation allows that to take place. The last contract I read to the chamber is very much the sort of contract which is far too common in our society. It illustrates the sort of negotiation which takes place and brings to us the sort of industrial chaos that we saw on our television screens only an hour or so ago: the sort of industrial chaos which comes from the unilateral declaration of a set of working conditions with little opportunity for the affected parties, the workers, to challenge the basis of what is being offered and to have the arrangements reviewed by an independent party.

We could spend a fair bit of time considering that particular debate that is only too familiar to us. But it is for the reason that this legislation will allow the opportunity for those who are aggrieved by what is offered to them to approach the Industrial Relations Commission that this legislation has our hearty support.

Part of the problem with this Bill is that before it had its first public hearing a campaign was wound up by those opposed to the concept of unions being involved in the industrial relations scene. The anti-unionists were paranoid about the potential of any Bill that mentioned the words `independent contractor'. Without even seeing the Bill, hundreds, even thousands, of people were frightened into writing—mainly to me—because they were told—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are kidding yourself.

—Yes, I am. I will give Senator Walters my letters to answer any day. The justification I have for saying that is that I have seen several examples of the advertisements and the fliers that were handed out, with my name and address on them, and the suggestion that the matter before us could be the subject of our exercising what was termed the balance of power.

PARA.TAB: These people were frightened by the lethal mixture of truth, exaggeration and imaginative assumptions. In fact, over 1,800 people wrote identical letters. They started with such words as `We are extremely concerned. . . '. I question the level of concern because the people who were apparently concerned were unable to follow up either by obtaining a copy of the Bill or by taking the trouble to write down what their personal concerns were. They simply copied a letter that had been provided to them by another party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Standard letters go out all the time.

—If Senator Walters would care to listen, I will explain the nonsense of what they were conned into doing. The majority of the letters were written to me on the letterhead of proprietary limited companies. The poor people who had been frightened into writing these letters were neither the subject nor the object of the Bill. I could see no capacity whatsoever within the Bill to consider commercial bodies as employees.

PARA.TAB: I have already given examples from the Tax Office and from within our community. None of those could be construed as being addressed to proprietary limited companies. In fact, I have the advice of a Queen's Counsel that the Bill is directed to natural persons. Of the 3,600 people who wrote to me, I estimate that about 12 were natural persons. The others were trading as companies. The nonsense of it is that it is about as stupid—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that? A husband and wife can do that.

—Of course, and it is about as stupid to suggest that they be considered employees as it is to suggest that BHP could be considered an employee of anybody with whom it engages in a contract. That is the stupidity of the paranoia generated by the anti-unionists, who frightened these companies into writing, suggesting that they would be the subject of this legislation. They never were and they will not be now because the amendment to be moved by the Democrats will remove from the Bill any possibility of enforced unionism.
—Do you seriously believe that there will not be any enforced unionism from this Bill as it stands?

—I did not say that. I said that because of the amendments I intend to move, the Bill will no longer contain any prospect of enforced unionism. I have had distributed two pages of amendments. I hope the Opposition sees the sense of the process that led to those amendments and the effect they will have.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister said in a recent press release, the concern about the Bill's capacity to enforce unionism was perhaps based on a misunderstanding. To ensure that the misunderstanding is not perpetuated, the Democrats will move an amendment to delete the clause which has the potential to require those approaching the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to be members of a union. The potential to require an aggrieved party to be a member of a union before approaching the IRC is contained in a couple of other clauses. I foreshadow that the Democrats will move consequential amendments to remove that possibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell has a lot to learn about proprietary companies. He must think that one needs 1,000 or 2,000 people or 100,000 shareholders to form a proprietary company. I have never known of a Bill that forces anyone to join a union but I have known plenty of Bills that allow unions to force people into them. I think Senator Bell should learn about that.

PARA.TAB: We are debating this evening the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. In broad terms, this Bill, firstly, gives the Australian Industrial Relations Commission extensive new powers over independent contractors—whether they are prime contractors or subcontractors, I presume; secondly, replaces existing provisions relating to certified agreements; and, thirdly, confers specific duties on the new office of Vice President of the AIRC relating to union amalgamations.

As Senator Parer said earlier, this Bill would be more aptly named the trade union subscription Bill. This Bill will have its greatest effect on the cottage industry, and I believe that that is what it is aimed at. It is designed to do nothing else but provide for trade union membership. It is not designed to force building workers or contractors or anyone else into the union; it is letting the union do that. It is designed to extend drastically trade union control over the cottage industry by recruiting contractors as union members.

Many people fail to understand that a lot of subcontractors especially are members of unions. They have the right to work as independent contractors, to work for a prime contractor or to work for a contractor who is building one house, two houses, or 100 houses. That is the relationship. They have a job to do; the contractor and the subcontractor sit down and come to an arrangement.

Does anyone in this chamber believe that if a subcontractor is asked to take on a contract that he does not think will give him normal wages he will sign that agreement? He absolutely will not sign an agreement if he sees that he will make less than normal wages out of the job; he will not make a living out of it. He will sign the agreement if he sees that he can do better than wages, otherwise he will go and get a wages job somewhere else. It is as simple as that. This Bill is designed to challenge the right of employers to use contractors. It provides unlimited scope to harass employees to go into the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't get many other jobs if you are a translator of Spanish.
—What was that? Anyhow, it does not matter.
—No, it does not matter. You are not interested, are you?

—I am interested. I am saying that employees have the right to go somewhere else if they do not get enough reward for their work. They have that right, just as I have the right to employ whoever I like. I can put a worker on contract or I can put him on by the hour or whatever I like.
—And he would be happy with whatever you put him on for.
—Yes, he will be happy to do it as long as he is getting a reasonable return for it.
—The log hauliers have nowhere else to work.

—Blame the Labor Government that put them in that position if they do not have any work. I will talk mainly about the cottage industry because that is what I am interested in at the moment. I should declare my interest, just in case I am picked up later on; I build a few cottages and rental units and things like that. In the last 12 months or so the construction of high-rise buildings has stopped. That is where the union dominance was, and now the trade union officials have nothing else to do but interfere with the cottage industry, which has been working so well. The trade unions want to have a say in whether builders use subcontractors.

PARA.TAB: The builders claim—and I believe they are right—that if this Bill goes through as is it will put up the cost of an average Australian cottage by $25,000, and in a lot of cases by more than that. The average Australian cottage would cost about $90,000; $25,000 on top of that would make it a very expensive cottage. What does this do for the average Australian about whom Senator Bell is worried, the average Australian about whom the trade unions are worried, or are supposed to be? I am not a union basher; my father came out of the unions. If this Government wants to look after people, the first thing it can do is give them a reasonable wage and the chance of owning their own home—the great Australian dream. By forcing prices up by $30,000, housing will be beyond the level of affordability.

Even under this Government, interest rates have come down from their record high. One can borrow to build a house at interest rates of around 10.5 to 11 per cent, whereas 12 months ago the figure was up to 17 or 18 per cent. Just when Australian workers—young Australians, old Australians, anyone—are getting to the stage where they can afford to buy a house or upgrade their housing, the price is going to be forced up by 25 to 30 per cent. This will also drive up the cost of existing housing. Do not tell me it will not do that; it will. If a person cannot afford to build a new house, he will look at buying an existing house or he will continue renting, and prices will be forced up.

A lot of property investors around Australia are laughing at this Bill. I asked an architect in Perth recently what he thought of this industrial relations Bill that was going to force up the price of housing. He was a fellow of around 50 or 55, looking towards retirement. He said, `At my stage of life, I'm laughing'. I asked him why. He said, `Because everything I own will be pushed up by 25 to 30 per cent'. He is right; that is what this Bill will do. Young people who are battling in this recession to get their first home will not be able to do so. Even existing buildings will be less affordable. There will be pressure on rentals and the cost of renting will rise.

We are in the worst depression we have had in 60 years, or probably in Australian history, and we are not coming out of it now, even though this Government thinks we are. In the worst part of this recession or depression or whatever it is, the vacancy ratio in Perth went up to only about 4.4 per cent to 5 per cent. Because of the downturn in new housing, that figure has already gone down to 2.2 per cent. If the cost of building or buying an existing house or of renting goes up by 25 or 30 per cent, the person who owns the house needs a better return and the vacancy rate will be wiped out. That is great for the people who hold rental properties, but it does not do anything for the average Australians whom these unions pretend they represent.

If this situation continues, I fear for the young people of Australia. We all have families to worry about, whether or not the unions worry about them. This is the result of Senator Cook's actions, when he pretends to represent the Australian worker. Whilst Senator Cook admits the cost increases, he insists that we will get better quality housing. Most Australians are more concerned about being able to buy their first house than about getting better quality. What is the point of getting better quality housing if people cannot afford it? Mr Acting Deputy President, if you want to trade in your Falcon or whatever it is in on, say, a Mercedes, while it would be a much better quality car to drive, it is not much good looking at a better quality car in the showroom if you cannot afford it. So it is a stupid argument for Senator Cook to say that we will get better quality housing. I do not believe we will.

As I said before, I have had a bit of experience in construction and real estate and I have found that some houses are better quality than others because of the fact that certain subcontracting teams specialise. Roofers, plasterers, grano workers and electricians specialise and work as a team. A team generally comprises two or three tradesmen and an apprentice. Roofers generally have three tradesmen on a team; an electrician works one for one, that is, a tradesman and one apprentice; and grano workers generally have three members in a reasonable sized team and five in bigger teams. They specialise and that is why there is better quality housing. That is better than employing one fellow here, another fellow there on each job and trying to bring those workers' efforts together in the completed job. A team working on a site has to be just that—a team. Subcontracting teams work together because they like working together. They may be mates and know how to complement each other. But when one man is recruited here and another here on each job, they do not necessarily work together. The specialisation occurs in the subcontracting team rather than the other way around.

I mentioned grano workers and would cite them as an example. If grano workers are working on high-rise buildings and are ready for a pour at lunchtime, under the usual regulations on the day labour system they knock off at 12 o'clock and they let the cement go off the mix. Worse still, if they have just done a pour, the union fellow may come around and tell everyone to get off the job. That used to happen, and still does, on the big sites. Senator Cook knew a lot about that in Western Australia in the 1970s. If Government members do not believe me, I will give them a few quotes later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was secretary of the union then.

—He was secretary of the TLC, I think. I know that employees have no incentive to work as a team or produce a well finished product. Their incentive is to pick up their wages at the end of the day. If employees do not want to work for the money that is offered, they are free to go somewhere else.

PARA.TAB: Why are Australians the most efficient cottage builders in the world? The answer is that Australia not only has the most efficient cottage building industry but it has the best building codes. Incidentally, some States have better building codes than others. At the same time, we have the most inefficient high-rise building industry in the world. The Gyles Royal Commission explained the situation in its report only last week. The royal commission outlined the rorts that have been operating in the building industry by the union and by the master builders. That is where the problems in the building industry are to be found. They do not exist in the cottage industry where subcontractors work.

So far I have only addressed the building industry, and that is why Senator Cook is pushing the hardest for this Bill, but effect of the Bill does not finish there. The reason this Bill is before us in the Senate at present is that the advent of high-rise buildings is now at an end. The cranes have disappeared, most having been exported to Singapore where a lot of work is going on. High-rise building around Australia is ending—with one exception, and that is in Canberra. The high-rise building industry is ever expanding in this city because of the ever expanding Federal Government's civil service. We saw the deal that was done last week between the Labor Party and the Government on the building for the Australian National Audit Office, but time prevents my going into that matter further.

With the end of high-rise buildings, the union dominance on those sites will move to other areas. As I said before, it is not limited to any particular industry or organisation, and most definitely not to the building industry. The contracting system is used in the mining, rural and transport industries. The transport industry is very important and the largest number of letters I receive relate to the transport industry. For example, a prime contractor takes on a reasonable sized contract and engages subbies who have the use of one vehicle. The contractor came to an arrangement before he looked for that contract. If the subcontractors did not agree to that, they did not offer their services. If they thought they would not get a reasonable return with one vehicle, whether large or small, they would not have gone into it. They came to an agreement with the prime contractor and the prime contractor got a contract. Now Senator Cook seeks to interfere with subcontractors. The result will be that the prime contractor will go broke and the person he is working for will have problems as well.

The Industrial Relations Commission will be permitted to vary, or even set aside, agreements freely entered into between an employer and an independent contractor. The important thing to bear in mind is that a less than honest contractor can cut his price to get a job. He can cut the price down to the minimum and get the job ahead of others who charge higher prices. Once he has started the job, he can then run to the IRC. Government members need not tell me that that cannot be done. At the end of the job the contractor could say, `I have not made enough at this. Now you tell me what I should have made and I will have to be paid'. There is no appeal. The amount set down will have to be paid without appeal.
I am involved in the farming industry, an industry that uses many subcontractors. I have in mind the shearing industry, contract harvesting, fencing and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —New Zealanders.

—Yes, I am proud to have employed New Zealanders. New Zealanders do not shear sheep for less than Australian awards and Senator Sherry should know that. But he has never been inside a shearing shed and should stick to the liquor trade, a trade that he is more used to.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the subcontracting system exists in the rural industry and subcontractors work very well with shearing, ploughing and fencing contractors. One particular person could take on a fencing contract. I could give a fencing contract for 12 kilometres of fencing to a subcontractor, supply the material, peg out the line and tell the subcontractor to go for his life. I could go away—perhaps come here for a fortnight because there are others there to watch what is going on and at the end the subcontractor could say, `I did not make enough out of this, so I will go to the Industrial Relations Commission and get more'. One has to pay up without any rights of appeal.

This Bill is all about union power. As well as union power, it is about Senator Cook's ideology as part of an agenda that, to my knowledge, he commissioned way back in the 1970s in Western Australia. I used to watch him on television night after night, the little bounce that he was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—It is a pity Senator Sherry was not around in those days to see how Senator Cook went on, but he went quiet after a while. He was skiting how he was going to cause further strikes and hold-ups on construction sites. Now he is a Federal Minister, and any Federal Minister in this place or in the other place should be working for the good of all Australians and not just for the BWIU, or any other favourite union that the Minister used to belong to. That applies to anyone in this place. The Minister has his own agenda which is not necessarily for the good of the average Australian worker, let alone for anyone else. Obviously there will be higher and higher costs and more and more unemployment. But Senator Cook does not worry about that. Australia has one million unemployed and yet the Minister is putting forward this sort of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, subcontracting is an opportunity for subcontractors to get into business themselves. Even Senator Foreman might recognise that fact. They start off as subcontractors, but the enterprising ones generally work towards a building ticket. They attend night school or something similar. They may be plumbers, electricians, granos or brickies and they get their building ticket at night school. So they then become prime contractors themselves.

What is going to be done now? Day labourers and people without hands-on experience in the building industry are going to try to get into business; the result will generally be disaster. That point is very important.
I mentioned Senator Cook and how he used to carry on in the 1970s. I will quote some of the relevant statements of the time. I will only selectively quote, otherwise I will be here all night:

SPEECH.PARA: After the 5 1/2 hour ACTU meeting, Mr Cook conveyed the resolution by telephone to TLC officers in Perth.

The Ban would halt the export of iron ore, bauxite, mineral sands, wood chips and nickel. There would also be a later move to extend the ban to include all key exports from Australia, including coal from Queensland.
This was supposed to be good for Australia. It occurred on 20 June 1979. Do not tell me Senator Cook was not a big little boy then! His idea was that cutting off all exports was good for Australia.

PARA.TAB: A newspaper article written before Senator Cook came to Federal Parliament said:

SPEECH.PARA: He enjoyed the role of industrial fireman—
not an industrial hoser down, but an industrial fireman—
but now wants to be a "long-term builder"—
I do not think he will be a long term builder the way he is going—
with hopes of acquiring a better understanding of what causes the conflict.
He has not learned much since 1979. The article continues:
He enjoyed being at the centre of the major disputes in WA—
he enjoyed causing them—
in recent years—the long stoppage at Mt Newman in 1977; the 11-week strike at Hamersley Iron in 1979; and the two-year battle for the 36-hour week at Alcoa.
The article continues:
He said: "Certainly one reason was the alliance that we had—
this was at the time of the big Noonkanbah dispute—
with the Aboriginal people—they took the decisions and we carried them out.
So Senator Cook even interfered there. He certainly came out second best.

PARA.TAB: I will summarise what is wrong with this Bill. Independent contractors are the backbone of the housing industry of Australia. That is why so many Australians can afford houses. I know that many more Australians, especially young Australians, but also older Australians, would like to own their own houses; But, by comparison with world standards, the number of people who own their own houses in Australia is fairly high, especially for people of foreign extraction. If this Bill is carried, that number will be cut back.

Independent subcontractors are the backbone of the housing industry, which is a shining example of flexible labour marketing operations. Senator Collins is always telling us how flexible the waterfront is. It is certainly inflexible when one thinks of how those involved in it carry on.

Why does a subcontractor, previously a tradesman, abandon a day job? He abandons it because he thinks he can do better. Builders are abandoning the security of company jobs and industrial awards for the satisfaction of relying on their own ability to succeed. I have already said that their earnings depend on establishing a reputation for quality and reliability. People will employ someone with a track record to build a house for them; they will not employ someone who comes from one job on a single building site, especially if it is a high-rise building site. I would not look at such a person a second time. After these tradespeople have done their share as subbies, they go on to establish their own businesses. Bringing self-employed contractors under the Industrial Relations Commission is certainly the wrong way to go.

It is ironic that, at a time when Australia must achieve more flexible arrangements in the labour market—Senator Collins claims to have flexible arrangements on the waterfront; he seems to be leaving Mr Sharp alone these days because Mr Sharp has moved out of that portfolio—the Federal Government is trying to erode one of the best examples of enterprise bargaining in the national economy. Senator Bell mentioned how employees are given contracts which they are forced to sign; they are told, `Sign this—or else go down the road'. We are in a deep recession; it was a depression. It was not so long ago—just before this Government came into power and in its early years, before it sent us to the depths of despair we are in now—that things used to be vastly different in the building industry. There was no call for union domination then because tradesman could demand what they liked.

I remember building in the country in 1984. One had to pay twice what is paid now to get a brickie team. That is supply and demand, as far as the economy goes. When there is a boom, subcontractors, like other building workers, demand and get big money. When there is no boom, the genuine ones—the ones who do not want this industrial relations Bill—are prepared to take less until things turn around. Otherwise, the only alternative is to get a waste job or go on social security. A lot of teams have stayed together knowing that, when we get into government, times will improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't be around.

—I will be around, God willing, unless something happens with my endorsement. When things improve, the subcontractors will be able to get more out of the system. If with this industrial muscle they try to get more out of the system than it can afford now, all that will cause is more unemployment, less building, higher costs of building and higher rents.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES BILL 1992BROADCASTING SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:

That the following Bills be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to Broadcasting Services, a Bill for an Act to make transitional arrangements and consequential amendments as a result of the enactment of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.
Motion (by Senator Collins)—by leave—agreed to:

That the order of the Senate of 26 May 1992, relating to the introduction of Bills into the Senate after 29 May 1992, not apply to the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 and Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: BROADCASTING SERVICES BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill is the culmination of a long effort to bring the 50 year old Broadcasting Act of 1942 up to date. It gives effect to the Government's 1987 election commitment, reiterated in 1990, to establish an appropriate regulatory framework for the broadcasting industry that will serve Australia into the 21st century.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's micro-economic reform agenda has already achieved landmark reforms in telecommunications, aviation, the national rail system and the waterfront. Now it is time to turn to the antiquated, even nightmarish, legislation that regulates the broadcasting industry.

Senators will recall that the Hon Kim Beazley, when Minister for Transport and Communications, tabled a draft Broadcasting Services Bill in the House of Representatives on 7 November 1991 as a basis for public consultation. That consultation process has been wide-ranging and comprehensive. Considerable change and improvement has been made to the original draft as a result.

The final form of the Bill balances the diverse, and often conflicting, aspirations of those interested in the broadcasting industry to develop a regulatory framework that serves public interest in all its dimensions—social, cultural and economic—while also meeting the needs of a changing and growing industry.
Let me outline for the benefit of honourable senators the reasons behind the need for change and the regulatory philosophy that underpins the provisions of the Bill.
Need for Change

Since 1983, there have been some 20 substantial amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942. Further ad hoc amendments will only add to its complexity and the potential for more loopholes to be created and exploited.

We need new legislation capable of allowing the broadcasting industry to respond to both the complexities of the modern market-place and the opportunities created by technological developments. Continuing to inhibit the natural development of this industry through outdated and cumbersome regulation will disadvantage consumers and be detrimental to the longer term prospects for Australia.
The limitations of the current Act have constrained development and structural adjustment of the broadcasting industry, and thus diversity of choice for consumers.
It has blinkered us to the technologies looming on the horizon, resulting in a slow take-up of technologies that have been available for years elsewhere.

We cannot and must not continue to ignore new technologies such as Digital Audio Broadcasting and compressed digital video. If we do, we run the risk of missing out altogether on development opportunities for Australia.
Regulatory Philosophy

The Bill before you provides a coherent regulatory framework based on a need to accommodate future developments. It continues to recognise that broadcasting is integral to developing an Australian identity and cultural diversity. It is vital to the operation of a democratic society. While this means that there must continue to be obligations placed on broadcasters, the Bill has nonetheless been developed in the context of the Government's broader micro-economic reform agenda. Every effort has been made to avoid unnecessary regulation.

Underpinning the whole framework is the intention that different levels of regulatory control apply across the range of broadcasting services according to the degree of influence that such services are able to exert.

The Bill incorporates objectives and policy guidelines. It sets out the categories of service, describing them by their nature rather than by their technical means of delivery—it should thus not need constant amendment as technical conditions change. It provides for: new types and greater numbers of services to emerge; greater public access to the regulatory processes; a continuation of obligations on broadcasters in relation to program standards; and ensures that Parliament's objectives about diversity of ownership are effectively delivered. It provides for far more accountability, while retaining a suitable measure of statutory independence for the regulatory agency.

At a more general level, the Bill seeks to set rules and requirements that are consistent with wider commercial regulation such as the Trade Practices Act and Corporations Law, except where industry-specific regulatory requirements have been pre-determined by Government policy. The processes proposed for program standards and industry codes of practice for programming, particularly the commissioning of robust research, seek to ensure that these standards reflect widespread community views. The rules, processes and enforcement provisions have less potential for abuse and delay and should ensure that both the letter and the intent of Government policies in these areas are delivered.
Provisions of the Bill
Mr President, let me now briefly outline for the benefit of honourable senators key provisions of each part of the Bill.

Objectives: The objects at Part 1 clearly state the outcomes we believe this Parliament seeks from the regulation of broadcasting. They focus on the need to provide a regulatory environment that will encourage an industry that is efficient and responsive to its audiences. The need for objects was widely supported in the consultation as necessary to clarify the outcomes for the industry expected by the Parliament. It is recognised that there are some inherent tensions between the objects that will need to be balanced by the regulator and the courts. Individual objectives emphasise the audience/consumer focus of the Bill and the desire to promote services which develop and reflect a sense of Australia's cultural diversity.

Regulatory Policy: The regulatory policy at Part 1 is a key provision of the Bill, building on the objects by outlining the philosophy to be pursued in administering the Act. It emphasises the need to deal with each type of service in a consistent, but not necessarily uniform, fashion.

Categories of Broadcasting: The categories of broadcasting service contained in Part 2 are the fundamental building blocks of the Bill. This is where we start to see the philosophy at work. Different degrees of regulation apply to each category of service based on an assessment, against listed criteria, as to how influential the service is. The categories are: national broadcasting services; commercial broadcasting services; community broadcasting services; subscription broadcasting services; subscription narrowcasting services; and open narrowcasting services. "Pay TV" would come within the subscription broadcasting category. Narrowcasters would include niche services like information services for tourists in hotels and the sports services to pubs and clubs. There was general acceptance of this industry structure during the consultation phase, as it better groups service types according to their market role and power to influence. Thus it allows differing degrees of intervention to ensure that the regulations imposed are only those necessary to meet Government objectives.

While the Bill acknowledges that, as a general principle, the ABC and SBS services are appropriately governed under their own Acts, the conditions of the Bill apply where they provide services that come within the ambit of the Bill.

Planning: The planning provisions will give greater industry certainty, and allow public input to key decisions about the introduction of new services in the broadcasting services bands. A significant reform in the Bill gives the new Australian Broadcasting Authority responsibility for planning of the broadcasting services bands. Section 23 lays out criteria to use in performing these functions based on the need to promote the economic and efficient use of spectrum and having regard to a range of factors including social and economic characteristics, technology, and demand for new services.

It is significant in that the ABA, the regulator of the broadcasting sector, will hold responsibilities for planning, licensing and program standards. Bringing these together will give it the scope to bring to bear the full range of technical, social, economic and public interest considerations in the critical judgements it has to make.

ABA planning is only required for services using currently scarce radiofrequency spectrum. In the first instance these will be bands used for AM and FM radio and UHF and VHF TV. Priorities must be established for the provision of new services and planning processes must be public. The Minister for Transport and Communications will retain responsibility for high level policy planning decisions and reservation of broadcasting spectrum capacity for the ABC, SBS and community broadcasters.
To prevent waste of a valuable public resource, there are provisions to allow temporary release of radio frequency spectrum for alternative uses when not required for broadcasting purposes.

The Bill contains a legislative requirement for a review, before 1 July 1997, to assess the national benefits if more than three TV stations were permitted. The review will take into account the state of the entire broadcasting industry at that time.

Licensing of Commercial Broadcasting Services: Licensing provisions for commercial radio and television, at Part 4 of the Bill, have been streamlined. The new arrangements will allow automatic renewal in most cases and there will be no requirement for formal, regular, financial reporting by licensees. The Bill also establishes a range of requirements to be observed by licences as enforceable conditions on a licence.

Licences for all new commercial services will be allocated according to a price-based competitive allocation mechanism in which economic rents can be garnered as a one-off payment and returned to the public. This approach is consistent with the precedent already set in the recent allocation of radio licences.

The regulatory authority is no longer required to hold public inquiries before allocating or renewing every individual licence. This is unnecessary when planning is done through a public process. The ABA has a clear role to monitor the industry. It also has powers to intervene at any time during the currency of a licence to act on breaches of licence conditions or this Act. The complaints process and the option to conduct random audits for regulatory compliance will also act as a disincentive to breaches of the Act.

Control of Broadcasting Services: Control provisions at Part 5 are another key reform of the Bill. The provisions focus on the important concept of control of a licence in which the level of equity holding is only one factor. In recognition of the increasing complexity of corporate structures, they move from the rigidity of attempting to describe every possible ownership or control structure to laying down unambiguous conditions and limits that must be observed by licensees. They empower the ABA to investigate and act on any suspected artifice or arrangement that may seek to contravene them.

The existing cross-media limits for commercial radio and commercial TV and newspapers have been retained in the Bill to encourage diversity of media ownership. Foreign ownership limits for commercial television have also been retained to ensure Australians have effective control of these services. The audience reach limits for commercial television licensees has been increased from 60% to 75% recognising the economies of scale that can be reaped through use of modern communication technology and the potential for diversity and choice of additional program sources that can be offered if existing services can be extended.
Definitions and exemptions have been tightened to clarify the treatment of relationships between licensees and lenders.

The limitation on the number of radio stations controlled by a person in a licence area has been increased from one to two. In metropolitan areas this will allow licensees to experiment with different formats within a single market. In regional areas, this two-to-a market rule enables an operator in a single station market to take up a second licence, thus increasing the range of services on offer. A second licence in single service markets will only be issued where there is another unused frequency available for any future entrant.
All ABA decisions related to control are required to be included in a register to provide better public access and accountability.

Community Broadcasting Services: The public broadcasting sector's role in Australia's broadcasting system continues to be recognised. This sector has been renamed "community" broadcasters to better reflect its important role in local communities. Community broadcasting licences for services using reserved spectrum will continue to be awarded by a comparative merit selection process within guidelines laid down in the legislation and any directions issued by the Minister for Transport and Communications. Restrictions have been placed on the nature and extent of sponsorship announcements.
