Subscription Television Broadcasting: Part 7 provides for a competitive, more market-driven, approach to the introduction of these services, colloquially known as Pay TV, and for their continued regulation. The arrangements will realise greater diversity in ownership and program types and provide a wide choice of services to subscribers. They offer unlimited scope for commercial and technical innovation.

The technological neutrality of the Bill is no more apparent than for subscription broadcasting services. Licensees are encouraged to use whichever delivery mechanism suits their commercial needs. This will contribute to the commercial modernisation of Australia's communications infrastructure.
This after all will be the most significant and largest scale new entertainment service that we will see in the next few years.
These services must be customer-driven to survive. They are subject to the ultimate test that if people don't want them, they won't pay.
There is a blanket prohibition on X-rated material and R-rated material can be accessed only by using a PIN number, smart card or equivalent secure device in recognition of community concerns.

Satellite is the only technology that allows immediate access to 94% of Australians. The delivery capacity is scarce and an equitable, price-based process is included to allocate transponders on the Optus satellites. Optus will be the only supplier of transponders for licensed services until 1997.

Industry development criteria will ensure that Australian manufacturing has the opportunity to participate in the provision of the hardware. The selection process will also be used to ensure that the new in-home entertainment equipment selected by the first service will be accessible for use by later operators, with benefits to consumers.

Our film and television production industry will also benefit from the new demand for programming. An Australian content requirement for drama channels on all satellite broadcasting services has been set. Licensees will be required to spend at least 10% of program expenditure on these channels on new Australian programs. This will make a significant contribution to the development of the Australian production industry in providing jobs and developing creative Australian product, with potential for export. The Government's aim in setting Australian content regulation for subscription satellite services is to send a signal to the industry that it has a role to play in the development of the Australian film and television industry.

Once we have some experience of Pay TV and it becomes an established industry, there will be a review of the operation of the condition relating to Australian content on satellite subscription television broadcasting licensees. This would be done by mid 1997.

The review will look at how licensees have met Australian audience needs and whether further regulation is needed to address any shortcomings. It will examine how the 10% expenditure requirement has been used in practice and the opportunities which have been generated for Australian creative talent and also the nature of Australian programming in non-drama areas. It will need to take account of the prevailing environment of all television services free-to-air, subscription broadcasting and narrowcasting.
A number of ownership conditions apply to the four transponder service. Ownership rules set for this service should see the emergence of a new player in this industry.

No free-to-air television equity is allowed. The telecommunications carriers and large newspaper groups have also been excluded. Foreign ownership on all subscription television services is restricted to 35% aggregate, with a 20% limit on any individual.

Although the more restrictive ownership limits on the initial four transponder licence will reduce the number of Australian companies which are able to participate in its operation, the advantages provided by being the first multi-channel operator gives it significant value.
The commercial television networks, national broadcasters such as the ABC, and telecommunications carriers such as AOTC will be able to wholly own a single transponder licence.
No one will be able to control more than one satellite licence.

Subscription Broadcasting and Narrowcasting Licences: Part 8 provides a sensible licensing regime for the least influential of the broadcasting service categories, subscription radio broadcasting and subscription and open narrowcasting. These will be regulated as "class licenses".

Examples of such services are those which are currently operated pursuant to the Video and Audio Entertainment and Information Services Guidelines. Once the provisions in this Bill are fully in place, the guidelines (tabled by the former Minister for Communications, the Hon Michael Duffy on October 17 1986) will no longer have effect. Instead, the class licence conditions set out in Part 7 of schedule 2 will apply.

Class licences are an open, standing authority for anyone to operate a service, provided it complies with the conditions of the particular class licence relevant to that service type. Thus, before offering a service, intending providers will need to:
(a) satisfy themselves that the intended service falls within a class licence category; and
b) obtain access to an appropriate delivery mechanism through the necessary transmission licences to deliver the service, (for example by obtaining a radiocommunications licence).
Services not complying with the conditions of the class licence are subject to a range of enforceable sanctions including fines, with the ultimate sanction of turning off the service.
Class licence services are subject to the Trade Practices Act 1974, which prohibits anti-competitive behaviour and unfair practices.

The class licensing regime is expected to facilitate the emergence of innovative services, catering to specialised interests which are not well served at present. This is another aspect of the forward looking and pro-competitive approach reflected in a number of parts of the legislation.

Program Standards are at Part 9 of the Bill. The approach in the Bill balances cultural objectives and community standards of taste and decency with the commercial realities of service provision. Since different types of services have varying degrees of influence, according to their ready availability or accessibility, they require different levels of direct regulation. The Bill therefore provides for a greater degree of regulation of free-to-air commercial television broadcasting services than for other services. Standards for Australian content and for children's television are mandatory requirements.

For the first time the onus is strongly placed on broadcasters to develop appropriate industry codes of practice. Guidance is given in the Bill on matters that codes can deal with. The ABA's research will be an important aid to the industry in developing these codes. Where industry codes are not developed to meet community concerns, where they fail to meet those concerns, or where they fail to be implemented adequately, the ABA is empowered to step in.

There is significant public access and accountability in the standard setting process. The legislation specifies that the ABA must determine standards for Australian content and children's programs on commercial television; there is a requirement that the ABA must seek public comment when setting or changing standards; and the ABA is required to satisfy itself that members of the public must be given an adequate opportunity to comment on industry codes of practice before they can be registered.

It is the Government's intention that codes of practice are regularly reviewed by the ABA to satisfy itself that they continue to meet community needs. The Minister has a power to direct such action if it does not occur. The area of advertising time standards will be of particular interest. The standard recently set by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in response to a clear failure in this area by the industry will continue in force for two years or until the industry determines its code or practice. No doubt this standard will be reflected in that code.

The inclusion of a requirement for a code of practice for Australian music on radio reflects the need to promote Australian character, identity and culture through this medium and to continue to foster a vibrant and successful Australian music industry. I urge the industry to fully investigate opportunities for increasing Australian content on radio.

Codes of practice will be required from the television industry for captioning of programs. This recognises the importance of these services in providing equity of access to television for the hearing impaired.

Part 10 provides the enforcement regime for remedying licensing and other breaches of the Bill. Breaches of the control regime are separately provided for in Part 5. In drafting Part 10, the criticism of the Broadcasting Act 1942 that it provided the regulator with too limited a range of redressive measures was addressed and a wider range of remedies provided to the ABA.

It is an offence to provide a service without an appropriate licence. This offence can attract fines commensurate with their ability to influence community attitudes. Penalties for individuals range from a maximum of $2,000,000 per day for providing a commercial broadcasting service without a licence to $5,000 per day for providing a community radio broadcasting service without a licence.

The magnitude of the penalties is consistent with the Telecommunications Act and changes proposed in other commercial legislation. They will act as a disincentive to service providers to push the regulatory boundaries.

When a service is provided without a licence, the ABA can either brief the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) or issue a notice to cease providing a service without authority. Failure to comply with a notice is itself a breach with the same penalties as the direct offence.

Breaches of licence conditions are likely to be the most frequent offences, with many being minor breaches. It is an offence to breach a licence condition with maximum daily penalties ranging from $200,000 to $5,000.
The ABA has the following range of remedies available to it:
(a) discussions with the service provider with a view to rectifying the problem;
(b) imposition of a licence condition, such as requiring compliance with a code of practice;
(c) briefing the DPP on the breach, with the possibility of Court imposed fines;
(d) issuing a notice to take a specified action to remedy a breach in a specified time or to cease providing a service;
(e) briefing the DPP on breach of a notice, with the possibility of Court imposed fines;
(f) for licensed services, suspension or cancellation of the licence; and
(h) for class licensed services, seeking a Federal Court order that the person cease providing the service.
To avoid "double jeopardy" the ABA is limited to undertaking action under only one of (c) and (d) at a time.
Prosecutions for offences with maximum penalties exceeding $50,000 may only be brought in the Federal Court.

This range of remedies allows the ABA to take action commensurate with the seriousness of the breach. For the regime of monitoring, investigation and enforcement to be effective, it is important that the ABA is active in informing itself and responding to emerging problems.

Mechanisms for Complaints to the ABA are provided for at Part 11. It is important in all industries that consumer protection mechanisms exist where consumers can seek redress for any perceived wrong-doing. In broadcasting, where a consumer is not satisfied with aspects of a service or is concerned about a particular program, there needs to be an effective mechanism to handle complaints.

Each sector of the broadcasting industry other than the national broadcasters will be required to develop a code of practice, in consultation with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), relating to complaints mechanisms. The code is to be registered with the ABA only after it is satisfied with the contents of the code and that there has been adequate public consultation. If the code fails the ABA may introduce a standard, which also must involve public consultation.

Complaints about offences or breaches of the Act may be made directly to the ABA. Members of the public may complain directly to the ABA about breaches of codes of practice. In this instance, the ABA is likely to refer them to the industry sector for resolution through mechanism developed as part of the code of practice. A complainant may also take a complaint to the ABA if there has not been an industry response within 60 days or if the complainant is not satisfied with the industry response.
A similar mechanism applies to national broadcasters as an independent complaints handling mechanism of last resort.

Australian Broadcasting Authority: Parts 12-15 of the Bill deal with the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) that will be formed by merging the broadcasting planning elements of the Department of Transport and Communications with the licensing and program monitoring resources of the ABT. This will create a single body responsible for the regulation of all aspects of broadcasting, and should lead to an integrated and resource efficient approach to regulation.

Members of the ABA will be appointed by the Governor-General, and will include a Chairperson, a Deputy Chairperson, and not more than 5 Members, each appointed for fixed terms. The Minister may appoint associate members for particular investigations or hearings or for investigations or hearings of a particular type.
The appointments to this body will be crucial to its effectiveness and it must be adequately resourced if it is to discharge its responsibilities effectively.

Broad discretion is afforded the ABA in the conduct of its functions, but this does not extend to all areas of its work. The range of powers which ABA Members may delegate has been restricted to less substantial powers. Decisions which must be made by Members include licence allocation; cancellation or suspension of licences; determinations of suitability; determination of class licence categories; determination of program standards; determination of licence conditions; the provision of opinions on licence categories or control issues; giving prior approval for breaches of the Act; the issuance of notices; extension of time for compliance with notices; and, the issuance of warrants to seize documents not produced when requested by the ABA.
The ABA has wide-ranging information gathering powers at Part 13 to enable it to effectively perform its functions, including
—consulting with persons, bodies or groups, and forming consultative committees as appropriate;
—calling for submissions from the public; and
—conducting hearings and investigations.

All information gathering powers are to be used in a manner which is the quickest and most economical in the circumstances, and which promotes the due administration of the Act. Various notification provisions will ensure the ABA is informed of changes to the ownership or control of broadcasting licences.
An investigation is the more informal means by which the ABA can gather information. The procedural conduct of investigations will vary in every circumstance and is left to the discretion of the ABA.

Some people have raised concerns about the use of these powers in relation to uncovering journalists sources of information. This Bill does not impose any new powers in this area that are not present in other legislation. It makes no specific mention of journalists in relation to powers of investigation. Journalists perform a valuable role in discovering important information that may otherwise remain hidden. Protection of confidentiality of sources is part of that role.

The provisions in this Bill are intended, among other things, to allow the ABA to obtain crucial information to uncover major breaches of this Act. However, I would expect it to take a prudent and reasonable approach in exercising these powers in relation to journalists gathering information for news and current affairs reports.

The ABA can hold public hearings into any matters relevant to the administration of the Act. Hearings can be held whenever necessary, and the ABA will accept submissions from the public. People can be summonsed to answer questions or produce documents.
The Minister retains an over-riding responsibility for broadcasting policy issues and specific powers are given to the Minister in the Bill.

The Minister will have the power to direct the ABA to conduct investigations or hearings into matters affecting the development of broadcasting in Australia and make recommendations to the Government. The Minister can direct the ABA to reserve channels for the provision of national and community broadcasting services.
The Minister can determine price based allocation mechanisms for the allocation of licences, and can also direct the ABA in the manner in which it gathers information.

Parliament has an overriding power to disallow directions given to the ABA by the Minister. It could also disallow regulations developed by the ABA, such as variations to categories of services or licence conditions for certain classes of broadcasting. The ABA is required to report to Parliament annually.

When it is first established, the various elements comprising the ABA will stay in their present locations. This approach will minimise disruption in the initial stages. Ultimately however, all elements of the ABA should be co-located.

There are important miscellaneous provisions in Part 15 of the Bill. It is made clear that fees determined under the Act must not exceed the costs of processing the application or doing the thing to which the fee relates. It provides special provisions relating to the retransmission of programs, to enable programs to be retransmitted outside a licence area with the permission of the ABA.

As it is the Government's intention that there will continue to be widespread consultation with consumers and the industry over future developments in broadcasting policy, provision is made for the establishment of Ministerial consultative and advisory bodies. The Part also introduces an important provision which allows "time sharing" on a single frequency, with each licensee being responsible for each portion of the broadcast.
Financial Impact

Full funding implications cannot be assessed until decisions are made on licence fees for commercial broadcasting services, and on the detail for the price-based competitive licence allocation processes. Staff savings, in both the ABT and those parts of the Department of Transport and Communications which are to be merged into the new ABA, can be expected but these may be offset by having to employ specialist skills as the need arises. Savings will accrue to the broadcasting industry from reduction in reporting requirements, and in the costs arising from regulatory intervention. Greater competition and a wider range of broadcasting services will improve the efficiency of the broadcasting industry. Facilitating the emergence of new broadcasting and other communications technologies, together with the anticipated increase in the range of services available, are expected to generate considerable economic activity relating to the supply of equipment and programs for broadcasting services.

Mr President, in conclusion I wish to thank all of those who have participated in the consultative process that led to the finalisation of this important piece of legislation. The Bill is better for the input of so many people.
The Bill will serve Australia well and allow the broadcast media to carry out its important role in our society in a responsive and effective way.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
BROADCASTING SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND
CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

In introducing the Broadcasting Services Bill a few minutes ago, I pointed out the substantial differences between the Broadcasting Services Bill approach and that of the current Broadcasting Act. Whenever we change from a highly regulatory, hands on system to one focused on matters of real concern and stressing flexibility of approach, there is obviously a need to move current services from the old system to the new, with a minimum of disruption. There is also a need to provide for the completion of matters being considered and to ensure effective interaction between the new Act and other legislation. In addition, there is a need to ensure that the legislation does not unwittingly place people in breach of the new Act if they are currently complying with the law and their circumstances remain the same.
That is the purpose of this Bill. To ensure a smooth transition to the new Broadcasting Services Bill regime.
The Bill is complex, but it deals with complex issues.

Clauses 5 to 9 deem current broadcasting services which will be subject to the regulatory regime of the Broadcasting Services Bill to be licensed under that Bill (either on an individual or class licence basis) and will fix the terms, licence areas and conditions of those deemed licences. This approach gives the Australian Broadcasting Authority the same degree of control over those licences as it will have over licences actually granted by it.

Clause 10, and related amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1983 in Schedule 2, will ensure that access to the radiofrequency spectrum is preserved on the same conditions as before. Under the proposed section 24B of that Act, radiofrequency licences for commercial and community broadcasting services will remain in force while the related broadcasting service licences are in effect and have not been suspended. That section will apply to current commercial, remote, supplementary and public broadcasting services, whereas limited licences and retransmission permits will be deemed to have licences under section 24 of the Radcom Act for the remainder of the period of their licence or permit. After that, narrowcasting and retransmission services will have to obtain Radcom Act licences. This includes retransmission services which may not currently hold permits under the Broadcasting Act.

Clauses 11, 12 and 13 allows uncompleted Australian Broadcasting Tribunal licensing inquiries to be completed. Applications for renewal of what will be commercial or community broadcasting services will, under clause 11, be deemed to have been granted immediately before the commencement of the Bill. This will give the services the maximum renewal period (in most cases, 5 years), but will not prevent the new Australian Broadcasting Authority from exercising its powers to investigate and hold hearings if it is considered warranted.

In the case of applications for the grant of what will, under the Broadcasting Services Bill, be commercial or community broadcasting services, clause 12 will allow the ABA to complete ABT licence grant inquiries under the current provisions of the Broadcasting Act as if it were the ABT. Any licence granted by the ABA under the Broadcasting Act will be dealt with under clauses 5 and 10 and will thus be translated into the new scheme.

Of course, there is no reason why applicants cannot withdraw their applications under the Broadcasting Act if they prefer the simpler and more expeditious Broadcasting Services Bill approach. I suspect that may happen in a number of cases.
Applications for what will be class licences under the new scheme will be dealt with under clause 13 as applications for a licence under the Radcom Act.

Non licensing inquiries by the ABT will cease to have effect on commencement of the Bill. This will not prevent the ABA taking up the work already done by the ABT, but it will ensure that the ABA can set its own priorities.

The Government has no intention of reneging on its commitment to ensuring additional services, both under Stage 1 of the Metropolitan Radio Plan (which allows metropolitan AM commercial radio stations to convert to FM) and the Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television policy. Stage 1 of the National Metropolitan Radio Plan is substantially complete, but clause 14 will preserve the relevant provisions of the Broadcasting Act until the Plan is fully implemented.

Paragraph 9(1)(d) and subclause 9(3) will preserve the obligations of licensees who are in the process of implementing equalisation, whereas clause 15 will allow the policy to be implemented in Tasmania, where the proposed 2 service form of aggregation has not yet commenced.

As I have already mentioned, one of the underlying principles of this Bill is that it should not unwittingly place people in breach of the new Act if they are currently complying with the law and their circumstances remain the same. Clauses 16, 17, 18 and 19 ensure that, where the rules of the Broadcasting Services Bill vary from the current rules, persons who currently hold directorships or who are not deemed to control a service under the current Act will not breach the new Bill by virtue of their current position or interests.

Naturally, any significant change in personal circumstances will deprive people of the protection of these clauses. They will then have to comply fully with the requirements of the Broadcasting Services Bill.

An issue of concern to a number of people is that of program standards for broadcasters. The Broadcasting Services Bill requires the ABA to maintain standards in the crucial areas of children's programming and Australian content, but only gives it the power to make standards on other topics where codes of practice fail or where no code of practice is made. Both the ABA and the industry need time to comply with these rules, but it would be undesirable for the industry to be totally exempt from program standards in the meantime.

Clause 20 deems certain provisions of the Broadcasting Act and relevant ABT standards to be the ABA standards for children's programming and Australian content. They will remain in force until the ABA develops its own standards.

The remaining ABT standards will also continue as if they were standards adopted by the ABA, but only until a relevant industry code is registered or for 2 years, whichever is the later. This will give the industry ample time to develop codes of practice after full public consultation and also the incentive to complete their work as soon as possible. Naturally, if codes have not been registered within the 2 year period, or if they are inadequate, the ABA can adopt its own standards.
The clause also provides for the ABT standards, or parts of those standards, to cease in respect of particular sectors of the industry if that sector has developed and registered relevant codes.

The Government is considering the most appropriate method of recompensing the public for access by commercial broadcasters to a scarce public resource, the radiofrequency spectrum. The options include a one off payment on grant of a licence and ongoing licence fees based either on the value of the spectrum or, as is currently the case, on income derived from its use. Another option is a combination of both. This gives rise to complex issues, such as the assessment of the value of spectrum and what should happen in relation to current licensees.

Consequently, the Broadcasting Services Bill, which provides for a price based allocation system for new commercial licences, while existing commercial licensees will continue to pay annual, income based licence fees under the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964 and the Television Licence Fees Act 1964, pending further Government consideration of the issue.
Clause 23 and the relevant consequential amendments to the Licence Fees Act will achieve this result.
Clauses 22, 23, 24 and 25 will preserve the current right and obligations of the ABT and enforce current directions and orders.
The staff of the ABT are employed under the Public Service Act 1922 and will be redeployed under that Act. There is no need to make specific provision for them here.

The ABA will be required to observe the secrecy provisions of the Broadcasting Act in relation to documents transferred to it by the ABT. The Broadcasting Services Bill has no specific secrecy provisions and we would not wish persons supplying information to the ABT to feel that its confidentiality would in any way be compromised under the Bill. However, a range of legal requirements under the Freedom of Information Act, the Privacy Act, the Public Service Act and the common law rules about disclosure during litigation of truly confidential material offer perfectly adequate guarantees under the new Bill.

Clause 26 recognises the fact that current technology standards under the Broadcasting Act must now be transferred to the Radiocommunications Act, the source of regulation of technical issues under the new scheme.

Clause 27 preserves the political broadcasting provisions of the Broadcasting Act. They are currently under challenge in the High Court and it is appropriate that they should not be touched pending the court's decision on their validity.
Clause 28 and Schedule 1 will repeal Acts which have no relevance to the new scheme and clause 29 and Schedule 2 make necessary consequential amendments to other Acts.
Those consequential amendments are primarily formal in nature, but I should mention a number of points.

They include amendments to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 and the Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991 which tie into the provisions applicable to the ABC and SBS in the Broadcasting Services Bill. The amendments in this Bill will require the ABC and SBS to develop codes of practice on programming matters and to notify those codes to the ABA. They will also allow the ABC to participate in subscription television broadcasting to the extent permitted under the Broadcasting Services Bill.

I have mentioned the licensing regime for services under the Radiocommunications Act. The initial planning for all services, broadcasting or radiocommunications, is also done under that Act, although a new subsection 19(3) will allow the Minister to assign certain parts of the spectrum to the ABA for planning purposes. The Minister will not plan for individual services in those bands and the licensing regime of the Act will only allow radiocommunications services to be licensed in those parts of the spectrum if the ABA allows the frequencies to "drop through" under clause 34 of the Broadcasting Services Bill.

The proposed section 92A of the Radiocommunications Act will also allow price based allocation systems to be determined in respect of the grant of Radcom Act transmitter or receiver licences. The system may apply generally, or in respect of specified areas or frequencies to licences of a kind identified for the purpose in the regulations. Price based allocation is likely to be used where there is substantial competition for available spectrum. Examples may well include subscription services. However, this allocation system will not apply to the broadcasting services bands except in respect of frequencies which the ABA has "dropped through" under subsection 34(1) of the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992. Details of successful applicants and the amount agreed to be paid to be published in the Gazette.

A proposed subsection 25(8A) of the Radcom Act will also allow conditions to be imposed on new entrants to the radiofrequency spectrum to require them not only to rectify interference problems caused by their entry, but to ask persons affected to approach them for that purpose.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
FINANCIAL IMPACT

The Bill will continue the current licence fees regime for existing commercial broadcasters and thus will have no direct impact on revenue or expenses. It is likely that new services, particularly services provided under "class licences", will be licensed under the Radcom Act as a result of the new scheme and the consequential amendments made to the Act under this Bill. This should increase revenues from licence fees from those services. The extent of those additional revenues will depend on demand, a factor which will be hard to predict accurately until some experience of the scheme is built up.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum relating to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that little charade, thanks to the Australian Democrats—working against their own notice—we are now debating the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill. This is very interesting. The Democrats have stood on their dig for so long to make sure that there is a cut-off time for legislation being put into this chamber. Yet here we are, only a matter of days later, and they side with the Government to allow a Bill to come in. It is typical of the Australian Democrats. As has been said so often before, one can never buy the Democrats, one just rents them by the hour. And here we go again.
—Why don't you freshen it up?
—It would be a better idea if Senator Collins freshened himself up. The whole situation is typical of where we have gone in this chamber.
—Order! I remind the Senate that we are dealing with industrial relations legislation.

—What I am saying has pretty much to do with industrial relations in this chamber, Mr President. It relates to the way in which the Labor Party is running this Parliament. It has its union mates in the Australian Democrats as part of its union. It wants bigger unions; it wants to get them all nice and cosy. I wonder what little deal it has done for this lot: probably more staff, more entitlements, more this and more that.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. It is a requirement that honourable senators speak to the matter before the Chair. That is not the matter which is before the Chair. We have some 50-odd Bills to get through, and I suggest that you make the honourable senator come to the matter before the Chair.
—I think I have been reasonably tolerant, Senator Knowles.

—It is interesting that Senator Coulter is so sensitive about this issue. He said we have 50 Bills before the chamber. As of now, we have 53 Bills before the chamber. I would not be too sensitive about this, if I were Senator Coulter. I know that the truth hurts, but never mind, we will just carry on.
—You have to work. That's what you get money for.

—I am pleased that the penny has dropped on Senator Collins. Tonight, before we were rudely interrupted by the introduction of unnecessary legislation for the rest of this chamber, we were debating the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1992. We will probably see the Australian Democrats siding with the Government yet again to increase the power of the trade union movement. Once again, this Labor Government proves beyond doubt that it is the lackey of the ACTU—its political master and the enemy of industrial relations reform.

PARA.TAB: Let us face it, the ACTU really runs this Government. This Government does nothing without the approval of the likes of Bill Kelty. The former Prime Minister did not even make the decision to hand over the prime ministership of this country to Mr Keating without the presence of Mr Bill Kelty from the ACTU—and let us not forget his other mate, Sir Peter Abeles. They were there as witnesses. Here we have another piece of legislation talking about the influence of the ACTU and the trade union movement in its entirety.

This total refusal to introduce real flexibility into the workplace and into the labour market by lessening the dead hand of compulsory unionism and de facto union control is costing Australia jobs and productivity. One in three young people in Australia today cannot find a job. What is the answer? Last Sunday the Prime Minister went on television and, when asked that direct question about the youth unemployment of this country, his simple answer was to keep them in education longer. While better education opportunities are desirable and tertiary education places are essential, that is not the answer to getting them jobs. The reality of it is that they still cannot get a job when they leave tertiary or secondary education. That is the real question, and that is what this Bill does not address in any way, shape or form.

When there are young people in this country facing the real prospect of not being able to find a job, that is tragic. That is why the Liberal and National parties have a very different attitude to the way in which employees can negotiate with employers to have satisfactory working arrangements that will not only create jobs but also sustain jobs, that will create productivity for Australia and make sure that there are long term jobs for young people not only for today but also for tomorrow.

The central issue of this Bill is the subjugation of independent contractors in any industry to the rulings of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, allowing unions to challenge an employer's use of contracts, to vary these contracts, and to have the Commission forbid their employment. The Keating Labor Government has a clear intention to aid its political masters, the ACTU, and to attack the subcontract system without regard to the increase in costs to vital areas of the economy such as housing.

My colleague Senator Panizza was talking earlier about the increased costs of housing that will result from this legislation. But does this Government care? Not in the slightest. It is of no consequence to the Government that one of the major ramifications of this legislation is that the cost of housing will escalate. The Keating Labor Government is making sure that it is favouring the bigger and bigger increase of unionism. The effect in Western Australia, for example, of eliminating subcontract labour from housing would be an increase of 25 per cent in the cost of a new home.

Home ownership, I believe, is still the great Australian dream, but unfortunately, thanks to this Government, the great Australian dream is slipping further and further away. Here we have yet another piece of legislation tonight which makes sure that it goes away even further and faster. Labor's willingness to let the ACTU impose de facto unionism on contractors would mean that the median price of a home in my State would rise to $125,000. That is just the median price; that is not the price of every home in Western Australia, and let me make that clear. But it is the average person, often an employee, who pays the ultimate cost of this union driven policy.

We cannot be surprised, however, that a Minister who once served as the assistant secretary of the Building Workers Industrial Union, the instigator of this Bill, should be in sympathy with the union view that contracting leads to a breakdown of union organisation and membership. That is quite damning coming from a Minister, Senator Cook, who, as a former union leader, is obviously very concerned that there may be an erosion of union membership and control. Therefore he is ensuring through this legislation that there is no such erosion, and that in fact the union movement gets bigger and stronger and everyone else pays the price. It is becoming obvious that the supposed concessions announced by the Minister are nothing but a sham. The industry knows they are a sham and private individuals will very soon know that they are a sham because they widen, rather than restrict, the scope of this Bill.

Expert advice has confirmed that the Industrial Relations Commission will retain the discretion to review the contracts of independent contractors. That is not acceptable to the Opposition. The prospect of standard form contracts imposed by the AIRC looms large when section 127B remains intact and gives the right to review a contract thought to be unfair or against the public interest. How ironic that the concept of the public interest should here be included when it is removed from certified agreements between employers and unions under section 115. Clearly there will be a green light for union mischief and the AIRC meddling with 127B(4)(e), which includes that wonderful ambit phrase `any other matter that the Commission thinks relevant'. Section 127B(5) states that the AIRC `must record its opinion'.

Other provisions in this Bill are equally designed to strengthen the hand of unions in a rigid and outdated system. The supposed facilitation and promotion of certified agreements under section 115 entrenches the role of unions in this process, so that they are the arbiters, along with apparent moves for flexibility in enterprise bargaining. Really, they are the last people who can judge. It is not a matter of freeing up the system, as the Minister foreshadowed last year. That is just a whole lot of filibuster. It is just a whole lot of bluff that this Minister goes on with—the same kind of thing that Minister Collins goes on with about the waterfront. It is a whole lot of bluff; it is not happening. We have not seen any indication of a freeing up of the system. Rather, the system is to be tied up for the benefit of the unions who have the vested interest in preserving their own privileges.

Rigidity is confirmed by the prevention of the reduction of any award or legislative entitlement. So often in the real world, employees are anxious to trade conditions for higher remuneration or, in tough times, for job survival. Let us face it, we have seen example after example in this country. Of course, one of the most recently celebrated examples is the case of the Shepparton Preserving Company. All of those employees would be out of a job today and the company would have closed down if the trade union movement had had its way. Fortunately, it did not get its way and not only has the company survived, but also all the employees have their jobs. Presumably, they have been able to retain their commitments and their homes, keep their children educated and clothed and, at the same time, earn more money—

TALK.START.PARA: —And got back pay.

—And got back pay, as Senator Walters quite rightly says, because they reduced their income to retain their jobs. Did this Government want them to do that? Not on your life. It wanted the union muscle to be exercised over the employees of the SPC so that the whole show would be shut down. Yet here is that company: the employees and the employers got together, came up with a system and the employees gave the concession of lower income. They have got it all back—and they also have their dividend checks.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, the Commission is required to ensure that an agreement is the result of consultation between unions and its members and includes all possible union parties. Even where an enterprise is not covered by an award, an employer must name a union party capable of covering its non-unionised employees. Union domination could hardly be more obvious. Every way we go down this path, we find that the union domination is getting stronger and stronger to the detriment of the employees and, of course, the employers. We are looking at a situation where unions have the right to muscle in on an agreement, despite the possible wishes of the employees, and to prevent employees from representing themselves.

I do not know whether this Government really believes that employees are so incapable of representing themselves that it simply will not allow them to do so, but I do not believe that. I have seen many situations in which employees have been quite capable of representing themselves and have come to a very amicable agreement with employers which suits both parties. But all of this is the complete antithesis of genuine enterprise agreement based on the principle of employee free choice, as the Liberal and National parties are advocating. Enterprise agreements under a coalition government would bring unions to their proper role as the servants rather than the masters of employees, able to act as negotiating agents if the workers so wished, but lacking the right of veto that this Labor Government is carefully enshrining in this Bill.

Yesterday, I happened to make reference to Senator Cook's constant misleading of the Senate with regard to the coalition position on industrial relations. He intentionally, willingly and deliberately—whatever adjective one could wish to imagine—says both in this place and out in the public arena that the workers are going to be worse off because minimum awards are going to be abolished. Minimum wages are not going to be abolished. He also says that employees will be victimised—`They will not be able to earn a cracker'.

He also cited the New Zealand experience. We will continue to hear plenty of rhetoric from Senator Cook and his Labor cronies that they are defending employees from a New Zealand situation. I suggest that Senator Cook and his mates go over to New Zealand and see what is really happening over there. Mind you, those opposite have been deafening in their silence about New Zealand in the last few weeks because New Zealand's balance of payments is slightly better than ours. They are in the black and we are in the red. The more we learn about what is really happening across the Tasman, the less workers, as opposed to unions, need to fear. Sure, the union movement might have something to fear, because it will have less responsibility. But what is happening is not some free-for-all as is being touted by the Minister and his Labor Party apparatchiks, but a massive swing, I must say, towards the individual enterprise agreements and individual contracts such as those covering the 1,200 workers at the Comalco Aluminium plant.

We learn that a clothing firm employing 50 staff abandoned standard wage rates for a piece rate system that resulted in take-home-pay arising from an award of $320 per week to $430 per week, and more staff being employed. That is what this Government want employees to miss out on—increased income, greater job security, and more jobs. That is what this Government is all about. This Government is not happy with one million people being unemployed. It wants more people to be in this situation.

In the Auckland brewery of Lion Nathan there is one enterprise agreement in place of 16 awards, there have been no strikes for five years, wage bills are lower and pay rates higher, and productivity just happens to be up by 300 per cent. Once again, this is something that this Labor Party does not want to see in this country. It does not want to see an increase in productivity, employees getting more money and greater opportunities right across the board.

The New Zealand experience shows that it is not workers who are losing out through genuine enterprise bargaining but the unions, which are becoming irrelevant and which have lost the monopoly power that this Bill seeks to reinforce in Australia. When staff in a national retailer were given freedom of choice to opt out of unions, 70 per cent did so. We will give employees the opportunity to opt out of unions. But if they are not happy with that, they will not be locked out forever—they can come back. According to the Government and the Labor lies that keep on being told, they will be locked out forever. That is simply not true.

It is predicted that overall union coverage will reduce to 25 per cent of the work force. That is what the Government is worried about. It is this, and not the supposed exploitation of employees, that is the ACTU nightmare. People like Ferguson could not solve a bun fight in a bakery, let alone solve union disputes. Yet, once again, he is the key ear to this Labor Government. He and Mr Kelty are de facto members of the Cabinet of this Government.

The desire of this Minister to increase centralised direction of the AIRC is made clear by the appointment of a separate Vice-President's panel, without the duties being defined in this Bill. The President of the Commission thus loses the prerogative to allocate work, and the Minister will effectively be providing the direction, and we well know what that direction will be under this Minister and this Government. The cynical determination to set and control the national industrial relations agenda is obvious with the appointment of another ACTU representative, and one from the Metal Trades Industry Association, to the National Labour Consultative Council.

The recent royal commission in New South Wales has reminded us that some construction companies are equally happy to rely on cosy deals with militant unions. I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Liberal and National parties are not happy with these cosy arrangements and they will certainly seek to have them wiped out. The observation needs to be made in the context of the New Zealand experience that some of the more hidebound employers opposed change because they had a vested interest in protection from competition, feared the challenge of active work force management, and even complained that workers would get too much freedom of choice. That is exactly what the unions fear in Australia and it is exactly what this Government fears.

The same retail chain that saw 70 per cent of employees ditch the unions had to replace 20 per cent of store managers who found they could not manage an unregimented work force. This is what real industrial relations reform is all about. This Bill continues to thwart such reform and to entrench ACTU domination of the system yet further.

This Bill just simply has to be rejected lock, stock and barrel. It is about time the employees and the employers of this country had a chance to negotiate real opportunities, a real future, real jobs and real progress.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the arguments that have been put forward by my colleagues. The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 has two major impacts—one on contractors and the other on certified agreements. Of course, some of my colleagues have mentioned some other aspects of the Bill. Both of these impacts are designed to increase union hierarchy power by enshrining in legislation the power of the Keltys of this world. The hidden agenda of this Government is not, as has been claimed in this place, about sham contracts. It is about increasing union power.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some comments about what has happened over the last month or so to employer organisations. The first point I want to make is that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has conned the employer organisations into believing that the changes he has accepted to this Bill will overcome their concerns. One must add that it is not to their credit that they have been conned. But in fairness to them, they had their first meeting three weeks yesterday at which they put their concerns to the Minister about the impact of this Bill. One must make the comment that, even with the proposed changes that have been put forward, not one of those employer organisations supports the Bill anyhow, even in its revised form.

Although that meeting was held three weeks ago, the Minister did not respond until about 10 o'clock last night and give them notice that this Bill was to be brought on at about 11 o'clock today. Consideration of this Bill was subsequently put back to 8 o'clock tonight. In other words, they were given less than 24 hours to analyse the changes that the Minister had agreed to. Yet, the Minister talks about consultation, about being fair to all sides of the community in terms of this Bill. Of course, his own union mates have had a much longer time to consider the legislation and would have been involved in discussions about the changes that were made.
I want to quote one paragraph of a letter from Reg Hamilton, who is the legal officer acting on behalf of the National Employers Forum. The letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: to provide the Forum with a commitment that the detail of Government amendments to the Bill to implement any in principle agreement would be discussed and agreed with the Forum;
As I said, in effect the employers were given 24 hours to respond to this.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Minister is now trying to present himself as a reasonable person. He is claiming that he has allowed time in that the Bill will not be back in the chamber for consideration until some time in the next fortnight or so. The Opposition has moved that the Bill be sent to a committee for consideration. This is the reason its passage through this place has been delayed—not because of any action by the Government. As a result, employers will have the opportunity to put their case. Of course, anyone else who wants to make a submission and put a case will also be welcome to do so. So any claim by the Minister that he is giving employers the opportunity to put their case to a much more independent forum selected by this Senate is just absolute nonsense.

I would like to deal with some of the details of this Bill. In doing so I want to re-emphasise the point that the Bill is about enshrining union power and union leadership. Let us look at the operative part of this Bill that is going to give so much power to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I refer to proposed new section 127B(2). Considering that the public interest has been specifically removed from `certified agreements' legislation, why should it be brought into contractor legislation? My understanding is that it is concerned with the integrity of the industrial relations system pertaining to awards. What relevance does it have to contracting and how would it be used by unions and the AIRC? This is a very legitimate concern.

Proposed section 127B(4)(a) refers to relative strength. This is very emotive. It gives the AIRC a judicial function interfering with legal contracts based on the worker signing a contract to get work; therefore he is at a disadvantage. No contractor of any kind could resist this premise. Proposed section 127B(4)(c) refers to development of the skills of employees performing work of the relevant kind. The question to be asked is whether this could be used to eliminate contractors from any enterprise because providing a trained work force will reduce employees' opportunities to develop skills in the industry.

Under proposed section 127B(4)(d), total remuneration, the question has to be asked: does this mean that if an employee takes, say, 38 hours to do a job but a motivated contractor on a considerably higher hourly rate takes 20 hours to do the same amount of work the total remuneration for the contractor is less? If a contractor is hired for a four-hour task and is paid a high hourly rate for those four hours but an award worker can be hired for only eight hours at a time, then the total remuneration for the contractor is less. Of course, contracting is about increasing efficiency and productivity and getting a lower cost per unit of work produced. Through the contract system people can actually earn significantly more money, yet at the same time have a lower unit cost. This proposed section will put that in jeopardy.

Proposed section 127B(4)(e) refers to any other matter that the Commission thinks relevant. The whole independent contractor legislation could be removed leaving only this section, and the AIRC could still do what it liked with contractors. In other words, this is an open door. Proposed section 126B(5) says that it must record its opinion. Why must the AIRC record its opinion, even if in the overview the arrangements are satisfactory? Some specific point must be recorded to build case law for further future interference by unions. This section will be used to enhance interference.

Proposed section 127B(7) outlines the objects of the Bill. Are not the objects of this Bill to bring everybody within the industrial relations system—that is, on awards—or at the very least under the control of the AIRC? The objects of this Bill are to have everybody under the control of the AIRC, and that will be done with union involvement and union coercion.

Turning to proposed section 127C(2), dealing with an order, this eliminates any available flexibility under the contracting system and forces rigid award standards on to a more productive system. Once again, this is going to force up costs, create much higher costs for the final consumer. It will have very serious implications for the housing industry, the construction industry, the farming industry, the mining industry—just about any industry we care to name.

I shall now make some brief comments about certified agreements. Under this legislation we find that an agreement will not be able to be put in place unless employees are represented by a union, even if in that workplace there are no unionists. Another point, and this indicates once again the lopsided nature of this legislation, is that that union on behalf of the employees can seek before the Industrial Relations Commission to have the agreement altered half way through. The employer does not have that option. The employer is left having to run the full term of the agreement. It should be remembered that in Australia 85 per cent of the work force are employees, yet only 42 per cent of those are members of a union. If we take out the Public Service component, the percentage of unions in other workplaces is less than 30 per cent. That leaves 15 per cent as contractors.

What is a contractor? Contractors are people who pit their wits against a job and quote a price to get it done. They do that because they believe they can do it more efficiently, more quickly and with higher productivity, and can thus earn more dollars and cents. People see contracting as an opportunity to be better off. Nobody forces anybody into the contract system. It is a matter of choice and it always has been a matter of choice. We will find now that a number of people who chose in the past and will choose in the future to be in the contract system will be forced out of it. One must make the point that the contract system has been an integral part of Australia's development.

The reason for this legislation is that the Government wants to unionise contractors. The legislation is before us not for the reasons we have been given but because of the Troubleshooters case. The Troubleshooters case was successful in two aspects. Firstly, it created an employment arrangement in the contract system which left all parties better off. Many of the people who worked through Troubleshooters were voluntarily members of unions but they chose to work through that system. The matter went before Justice Woodward of the Federal Court, where the legality of the arrangement was challenged; it was upheld. It then went before the Full Bench of the Federal Court; once again it was upheld. Leave was sought to take the case to the High Court but was not granted. The High Court upheld the position of Justice Woodward and the Federal Court.

The reasons for that action are set out in a letter to Mr Bill Kelty from the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, under the signature of Mr Tom McDonald, National Secretary. It reads in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of the agreement between the BLF and Troubleshooters is an important matter for the trade union movement and trade unionists.
The agreement represents the first major breakthrough for the New Right in its efforts to take the Australian workforce out of the award and arbitration system and into the quagmire of contracting.
This development represents a serious threat to the future of the trade union movement because as history shows, contracting leads to a breakdown of union organisation and membership.

BWIU have been in a long running battle with Troubleshooters and has incurred legal costs to the order of $200,000 and is currently facing legal action by Troubleshooters for damages against the union.

The letter very clearly spells out what this matter is about, and it is no credit to the Minister that he has accepted this argument. It is worth noting that at the time the High Court made its decision the reaction of the Minister for Industrial Relations was to call the law an ass. Since that time it has been on the Government's agenda to bring this legislation before us.

PARA.TAB: These amendments will not do what the Minister claims. He has claimed that the housing industry will be quarantined. The fact is that we cannot quarantine any industry in legislation. If we tried to do that by legislation, it would not stand up to constitutional scrutiny. This Bill broadens significantly the power of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and, as I have already said, it further expands union power.

I shall quote from a couple of legal opinions I have received. Amendment No. 2, which was dealt with by the Minister, involves the deletion of proposed section 122(4) of the Act. A legal opinion from Taylor Szekely Kelso states:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect will be that the AIRC can grant preference to employees over independent contractors or vice versa.
The opinion states that this is not in the interests of any industry.

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 179(3) extends the definition of employee to include independent contractors. So we now have operating in this country a definition of employee which includes someone who is not an employee, but a contractor—a person who quotes a price to do a particular job. It is a very serious development in terms of turning back the clock in industrial relations in Australia.

I now turn to another legal opinion I have in terms of this particular Act. This has been done by Terry Chamberlain of Gallens Crowley & Chamberlain. I want to quote a number of points he makes about the principal Act as it pertains to this amending legislation. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The result of this conclusion is that the removal of 127A from the proposed amendments may in fact widen the jurisdiction and powers of the AIRC in relation to disputes concerning the engagement of independent contractors as well as employees.
So that just reinforces the point that I made earlier in my comments. He continues:

Under the proposed amendments the jurisdiction of the AIRC to determine the consideration payable to independent contractors would be limited to the extent necessary to prevent the engagement of independent contractors on terms that are unfair, harsh or against the public interest. Despite the uncertain limits of these restrictions and, in particular, the criteria of public interest, it is still more limited than the power that the AIRC would have under the current Legislation if it were found to have jurisdiction to hear such disputes.
In this light, I believe any challenge to be made in the High Court concerning independent contractors would or should seek clear answers to the following issues:
1.What is an independent contractor? If in fact the types of people which this Legislation is concerned to protect e.g. clothing out-workers,—
and we have heard a little about them in debates here in recent times—
are in fact employees and not independent contracts, then there is no rationale for this Legislation.
That is one of the reasons that this legislation has been put in this place, I believe, by the Minister for Industrial Relations and certainly by Senator Sherry. He continues:
2.Whether a dispute about the engagement of independent contractors rather than employees is an "industrial matter" capable of forming the subject of an "industrial dispute".
3.Whether in reviewing contracts the AIRC is being called upon to exercise judicial power.
4.The extent to which the Legislation is supported by the relevant heads of power under the constitution.
It continues:

In this regard we note that the Federal Court has recently held that a corporation can be liable for misleading or deceptive conduct during employment negotiations. In this regard the proposed amendments can be seen as a logical extension of existing law and the provision of the Trade Practices Act. Indeed, they would seem to be as simple as provisions to the following effect:

It goes on. Finally it comes to the point that the way to handle unfair, harsh or unconscionable contracts is through the Trade Practices Act, not the Industrial Relations Act. That is a view that I hold very strongly, if in fact it is necessary. The amending legislation is misplaced legislation introduced for the very purpose—as I have said before, and I will keep repeating—of enshrining the power of the Bill Keltys in this country of ours.

PARA.TAB: I just want to give some practical examples of what is going to happen in the marketplace under this legislation. The first thing that we will see when people tender to do a job under the contract system—and it is a competitive business—is underpricing. We will see underpricing because whoever is tendering will know that once he has his foot in the door and has started work—he might be a quarter of the way through the job, he might be halfway through the job—that he can go running cap in hand to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission with union representation and have that contract reviewed. It is going to put many industries into absolute turmoil.

As a farmer, I get quotes to have produce carted from the farm to the port or wherever it has to go—it could be to an abattoir. Under this legislation, particularly when it comes to the cartage of bulk commodities, I could never be certain that the quote would hold good. Whoever gives the quote will always have the option of a second string to his bow and will be able to put arguments. Not only will that cost significant amounts of money; it will also cost an enormous amount of time.

Let us look at another aspect of the practical implications of this particular legislation. Under this legislation, a contractor, as defined, can now be legally a member of a union, which he could not be before. We will find a closed shop situation, as has happened before on the waterfront and in the activities of the Transport Workers Union. When subcontractors cart their product to the wharf, they will be given an ultimatum that if they do not join the union their truck will not be unloaded. That will be the practical application of this legislation. Once again, it will be coercion that will force these people to join a union against their will. They will have no choice, because they have to proceed with their work and get the truck unloaded, or complete whatever the task might be, if they do not want to be forced into bankruptcy.

They are just two practical examples of the types of things that will happen under this legislation. They are the types of things that even blind Freddy can see. In terms of the example I have given, in the past there was some defence because individual contractors could not legally be forced to join a union. Now they will be forced to do that, and it will undermine, as I have already said, the whole contracting process, both in the pricing and in the operation.

I also want to mention one other example that we had just recently where the contracting system could have improved very significantly the efficiency and productivity across our wharves. It occurred in Fremantle with the Jill Coast. It relates to the loading of potatoes. The master of the Jill Coast was not satisfied with the price he was quoted from the two stevedores: one was $30 a tonne with additional costs on it, which usually worked out to about half the price, which takes it up to about $45; the other one was $36 a tonne, with additional costs on it, which would have taken the price up to about $48 a tonne. He was not satisfied with those quotes, so he got a quote from some independent people. He was quoted $7.50 a tonne without any additional costs. Of course, in stepped the Waterside Workers Federation. The Potato Marketing Board fell into line because it did not have the gumption or the guts to stand up to it. In the end that ship sailed from Fremantle without a cargo.

This legislation will make it even more difficult to get some real reforms on the waterfront, which would lower the cost of getting the product across the wharf and onto the ships. That is what waterfront reform must be about.

I deal briefly with the principal amendment that the Democrats brought in. I have a legal opinion relating to that amendment, which reads in part:

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I highlight what I see as the worst features of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. PARA.TAB: I note that on the speakers list there are no Government speakers. The very simple reason for that is that there is no defence to the legislation that has been put before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to get it through the House.

PARA.TAB: This Bill is turning industrial relations policy backwards. It is a result, as I have already outlined, of the success of Troubleshooters—not sham contracts, as has been claimed. I emphasise that when the Troubleshooters case was brought down the Minister described the law as an ass. He is altering the law to facilitate his mates. The BWIU said to the Minister `jump' and the Minister has jumped.
