SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. It is obvious that the Government is in trouble. It is in deep trouble when Senator Cooney has to come in and add his name to the speakers list. A whole group of senators from this side of the chamber are speaking on this Bill. Senator Cooney is always called upon when the Government is in trouble. He has come in here tonight to see what he can do for the Government. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill now before the Senate is another significant step along the path of fundamental reform initiated by the Government since taking office in 1983: reform which is transforming Australia's industrial relations landscape.

Let us have a look at the present Australian industrial landscape. We have seen tonight on our television sets a scene that I did not expect to see in my State. It is a very conservative State. The workers and, indeed, industry have always claimed that it has the most stable work force of any State, yet under this Government's legislation we have tonight seen violence perpetrated by picketers of APPM blocking people from going to work. Indeed, the picketers were carrying out what this Minister for Industrial Relations told them to carry out—what this Minister for Industrial Relations foreshadowed.

PARA.TAB: The Minister demanded that the company meet with the unions and the Liberal Government in Tasmania. The whole thing fell through because governments and politicians should not get involved. He demanded the meeting and made a fool of himself. When the whole thing fell through, he came into this place and said, `There will be bloodshed'. He foreshadowed it. He inspired the picketers to carry on to the extent where they defied the police and today in my State there has been bloodshed at the Minister's request. I hope that all people in Australia realise that is exactly what has occurred under this Government's legislation and this stupid second reading speech which says that the reform is another significant step.

Let us get it perfectly clear what this significant step is, because it is very significant. For the first time in the history of this country it brings contractors under the Industrial Relations Commission. I will come to that in a few minutes. In the Minister's second reading speech, he makes quite elaborate statements, such as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the existence of democratic organisations of employees and employers to represent the interests of their members, as in all truly free societies;. . .

Nowhere in this democratic speech or organisation is there the ability for the employees to come to an arrangement with their employer themselves. They must do it through the organisation. There is no voluntary organisation. They are closed shops—no ticket, no work. This is what the Labor Party calls democracy. There is no freedom to join the organisation or not to join the organisation. There are simply closed shops—no ticket, no work.

PARA.TAB: This is the Government's legislation and picketers have been drawn up for weeks, refusing to allow those people who want to work to go through the picket line and work in their workplace, until we reached the position when the police had to go in and remove them forcibly. The Minister supports this sort of industrial relations. He inspires bloodshed and talks about bloodshed because he could not get his way with the company. This is the sort of democracy that this Government works under.

Our policy is for voluntary unionism. Our policy is true democracy where if someone wants to join a union, then they may certainly do so. If they do not want to join a union, then equally they do not have to. In his second reading speech, the Minister also says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consultation and cooperation between workers, their unions and employers as essential ways to ensure that industrial reform and workplace changes are best framed and implemented on a sustainable basis;. . .

All I can say is that our policy is choice. I will talk about the workers of APPM, because this dispute is occurring under this Government's policy, not our policy. We would say to APPM, `You must abide by the choice of those workers whom you employ who choose to ask the union or any other agent to negotiate on their behalf and you must abide by the choice of those who want to negotiate with you on their own behalf.' That is our industrial relations policy. Those people who do not choose to belong to a union can negotiate with the employer on their own grounds and those who do want to join a union, or choose some other agent, can do so. Our policy is a matter of choice.

PARA.TAB: The Government is frightened of giving the Australian people choice. It tells them, `No ticket, no work. You will belong to a trade union and if you do not, you will not get a job'. We are also told in the Minister's second reading speech that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we have applied a flexible accord wages policy responsive to Australia's economic circumstances.

We know what Australia's economic circumstances are. The Government is trying to bring contractors into the same position under the IRC as employees. In the middle of a recession, we have one million unemployed. Those unemployed are ignored by the union movement. I am not sure, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether you were a member of the committee under Senator Elstob that looked at superannuation. Bill Kelty gave evidence before us on the rights of employees to have superannuation. We asked him, `What about the unemployed?' He answered, `The union is not interested in the unemployed. The unions are only interested in the employees. They are our members'. That is the truth of the matter, of course. The union movement is not interested in the unemployed. It is only interested in employees because they are the union members.

PARA.TAB: Our policy, as opposed to the Government's policy of recession with one million unemployed, is our Fightback package which will employ two million people. There will be two million new jobs. As I said, this Government's alternative is to go back to the Dark Ages, as in Burnie now, where the picketers are lined up and the intimidation is unbelievable. Tonight we saw only 20 or 30 brave men being escorted by the police through the picket lines and being bashed by their co-workers as they went. It is a disgusting way to carry on and it is only under this Government's legislation that it can occur. Our policy is that the company must take note of the choice of the unionists.
I turn now to the Bill. In the part of the Minister's second reading speech that I have been quoting from, the Minister had not yet got to the Bill. It all sounds so easy, because the Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a fundamental revision of the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to facilitate and encourage workplace bargaining. The parties to a dispute. . .

The parties to a dispute! Who in the heck are the parties to the dispute? Surely to heavens it is the employer and the employees. That is not what the Minister means. He does not mean the employer and the employees. He means the employer and the unions.

PARA.TAB: Let me give just a few examples. My colleague Senator Knowles tonight gave the example of the SPC canning factory. She said that the employees there came to a decision with the employer, but the union would not have a bar of it. Eventually, it was forced into getting it up and agreeing with the employees before the Commission to have it ratified. Since then, SPC has done very well. At Christmas, Mr Corboy from the company said that 300 permanent workers at the plant had been told that they would receive all their accrued lost earnings in one payment. An amount of $600,000 was divided pro rata among the permanent staff and the large seasonal work force which took wage cuts in the last harvest. But let us look beyond that.

The workers and management of a small sawmilling company in Queensland reached an agreement whereby, if the employees started an hour earlier on Monday to Thursday, they could have Friday afternoon off. That was the choice of the workers and the management. They came to an agreement that the employees would work an hour longer Monday to Thursday and then have Friday afternoon off. What did the union say?

SPEECH.PARA: The union said, `Not on your life'. The AWU intervened and claimed that if the workers started an hour earlier they had to be paid penalty rates. It did not matter what the employees wanted and it did not matter that the employer said it suited him and he wanted a happy work force; the AWU said, `No, we will not allow it'.

PARA.TAB: Another example involves a major service sector company. It enjoyed very little benefit out of the current restructuring and efficiency principles. But one area where improvements could be made was in relation to its RDOs. In the service sector, continuity of supply and of a particular driver are very important. So, when discussing possible ways that that organisation could make gains under the structural efficiency principle, a number of workers said that they would be happy to have their RDOs rolled up in a bonus type payment to be given to them at the end of the year—at Christmas, when everyone wants that bit of extra money.

This deal would have suited the company, and obviously many workers wanted it. However, when it was put to the unions, guess who intervened—Bill Kelty. He intervened by saying that it was just not on. When it was explained to the ACTU Secretary that the employees themselves had put it forward, his response was, `We have to protect the work force from themselves'. It sounds like Senator McMullan's arrogance to me. That was Bill Kelty telling the workers that they do not know what is best for them but that he does.

The dispute in Tasmania was caused by the union movement. Martin Ferguson has been down there causing all the problems under the sun, and the Minister was here inciting violence. That is exactly what occurred because the unions have deliberately set about creating this situation in Tasmania.

As I say, the main purpose of the Bill is to bring independent contractors under the umbrella of the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government took this decision months ago, but then put it off. I wonder why. It put it off because at one stage the Democrats were going to agree to it; everything in the garden was rosy because the Democrats said that they would support the Bill. But the employer organisations would not. The employer organisations threatened that, if the Government did not alter its legislation, they would undertake a campaign of paid political advertising directed solely at the industrial relations legislation that we are debating here tonight.

What did the Government do? It has been having a pretty bad time of late. Indeed, it has been having a disastrous time. Senator Richardson in this chamber proved that he was misleading the Senate and was forced to resign. Senator Evans is going down the same track. A motion has been passed in this Senate saying that there should be a judicial inquiry into what has occurred in his Department and in the Marshall Islands. So the Government has been having a pretty bad time. Mrs Ros Kelly in the other place has been telling Australia that she endorsed only the cover of a school kit—not its contents—that told the children of Australia that farmers were totally irresponsible in their land care. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has had to acknowledge that his family company, of which he has a 50 per cent share ownership, has never put in a tax return. So the Government has been having a pretty bad time of late. It could not withstand the CAI members undertaking a political advertising campaign against the industrial relations Bill that we are discussing tonight, so it crumbled.

The Government has suddenly decided that it was terribly necessary for 18 amendments to be brought into the Senate today because it just could not withstand a campaign against it by the CAI. The Minister promised that he would pass these various amendments to overcome the greatest problems. But I do not think that will be good enough. It certainly will not be good enough, because I can assure the Government that those amendments would not carry out what the Minister thought they would. Whether that is through ignorance or whether it is deliberate, I am not quite sure. But they certainly do not cover what Senator Cook has told people they cover. So there is still a fair problem ahead of the Government.

However, the Bill is being sent off to a committee following the second reading stage; we are told that some of the speeches on the second reading will be concluded by midnight tonight. The Committee will be looking at it at some future time. By the time that Committee looks at it, I am quite sure that there will be many more than 18 amendments to cut out of this Bill all the independent contractors, who should, as Senator Crane said earlier, be covered by the Trade Practices Act. We will see what happens. This Government really is having a pretty bad time at the moment, and it is not willing to make a fight of anything.

It is time that the Government realised that it is under its legislation that we have scenes such as those in Burnie we saw on our televisions tonight. It is not our legislation; it would not happen under our legislation because the employer must abide by the employees' wishes. It cannot happen under our legislation; it can happen only under this Government's legislation. It is high time the Government realised that it must change its ways.

I am not the only one who says that the Government cannot be trusted. I refer to Mr Turbet's letter to the Minister for Industrial Relations. We all know who Mr Turbet is; we are all well aware of that. I will read a few paragraphs of his letter so I will not be considered the only one who does not trust the Government. Mr Turbet's letter to the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I respond to your letter to the President, Mr Justice Maddern, dated 8 April 1992, by advising of my intention to tender my resignation, as a Commissioner of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, to the Governor General with effect from 10 May 1992.
He continued:

The reasons for my resignation after 14 years as a Commission member, which was preceded by 16 years service to the trade union movement and 20 years membership of the Australian Labor Party are three-fold. Firstly, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word.

That is from one of the commissioners of the Industrial Relations Commission. As I have said, I am not the only one who does not trust the Government. Mr Turbet believes that the commission is being heavied by the Government and is no longer independent. He says that his number one complaint is that the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word.

PARA.TAB: It is high time the Government realised that it cannot berate the commission in one breath, tell it off, decide to ignore it and do deals with its own employees—as it did when the commission did not accept its accord propositions—and then berate APPM for not abiding by the commission's request for it to negotiate with the unions. It is hypocritical and not acceptable to the Australian people.

The Government will be forced to make more than the 18 amendments it has already been forced to make. It will be forced to accept some of the Democrat amendments, but that will not be good enough. Further amendments will have to be made following the Committee. It will be very interesting from this side of the chamber to see how many amendments the Government will be putting up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill has been strongly attacked in its entirety by a number of employer groups ever since its real intent—that is, to rope contract labour into the Federal industrial relations system—was made public by the Government last month. In short, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) wants to achieve through this legislation what the building unions could not achieve through industrial action. He wants to reverse the effects of the High Court and Federal Court decisions. Put simply, he proposes to restrict the rights of individuals to control their own working life as independent contractors. The battle to reform Australian industrial relations is beyond the courts. It is now a battle which has to be fought in this Parliament, in State parliaments, and indeed in national and State elections.

PARA.TAB: This Bill has absolutely nothing to do with attending to the real needs of those who may be exploited in our system. It has nothing to do with migrant women who may be exploited as piece workers in the textile industry. It does not even have anything to do with the oppression of the factory worker. But it has everything to do with altering and transplanting the industrial relations conditions of the commercial building industry of Australia into this nation's home building industry. The Liberal and National parties are therefore obviously implacably opposed to the proposals contained in this Bill. We support the successful moves already made by employer groups to thwart the legislation.

Essentially, the most important provisions of the Bill are those relating to contractors and certified agreements. The Bill would give the commission absolute jurisdiction over the use of contractors and the terms of contracts. It would give unions monopoly powers to represent contractors in the Industrial Relations Commission. Indeed, it would also confirm the role of unions as opposed to employees in the certified agreement process. The Bill travels well beyond its declared intention merely to get rid of fraudulent contracts. It has profound implications for the contracting systems and for the industries which use it.

Since the Bill's introduction to this place earlier this month by the Minister, we have been told that it has undergone some changes, with the Government's agreeing to withdraw its most controversial amendment relating to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's powers over independent contractors and contracting arrangements which, in fact, were quite extensive new powers for the commission. As is by now well known, two days ago employer groups, following their threat to mount an expensive, concerted, well-planned television and newspaper campaign against the Government on this legislation, won significant concessions in discussions with the Minister Cook on the direction of the legislation. As a result the Government has agreed to make this change.

I note that the Government believes that employer concerns are based more on misunderstanding than on fact. Nevertheless, it agreed to withdraw the relevant clauses, so one could well question the Government's claimed basis for the legislation. It is a sad reflection on this failing Government that it took the threat of the employers' campaign, rather than the undoubted logic of their arguments, to have some effect on its attitude. The Government claims that in law at least the Australian Industrial Relations Commission already has jurisdiction in certain disputes over the use of independent contractors, but that the extent of any jurisdiction in the High Court would need to be clarified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop shouting.
—I want to make sure that Senator Faulkner hears the points I am making.
—He will hear, but he will never understand.
—That is true. It is a sad reflection of members of the Government that they simply do not understand the consequences of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Regardless of the Government's bleatings over the refinements of the legislation, we have now seen the Australian Democrats enter the fray with some amendments of their own. This happened after they initially rejected the criticisms of the Liberal and National parties as an unwarranted scare campaign and accepted the Government's propaganda that it was aimed merely at sham contracts. It is not just about sham contracts. The sooner the Democrats pull their heads out of the sand, the sooner they will be aware of the ramifications of this insufferable legislation. We have seen the Democrats change their minds yet again, as is becoming their usual behaviour, in deciding that the monopoly position offered to the unions to represent contractors offended their sensibilities, such as they are, on voluntary unionism. They have offered a new definition of `a `contractor' which excludes the unions' monopolistic representation.

It would appear that the Australian Democrats are not aware of any inconsistency in their stance on the contractors provisions, nor of their acceptance of the proposed changes to certified agreements provisions, which will confine certified agreements to employers and unions and exclude employees who are non-unionists. Despite the Democrats changing their mind at every twist and turn, it has been the numerous employer groups—such as the Australian Small Business Association and a number of larger employer groups—which formed themselves into a national employers forum, convened by the Confederation of Australian Industry, and which eventually forced the Government's hand on this matter after some protracted negotiations.

In his second reading speech nearly a month ago, the Minister claimed that this Bill would transform the industrial relations landscape and that it was another step along the path of fundamental labour reform. He claimed, too, that this Bill exemplifies his Government's approach to industrial relations. He was only correct about his first point. Indeed, the Bill will transform industrial relations in this country, but it will be altered to a form not acceptable to industry, not acceptable to the Liberal and National parties and certainly not acceptable in any way to Australian workers or indeed the Australian people at large, who are desperate to see genuine industrial relations reform.

Industrial relations in Australia, should the Government's legislation be passed, will become even more of a sad joke than it is at present. This Government has no worthwhile relationship with employer groups; it has merely built a cosy intimate relationship with trade unions. It is not in any way interested in developing an industrial relations policy which will take Australia into a productive and competitive future. This was highlighted just the other day in the negotiations with the industry groups over this legislation.

The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is perilous. It will not deliver the best and fairest economic outcomes for Australia and it has many more ramifications than this Government would have us believe. Both the Master Builders Federation and the Confederation of Australian Industry were quick to criticise the Bill, claiming that a major consequence of the legislation—that is, the displacement of contract labour by award labour—would be to increase the cost of a new house by an average of $25,000. The Master Builders Federation is right. This Government, with its original legislation, would have denied many thousands of young home buyers the opportunity of owning a home. It would have placed purchase beyond the reach of most of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your goods and services is going to do that, Senator Chapman.

—It certainly will not. Again, Senator Collins is misrepresenting the impact of the goods and services tax on home building. Either he fails to understand the goods and services tax or he deliberately and continuously misrepresents it. That is what we have come to expect from this failing Government, which is on its last legs and will plummet to defeat at the next election.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister: why is this Government so opposed to young people buying their own home? In recent years it destroyed their home ownership dreams with devastatingly high interest rates. Now, with interest rates lower—though still excessive in real terms—it continues to destroy their dreams with legislation like this, which would put the price of new homes beyond the reach of many of them.

The Confederation of Australian Industry, as well as the Master Builders, also spoke out strongly against the Government's original legislation, also correctly believing that it could be too easily used as an avenue for the unions to extend their coverage to industries such as residential housing where most of the work is now conducted on a subcontract basis.

Let us hope that the Minister displays some commonsense and backs down on the relevant clauses in the original Bill which specify that a contractor has to be a union member before the Industrial Relations Commission can review a contract. What a load of nonsense! The only purpose this serves is to expand and make cosy the membership of the trade union movement. All too often government bureaucrats and bureaucracies do not consult with those closely and heavily involved in industry. This is yet another typical example. Let us hope that the Minister has learnt that he should not again ignore industry leaders, because it will be at his peril if he continues to do so.

When some of the biggest and most influential employer groups in Australia, representing hundreds of thousands of employers, come out fighting and lambast this piece of legislation, one must ask why they are they doing that. The clear answer is that the Government has not adequately consulted them with regard to the ramifications of this legislation.

The Government has not listened, at least up until two days ago, to informed relevant industry expertise—a mistake which it has made repeatedly during its time in office, and a mistake which we have again seen as another recent example in the Government's relations and failure to consult adequately with the many thousands of Australians involved in the road transport industry.

The Bill before us is a significant one—significant in that the Government would have used it as a vehicle to ensure further entrenchment of its myopic trade union principles into current industrial relations practice. The Bill will reshape institutional procedures to ensure the institutions themselves become less resistant and more compliant to the Government's industrial relations objectives.

Employer groups are concerned, as they should be. Indeed, the resolution of the national employers forum on independent contractors, as it was resolved, was to oppose all provisions of the Bill which sought to give trade unions rights and the Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction with respect to independent contractors. The Confederation of Australian Industry has been very concerned with the ramifications of the legislation and its press statement of 2 June reflects that concern. The CAI secured an undertaking from the Government that provisions similar to those which were agreed to be deleted would not be reintroduced during the life of this Government. The Government is on record now. I am sure that this undertaking will be monitored very closely by the industry, and it will most definitely be monitored very closely by the Liberal and National parties which remain in Opposition only until the next election. Even the Master Builders Association has branded what the legislation would mean:

SPEECH.PARA: The full unionisation of the housing industry and the end of the independent contract system.

The legislation has always been nothing more than a sell-out—a sell-out to the union campaign to unionise building subcontractors across the country. The Minister has not been able to convince any of the employer groups that his legislation is justified. The Confederation of Australian Industry has argued that the Minister never attempted to define sham contracts, which he claimed were the target of this legislation, and in fact when pressed to table any evidence of unfair contracts he could not.

PARA.TAB: The common law courts are the appropriate venue to determine whether a person is an employee or an independent contractor, not the Industrial Relations Commission. Of course, that former location has indeed been the appropriate place for determining these matters on many occasions.

The legislation as originally proposed by this Government was nothing more than an outright attempt to attack the private sector and the opportunities which exist there for independent businesses. Its four key areas of amendment will replace the existing provisions relating to certified agreements. The amendments will confer specific duties on the new office of Vice-President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission relating to union amalgamations, simplify procedures for the recovery of unpaid award wages and change the membership provisions of the National Labour Consultative Council by amending the National Labour Consultative Council Act 1977.

The Bill then seeks to replace the existing certified provisions in the Act with a new division with additional objects to facilitate and promote certified agreements. The new division would, firstly, abolish existing requirements that an agreement inconsistent with existing wage fixing principles be referred to a full bench. Secondly, it would require the Commission to be satisfied that the agreement is fair, contains dispute settlement procedures and has been the subject of consultation between unions and their members, except on greenfield sites. Thirdly, if the certified agreement is a single enterprise agreement, the division would require that it include all possible union parties and that it has been negotiated by a single bargaining unit. Next, it would provide a fairness test that will effectively prevent the reduction of entitlements under any award or legislation and would remove the public interest test for single enterprise agreements and give the Minister discretion to seek the public interest test application. It would also remove the present prohibition on a certified agreement being based on the terms of another and provide the terms for variation, extension and termination of an agreement.

While this new division would change the certified agreement process, it is not so clear whether the changes would simplify or promote certified agreements. They would, though, entrench trade unions. The Liberal and National parties' objections to the proposed amendments to the certified agreement provisions remain. The amendments would merely entrench unions in the process and preclude certified agreements between employers and employees who are not trade unionists.

With respect to that section of the Bill relating to vice-presidential duties, the Bill seeks to create a vice-president's panel consisting of the vice-president and at least one other presidential member nominated by the President. I believe the position was originally proposed by the Gleeson committee which recommended a restructuring of the Commission and a revised salary structure breaking the traditional nexus between deputy presidents and Federal Court judges, and effectively imposing a salary cut on deputy presidents. The President and some other Industrial Relations Commission members successfully argued that the breaking of the nexus was unjustified and that there was insufficient work to justify the creation of a vice-president's position. Hence, the Remuneration Tribunal subsequently declined to set a salary for deputy presidents because of, among other things, the lack of defined duties.

The Minister claims that the vice-president and his panel will concentrate on work flowing from union amalgamations. But, in this Bill, the vice-president's duties are not at all defined, nor does the Bill stipulate who will allocate the vice-president's responsibilities to him. Traditionally, appointment of a presidential member to a designated task, an allocation of work through him, is the prerogative of the President. But proposed section 38 removes the prerogative. Hence, under this legislation we have a situation where the position of vice-president has been created contrary to the President's wishes. The President may or may not be consulted as to who should be appointed and the President will not have the power to direct the work of the vice-president or the way the vice-president allocates this work.

The Minister apparently will be expected to provide a duty statement. If this is the case, the new arrangements compromise the President's authority by transferring some of it to the Minister. They further compromise the Commission's statutory independence and must undoubtedly exacerbate existing tensions between the pro-ACTU and the anti-ACTU factions within the Industrial Relations Commission.

With regard to the provisions relating to the National Labour Consultative Council Act, the principal amendment seeks to appoint a representative of the Metal Trades Industry Association to the National Labour Consultative Council. This will only compromise the authority of the Confederation of Australian Industry to speak as the sole employers' representative and will give to the Government two more votes within the Consultative Council—a clear indication of the Government's intended strategy to divide and rule as far as employers are concerned with regard to industrial relations.

Since the Confederation of Australian Industry and its constituent organisations now favour rapid deregulation of the labour market and an end to compulsory arbitration, this proposal will produce a difficult situation since the Metal Trades Industry Association is aligned with the Government and ACTU approach to an inadequate incremental change to our industrial relations system.

In the area of simplified small claims procedures, the Bill would also make it possible for an employee entitled to a benefit from any award or order of the Commission to proceed with a claim in a magistrate's court for up to $5,000 under simplified rules of procedure, evidence and representation. But because of constitutional requirements, the proposal would proceed only in those States which already provide, or are prepared to provide, simplified rules of procedure, evidence and representation. Despite this being a quite sensible proposal, it is unfairly and unduly restrictive to the extent that it is limited to employees with an entitlement under an award or order of the Commission. Again, it discriminates against employees who do not operate under the award system.

In totally opposing this legislation on behalf of the Liberal and National parties, let me say that the building industry in Australia can be divided into two sectors: the residential and the commercial industrial. This Government wants to impose the conditions endured by those involved in the commercial industrial sector of the industry onto the home building industry, but that will be a crying shame for this country.

The simple fact is that the home building industry in Australia is among the most efficient in the world. It is cost efficient, it is productive and it is relatively free from industrial strife and mayhem. And the reason for that is because it is built on independent contractors, on the honest sweat and initiative of small business operators. It is free of the type of union thuggery that the Minister wants to introduce so that he can wreak havoc in the home building environment across this country, similar to the thuggery and havoc that is very evident in the commercial industrial building sector, as revealed and highlighted by the Gyles royal commission report published only last week.

Australians will simply not tolerate building union officials levying their members to pay their $300,000 Federal Court fines and saying, as they do, `Don't worry, brothers—we have been promised that they will act to overrule the decision of the courts'. The unions should not have such power and, undoubtedly, under a Liberal and National party government—which will be elected within the new few months—that sort of power will be taken away from them. Of course, it is for that reason that the Liberal and National parties, presently in opposition, absolutely oppose this reprehensible piece of legislation.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collins) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: How many training courses has the department already undertaken, or planned, for staff personnel under the Training Guarantee Act 1990 in 1991-92, please provide: (a) name, purpose and duration of the course; (b) number of participant officers (both trainers and trainees); (c) trainee officer level; (d) details of how course participation is assessed, and whether the trainees' branch undertakes its own assessment of the benefit of the course to the participants' post-training performance; and (e) estimated costs of running each course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: This Department, like all others, reports detail of all training undertaken throughout the organization, by staff category and numbers trained, cost and the type of training, in its response to the Annual HRD Survey conducted by the Public Service Commission, and in its Annual Report, as required by the Annual Report Guidelines. These reports are currently available for the period up to 30 June 1991. The next such reports will reflect the year to 30 June 1992, and the HRD Survey report is expected to be available in December.
The many weeks/months of effort required to prepare a detailed response to this question at this time cannot be readily justified.

Evaluation of our training programs is undertaken against the National Training and Staff Development Strategy which was developed in August 1991. In the case of our program of Training for Overseas Service, it is a requirement of the departmental Program Evaluation Plan that a formal evaluation be undertaken this financial year.

At an individual program evaluation level, training events and programs are assessed quickly at the time of the actual event. More involved programs, particularly those relating to management skills, are not only formulated in part from a pre-course assessment of the needs of the particular participant group, but are followed, after a meaningful time interval, by an evaluation process involving the participants' supervisors and the course deliverers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under what provision of the Public Service Act was the position of part-time Chairman of the Commonwealth Fire Board recently created, what procedures were followed in the selection, were there any prescribed qualifications and what selection criteria were used.

(2) How is the payment of the part-time Chairman arranged and what arrangements have been made in the Department of Administrative Services to provide funding for this new position particularly as the Commonwealth Fire Board is located in Melbourne and the appointee is based in South Australia.
(3) Are the same selection and payment arrangements being made for other part-time non-Commonwealth Public Service members of the Commonwealth Fire Board.

(4) The position of Chief Executive Officer of the Commonwealth Fire Board was advertised in Commonwealth Government Gazette No. PS1 of 1991, what arrangements are being or have been made to fill this position.
(5) Are there any prescribed qualifications.
(6) What are the selection criteria.
(7) Why, for such an important position, was it not advertised outside the Public Service.
(8) When is the position expected to be filled and when will the appointee take up the position.
(9) Will these new arrangements result in increased expenditure for the Commonwealth Fire Board.
(10) Provision has been made for two committees of the Commonwealth Fire Board. How will these operate and what additional resources or funding will be required to ensure adequate functioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I appointed the part-time Chairman by invitation. Mr Grubb is well qualified for the position as a former Head of the South Australian Metropolitan Fire Brigade.
(2) The part-time Chairman is paid a daily allowance as recommended by the Remuneration Tribunal for the part-time holders of public office.

The activities of the Commonwealth Fire Board and its Secretariat are fully funded by the Department of Administrative Services to a level which the Board can demonstrate is required for the effective performance of its functions.

(3) The other two non-Public Service appointees are representatives of the ACTU and the Australian Assembly of Fire Authorities, and are nominated by these bodies. Airfares and travelling allowance under Regulation 72 of the Public Service Act are paid for both. At present neither receives any other payment however their eligibility for payment under Remuneration Tribunal determinations is currently being investigated.

(4) A person has been appointed to this position. The appointment is being examined by the Merit-Protection and Review Agency in relation to an application for review by the former acting Chief Executive Officer.
(5) The prescribed qualifications are those which apply to the Senior Officer Grades of the Public Service, in relation to the category Senior Professional Manager.
(6) Selection criteria for the position are:
(1) Proven management skills of a high order, including the capacity to operate in a managing for results framework.
(2) High level conceptual, analytical and creative skills.
(3) Highly developed communication skills, both oral and written.
(4) Sound negotiating, representational and liaison skills.
(5) A good understanding of the machinery of government.

(6) Knowledge of and commitment to DAS' corporate goals and values relating to staff satisfaction and leadership together with an ability and willingness to motivate subordinates to work towards them.

(7) Demonstrated ability to implement programs and work with staff in a manner consistent with the Department's Equal Employment Opportunity, Industrial Democracy and Occupational Health and safety Policies."

(7) With the recent review of the operations of the Commonwealth Fire Board, the responsibilities of the position related chiefly to the managerial area. It was believed appropriate to first test the market for suitable senior managers within the Public Service.
(8) The appointment was Gazetted on 2 April 1992, and the appointee commenced duties on 27 April 1992.
(9) As a result of the new arrangements, the Department expects some increase in the Board's financial requirements.

(10) The Technical and Standards Committee of the Board was established under the Commonwealth Strategic Plan 1991 for the Commonwealth Fire Board, its main functions being related to the development and promulgation of fire safety policies, practices and standards.
The proposed Administrative Committee has been held in abeyance pending a review of its proposed Terms of Reference by the Board.

Estimates for the additional resources for each Committee of the order of $10,000 are being examined by the Department. It is expected the Board should be able to identify other savings in its operating budget which will offset these costs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australian Estate Management and fire protection of Commonwealth property where, under this program, fire protection has increased in estimate to approximately $7,000,000 from approximately $5,984,000:
(1) Why was this matter not referred to the Commonwealth Fire Board for advice.

(2) Some figures being suggested for fire protection for Telecom in New South Wales in 1992 are around $1,000,000, if the Government Business Enterprises are contributing their fair share why is the Commonwealth cost increasing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following representations from Victoria, the Prime Minister wrote to all State Premiers on 2 December 1989 advising that the Commonwealth was prepared to consider basing its contributions to State fire protection services on a resource use base.

The Commonwealth Fire Board was aware of the move to a resource use base scheme and the then Chairman of the CFB, Mr R. B. Turner was involved in discussions with officers of the Department of Finance which recognised that a resource use base scheme would be more equitable.

(2) The estimate of $7,000,000 reflects an expectation that all States would be moving to a resource use based scheme in 1991-92. This was estimated in recognition of the true value of the services provided. At this stage, Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania have opted to remain with the old scheme. As a result expenditure this financial year will be about $5,900,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent reports of increases in house insurance premiums under the Defence Service Homes (DSH) Insurance Scheme where sharp increases in both valuations and premiums, in the order of 50 per cent or greater, have been reported:
(1) Has the department or the Minister received an increasingly large volume of correspondence on this issue in the past twelve months.
(2) How widespread are these increases.
(3) Do the sharp valuation increases run counter to the trend of real estate prices in the past year.
(4) Why are these increases occurring and why are they so pronounced.
(5) Do the increases reflect a correction for previously undervalued insurance premiums (prior to the arrangement being reached with Mercantile Mutual to underwrite the DSH Insurance Scheme).

(6) Do such increases undermine the Government's promises of DSH client access to household insurance at very competitive premiums following the agreement of Mercantile Mutual to underwrite the insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) There has been an increase in correspondence about valuation and premium increases but the volume received still represents a small proportion of DSH Insurance clients.
(2) Premiums and valuations have increased nationally.

(3) DSH Insurance bases the amount of insurance on what it would cost to rebuild a home, not on the market valuation. While real estate prices may have declined in some areas, the cost of rebuilding homes did not.

(4), (5) and (6) The DSH Insurance Scheme along with other Australian insurers has suffered a number of major natural disasters and over the past two and a half years. It has been necessary to increase premiums to rebuild reserves. In some cases, the Scheme also found that insured values had fallen below replacement value. The combination of increases in rate, replacement cost and building cost accumulated in some instances to produce substantial premium increases.
Mercantile Mutual underwrites only the DSH Contents insurance product. The DSH Insurance Scheme continues as a Commonwealth insurance scheme insuring those homes eligible under the DSH Act.
The Scheme continues to offer a cover broader than most other insurers, at competitive premiums.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: War Graves in Papua New Guinea

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent reports of a group of hikers in Papua New Guinea discovering an allegedly unrecorded mass grave of Australian soldiers who died on the Kokoda Track 50 years ago:
(1) What is the process for determining if such a claim is a valid one, and how long will this process take.
(2) If the claim is proven to be a valid one, what will become of the remains, for instance, will they be transferred to the Bomana War Cemetery.

(3) What action has the Australian Government taken to investigate the validity of this claim; if none, why not and when will action be taken; if action has been taken, has it involved a physical inspection of the site by a representative of the Office of Australian War Graves.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: As the investigation into and recovery of remains is the responsibility of the Department of Defence the senator's question would be more appropriately one for the Minister for Defence. The Department of Veterans' Affairs, through the Office of Australian War Graves (OAWG) would only become involved after Defence have confirmed that any remains found are indeed ones which should be buried in a Commission War Cemetery. The OAWG provides new burial locations, headstones and future maintenance. However the following information has been kindly provided by the Minister for Defence in answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) and (3) Following the assertion that 72 Australian war graves had been located on the Kokoda Track, Headquarters Australian Defence Force commenced a search through World War II Defence records to ascertain the validity of the claim. Research involved not only Defence records but also records held by the Department of Vete-

ANSWER.PARA: rans' Affairs (Office of Australian War Graves) and the Australian War Memorial.

PARA.TAB: The research revealed that 72 Australian bodies were recovered from the area in question on 28 April 1944 for reburial in the Bomana War Cemetery.

Although the research undertaken would tend to indicate that the claim is invalid the records cannot be taken as absolutely conclusive. Headquarters Australian Defence Force has directed the Head of the Australian Defence Staff in Port Moresby to arrange with PNG authorities for a random exhumation of the site to be undertaken.
(2) Should the claim prove to be valid the Department of Defence will arrange for the full exhumation of the grave site with the remains being transferred to the Bomana War Cemetery for reburial.
